Shoulder sores and "Le" sores are on the right hand, and the pomegranate is three inches from the elbow. Left kidney yin and right crotch sores appear, while biting bone occurs above the "Yinbao" point. Deep kidney sores are found on the legs, attached to the bones, while "Fo Ding" sores arise from the top of the brain.

Remember these worldly toxic sores; treating patients appropriately leads to peace in life.[354p]
The zygomatic bone is where the furuncle occurs, above the lips is a sore treated by doctors. Between the eyebrows, the phoenix brow encroaches upon the brain; a black furuncle in the ears is not surprising. A furuncle inside the nose must be treated swiftly; the origin of the condition actually starts at the hairline. The sore at the end of the eyebrow is very toxic; the cheek furuncle near the mackerel eye is in line with the jaw.

A horse blade can cause tuberculous lymphadenopathy and goiter, a condition originating from the neck. The poison of the tiger and the dragon's spring lurks within the upper and lower lips, originally concealed within the mouth. The abscess at the root of the teeth is no different; the furuncle below the teeth occurs in a line. The protrusion in the gap of the upper teeth needs treatment; do not let it develop into a common sore in the world.

Abscesses from the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys should be examined by a physician of acupuncture in the chest. Furthermore, there are yellow heads and white blisters appearing rapidly without a fixed place. On the left is the horse's sitting position, on the right, its dismount; the tip of the coccyx and the stork's beak raise suspicions. This ailment can kill; urgent treatment is necessary without delay.

Women may experience various types in the breast; a high lump indicates an abscess and hardened sore. There are also true evil symptoms resembling a lump the size of a stubborn stone, breaking apart like a ruin. The wind of the button appears on the neck; the wind sore beneath the skirt must be treated at the feet. There are also humid eczema and similar diseases, commonly occurring on the lower legs.

Infants may suffer from rotten teeth and black decay; the opening of sores becomes unbearable. Scarlet fever and other diseases can spread throughout the body; thrush can cover the mouth entirely. Wind sores and milk crusts bring much itching; blood and pus create painful and unsettled nests. Additionally, there are signs of fetal heat in the heart and spleen, and mouth sores often resemble a heavy tongue.[355p]
Discussion on Carbuncles

Carbuncles are a swift external disease. They can appear in the morning and result in death by evening; some may not die for three to five days, yet eventually succumb after a month or a half-month. This variation depends on the depth of the poison, the imbalance of the organs, and the temperature of the season, as well as sudden changes in the environment. In livestock, when a body decays, their temperament can drastically change, causing a violent reaction that leads to immediate onset. For humans, those with deficient qi and blood can be affected according to their organs. For example, if toxic energy arises from the heart meridian, it manifests as fiery carbuncles. This condition often appears in the lips, mouth, palms, and finger joints, starting as small red-yellow blisters that cause intense itching and pain, along with numbness in the limbs. In severe cases, one may experience alternating chills and fever, dizziness, irritability, mental confusion, and disorientation; these symptoms arise from heart-related afflictions. If toxic energy arises from the liver meridian, it presents as purple sparrow carbuncles.[356p]
The affliction often manifests as sores between the limbs, waist, and sides of the body. It begins with purple blisters that burst the next day, leading to bleeding and watery discharge. After three days, it causes the muscles to rot and the bones to decay, resulting in severe pain and suffering. In serious cases, the eyes become red and squinting, the nails turn dark blue, the tongue stiffens, and the spirit becomes dull, often accompanied by restless sleep and startling dreams. These symptoms arise from diseases of the Liver channel.

When toxic qi arises in the Spleen channel, it manifests as yellow festering sores. Initially, yellow blisters appear, shiny and moist, surrounded by red edges. The affliction first emerges at the corners of the mouth, the lower and upper eyelids, and the frontal area of the temples, causing itching and tightness. In severe cases, it leads to nausea and vomiting, pain in the limbs, alternating chills and fever, and excessive thirst. These symptoms are signs of diseases of the Spleen channel.

When toxic qi arises in the Lung channel, it results in white festering sores. At first, white blisters emerge, hard on top and protruding at the roots. They burst, releasing greasy fluid, leading to sudden itching and pain, easily becoming rotten and sunken. In severe cases, it can damage the jaw and throat, cause elevated body temperature and cough with purulent phlegm, and lead to difficulty breathing. These conditions stem from diseases of the Lung channel.

When toxic qi arises in the Kidney channel, it presents as black festering sores.[357p]
The affliction often emerges in the ear canal, chest, abdomen, waist, and obscure soft tissues between the kidneys. At first, it manifests as black spots with purple blisters, toxins invading the skin, gradually attacking the muscles, becoming as hard as nails, causing pain that penetrates to the marrow. In severe cases, the extremities turn blue and purple, accompanied by fright, depression, and a sinking sensation. The eyes may reveal distress; these symptoms arise from kidney channel disorders. The five types of sores correspond to the five visceral organs.

Additionally, the red thread sore appears between the joints of the palm, initially resembling a small wound, then developing red threads that escalate to the knuckles, causing chills and fevers, and in severe cases, nausea and vomiting. If left untreated, the red threads can reach the heart and may lead to serious harm. To treat the red thread sore, one should use a needle at the tip of the red thread to create an incision and let it bleed, then make an incision at the initial wound, inserting toad venom strips and applying medicated plaster, with internal consumption of diaphoretic medicines for self-healing.

In treating this condition, early intervention is crucial. Those treated promptly have a full chance of recovery, while those treated slightly later may have a chance of only fifty to sixty percent. Those who neglect treatment only have a slim one or two in ten chance of recovery.[358p]
When the condition begins above the neck, if the three yang channels are affected by poison, one must use a beryllium needle to pierce the center of the sore four or five fen deep, severing the root of the carbuncle to allow the bad blood to flow out. Then, one should apply Huai-Deng Dan or toad venom strips into the opening and cover it with an ointment. If the condition is below the neck and the three yin channels are affected, one should resort to moxibustion. If the moxibustion is painless, it is also necessary to use needles to insert medicinal substances for effectiveness. Subsequently, one should use toad venom pills. In winter, with Wanling Dan, inducing a vigorous sweat is necessary to dissipate the poison, lest it linger and cause transformations. Nowadays, people’s treatment methods do not differentiate between yin and yang or the surface and internal; whenever they see a sore, they apply moxibustion indiscriminately. They do not realize that the head is the apex of all yang, and excessive yang heat leads to serious issues. Although small, its harm is significant; further moxibustion only enhances the fire, forcing the poison inward to attack, which may result in severe symptoms such as yellowing of the skin. After this occurs, the head, face, ears, and neck can all swell, resembling a bloated corpse, arising with seven evils. Even if there are methods available for treatment, only one or two out of a hundred may be effective. Moreover, there are various types of carbuncles with differing shapes, hence the old sayings about them are not recorded in detail here.[359p]
At first, it appears like mange, resembling a pimple, either as small blisters or bumps, and if it is swollen and does not dissipate, it is considered favorable. If the sore does not exhibit cold or heat, does not cause nausea, and the appetite is normal with warm hands and feet, it is also favorable. Once the condition has formed, if the sore is swollen but the flesh is not, surrounded by white, causing more pain and less itching, and produces pus, it is favorable. If pus has already oozed out but the sore remains high and swollen, with bright flesh and a gradually flattening center that is red and lively, it is favorable. If it begins resembling a carbuncle but is soft and greyish, with flat, swollen edges, it is unfavorable. If before erupting, there are symptoms of cold and heat like malaria, with nausea and loss of appetite, and later, the sore appears like mosquito bites or flea spots, or in bluish-purple and black blisters, soft and depressed with deep rotten holes, and there is coarse breath with cold extremities, it is unfavorable. If the sore resembles a fish's navel, soft and puffy with a sunken, greyish-white top, with a thin pulse and cool body, it is mostly unfavorable; if already formed, with swollen flesh but the sore not rising, roots scattered, and the tip decayed and foul with blood and fluids, it indicates death. In general, for sores above the neck, needle punctures do not cause pain; below the neck, moxibustion does not cause pain, both indicate death. If it has already spread, causing swelling in the head, neck, ears, and face, accompanied by irritability, a thin pulse, and wheezing, it indicates death. If over time, the original sore shows no traces and the areas it spread to produce pus again, with a rapid pulse and dry lips, it will ultimately lead to death. However, if the illness is severe but the circumstances are favorable, life can be preserved; if the sore is minor but the circumstances are unfavorable, danger is constant.[360p]
When a condition arises above the neck, one must first use acupuncture to remove the bad blood, ensuring that the poison does not attack internally. When the condition arises below the neck, one must first use moxibustion to eliminate its force, so that it does not invade the healthy flesh. For fever and chills, with a tense and rapid pulse, indicating an external pathogen, it is appropriate to induce sweating to disperse it. If there is body heat, dry throat, strong pulse, and constipation, it is advisable to allow for a purgation. After acupuncture, if sores do not become rotten, and the swelling does not subside, additional internal medication should be applied. If initial moxibustion leads to unceasing yellow toxins, one must urgently use needling at the exit points to remove the bad blood. If there are chills and fever with dry retching, irritability and thirst, as well as confusion and faintness, it is necessary to detoxify and clear the heart, and protect the membranes. After a rupture, if qi and blood are injured, with lethargy and poor appetite, and restless sleep, it is advised to support the spleen and stomach to stabilize the spirit. As one nears recovery and qi and blood gradually return, food should be consumed. If there is still thirst, it is urgent to nourish the kidney water.[361p]
Treatise on Phlegmon

Phlegmon arises when wounds fester for too long without healing, resulting in the stagnation of qi and blood, leading to a lack of nourishment for the bones. Fine bones accumulate toxins and transform into larger bones. This occurs from the mingling of essences and blood during conception, which will eventually lead to this condition. Since the kidneys govern the bones, it is advisable to take Kidney Qi Pills and Shiquan Dabu Decoction to first replenish the spleen and kidneys; then apply moxa sticks wrapped in mugwort and attach them to warm the area, causing the necrotic and decayed bones to naturally shed, allowing new flesh to grow and the wound to heal.

External Medicine for Boils, Abscesses, and Poisons

Formula

Internal Xiao Huanglian Decoction to treat nausea, heat, and agitation; pulse is deep and hard, with swollen, firm skin that remains unchanged in color, deep roots, and the cause lies within the viscera requiring urgent resolution.

  • Huang Lian
  • Shao Yao
  • Dang Gui
  • Bing Lang
  • Mu Xiang
  • Huang Qin
  • Zhi Zi
  • Bo He
  • Jie Geng
  • Gan Cao, each one tael.
  • Lian Qiao, two taels.

Except for Bing Lang and Mu Xiang which should be ground into a powder, mix and file. Take one and a half cups of water for each dose, boil down to one cup, take one or two doses initially; then, for subsequent doses, add one qian of Da Huang, and then increase by two qian, to improve the condition. If there are signs of heat, cease using the Huanglian Decoction; if there is constipation, add more Da Huang. If there are no signs of heat, continue using the decoction as needed. By ensuring both internal and external communications are unblocked, and harmonizing the qi and defensive mechanisms, the meridians will certainly not be obstructed.[362p]
Internal Infusion and Re-brewed Powder: This treats swelling and heat on the surface, where the root is not deeply entrenched, and the symptoms are on the exterior. The pulse is superficial, and the pain is beneath the skin. If the evil energy is strong, it will certainly invade the interior; thus, immediate internal infusion is necessary to rescue the inner balance.

Ingredients:
2 liang of Ground Cudrania, Astragalus, and Siler, 5 qian of Cinnamon, 1 liang each of Peony, Scutellaria, Atractylodes, Poria, Ginseng, Licorice, Angelica, and Stephania.

Preparation:
Crush and mix the above ingredients. First, take 1 jin of Atractylodes and boil it in 5 sheng of water until reduced to 3 sheng. Remove the Atractylodes residue, then add the twelve ingredients above and boil again until there's about 3 to 4 cups of clear liquid. Strain this to make 3 or 4 doses to be taken throughout the day. Additionally, brew a soup from the Atractylodes residue, remove the residue, and then take the decoction of the twelve ingredients.

This method eliminates dampness, disperses heat, and harmonizes the stomach qi. If the condition persists, prepare half the original dosage. For constipation and irritability, take a small amount of Huang Lian decoction; if there is mild diarrhea and irritation has subsided, take half of the re-brewed powder. By following these instructions, both the protective and nutritive energies will operate harmoniously, preventing the intrusion of evil energy into the internal space.[363p]
Danggui and Huangqi Decoction treats sores and abscesses, particularly when the internal organs have been affected and the pain is intolerable. The ingredients are: Danggui, Huangqi, Shenggande Huang, Chuanxiong, Digupi, and Shaoyao, each half a money.

Prepare by grinding these ingredients, then decoct in water and take as a drink. If there is fever, add Huangqin; if there's restlessness and inability to sleep, add Zhizhi; if there is vomiting, this indicates dampness invading the stomach, so increase the amount of Baizhu.

The three prescriptions mentioned above are methods used by a disciple of Yishui for treating sores. They are listed here at the beginning, followed by various ancient and modern prescriptions. When treating illnesses, one should carefully examine the pulse and symptoms to apply these methods, which should ideally lead to no mistakes.[364p]
Tori Rongwei’s Decoction treats boils, abscesses, and unnamed swellings.

Ingredients:

  • 7 parts of cinnamon twig
  • Ginseng
  • Astragalus
  • Safflower
  • Genuine Atractylodes
  • Bupleurum
  • Forsythia
  • Angelica (root)
  • Notopterygium
  • Scutellaria
  • Saposhnikovia
  • Honey-fried Licorice, each 1 qian (about 3 grams)

Prepare one dose with one cup of water and one cup of wine, simmer until reduced to one cup, and take before meals.

Modified Angelica Decoction treats various sores and ulcers. Any painful or itchy sore is attributed to heart fire. When the fire is stagnant, it manifests.

Ingredients:

  • Angelica, Rehmannia, and Cimicifuga, each 5 qian
  • Saposhnikovia 2.5 qian
  • Mentha and Fo-Ti, each 2 qian
  • Bupleurum, White Peony, Chuanxiong, Notopterygium, Astragalus, each 2 qian
  • Safflower, Pterocarya, and Licorice, each 1 qian

Prepare (grind) the ingredients, taking 5 qian each time, with 2 cups of water and 3 slices of fresh ginger, simmer until reduced to 80% of the amount, and take far from meals. Bathing to induce slight sweating has a rapid effect, aiding in the harmony of blood and qi; taking this should yield results.[365p]
Ginseng Bai Du San
Ginseng, Du Huo, Chai Hu, fried Jie Geng, fried Zhi Ke with bran, Qiang Huo, Fu Ling, Chuan Xiong, Qian Hu, licorice, each one qian; make one dose, with two zhōng of water, three slices of ginger, decoct to one zhōng, take after taking internal detoxifying powder.

Guo's Divine Efficacy Wu Jin San
Used to treat malignant boils, carbuncles, tumors, and various festering sores caused by toxic factors attacking the bones. If the sore is dark, sunken, and as hard as stone, with cold limbs, fine pulse, sometimes fainting, talking senselessly, thirst, in severe danger, take this to induce sweating to bring the sore forth.

Collecting Herbs
Collect Cang Er Tou on the fifth day of the fifth month at noon;
Cao Wu Tou,
Huo Ma Tou on a sunny day;
Mu Zai removing joints;
Xia Ma Tou;
Birch bark and joints fried crisply;
Ma Huang removing root joints.

Dry each equally under the sun, then place inside an earthenware jar, seal with salt mud, and use charcoal fire to roast from morning until the time of Shen; when it turns black like coal, grind it to a powder. Take two qian per dose, for severe cases, take three qian; mix with hot wine to take. Use detoxifying and purging medications as needed. If preparing this medicine, it must be done on a clear, good day, in a quiet room, away from chickens, dogs, cats, and the sight of ghosts. Also known as Shou Gong Yuan Hei San.[366p]
Deadly Dan: Treats various kinds of swelling, toxins, carbuncles, and malignant sores.

Toad Venom: 5 grams of powdered light, 3 qian of cinnabar, 1 qian each of white alum, dried cold water stone, copper green, frankincense, myrrh, musk; 21 grains of snail, ground separately. Mix these into a fine powder, grind the snail separately; if not round, use good wine for shaping into pills the size of mung beans. Take one pill each time, chew 3 to 5 stalks of fresh green onions extremely fine, spit into the palm, wrap the medicine inside, and swallow with hot wine and onion. Walk 5 to 7 miles until sweating occurs for efficacy. For severe cases, take an additional 1 or 2 pills.

Toad Venom Pills: Treats carbuncles and all malignant sores.

Chuan Wu, Lotus Petals, and Cinnabar: 1.5 qian each of Chuan Wu, lotus petals, and large cinnabar; 2 qian each of frankincense and myrrh; 1 qian each of powdered light and toad venom; 2.5 grams of musk. Grind these into a fine powder, mix into pills the size of peas. For each dose, take one pill; for serious cases, take two, following the previous method to induce sweating.

These three formulas are called the chief medicines by the Guo family, mainly aimed at dispersing diseases. The first formula is for the Taiyang pattern, while the latter two are for the Shaoyin pattern. However, all are potent substances; the wise should determine the severity and balance of Yin and Yang for appropriate selection and use.[367p]
Cinch of Gold Elixir

This is also known as the Returning Soul Pill, the Rebirth Round, the Life-Chasing Pill, the Longevity Round, the Reviving Round, the Know-Fate Round, the Attaining Dao Round. It must not be shown to non-humans. If someone suffers from sores that are not yet rotten, give them three rounds to swallow, and they will come back to life. If their mouth is closed, just open their teeth gently, grind the three rounds, and pour it down their throat to bring them back to life immediately. This medicine treats back boils and abscesses, and all-over body bone pain where one first feels thirst when drinking water, has a burning sensation in the mouth, heaviness in the limbs, and a strong heat in the body.

Ingredients:

  1. One part musk
  2. One part southern frankincense
  3. One part black gold stone
  4. One part light powder
  5. One part realgar
  6. One part dog treasure
  7. One part myrrh
  8. Three parts powdered frost
  9. Three parts yellow wax
  10. Five parts realgar
  11. One carp gall bladder and one dog gall bladder, dried in the shade
  12. Seven whole golden-headed centipedes, toasted
  13. One cup of breast milk from a first-born son
  14. Two parts toad venom

Preparation:
Grind the above ingredients, except for the yellow wax and breast milk, into fine powder. Boil the yellow wax and breast milk into a paste. Combine and form pills the size of mung beans for adults and as large as mustard seeds for children. Take one pill; for severe cases, increase to three pills. Grind seven cloves of white cloves into a paste, mix with water drawn fresh, take it down, and cover with clothing to sleep, avoiding drafts. Sweating is good for recovery. Severe pain, akin to swelling from a headless sore, will resolve in no more than three doses and will have immediate effects. After taking the medicine, consume plain porridge and melon, then sleep—it's wonderfully effective.[368p]
Wujin San is used to treat the pain and swelling of boils and toxic swellings.

Take four parts of tooth soap, five parts each of toad venom and musk, one part each of bloodstone that has been roasted, snake skin that has been roasted, and bee larva that has been roasted. Use two parts each of cicada skin washed in wine, blood-resisting agent, incense, and roasted silkworms with the silk removed. Use three parts of whole scorpion, soaked in hot water seven times; two and a half parts each of cinnabar ground and floated in water, realgar, and roasted pangolin. Use four parts of heavenly dragon, roasted in wine, with the head and feet removed; as well as two and a half parts each of Chuanwu tip and myrrh.

Grind all the above into fine powder, measure and mix evenly in two portions. Take three grams each time, mixed with red sand sugar and green onion wine to swallow, inducing sweating as required.[369p]
Sheng Jindan
Treatment for symptoms as before.
Musk, white arsenic, each five grams; toad venom one tael; realgar, cinnabar, frankincense, myrrh, dragon's blood, each one and a half taels; whole scorpion (soaked and roasted), heavenly dragon (head and feet removed, roasted), and pangolin (roasted), each three taels; fried silkworms, five taels. Mix the above into a fine powder, and take as before.

Duoming Dan
Treatment for symptoms as before.
Light powder, musk, white arsenic, each five grams; white alum (calcined and ground), bloodstone, each one tael; toad venom (dissolved in wine), verdigris, cold water stone (calcined), frankincense, myrrh, realgar, each two taels; twenty-one snails, with shells. Grind the snails into a paste, mix with the above ingredients to form pills the size of mung beans, coating with one tael of cinnabar. If the pills do not hold, add good wine and mix well. Take two or three pills at a time. First, chew three inches of green onion thoroughly and spit out onto the left palm for men and the right palm for women, then wrap the pills in the green onion and wash down with warm, ash-free wine, then cover and seek to induce sweating. For severe cases, do not exceed three doses.

Nei Tuo Qiang Huo Tang
Qiang huo and yellow bracken (washed with wine), each two taels; fang feng, dry roots, lonicera, and angelica, each one tael; cinnamon three grams; licorice (roasted), aster, dried citrus peel, each five grams; astragalus one tael and five grams.
Prepare as one dose with two large cups of wine and one large cup of water, decoct until reduced to one cup, strain and take hot on an empty stomach. Cover the abscess with a cloth to ensure the medicine works effectively. One dose is sufficient for healing.[370p]
Toriwen Herbal Decoction: It treats cold obstructing the skin and hair, restricting the meridians, preventing extension and movement. When heat traps in the inner tissues, it gathers and causes redness and swelling, leading to unbearable pain, with chills and fevers. There may also be joint pain.

Ingredients:

  • Ephedra (removing roots and joints) - 2 qian
  • Angelica - 2 qian
  • Ligusticum chuanxiong - 2 qian
  • Saposhnikovia - 3 qian (remove the reed)
  • Pueraria - 3 qian
  • Cimicifuga - 4 qian
  • Honey-fried licorice and white peony - 0.5 qian each
  • Ginseng and Atractylodes - 1 qian each

Mix the above, grind to the size of a mung bean. Each dose is 1 tael, with 2 bowls of water. First, boil the Ephedra until cooked and remove the foam. Then add the remaining herbs and simmer until reduced to 1 bowl. Strain, take while warm, and rest in a warm place, covered with cotton clothing, until sweating occurs and it disperses.

Angelica Pain Relief Decoction: It treats all types of wind-damp heat toxins, infiltrating sores and ulcers, with damp toxins settling in the lower parts, causing sores and redness on the knees and feet, both internal and external sores, with pus that doesn’t stop, itching or pain. If the pulse is deep, tight, and slippery, it is also appropriate to take.

Ingredients:

  • Notopterygium - 2 qian
  • Ginseng - 2 qian
  • Bitter Hydrangea (prepared in wine) - 2 qian
  • Pueraria - 2 qian
  • Real Atractylodes - 2 qian
  • Cimicifuga - 2 qian
  • Scutellaria (prepared in wine) - 0.5 tael
  • Artemisia capillaris (stir-fried with wine) - 0.5 tael
  • Honey-fried licorice - 0.5 tael
  • Saposhnikovia - 3 qian
  • Angelica (whole) - 3 qian
  • Anemarrhena (prepared in wine) - 3 qian
  • Alisma - 3 qian
  • Polyporus - 3 qian
  • White Atractylodes - 1.5 qian

Mix, chew, and for each dose take 1 tael, simmer in water and consume on an empty stomach. Take again before sleeping.[371p]
Fu Jian San - for the treatment of carbuncles and abscesses.

Huangbo, Huangqin, Huanglian, Zhimu, Shengdi (washed with wine), each one qian; Fangji, Shanzhi, Qianghuo, Huangqi, Maidong, Gancao (roasted), Duhuo, Renshen each half qian; Danggui (tail) two qian; Chenpi, Fangfeng (young shoots), Gancao (young shoots, fresh), Sumu, Danggui (body), Wumeizi, Zhuling, Gaoben, Lianqiao, Jiegeng each one and a half qian.

All these ingredients are to be ground. For each dose, take four qian, mix with one cup of water, boil down to seven parts, strain, and take depending on the symptoms, before or after meals.

Jinzhen San - for the treatment of various swellings arising from boils.

Zaojiao needles, spring harvested, half fresh and half black.

Take one ingredient from above, amount as desired, dry it and grind it to a powder. After meals, take two to three qian mixed with wine.

Jingyao Shixuan San

Renshen, Danggui, Huangqi each two liang; Chuanxiong, Fangfeng, Houp kua, Jiegeng, Guanggui, Gancao, Baizhi each one liang.

Grind these into fine powder. For each dose, take two qian, increasing up to six qian maximum, mixed with hot wine. Take multiple times daily, with more being better. For those who do not drink alcohol, use a concentrated decoction of wood fragrance, but this is not as effective as the power of the wine. Scholar Xu has said: This formula was obtained from a unique individual in the capital, helping countless people relieve their suffering.[372p]
Sixteen-Herb Flowing Qi Drink: Treats nameless swollen carbuncles and related conditions. Ingredients: Chuanxiong, Angelica, Peony, Fangfeng, Ginseng, Mu Xiang, Astragalus, Guanggui, Platycodon, Bai Zhi, Betel nut, Hou Po, Wu Yao, Licorice, Zi Su, and Zhiqiao. Grind and prepare, then decoct with water for oral administration.

Thousand Gold Tuo Li Powder: Treats all types of sores and swellings, furuncles, and carbuncles. Ingredients: One and a half taels of Astragalus, two taels each of Hou Po, Fangfeng, and Platycodon; two taels and two qian of Lian Qiao; three qian each of Mu Xiang and Myrrh; two qian of Frankincense; half a tael of Angelica; one tael each of Chuanxiong, Bai Zhi, Peony, Guanggui, Ginseng, and Licorice. Grind into a fine powder. Take three qian with a large cup of wine, simmer for three to two boils, and consume warm after straining.

Tuo Du Powder: Treats the initial stages of high swelling and pain of abscesses with breathlessness. Ingredients: One piece of Fu Zi (prepared and skinned), Angelica, Ephedra, Licorice, Guanggui, Chuanxiong, Qiang Huo, Stone Awake, and Gentian. Grind the nine ingredients into equal parts. Each dose is two qian, brewed with a large cup of water, three slices of ginger, and a little salt.[373p]
Sheng Ji She Gan Decoction: Treats carbuncles, sores, and swellings on the back with painful throbbing, with a rapid and strong pulse. Ingredients: She Gan, Xi Jiao, Sheng Ma, Yuan Shen, Huang Qin, Mai Men Dong, Da Huang, each one tael; Shan Zhi half a tael. Take in powder form, each dose is five qian, add bamboo leaves and Mang Xiao one qian for additional efficacy.

Tuo Li Powder: Treats all kinds of malignant sores, explosive back sores, and beginning toxins, with a rapid and strong pulse, and severe swelling about to form pus. Three doses will eliminate the condition. Ingredients: Chuan Da Huang, Mu Li, (Cao She) Lou Gen, Zao Jiao Zhen, (Shi Bu) Xiao, Lian Qiao each three qian; Dang Gui, Jin Yin Hua each one tael; Chi Shao Yao, Huang Qin each one qian. Prepare a coarse powder, take half a tael mixed with equal parts of water and wine for decoction.

Po Guo Dan: Treats all types of heat swellings, wind-heat sores, fever, excessive sweating, severe thirst, constipation, and symptoms of verbal dysregulation due to Yang constraint. Ingredients: Da Huang two and a half taels, half raw and half cooked; Mang Xiao, Gan Cao each two taels. Prepare as powder, refine with honey into pill size of a ball, each dose is half a pill, for severe illness take one to two pills, dissolved in half a cup of child's urine mixed with wine after meals, or in white soup mixed with wine.[374p]
Xie Xin Decoction: Treats sores, toxic swellings, agitation, thirst, and pulse that is hard and rapid.

  • Ingredients: 4 liang of Dihuang, 2 liang each of Huanglian, Shanzhi, Loulu, Zelan, Lianqiao, Huangqin, and Sumac; 1 liang of Rhinoceros horn.
  • Method: Grind together and take 3-5 qian per dose, decoct in water.

Qingliang Drink: Treats sores, restlessness, pain from cold drinks, pulse that is hard with constipation, and red, painful dark urine.

  • Ingredients: Stir-fried Dihuang, 2 qian each of Chishao, Danggui, and Gancao.
  • Method: Decoct in water for use.

Jingyao Loulu Decoction:

  • Ingredients: 1 liang each of Huangqi, Lianqiao, Chenxiang, Dihuang, and Loulu; 0.5 liang of powdered grass.
  • Method: Grind to a fine powder and take 2 qian per dose mixed with ginger and jujube soup.

Neixiao Shengma Decoction: Treats vigorous blood and qi; for cases of carbuncles or abscesses, with obstruction of urination and defecation.

  • Ingredients: 2 liang each of Shengma and Dihuang; 1.5 liang of Huangqin; 1 liang each of Zhirou (stir-fried), Danggui, Shaoyao, and Gancao.
  • Method: Grind and decoct in water, take before meals.

Sun Zhenren's Single-Boiled Dihuang Decoction: For hard, rapid pulse, typically in those with rich diets, and for significant constipation; use with caution.

  • Method: Wash one ingredient of Dihuang in Jinxin wine, chop it into bean-sized pieces, and boil in water for use.[375p]
    Xuan Du San: Treats all sores and toxins, its effects cannot be fully described. Prepare five qian each of da huang (rhubarb) and bai zhi (angelica dahurica) as one dose, with two sheng of water, decoct to one sheng, and take before meals.

Nei Tuo San: Treats various swellings and toxic ulcers, one dose can lead to immediate recovery. Use half a liang each of da huang and mu li (oyster shell), two pieces of (cao she) luo, and three qian of gan cao (licorice). Grind these and take three qian each time, with one large bowl of water, decoct to seven parts, strain, and take warm.

Che Ao San: Treats the initial stages of carbuncles and swelling pain, or conditions in the young characterized by excess heat manifesting on the back. It is urgent to dispel toxins and facilitate downward movement. Suitable for both adults and children at all times of the year. Take one pair of purple-backed crab pincers, secure with salty mud, and fire roast until red; place it on the ground. Mix with qing fen (light powder) and gan cao, both two qian each, da huang five qian, huang qin (scutellaria) and lou lu, the roots without hair, each half a liang; grind them into a powder. Take two qian each time, quickly ingest with mint tea or wine.

Nei Xiao Wan [from "Bao Jian"]: Treats newly sprouted swellings, such as lymphatic nodules and tubercles, where heat toxins are congested. Take to promote internal resolution. Use mint leaves and uninfested zi qiao (soap pod), boil in water until soft, then decoct both into a thick paste. Add half a jin each of qian niu (morning glory) head powder, qing pi (green tangerine peel), and chen pi (aged tangerine peel), one half a liang of zhen zhu (benzoin) and three qian each of guo zhu (perilla) and jing san leng (three-edged bellflower) as powders. Mix them with qian niu head powder to form pills the size of mung beans. Take thirty pills each time, along with decocted lian qiao (forsythia) tea after meals.[376p]
The Immortal's Detoxifying Ten Thousand Diseases Pill, also known as the Pursuing Toxin Pill, Jade Pivot Elixir, and Purple Gold Ingot, treats all poisons, including those from mushrooms, rats, and toxic plants, as well as poisons from dead cattle, horses, pufferfish, and epidemics such as fevers and mountain miasmas. It addresses urgent throat closures, binding throat winds, spleen diseases with yellow swelling, red eyes, exposure to temperature extremes, heat toxins attacking upwards, as well as hanging, drowning, impacts from blows, incidences of carbuncles, boils, and burns, injuries from snakes, insects, dogs, and rodents, and symptoms of possession or insanity; it is recommended to take this pill. When going about your daily life, do not be without this medicine; it is a true treasure for saving lives and protecting health.

Ingredients needed: three to two taels of fresh文蛤 (a type of clam), preferably pale red or yellow, crushed and cleaned; two taels of山慈姑; one tael of ground续随子 (with the shell removed, pressed to extract oil, then ground further); one and a half taels of cleaned red芽大戟; three qian of musk, ground.

Each ingredient should be finely ground and mixed thoroughly, then combined with glutinous rice porridge in a wooden mortar and pounded over a thousand times. Divide the mixture into forty pellets, to be consumed on the Dragon Boat Festival, Double Ninth Festival, or the Night of Sevens. If needed urgently, it can also be taken on the day of the Dragon (辰). Do not let women, elderly, or children consume it, nor allow chickens or dogs to see it. Handle with care, or it may lose its efficacy.[377p]
If a boil or sore has not yet burst, apply ground cold water to the painful area and take it internally. After a while, if you feel itching, it will gradually dissipate. For ailments related to the dual poisons of yin and yang, such as feeling heavy in the chest from a cold or speaking irrationally, if the evil poison has not yet erupted, and in cases of pestilence or miasma that constricts the throat, mix cold water with a leaf of peppermint and grind it together. In urgent situations where one is disoriented, shouting and running about, as well as experiences of ghostly fears, consume this mixture with warm, unburnt liquor. If someone has hanged themselves or drowned, and shows warmth in the heart, or has been frightened to death by ghostly encounters and has not been dead overnight, administer the ground mixture with cold water. For injuries from snakes, dogs, or centipedes, apply the ground mixture with cold water to the affected area. In cases of abdominal swelling or confusion, it is especially advisable to take this remedy. For all kinds of intermittent fevers, regardless of whether they are new or old, brew a decoction of peach and willow branches and take it. For children experiencing sudden or chronic convulsions, as well as various forms of diarrhea, grind a leaf of peppermint with honey water and administer it. If the jaw is clenched tightly, grind a pill for both external application and internal consumption, adjusting the amount according to size. For toothaches, grind with liquor and apply it, while also swallowing a little. For burns from fire or boiling water, apply ground water from the East River to the affected area. For injuries from strikes or falls, consume fried pine resin mixed with liquor. For chronic headaches in the temples, use liquor mixed with peppermint to grind paper flowers and apply them to the temples, and consume this as well. For all kinds of epilepsy, where the mouth and eyes are askew, eyelids flutter, there is excessive salivation at night, speech is slurred, one might suddenly suffer a stroke with a locked jaw, clenching of the muscles, swelling in bones and joints, pain in hands and feet, and difficulty in walking, use liquor to grind and take this remedy. Pregnant women should not consume this.[378p]
Guo's Ruiround Pills are used to treat intestinal abscesses, gastric abscesses, and internal accumulations, and are also effective for both men and women with accumulation-related conditions. The ingredients include: one tael each of Angelica sinensis, Beijing sanleng, betel nut, wood turtle, and stir-fried pangolin; powdered oyster and stir-fried pangolin, with each ingredient used in the prescribed amount. One and a half taels each of forsythia and bitter orange, one tael each of roasted gypsum and amber, twenty-one pieces of indivisia (without oil), and a small amount of musk. These are all ground into a powder, mixed with wine to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take ten to thirty pills with warm wine before lying down. If bowel movements become loose, reduce the number of pills. If there is blood and pus in the urine or stool, treat with different medicines.[379p]
The Ten Thousand Spirits Lifetaking Pill by the Guo Family, also known as the Tingshou Jishi Ointment. It treats all kinds of wounds, swellings, and sores. When they first appear, with a deep and strong pulse, and if the poisonous qi remains after taking diaphoretics, it is appropriate to take this remedy.

Ingredients include:

  • 2.5 qian of cinnabar and salt flowers each
  • 2 qian of realgar and sweet-scented wood
  • 2 qian of alum (raw)
  • 1.5 qian of red stone resin, yellow lead, amber, and genuine light powder each
  • 7 seeds each of processed mother-of-pearl and castor beans (the latter boiled ten times)

Musk and powdered brain each amount to 1 qian. Grind these ingredients into a powder. Mix with the processed mother-of-pearl and castor bean paste to form pills. If the mixture is too dry, add processed honey until it becomes a paste and store it in pottery. When using, roll into balls the size of Chinese water chestnuts, taking one with well water or broth. Avoid hot foods for half a day. Adjust dosage for adults and children according to need.

A single gold pill treats all kinds of evil sores, carbuncles, and unknown tumors.

Ingredients include:

  • 0.5 qian each of sandalwood, agarwood, and frankincense
  • 1.5 qian of processed mother-of-pearl

Grind these ingredients into a fine powder, mix in the specified amounts. Use one and a half black fat jujubes, skin removed and mashed to form pills the size of Chinese water chestnuts. For each dose, take one pill, adjusting based on the person's condition. Those with strong stomach qi may only take a few sips of water; do not overdo it. After this, take a sip of water to swallow the pill, and repeat several times, using rice drink to replenish.[380p]
Drinking Wei Ling Xian

Wei Ling Xian is not limited by quantity. Each dose is one qian, mixed with warm wine, taken on an empty stomach, adjusting daily for slight efficacy.

Five Spice and Forsythia Decoction

Treats various swellings and sores. Initially, in one or two days, one may feel reversed chills, throat blockage, with alternating heat and cold. Ingredients:

  • Agarwood, Mu Xiang, Musk, Cloves, Forsythia, Belamcanda, Cimicifuga, Angelica, Sang Ji Sheng, Licorice (roasted), each one liang;
  • Frankincense, Mutong, each two liang;
  • Da Huang (Rhizoma Rhei), one and a half liang.

For preparation, grind as needed; each dose is five qian, mixed with one and a half cups of water, decocted to seven parts, taken warm for effect.

Qian Jin Lou Lu Decoction

Treats carbuncles and rotten flesh, with seasonal heat toxicity causing reddened swelling. Ingredients:

  • Lou Lu, Forsythia, Huang Qin, Bai Lian, Zhi Ke, Cimicifuga, Powder Grass, Ma Huang, and (Shi Bu) Nitre, each one liang;
  • Da Huang, one and a half liang.

For preparation, exclude Nitre; each dose is two qian, mixed with one cup of water, three slices of ginger, and three leaves of mint, decocted and taken warm for effect.

Fang Feng Tong Sheng San

Treats seasonal toxins and heat toxicity, with constipation and dryness. If after seasonal hunger or famine, the stomach's energy is depleted, must assess carefully and do not use if overly full. Ingredients:

  • Fang Feng, Dong Quai, Chuan Xiong, Bai Shao, Da Huang, Mang Xiao, Forsythia, Mint, Ma Huang, Jie Geng, Gypsum, Huang Qin, and Hua Shi, each one liang;
  • Bai Zhu, Shan Zhi, Jin Jie, each two qian five fen;
  • Licorice, two liang.

For preparation, boil with water for consumption; or grind into powder and mix with clear soup. Adjust based on individual conditions.[381p]
Zhonghe Decoction treats wounds that are half Yin and half Yang, appearing neither sore nor swollen. This condition arises from a deficiency of vital energy and the failure to support it adequately.

Ingredients:

  • Ginseng and dried tangerine peel, 2 qian each
  • Astragalus, white atractylodes, angelica, and white peony root, 1.5 qian each
  • Poria, chuanxiong, fried soapberry thorn, frankincense, myrrh, honeysuckle, and licorice root, 1 qian each

These should be prepared with equal parts water and wine for decoction.

Nei Tuo San, also known as Huxin San, should be taken in ten or more doses over one to three days.

Composition:

  • 1 tael of pure soybean flour
  • 0.5 tael of prepared frankincense, lightly roasted in a silver vessel, stirred with fingers until dry, then quickly poured out, fanned to cool, and ground very finely.

Mix this powder evenly; take 2 to 3 qian at a time, decocted in a strong licorice soup for oral administration, sipping frequently to ensure the medicine stays in the chest and diaphragm. If there is a poison affecting the heart, presenting symptoms of vomiting, this should be administered. However, if there is cold accompanied by vomiting, this is not advisable, and instead, warming herbs should be used.

Guo Lao Gao treats all types of abscesses, reduces swellings, expels toxins, and prevents internal attacks from poison; its effects cannot be fully described.

Ingredients:

  • 2 jin of large licorice

Crush and soak in river water overnight, knead to extract a thick juice, remove all fibers, and filter through silk. Then, slowly boil down in a silver vessel to form a paste, and store in a container. Each dose is 1 to 2 spoonfuls, with no ash wine or plain broth as alternatives. Those who have previously taken dry medicine pills may also find relief with this preparation.

In the collection of formulas, each pound of licorice should be divided into three doses mixed with warm wine for administration. Currently, the recommendation is 1 to 2 spoonfuls, which might suggest less power.[382p]
Detox Powder: For treating the initial stage of festering sores, it is suitable for immediate use.

Ingredients: Shavings of rhinoceros horn, Licorice root, nitrate of barium, Red peony, and Akebia; each one tael. Additionally, two taels of ground gypsum, half a tael each of Yunnan bellflower, dried Ophiopogon root (pits removed), and fresh Licorice shavings.

Directions: Take four qian of the above mixture, boil in one medium cup of water until reduced to two-thirds, strain, and take warm without time restrictions.

Clear Heart and Stabilize Inner Gold Powder: Also known as Golden Flower Powder.

Ingredients: Cinnabar ground separately, White poria, Ginseng, and Licorice; each seven and a half qian. Additionally, four taels of ground Hyacinth bean flour, half a tael each of ground white cardamom and nitrate of barium, ground separately. Furthermore, two and a half qian each of ground realgar, ground musk, and ground brain.

Directions: Mix the powdered ginseng, poria, and white cardamom thoroughly, take one and a half qian each time, and dissolve in honeyed water; there's no specific time for consumption. This medicine specifically treats sores that are hot, painful, causing thirst and restlessness. This medicine detoxifies.

Inner Pursuit Detox Dan: Clear Heart Detox Powder upgraded.

Ingredients: Big cinnabar, realgar, fresh rhinoceros horn, amber (all ground finely), Five qian each of black horn and agarwood, and one qian of musk.

Directions: Grind to a fine powder, form into honey pills the size of a Chinese parasol seed, and take twenty pills each time, consumed with thin mint tea.[383p]
Du Sheng San: This remedy treats boils and carbuncles, which are caused by stagnant blood and constrained qi. Use Xiangfuzi by cleaning it of hair, soaking it in fresh ginger juice overnight, then drying and grinding it extremely fine. Take two qian mixed with white soup at any time. It is said that many cases of carbuncles arise from anger. If experiencing such a condition, there will likely be a lot of anger, but just taking Xiangfuzi and eating to relieve qi will be effective.

Yuan Zhi Jiu: This remedy treats all types of boils, carbuncles, abscesses, and severe toxic conditions. If there is dead blood or hidden toxins inside, it may not hurt; applying the remedy will cause pain. If there is emotional distress like anger causing internal obstruction, the pain will be unbearable; applying it will alleviate the pain. If there is internal heat causing sensitivity, the application will bring coolness. If qi is deficient and blood weak, leading to non-healing wounds, or if there is internal emotional repression, treating it will surely bring recovery. Prepare Yuan Zhi by soaking it in an adequate amount of water, then pounding it into a powder. Mix three qian of the powder into a cup of wine, strain, and drink the clear liquid while applying the residue to the affected area.

Wu Xiang San: This remedy regulates the ascending and descending of qi, opens and benefits the three burners, alleviates stagnation, dissipates evil heat, and treats the stasis of yin and yang qi, toxins that create heat, swollen painful lumps, or conditions resembling boils but not true ones, leading to headaches, nausea, and chills with urgent heat. The components include equal parts of Mu Xiang, Ding Xiang, Chen Xiang, Ru Xiang, and Huo Xiang. Prepare this by grinding it into a powder, taking three qian each time, decocting it in one and a half cups of water, and drinking it warm after meals.[384p]
Honeysuckle Wine

At the onset of illness, one should take this remedy. It is effective for those who are impoverished or live in remote rural areas—always hits the mark. Take a handful of honeysuckle vines, mash the leaves in a sand pot, adding a little wine and properly mixing. Apply it around the affected area, leaving a gap in the center. Then take five taels, use a wooden pestle to crush it without iron tools, and one tael of raw licorice finely shavings.

Combine the two ingredients in a sand bottle, add two bowls of water, and simmer over gentle and strong heat until reduced to one bowl. Add a large bowl of good wine, boil for about ten times, strain out the residue, dividing it into three doses, to be taken continuously day and night. For severe conditions, two doses can be taken in one day.

Raw Rehmannia Powder

This treats boils, swelling, hot toxins, and pain, along with agitation of the heart.

Two taels of raw rehmannia, chopped and stir-fried rhubarb, and one tael each of the following: siler, scutellaria, lycium root, slightly stir-fried angelica, akebia, red peony, astragalus, and codonopsis, along with one and a half taels of red poria.

This is prepared as a powder, with each dose being four qian (a measurement unit), steeped in one medium cup of water. Add fourteen bamboo leaves, simmer until reduced to six parts, strain and drink warm at any time.

Ejiao Drink

Optimal ejiao is lightly fried until glossy, together with one tael each of powdered licorice, half a tael of dried tangerine peel.

Mix and divide into three doses. Use one cup of water, simmer until reduced to seven parts, strain and drink warm.[385p]
Beef Gel Drink: For severe cases of carbuncles and ulcers, take this to prevent the toxic qi from attacking internally. Use four ounces of clear beef gel, add a bowl of wine to the gel, boil in heavy broth until it dissolves and mixes well, then pour it out and soak in more wine as desired. Those who can drink may do so to the point of intoxication. This formula has saved many lives.

Alum Pill: Taking more than one ounce always yields results, especially effective in relieving pain without harming internal organs, benefiting countless people. Use one ounce of white alum and half an ounce of yellow wax, mix and form into pills about the size of a tung seed. Take ten pills at a time, gradually increasing to fifty pills, taken with warm wine. If the sore has not yet burst, it will dissolve; if it has burst, it will close up. Taking a hundred pills in a day is effective, able to prevent internal toxic attacks, especially protective of the membrane. It is best to take half a pound continuously. It is especially good to take after the wound has healed.

Disinfectant Powder: For treating weak gastric qi, or when due to blockage it cannot dissolve, taking this will allow it to dissolve if not formed, and will burst if it has formed, allowing rotten flesh to fall away and new flesh to grow. If the rotten flesh has ruptured but new flesh cannot heal, those with qi deficiency should use the Four Gentlemen Decoction as the main treatment, while those with blood deficiency should use the Four Substances Decoction as the main treatment, and if both qi and blood are deficient, the Ten Complete Great Supplement Decoction should be used as the main treatment. One should avoid cold and cooling disinfectant agents.

For the decoction: take ginseng, yellow qi, and salt water stir-fried; angelica with wine; peony stir-fried; ligusticum; white atractylodes stir-fried; and white poria, each one qian (a unit of weight). Seven parts of honeysuckle and white angelica, and five parts of roasted licorice and forsythia. Boil and take with water.[386p]
Translation:

To treat ulcers caused by deficiency of Qi and blood that cannot heal or contract, as well as cases of aversion to cold with fever, this formula should be used for supplementation. If the condition results from the six excesses and seven emotions, or from various entangled evils affecting the patient, one should examine the root causes and adjust with appropriate medicinal treatments. For cases of weak stomach Qi, the primary remedy should be Six Gentlemen Decoction. For those with Qi deficiency, use more of the following:

  • Ginseng, 6 grams
  • Atractylodes (fried), 6 grams
  • Tangerine peel
  • Angelica (Danggui)
  • Prepared Rehmannia (self-made)
  • White peony root (fried with wine)
  • Poria, each 4.5 grams

The above should be decocted in water for consumption.

Detoxifying Decoction is for the initial stage of boils and carbuncles where swelling has not yet formed; it can help dissolve them.

Ingredients include:

  • Astragalus, 60 grams
  • Licorice (roasted)
  • Tianluo (Qing)
  • Fried Chinese yam, each 30 grams
  • Ghost waist leaf, 15 grams (the kind that grows in damp stone banks in the shade; avoid the variant that grows on wood)

Prepare the above as a coarse powder, take 9 grams with one cup of water, boil down to seven parts, add three cups of wine, continue to boil briefly until a few bubbles appear, strain and take warm.[387p]
Shenxiao Tori San
For treating carbuncles and boils, intestinal abscesses, mastitis, unnamed swellings and toxins, with red swelling and pain, aversion to cold and fever, applicable to all ages, whether weak or strong.
Use: 5 taels of astragalus (remove the fibrous part), 5 taels of honeysuckle vine leaves, 1.8 taels of angelica, and 0.8 taels of roasted powdered licorice.
Grind into a fine powder; each dose is 5 qian, taken with 1.5 cups of wine, boiled down to 1 cup. If the illness is located above the diaphragm, take after meals; if below, take before meals, and after a short while, take again. The leftover dregs can be applied externally.

Huangqi San
Use: 1 tael of fine astragalus, 1 tael of red-purple picked soapberry thorns, and 0.5 taels of fine licorice powder. Each dose is 5 qian, taken with a cup of wine and a piece of frankincense, boiled to 7 parts, and remove the dregs before consuming.

Huangqi Siwu Decoction
Ingredients: Ginseng, astragalus, white atractylodes, poria, peony, licorice, fresh ginger, angelica, rehmannia, and chuanxiong.
Add more honeysuckle; boil in water for consumption.

Nei Gu Huangqi Wan
Ingredients: 0.5 taels each of fine astragalus and ginseng.
Grind into powder and add 1 qian of real dragon brain, mixing finely, and form into pills the size of soybeans. Take 30 pills with warm water, increasing to 40 pills daily, three times a day. [388p]
Huiyang Decoction treats spleen and kidney deficiency cold, with sores being purely yin; may also be applied when medicine damages original qi, resulting in no swelling, pain, or ulceration; or in cases of abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and reverse qi; or when yang qi has collapsed.

Ingredients:

  • Dried ginger and prepared Aconite, 2 qian each
  • Ginseng, White Atractylodes, Huangqi, 3 qian each
  • Angelica, Chenpi, and Honey-fried Licorice, 2 qian each
  • Chaihu, and Shengma, 5 fen each

Prepare with wine and water for decoction. If ineffective, double the ginger and Aconite. For external application, use Huiyang Yulong ointment.

Qingre Xiaodu Powder treats all types of carbuncles and Yang syndromes with swelling, pain, fever, and thirst.

Ingredients:

  • Prepared Huanglian, and prepared Sanjizi, 1 qian each
  • Lianqiao, and Angelica, 1 qian each
  • Chuanxiong, prepared Peony, and Sheng Dihuang, 1.5 qian each
  • Jinyinhua, 2 qian
  • Licorice, 8 fen

Prepare with water for decoction.

Huanglian Xiaodu Powder treats brain and back abscesses, swelling with burning pain, or numbness.

Ingredients:

  • Prepared Huanglian, and Qianghuo, 1 fen each
  • Huangqin and Huangbo, 0.5 qian each
  • Sheng Dihuang, prepared Zhimu, Du Huo, Fangfeng, Angelica tail, and Lianqiao, 4 fen each
  • Gaoben, Fangji, and Jie geng, 0.5 qian each
  • Huangqi, Su mu, Chenpi, and Zexie, 2 fen each
  • Ginseng and Licorice, 3 fen each

Prepare with water for decoction.

Huanglian Jiedu Decoction treats sores and ulcers with burning pain, irritability from drinking cold, rapid and flooding pulse, or delirium.

Ingredients:

  • Huangqin, Huangbo, and prepared Huanglian, 1.5 qian each
  • Sanjizi, 1.5 qian

Prepare with water for hot decoction.[389p]
Pus-Dispersing Decoction [Zhongjing]
Two liang of licorice, three liang of balloon flower, one liang of raw ginger, ten jujubes. Take these four ingredients, boil with three sheng of water until one sheng remains. Take warm, five out of ten, twice a day.

Pus-Dispersing Powder
Sixteen pieces of bitter orange, one and a half liang of peony, five qian of balloon flower. Grind the three ingredients into a powder, take one chicken yolk, mix it with the powder until equal, knead and cook into a thin porridge. Take warm, one sheng; this will cure.

Forsythia Decoction for treating boils, swellings, sores, and abscesses.
Three liang each of forsythia and siler (with forked parts removed), two liang each of shepherd's purse, white peony, yellow root (black heart removed), and original ginseng, one liang each of white poria (black skin removed), ginseng, balloon flower (chopped and roasted), and forsythia (removed from the stalk); half a liang of astragalus (raw); one and a half liang of mulberry root (white skin chopped). Pound and sift, take five qian each time, with one and a half cups of water, boil down to one cup, discard the dregs and take warm, twice a day.

Oak Tree Leaf Decoction [from the "Essentials"]
Four and a half liang of dry oak leaves, one liang each of dry lotus leaf central stem, dry daylily root, licorice piece, and earth tufu. Chop finely. Take half a liang each time, with two bowls of water, boil down to one bowl, divided into two doses, one in the morning and one in the evening. Those that are not yet mature will dissipate by themselves, and those that have ruptured will dry on their own. The lotus stem purges evil blood; daylily root clears water and detoxifies, regulating the diaphragm; oak has thorns that can drive them away; earth tufu is primarily for conditions of lower blood ailments. Minor symptoms might improve with this method.[390p]
Carapace Powder
One tael of carapace, calcined until red; two and a half qian of raw licorice; five fen of light powder—grind these into a fine powder. Take four qian per dose, decoct strongly, and mix with herbal wine to consume at dawn, to expel the harmful substances. Its effects are superior to those of the Five Spices.

Internal Dissolving Powder
Treats carbuncles, abscesses, painful swellings.
One tael each of ginseng (peeled), Hound's Tongue, Baical Skullcap, Sichuan Shepweed, slightly stir-fried Angelica, and Astragalus, and half a tael each of Poria and raw licorice; one cup of cooked red beans—grind these into a fine powder. Take two qian at a time, mixed with warm wine, without regard to timing.

Toxic Transformation Water Internal Elixir
For abscesses, carbuncles, and pock marks, breast lumps, and various unnamed and unidentifiable sores, this medicine can induce internal dissolution, detoxifying and transforming it to black water, expelled through the urine, with guaranteed efficacy. This formula should not be kept secret or taken lightly. Treasure it!
One qian each of frankincense, pangolin scales, White Root, Anemone, Fritillaria, Pinellia, honeysuckle, soapberry thorn, and Tianhua powder.
Grind these and prepare with one bowl of non-ash wine, simmer to half a bowl, strain out the dregs to create a dose, warm and take without variation. Crush the dregs and add one tael of finely ground autumn hibiscus leaves, moisten with honey water, allow to settle overnight, and no second dose is necessary. Avoid pungent stimulating foods for maximum effect.[391p]
Xianfang Huoming Decoction, also known as Zhenren Huoming Decoction, treats all kinds of sores and ulcers: It can disperse those that have not yet formed pus, and it causes those that have formed pus to burst. Additionally, it is a miraculous medicine for alleviating pain and disinfecting.

Ingredients include:

  • 1 qian of frankincense powder
  • 1 qian of fangfeng (siler)
  • 1 qian of bai zhi (angelica)
  • 1 qian of fritillaria
  • 1 qian of red peony root
  • 1 qian of radix angelicae sinensis (donqgui tail)
  • 1 qian of myrrh powder
  • 1 qian of fried soapberry thorn
  • 1 qian of tianhuafen (trichosanthes root)
  • 1 qian of licorice root segments
  • 1 qian of pangolin scales (prepared)
  • 3 qian of dried tangerine peel
  • 3 qian of honeysuckle

For application, on the back (back shu points), use soapberry thorn as the principal herb; for the abdomen, use bai zhi; for the chest, add 2 qian of fruit of the loquat; for the limbs, honeysuckle is the principal herb. If there are carbuncles, add 3 qian of purple river car grass root; if unavailable, it is still acceptable.

Prepare a coarse powder. The larger dosage is four liang, the smaller two liang for one dosage. Use ten tea cups of no ash wine, or five tea cups for smaller sores, and put into a bottle with a mouth, seal with thick paper to prevent gas from escaping. Boil down to three large cups, strain out the residue, and take this three times in succession without interruption. Administer according to the sores’ progress. Those who can drink alcohol may consume three to five cups afterward. This medicine has no alcohol effects, does not disturb the organs, and does not harm qi or blood. Avoid sour, light wine and iron utensils. After taking, lie on the side; if pain relief is felt, recovery is imminent. Its efficacy is vast, and one should not speculate.[392p]
Bao Anfang, Jie Gu: For treating sores, if they are already formed, they should be quickly drained.

Take one fresh loquat, peel and roast it over fire. Use one penny's worth of myrrh, finely ground. Additionally, take half a tael each of honeysuckle, licorice, and fresh ginger.

Grind all these into a fine powder, and use three sheng of good, ash-free wine to decoct in a silver vessel until reduced to one sheng. Divide this into three cups and drink it all over three times. For mild ailments, one dose is sufficient. If the sore medicine cannot disperse and new sores form, use this preparation.[393p]
Secret Formula for Detoxifying Powder
This treats all kinds of sores and toxins. Continuous use from beginning to end prevents internal complications. Use one large ingredient of (herb) Luo, pounded and mixed with angelica wine, Huangqi, and salt water, stir-fried together. Also include one and a half taels each of licorice and white peony, stir-fried Zaojiao thorn, honeysuckle, tianhuafen, and use cooked earthy substances in their raw form. Mix with wine in a porcelain vessel and steam for half a day, using one tael of each ingredient. Use five tea cups of alcohol without ash, mix with five taels of medicine, place in the porcelain vessel, seal the mouth with thick paper and then with oiled paper, boil in a water bath, covered, until the medicine's aroma arises. Take out and divide into doses until the sores heal.

Secret Formula for Drawing Out Poison Powder
This treats all kinds of abscesses and swelling toxins, and its effects cannot be fully described. Use one qian of frankincense, myrrh, and pangolin shell, along with angelica, wood turtle seeds, and forsythia, as well as (herb) Luo fruit at eight qian, five fen of roasted licorice, seven fen each of stir-fried Zaojiao and fritillary bulbs, and one and a half qian of both raw and cooked rhubarb, and two qian of honeysuckle vine. Prepare one dose, using one cup each of wine and water, and boil until reduced to one cup, to be taken before meals.[394p]
Guiqi Decoction: Treats abscesses without heads, but with swelling and pain.
Ingredients: Astragalus, Angelica, (Herb) Sour Jujube Seed, Soapberry Thorn, Honeysuckle, Licorice, each 1 qian. Prepare by grinding the above ingredients, add 1.5 sheng of water, boil down to 8 fen, strain, then add myrrh wine and boil again to take.

Rongwei Returning Spirit Decoction: Also known as Tongshun Powder or Heshoubird Powder.
Ingredients: Fo-ti (not to be combined with iron), Angelica, peeled and pointed Mu Tong, stir-fried Red Peony, fire-free White Atractylodes, stir-fried Fennel, stir-fried Earth Cyperus, Licorice, stir-fried Chen Citrus Peel. If nauseous, add fried ginger juice. The formula consists of these nine ingredients, each in equal parts, using water or wine based on the condition; a mixture of both is also acceptable. For flow issues, add Duhuo. Take 4 qian before meals if the condition is in the upper body, and after meals if in the lower body.

Dragon-Tiger Intermingled Powder: Treats back pain, abscesses, headaches, and facial hair issues, as well as symptoms of brain deficiency and wind dampness.
Ingredients: Southern Wood Fragrance, crushed and dried, ground into fine powder; Poppy Shell, removing the top and fiber, dried, ground into fine powder; Licorice, wrapped in damp paper, baked and ground into fine powder; Wu Atractylodes wrapped and baked, ground into fine powder; Chuanxiong wrapped in damp paper, baked and ground into fine powder.[395p]
The above-mentioned powdered medicines should be packaged separately for use according to the condition of the wounds.

For initial cases of sores such as furunculosis or carbuncles, as well as all types of swellings and toxins, and for treating the effects of exogenous pathogens:

  • Cang'er grass root
  • Tu'er grass root
  • Jin yin teng (Silver vine) flowers can also be used
  • Five-flavored fruit root

Each ingredient should be of equal parts. The above should be ground and taken in a dosage of five qian, mixed with two cups of raw white wine, and boiled down to seven parts. Strain and consume the liquid while warm, taking care to extract any residual juice. The residue can be reboiled.

For treating all types of boils and abscesses, regardless of whether they are on the back or shoulder and cause pain, this formula proves highly effective:

  • Jing Jie (Schizonepeta)
  • Mint
  • Mountain centipede
  • Old man's beard
  • Tian hua fen (Trichosanthes root)
  • Mushroom slices
  • Mushroom seeds
  • Withered lotus heart
  • Chuan Bai Zhi (Angelica)
  • Red peony
  • Pig's teeth soap pod cut and stir-fried, in equal parts.

Use one large Huai Wu for decoction, double the quantity of red inner powder, and add each fifteen wen of licorice, with an additional one if desired for sweetness.

This mixture should be ground into powder, with an intake of two qian mixed in mint tea for clarity. If a quick effect is desired, consume with wine. If no results are seen after several days, it is likely that the cold medicine is obstructing the blood flow; Alternately, you may add ingredients like Dang Gui (Chinese angelica) and Qiang Huo (Notopterygium). If there is excessive heat, use realgar mixed with wine. For breast abscesses, add Xuan Cao root juice for mixing. The remainder can be consumed with either wine or a soup made by decocting Mai Men Dong (Ophiopogon) after removing the core, though this is a slower remedy.[396p]
　　To prepare soldiers, first use this medicine to relieve thirst and heat, and reduce fever. Use it with Shengma and Gancao Decoction to disperse before taking this.

Ingredients include:

  • Mutong
  • Qumai
  • Jingjie
  • Bohe
  • Baizhi
  • Tianhuafen
  • Gancao
  • Chishaoyao
  • Maidong (with heart removed)
  • Shenggandi
  • Shanzhizi
  • Cheqianzi
  • Lianqiao, all in equal parts.

Grind these together, taking 2 qian each time, decocted with Dongxin Shenggandi and a light bamboo leaf decoction, served warm. Take before meals for upper abdomen and on an empty stomach for lower abdomen. For elderly patients with qi deficiency, add Danggui and Qianghuo.

Add-on special Ten Miracles Powder is for internal protection, treating both formed and unformed abscesses. If taking internal medicine for three to five days does not yield results, or for those over forty with weakened qi and blood, if abscesses have formed, hasten their eruption; if not, promote dispersal until the wound closes. This supports the internal organs and generates new elements, also known as Gu Lei Yuan Shuai.

Ingredients include:

  • Danggui (soaked in wine)
  • Guixin (unburned)
  • Renshen
  • Tuxiong
  • Jiegeng
  • Xiangbaizhi
  • Fangfeng (with the reed removed)
  • Houpo (with coarse skin removed, stir-fried with ginger juice)
  • Gancao (five wen each)

Other items:

  • Ruxiang
  • Mo Yao, ground separately and each in equal parts.

Grind the ingredients into a powder, take 2 qian each time mixed with wine, three times a day until recovery. For those who cannot drink alcohol, use Maidong (heart removed) decoction or Muxiang decoction.[397p]
Pigweed Powder
Effective for treating abscesses, back rashes, and all types of boils and toxins. Pigweed has leaves as long as an ox's tongue and smells like pig odor. Small thistle root, five-clawed dragon (which refers to five vines), and garlic should be used. Mix these four ingredients in equal parts, grind finely, then mix with wine to the proper consistency, strain out the residue, and take one bowl. This should induce sweating throughout the body and lead to recovery.

Surrounding Medicine
Fried gallnut, one tael; tian nanxing,草乌头 (Aconitum), huangbai (phellodendron), and baiji (bletilla) each two taels. Grind these into a fine powder, mix with water to form a paste, and apply it around the affected area like a wall to prevent further spreading. It can be shifted from dangerous areas to safer ones, working effectively.

Topical Medicine
Bailian (白蔹), baizhi (白芷), tian nanxing, baiji, and mother-of-pearl (贝母) in equal parts. Grind these into a powder, mix with water for external application. Use the surrounding medicine to secure the area and the topical medicine to elevate it, ensuring proper treatment.

General's Iron Ring Ointment
Treats various severe toxic sores that are red and swollen. Apply the medicine as a ring around the sore to prevent spreading and curb toxic gases. Salt frost white plum, tian nanxing, da huang (rhubarb), and cang'er gen (Xanthium) each one tael; baiji, bailian, fangfeng (saposhnikovia), and chuan wutou (Aconitum) each half tael; and cǎo wū tóu (Aconitum) and xiong huang (realgar) each three qian. Grind these into a powder, first crushing cang'er gen and frost plum, then mixing in the remaining ingredients to form a paste. With vinegar, adjust to the right consistency and apply the medicine around the sore to create an iron-like ring. Gently dab with a chicken feather dipped in water on the raised areas of the sore, changing two to three times daily for excellent results.
Another formula for treating all abscesses and swollen toxins.[398p]
Grass and herbal medicine such as Aconitum, Fritillaria, Trichosanthes, Nante, and Hibiscus leaves are evenly divided. The above should be ground into a fine powder, mixed with vinegar and applied around the area, leaving the head out to expel toxins. If dry, moisten with vinegar.

For the Zheng Tiehu (Proper Iron Hoop) Powder:
Remove the heart from Fritillaria, add Bai Zhi, and Cang Er grass ash mixed with vinegar and dried, each two taels. Adding two qian of dragon bone is especially effective. The above is ground into a fine powder, mixed with water or scented oil, to be applied to sores.

For the Da Tiehu (Great Iron Hoop) Powder:
Use four taels each of Hibiscus, pig skin, and Semen Jangana; two taels each of Bai Zhi, Huangbo, Han Shui Stone, red beans, white lily, and Fritillaria; one tael each of Da Huang, Zijing Pi, Bai Ji, true earth green, and Qiang Hu (Remotest active herb), removing the bulrush. Use half a tael of Fang Feng. The above is ground into a powder and mixed with cool water to encircle the abscess. If the meat is tender, remove Bai Ji and Bai Lian, adding fresh Di Huang and Di Yu, applying with banana oil. For severe heat, use the San Xiao Powder.[399p]
Water Yellow Powder: For surrounding swelling and toxin.
Ingredients: Rhinoceros horn powder, rhubarb, white atractylodes, leadwort, white vine, musk, and (stone salt) each in equal parts. Prepare into a fine powder, mix with honey and vinegar, spread thinly on oiled paper, let it dry slightly, peel off, then add moisture again, and apply to the area for immediate reduction.

External Toxic Application: Treats various swellings and hardened toxins.
Ingredients: Clematis, kudzu root, mouse glue, earth root bark, honeysuckle, yellow flowered dandelion, and licorice, each in equal parts. Prepare into coarse powder, and for each use, take 5 to 7 qian, add one liter of water, boil until it emits ten bubbles, apply heat to the surrounding swollen area, and warm again if it cools down.

Surrounding Swelling Formula:
Ingredients: Aconite, white atractylodes, white vine, yellow bracken, and (stone salt), each in equal parts. Prepare into powder, mix with honey and vinegar for external application around the swelling, which should quickly contract.

Divine White Ointment: Used for five unopened blisters.
Ingredients: Nanjing star, rhubarb, aconite, and white vine, each half a liang; clam powder, cedar bark, and red adzuki bean, each one liang. Prepare into powder, use the head of the banana to extract oil, and mix with the corners. Adding milk resin enhances the effect.

Xionghuang Powder: For treating carbuncles with purple halos, and persistent pain.
Ingredients: Millet powder, three liang, stir-fried; aconite head, Nanjing star, rock stone, and lily, each one liang; white atractylodes, two liang; frankincense, myrrh, xionghuang, and yellow lead, each half a liang. Prepare into a very fine powder, mix with warm water for application.[400p]
Iron Well Barrier: Treats unnamed swellings and toxins, or boils and abscesses. Collect hibiscus leaves before the Double Ninth Festival, grind into powder. Collect common cocklebur before the Dragon Boat Festival, burn to ash for efficacy. Mix both finely and apply with honey water.

Birdcage Ointment: Also known as Black Gold Powder. Treats all types of swellings, toxins, and boils, reduces redness. Use the shellless seeds of the mumpod (two taels), pinellia (two taels), small powder (four taels), and five-leaved akebia (half a tael). Roast in an iron pan over low heat until burnt to fine powder, then remove the heat toxin and grind again. Adjust thickness with water and apply to sores, leaving the center exposed to release toxic gas. Vinegar can also be used for mixing.

Radiating Toxicity Powder: Initially applied or used after cauterization to reduce swelling and redness. Use three taels of wasp nest, fried until charred; half a tael each of nanchang star, red adzuki bean; one handful of millet; two and a half qian of freshly rooted five-leaved akebia; half a qian of fresh white alum. Grind into fine powder, mix with light vinegar and apply around the area; reapply once dried.

Detoxifying Powder: Commonly used for boils and swellings, effective for dispersing and causing them to rupture. Use one tael of high-grade white nanchang star, half a tael each of five-leaved akebia and white angelica, and one mumpod seed, ground. Grind into fine powder, divide into two applications, mix vinegar with honey to adjust for application, and cover with gauze.[401p]
Detoxifying Powder: Treats carbuncles and boils. If not yet formed, it disperses; if formed, it promotes ulceration and expels pus.

Ingredients:

  • 1 tael Tian Nan Xing
  • 7.5 qian Bei Mu
  • Bai Zhi
  • Chi Xiao Dou
  • Zhi Jiang Can (fried), each 0.5 tael
  • 2 qian Xiong Huang

Grind into a fine powder. Initially apply mixed with vinegar, and later with honeyed water.

Retreating Poison Powder: Commonly used for boils and swellings.

Ingredients:

  • Oil-free Mu Bie Zi
  • Tian Nan Xing
  • Ban Xia Sheng
  • Chi Xiao Dou
  • Bai Zhi
  • Cao Wu (with skin tip), all in equal parts.

Grind into a fine powder. If hard, mix with vinegar for application; if hot, use honeyed water.

Miraculous Paste Powder: Applied to carbuncles and boils on the perimeter to transform purulent blood into fluid, drawing toxins inward.

Ingredients:

  • Round white Da Nan Xing
  • 4 qian Ricinus Communis seeds
  • Ban Xia Sheng
  • Bai Zhi tips
  • Wu Bei Zi
  • Jiang Huang
  • Bei Mu
  • Bai Ji, each 3 qian
  • Myrrh, Frankincense, each 2 qian
  • Hua Rui Shi powder, two pastes.

Grind into a fine powder, mix with well water, and then add honey for application. If the sore is dark, apply ginger juice. Spread from the edge of the mise to the interior, leaving a central area the size of a coin for the plaster. If the sore opens widely, apply all with gauze, using two pieces of white bamboo leaves cut to fit the sore shape to cover the medicine, then apply on the sore. Over the years, old bamboo leaves may also be used. Bamboo leaves are also soaked with water to help the medicine. When applying, ensure the powder is finely ground to avoid pain.[402p]
Special Efficacy Ten Thousand Spirits Powder treats carbuncles, boils, and swelling poisons, with miraculous effects.

Soft gypsum, burnt until red hot, is covered in a bowl and placed on the muddy ground for one night.

Big white southern star, red lentils, and the skin of Aconitum, each half a tael; two qian of frankincense, ground separately.

These are made into a fine powder, mixed with honey water to form a paste, applied externally while avoiding the highest part as much as possible. If the sore is already open, do not let the medicine enter the sore to avoid pain. It will draw out toxins and pus, preventing ulceration, proving effective many times.

Another formula for treating cold carbuncles that are green and hard, those without heads, and toxic sores.

Fresh iron rust and light powder, each two qian; white resin, one tael and five qian; a little musk. First, grind the iron rust and resin into a fine powder, place it in a pan, add one tael of sesame oil, and simmer on low heat until it boils several times. Remove from heat and let it cool slightly, then stir in the light powder and musk powder until evenly mixed, which creates the paste. Store it. Adjust the amount of paste according to the size of the sore and apply it to the affected area.

Method of extracting pus through the skin to treat various types of swelling poisons.

Finely chop and fry donkey hoof nails, and buckwheat flour, each one tael; half a tael of white salt; four qian of peeled Aconitum.

Grind these into a powder, mix with water to make a cake, and toast it over low heat until it turns yellow. Extract the fire toxin, grind it with rice vinegar to form a paste, and apply it with white paper to the affected area, allowing the poison to exit through the skin's pores, resulting in the swelling retreating.[403p]
Xionghuang Powder treats carbuncles that are red, swollen, and painful without purulent discharge; applying it will induce suppuration. The ingredients include: 7.5 grams each of Xionghuang (realgar), Huangbó (berberine), Bīngláng (betel nut), Chuan Dà Huáng (Rhizoma Rhei of Sichuan), and Xuejue (dragon's blood), 1 gram of ground musk, 50 grams of Huanglián (coptis), 25 grams each of Báizhǐ (angelica) and Mùxiāng (costus), and 25 grams each of Qiūxiān (szechuan lovage) and Guìxīn (cinnamon bark), with 30 grams of fried Dāngguī (angelica). Mix into a fine powder, blend with lard from a pig, and apply to silk fabric, placing it on the swollen area. After pus forms, use a poultice to promote healing.

Wànyìng Zhēntóuwán (Universal Needle Head Pill) treats severe brain and back carbuncles or deadly sores; one pill can cure. The ingredients include: 6 grams of musk, used in solid form of Xuejue, not powdered; 3 grams each of Qingfěn (light powder), Chánzhū (toad venom), and Nàoshā (arsenic); 3 grams of Pǐan nǎo (slice of brain), 2 paired centipedes, all ground into a very fine powder, mixed with honey to form pills.
