    For treating back sores: Mix equal parts of pigweed, five-leaf grass (also known as five-claw dragon), wild safflower (small thistle), and garlic. Crush them and mix into a bowl of hot wine, squeeze out the juice and drink; sweating will produce immediate results.

For swollen toxic sores: Collect pigweed on the Dragon Boat Festival, dry it quickly into powder. Take half a tael with hot wine, and sweating will lead to recovery, very effective.

For carbuncles and necrotic flesh: Use equal parts of white charcoal skin and white reed ash, boil into a paste and apply it to erode the necrotic tissue. Cover with fresh meat paste to also remove dark spots. This remedy should only be used for ten days; otherwise, it will lose effectiveness.

For carbuncles and pustules: Take three jin of yellow root (Rehmannia), boil with a dou of water to extract three sheng, then mash and apply. Alternatively, strain and boil down to a thick paste, apply to paper and stick it on, changing it three times a day.

For already ruptured boils: Slightly scrape off the skin of the root of ox knee, insert it into the sore with half an inch left outside. Crush a handful each of tender tangerine leaves and ground ivy, applying them on top. Ox knee can remove bad blood, and both herbs soothe pain with their warming properties. Change as necessary for significant effects.

For malignant sores: If a dark spot suddenly appears in the flesh, as large as a bean or a small plum, it can be red, black, white, or green, with a core having deep roots. It can rot muscles and bones, and if the poison enters the internal organs, it can be deadly. However, drinking juice from sunflower roots can relieve the heat toxin.[503p]

  • For boils without heads: After three days, take 100 grains of sunflower seeds and swallow them with water; they will open that very day. Some say swallowing just one grain will cause it to burst; if two grains are swallowed, there will be two heads. Another method is to grind sunflower seeds into powder and apply it with water.

  • For intestinal and stomach boils: Use Huai Zhong Dan, which treats internal boils with stagnant blood and foul odor, accompanied by cold pain in the navel and abdomen; this will expel pus and blood. Take one or two taels of single-leaf red okra root and white angelica, and five qian each of white alum and white peony, grind them into powder, mix with melted yellow wax, and form pills the size of a jujube. Take twenty pills with empty rice water, and once pus and blood are completely expelled, follow up with ten Xuan San for nourishment.

  • For unbearable sores and painful swellings: Mash okra roots without the black skin, mix with well water to create a thick paste and apply it.

  • For boils and carbuncles: Use yellow okra flowers mixed with salt, store in a ceramic container, sealed tightly, and it will not spoil for years; apply as needed for self-healing or to aid drainage. If there are no flowers, the roots and leaves can also be used.

  • For the initial onset of boils: Grind 77 grains of yellow okra seeds and half a pod of soapberry into powder, mix with quicklime and vinegar to apply.

  • For boils without heads: Mash and apply the stems and leaves of dragon eggplant.[504p]
    For boils and sores that have developed on the back: take one tael of dragon nightshade, add one-fiftieth of musk, grind together and apply, which is effective.
    For all types of boils and foul sores: use one toad, mash it together with the stalks and leaves of old crow's-eye grass, apply the mixture, and it will disperse the condition, with remarkable efficacy. If toad is not available,
    For carbuncles and toxic sores that are black and swollen, it indicates poison from cinnabar; if red, it is from flesh. Take one handful of dragon nightshade root, wash and slice it, mix with three taels of myrrh powder and sixty pieces of almonds, pound into a cake thick as three cents, apply according to the size of the sore, and change when it itches. If the itch is intolerable, do not scratch; wait until the sore feels like it has small seeds within, then remove the cake. Wash frequently with licorice decoction, and after washing, apply beeswax. Never eat sheep's blood for life. If there is no dragon nightshade, use turnip root instead.
    For fish vent sores: ash from the herb qu mai, mixed with oil, is very good for application.
    For the initial onset of carbuncles: grind the seeds of Wang bu liu xing into powder, roll them into balls the size of millet, take one ball with wine, and sweating will lead to recovery.
    For boils that are unbearably painful: use dragon tooth grass, also known as horsewhip grass, extract the juice and drink it, using the residue to apply to the affected area.
    For carbuncles that swell foully: gather dry water lily grass on the fifth day of the fifth month, dry it in the shade, and expose it overnight; when ill, chew one leaf and apply it, protecting with disinfectant ointment. In two to three days, the carbuncle will be expelled.[505p]
    Boils and Sores: One liter each of Forsythia grass and root, six liters of water, boil down to three liters of juice to be taken, inducing sweat. [From "Essentials of External Treatment"]

For boils and necrotic flesh that do not dissipate: Ash from wild candytuft and lime, extract the juice, combine and boil into a paste to apply, which can erode the necrotic flesh. It also removes blemishes. This medicine is ineffective after ten days. [From "Prescriptions of a Thousand Gold"]

For painful and itchy ulcers: Pound bamboo grass and apply, the scabs will fall off and it will heal. [From "Formulas for Later Use"]

For all abscesses and swellings: One liter of burdock seeds, pound and mix with vinegar, apply to the root of the boil. [From "Essentials of External Treatment"]

For various sores and swellings: Wash three inches of burdock vine, boil with five liters of water to yield two liters, remove the residue and place in a copper vessel; also boil to yield one liter, reduce until syrupy, to apply to the affected area. [From "Prescriptions of a Thousand Gold"]

For all boils and sores, intestinal abscesses, and breast abscesses, whether red and swollen but not broken or already broken but not discharging pus and blood, and still experiencing fever and pain allowing for food intake, should expel pus through a tonic. Use equal parts of centipede, red peony, angelica, and licorice, ground into powder, take two qian with warm wine. [From "Formulas of the Bureau of Harmonious Remedies"]

For boils and sores: Pound together roots of purple flower ground ivy and equal parts of cocklebur leaves, mix with wine and extract the juice to apply. [From "Experiential Formulas"][506p]

  • For carbuncles on the back and various unnamed swellings: Collect purple flowering ground ivy during the hottest part of summer, mix it with white flour, and soak it in salt and vinegar overnight before applying it. In the past, there was a nun who suffered from a carbuncle on her back, and she dreamt of this remedy; she recovered within a few days.

  • For all kinds of sores: Dry the root of purple flowering ground ivy daily, burn it in a jar, and use the smoke to fumigate the sore, drawing out yellow pus until it is completely gone.

  • For boils and poisonous swellings: Crush purple flowering ground ivy to extract its juice and ingest it; it is effective even in critical cases. Another remedy involves mixing scallions with raw honey and crushing them together for application. If it’s a tumor, add fresh black cow dung.

  • At the onset of swelling and toxin: Grind equal parts of rhubarb, gallnut, and goldenseal into a powder, mix with fresh spring water, and apply daily four to five times.

  • For painful, inflamed carbuncles: Mix powdered rhubarb with vinegar for application; change it as it dries. After a few applications, it will recede—this is very effective, a miraculous remedy!

  • For all types of toxic swellings: Crush the root of ophiopogon and mix with a little salt for application, changing it three times a day.

  • For hard stone-like carbuncles that do not suppurate: Use fresh ophiopogon root to rub the area, changing it as it dries, and stop when it becomes soft. This also treats damp, leaking sores.

  • For sores caused by water toxicity: Crush ophiopogon, roast it, and wrap it in cooked cloth for application; change it when it cools.

  • For pain from chronic ulcers: Use one tael of (herb) and mix it into powder, taking two qian with warm water.[507p]
    When a stone abscess is hard and does not form pus: grind the seeds of the stramonium to a powder, mix with vinegar and apply to the sore, then the root will be pulled out.

For tumors and toxic swellings: take one tael each of fried Aconitum and fried Berberis, grind to a powder, mix with saliva and apply, leaving the head; when dry, moisten with rice wash.

For protruding flesh from abscesses: take five pieces of Aconitum, soak in three sheng of strong vinegar for five days, wash, and apply three to four times a day.

For painful sores: mix vinegar with powdered Aconitum and apply, reapply when dry.

At the first sign of abscess: take three pieces each of grass Aconitum and Sichuan Aconitum, nine almonds, and one tael of sifted flour, grind into a powder; mix with water and apply, cover with paper, and keep moist until it dries.

For swollen and painful abscesses: slice fresh Aconitum and boil in vinegar to make a paste, apply, and the root will come out the next day. Another method: take one tael of pointed Aconitum and four mashed hemp seeds to apply, and the abscess will pull out itself.

For abscesses appearing on the back: peel the grass Aconitum and grind into a powder, then mix with the white part of spring onion, rolling into pea-sized pills coated with realgar; take one pill each time, first chew a spring onion finely and wash it down with hot wine. If there's nausea and vomiting, take a sip of cold water afterward. Then keep covered with a thick blanket until sweating, which also treats head wind.[508p]
Malignant sores, as well as back boils, ulcers, and similar conditions: Use a mixture of black nightshade and Chuanwu (a type of aconite) to grind on a tile, then apply with well water; if there’s an opening, apply around the edges, and when dry, apply again. Alternatively, one may grind black nightshade alone and apply with vinegar.

For the early stage of boils: Mix powdered snow herb with胶 (a type of gum) and apply.

For already ruptured boils: Take the root peel of snow herb, twist it into a plug, and insert it, so the opening doesn’t close, which allows the pus to drain easily.

For unruptured boils: Take one ounce of the herb of the reed, grind it into powder, mix it with egg white, and apply it on silk cloth to stick on. Change it twice a day, and take pain as a positive sign.

In the early stage of boils: Use the root of bitter vine, boil it in bitter wine until dry, then grind and sieve it. Mix with bitter wine and apply on paper to stick.

For various types of boils and swellings: Freshly dug Asparagus tubers, three to five liang, wash clean, then pound finely in a sand basin, filter out the juice with good wine for instant consumption; if there is no effect, take again, and it will surely cure.

For toxin boils and sores: Use red fleeceflower root in any quantity, boil it with a mixture of good wine over a gentle fire until approaching doneness; add an equal amount of good wine without ash, boil a few more times, and drink regularly. The residue should be roasted and ground into powder; mix with wine to make dough balls the size of a walnut. Take thirty balls with warm wine. If symptoms improve, it is advisable to take regularly.[509p]

  • For the initial onset of carbuncles: apply a mixture of water and powdered white reed.
  • For all abscesses: mix two parts white reed and one part rhubarb into a powder, then mix with wine and apply three times a day.
  • For ulcers that do not heal: use three qian each of white reed, red reed, and barberry, stir-fried and ground, add one qian of light powder, and wash with scallion juice for application.
  • For abscesses that do not disperse: pound fresh white medicine root for application; if it dries, replace it; if not fresh, grind into powder and mix with water for application.
  • For all initial abscesses, regardless of location: use forty-nine pieces of wood lily, remove the hairs, grind finely and dissolve, take warm. Its efficacy is comparable to that of honeysuckle.
  • For black, recessed carbuncles: use a hair tie to secure it, pound the juice from pointed leaf vine and mix with honey to take, while applying a mixture of scallions and honey around the area.
  • For all swellings and toxins, whether ruptured or not, or at initial onset with fever: use honeysuckle, known as sweet vine, collect flowers along with stems and leaves, extract half a bowl of natural juice, boil down to eight parts for consumption, and apply the residue, alleviating toxins, dispersing qi and harmonizing blood, which is uniquely effective. The prescriptions for carbuncles, dysentery, throat obstruction, and mastitis are similar.[510p]
    For treating swellings and removing toxins: Take large quantities of Jinjinteng (a medicinal vine), burn it for preservation; and dry the leaves to make a powder, each three qian (a weight unit). Use four qian of roasted Dahuang (rhubarb) grounded into powder. For initial swelling and toxins, mix with water or wine to apply around the area, staying mindful to relieve excess heat.

For carbuncles and boils on the back: Crush fresh calamus and apply it. If the sore is dry, grind it into powder and mix with water to apply.

For initial swelling and toxins: Crush duckweed and apply it.

For all types of carbuncles and boils: Horsetail (equally known as water plantain), use stems in spring and summer; in winter, use the seeds. Locate near the roots, crush and apply it; if not fully formed, it will dissipate, if fully formed, it will disperse the toxins. Using the plant as food is also acceptable.

For various boils: Horsetail is also known as Queue Pan Cao, Da Qing Ye (great blue leaf), or Stinky Purple Grass. Take equal parts, grind them, soak in a bowl of wine, remove the dregs and drink warm; after three servings, one will be healed.

For heat-related swellings and dan (toxic) boils: Just take algae from the canal, chop and crush it to apply, up to three fen (a smaller weight unit) thick, and replace when dry. It is exceptionally effective.

For heat toxins and dan sores: Per “Qian Jin Fang,” use Shenhuo Grass to extract juice and wipe it; wipe day and night for ten to twenty times. Another method is to mix with bitter wine to make a paste and apply; replace when dry.[511p]
All swellings and toxins: Take a handful of wild coriander, burn a pangolin to retain seven parts, three qian of angelica root, crush it, mix with a bowl of wine and extract the juice to take, using the residue as a poultice.

For sores and ulcers: Apply blood gall of thorny bones, pounded into paste, to draw them out.

For initial swellings and toxins: Use equal parts of透骨草 (bone penetrating herb),漏芦 (skullcap), 防风 (windbreak), and 地榆 (sorrel), boiled together as a decoction, dip cotton in and apply it hot repeatedly; in two to three days, it will dissolve.

To treat boils similar to cherries: Use the root of Buddha’s hand flower mixed with ginger and honey to create a juice to drink, while applying the leaves of the celestial nightshade externally.

For boils and sores: Grind sesame ash and needle sand in equal parts into powder, mix with vinegar and apply thrice daily.

For stubborn boils: Use black sesame roasted and pounded into a paste to apply.

For the initial onset of furuncles: Take one jin of sesame oil, boil it in a silver container until bubbling, mix in three bowls of fermented vinegar, and consume it in five doses within one day.

For initial swellings and toxins: Fry green onions in sesame oil until blackened, then apply warm for gradual absorption.

For sores with worms: Apply raw sesame oil residue and cover with cotton; this will draw out any worms.

For all boils and swellings: Mix flour with pig fat to seal over it, which is effective.[512p]

  • For carbuncles and all swellings or toxins: Powder two taels each of buckwheat flour and sulfur, mix with well water to make a paste, dry it in the sun. When using, take one piece, grind it with water and apply it. If it hurts, it will relieve pain; if there is no pain, it will cause pain, and then it will heal.

  • For black and depressed sore heads: Cook buckwheat flour and consume it to promote healing.

  • For red-rooted abscesses: Cook white powder until black, then mix with honey and apply it.

  • For carbuncles on the back: Cook millet flour until black, mix with egg white and apply it; cut a hole and stick it on. When it dries, it is easy to remove and works effectively.

  • For painful sores and swellings: Apply ground small bean flowers.

  • For swollen sores, especially if there's severe pain from wind-cold: Burn millet chaff, let the smoke induce sweating to promote healing.

  • For stone carbuncles and various abscesses: Use five cups of red beans, soak in bitter wine for five nights, fry and grind, then mix with the bitter wine and apply until it dissolves; also add equal parts of Loquat root.

  • For newly developed carbuncles: Grind red beans with water and apply; the toxin will dissipate, and frequent application is effective.

  • For carbuncles caused by sulfur ingestion: Mix vinegar with bitter soaked paste and apply; it will dry easily.

  • For all swellings or toxins: Soak with green onion juice four to five times a day.

  • For painful sores: Pierce them, crush old green onion with honey and apply; leave for a while to let the abscess form, then wash with vinegar soup for effective results.[513p]

  • For sores inflicted by lochia, which can be severe enough to be fatal: pound scallions until they are mushy, wrap them in cloth and heat them, then remove the cloth and apply; replace when cool. Alternatively, you can make a cake from it and apply moxa to it; the heat will draw out the fluids and promote healing.

  • For all foul sores: boil fermented soybeans and grind them for application; it usually takes no more than three or four applications to see results.

  • For fish belly carbuncles: applying cold food syrup is effective. For the dried form, burn it to ash.

  • For wind-heat swelling toxins: take three taels each of rapeseed seedlings' leaves and turnip roots, grind them into a powder, mix with egg white and apply to absorb the toxins. If turnip is unavailable, you can replace it with the root of the poisonous plant, which is also very effective.

  • For abscesses that have not burst: mix bitter wine with bird droppings, forming them into the size of small beans, and apply to the head of the sore to promote incision.

  • For early-stage abscess: fry one tael of dried ginger until it turns purple, grind it into powder, mix with vinegar, and apply around the area while leaving the top exposed; it can heal on its own, a miraculous remedy!

  • For severe toxic swellings, or those that connect to the groin and cause intense pain that radiates into the lower abdomen and is unbearable, potentially fatal within a night: use one sheng of fennel sprout juice and take it in three to four doses daily, applying the residue onto the swelling. In winter, use the root instead. This is an ancient foreign remedy, since the Yongjia period, known for its miraculous effects in reviving the dead.

  • For all swellings and toxins: mix eight taels of pine resin, two qian of green copper, and five qian of castor bean that has been cut, pound them together to create an ointment for application.[514p]

  • For carbuncles and abscesses: Grind two parts of horseweed and three parts of lime into powder, mix with egg white, and apply.

  • For mouth sores: Pound wild bitter herb (grass family) to extract one cup of juice, add one spoon of ginger juice, mix with wine and consume. Apply the residue one or two times for healing.

  • For fish navel sores, where the head is white like millet and causes unbearable pain: First, prick the head and surrounding area with a needle, then drop fresh lettuce juice into the hole to heal it.

  • For emergent carbuncles, whether developed or not: Use ten sections of white flower grass, decoct in wine and consume; sweating will bring recovery.

  • For painful carbuncle poison: Crush fish mint and apply it; do not remove the herb for one or two hours, and you will feel better in one or two days.

  • For carbuncles with festering swelling: Burn the leaves of wild gray herb to ash, break the sore skin, and apply a little mixed with spit, allowing blood to flow.

  • For initial swelling and poison: Mix equal parts of mud yam, castor seeds, and glutinous rice, soak in water and grind, then apply for dispersal.

  • For heat-related sore swelling: Cut away two parts from a fresh eggplant, scoop out the insides to form a vessel shape, apply it directly to the sore until it dissipates. If pus has already emerged, use again for healing.

  • For deep and unhealed sores: Frequently apply the juice of loofah.

  • For long-lasting ulcers: Boil the root of the loofah in water and use it to wash; cooling will lead to healing.[515p]
    Difficult boils: For black bull droppings on the ground, wait for mold to dry, then grind it with pigweed into a powder. Use a bamboo tube with both ends closed tightly over the boil. Mix a small amount of the powder with water, put it inside the tube, and after some time, when it starts to boil, the root should come out; if it doesn’t, repeat two or three times.

All swollen painful sores: Peel apricot kernels, grind and strain for the paste, mix with fine powder and hemp oil to apply; it is remarkably effective.

Boils and sores, whether ruptured or not: Either can utilize salt and white plum roasted into powder, mixed with a little fine powder and fragrant oil to apply around.

Sudden onset of sores, unknown to others: Use peach skin to apply to them.

All longstanding sores that do not heal: Three liters of jujube paste, boiled in water for washing to facilitate healing.

Toxic boils: Prick the surrounding areas with needles, apply pomegranate peel on the sore, surround it with flour for moxibustion according to pain tolerance, and then apply crushed pomegranate inside, binding it tightly overnight for the root to come out.

All boils, back boils, and bone attachments that have not formed pus: Ten walnuts, cooked and shelled, mix with a tael of locust flower ground into powder to combine, then consumed with hot wine.

Boils and swellings: Break one walnut flat, chew the kernel to mash it, place it back in the shell, apply on the sore, and change it frequently for notable effectiveness.[516p]
Stone abscesses are hard as stone, not producing pus: use one acorn, grind its juice with vinegar on a青stone, and apply it. When dry, it is easy to remove, usually after ten applications.

For carbuncles and swelling: use five or three lychees, avoiding even numbers, and grind them with clean rice milled in dog feces mixed with glutinous rice porridge into a paste. Apply it on paper, leaving a hole to let out the toxic gas. Another method: take three lychee meats and three white plums, pound them into a cake, and stick it on the sore, causing the root to emerge.

For painful swellings: mix ground green pepper, dirt from the stove, and buckwheat flour in equal parts, grind with vinegar, and apply.

For intestinal abscesses that have formed, with swollen lower abdomen, painful urination, or difficulty in bowel movements: take one small pouch of melon seeds, one tael of stir-fried angelica, and one strip of snake skin, chew them, and take four qian with one and a half bowls of water, boiling down to one bowl, and take it before meals for effective excretion of harmful substances.

For all swellings and toxins: dry and grind wild grape roots into powder, mix with water and apply; it will reduce the swelling.

For various abscesses, drawing out poison and alleviating pain: use the center of lotus leaves with stems resembling coins, regardless of quantity, boil to make a soup, wash with it, dry, and then apply mixed with cold stone and pig lard.

For poisonous swellings in the abdomen: take one tael each of chicken tongue grass, green wood incense, fragrant earth incense, and musk, boil with four liters of water until reduced to two liters, divided into two doses.[517p]

  • For abscesses and ulcers: Apply clove powder and protect it with a medicated plaster.

  • For poisonous abscesses: Mix equal parts of myrrh powder and frankincense powder, fumigate, and it effectively eliminates foul odors.

  • For all types of sores: Use one tael each of white resin and pitch, and two and a half qian of sesame oil and yellow wax. Melt them and pull in cold water a thousand times before applying.

  • For painful sores: Mix equal parts of frankincense and powder, wash with rice water, and apply.

  • For abscesses accompanied by chills: Take half a tael of frankincense, grind it with warm water and take it, as it acts on the spleen.

  • To close open sores: Use one character worth of blood resin powder, a small amount of musk, and half a qian of charcoal from burnt jujubes, ground together and mixed with saliva to apply.

  • For swollen and poisonous abscesses: Stir-fry golden thread bark and equal parts of processed aconite, grind into powder, and apply with saliva, while frequently moistening with rice wash.

  • To promote skin regeneration: Apply yellow thread powder mixed with flour paste.

  • For all forms of toxic swellings, regardless of hardness: Take ten layers of catalpa leaves and apply to the swelling, wrapped in old cloth, changing it three times a day. The toxic fluid will manifest on the leaves. In winter, use dried leaves soaked in salt water until soft, or pound the root bark and apply, both are effective. They relieve pain, reduce swelling, and purify pus and blood, superior to many medicines.[518p]

  • When a carbuncle appears on the back, as large as a pan and smelling foul, apply a steamed mixture of catalpa leaves and vinegar. It will reduce fever and relieve pain, gradually promote tissue regeneration, and close the wound—this is a highly effective secret formula.

  • For an initial carbuncle: light a lamp with tung oil, place it in a bamboo tube and let the smoke envelop it; once yellow pus emerges, it will dissolve.

  • For boils and carbuncles, and any type of swelling with pain, whether already formed or not, treat all painful areas: lightly fry two liang each of locust flower and walnut kernels, mix with a jar of unashamed liquor, decoct until boiling, and consume while hot. For those not yet formed, take two to three doses; for those already formed, one to two doses will be effective.

  • For bad sores and carbuncles: take the pod of the soapberry, remove the skin and char it to a powder, mix in a little musk and some human dung, and apply this mixture; the root will appear after five days.

  • For an initial boil: use seven soapberry seeds, grind them into powder and apply. Another method is to swallow a dose according to age.

  • For sores in the abdomen that cannot be treated with medicine: take a number of soapberry spines, mix them with a bowl of good wine, decoct until warm (about 70% done), and consume; all pus and blood will be expelled through urination, proving highly effective. If one does not drink alcohol, it can be boiled in water instead.

  • For a sore without a head: burn soapberry spines to ash, consume three qian with wine, and chew three to five sunflower seeds; the area will respond as if pricked by a needle.

  • For sudden onset of bad sores that cannot be identified: boil willow leaves or bark in water, add a little salt and wash the area frequently.[519p]
    All types of sores: thirty grains of castor bean, stir-fried in sesame oil until black, remove the beans, mix the oil with powdered sulfur, and apply frequently for effect.
    For carbuncles and malignant flesh, as well as all sore poisons: fry the castor bean seeds until black, grind into a paste, and apply directly to the painful area to detoxify; apply to the bruised flesh for natural resolution. Adding a small amount of frankincense is also acceptable. If the poison is deep and cannot be contained, it is advisable to form a compress to prevent pain from developing. 【"Essentials of Surgery"】
    For hard stone carbuncles that do not form pus: finely grind the white bark of the Sichuan mulberry tree that has been air-dried, melt it with glue, and mix with wine for application to soften. 【"Thousand Gold Essentials"】
    For carbuncles with open wounds that do not close: use frost-kissed yellow mulberry leaves, ground into powder for application. 【"Direct Guide Recipes"】
    For carbuncles and poisonous boils: mix equal parts of dog skull ashes and other ingredients into powder, combine with water for application. 【"Thousand Gold Essentials"】
    For unhealed sores: use equal parts of dog skull ashes with yellow lead powder for application. 【"Longevity Domain Recipes"】
    To promote flesh growth and muscle formation: fry old dog skulls and tiles for two ounces, one ounce of mulberry white bark, and two and a half qian of angelica, ground into powder, and mix with sesame oil for application. 【"Direct Guide Recipes"】
    For severe pain from carbuncles: dry and grind wall lizard into powder, mix with oil for application to relieve pain immediately. 【"Medical Recipe Summary"】
    For carbuncles that do not close properly: burn reed matting to ash, mix with pig fat from December, and apply into the opening. 【"Thousand Gold Essentials", same as above.】[520p]
    If an internal boil has not fully developed: Take the water from roasted chicken droppings, mix it well and consume it to heal.

For various kinds of foul sores: Take soil from the east wall and mix it with da huang in equal parts, powdered. Use water from the rootless well flowers to mix and apply, and reapply when dry.

For all foul sores: Take the mud and droppings from a swallow’s nest, grind finely, and mix with oil for application. Add powdered berberine.

For foul sores with swelling and toxins: Use white ant mud from pine wood, fry it with yellow lead until black, then grind and mix with fragrant oil for application.

For nameless foul sores: Take two strips of dust from the beam, a small amount of earthworms’ droppings, mix with raw honey to form a cake the size of a coin, air dry in the shade, and use honey water to frequently apply.

For all kinds of toxic sores: Use dust from the door mortar, dip garlic to scrub, and it will dissipate upon sweating.

For sores injured by moisture: Mix equal parts of starch powder and charcoal ash, and apply with grease to the puncture, and water will seep out.

For snake skin sores: Apply iron paste frequently.

For all foul sores: Use mica for application.

For toxic rotten flesh sores: There was a girl, age fourteen, with a growth like a yellow bean in the soft part of her wrist, half embedded in flesh, red-purple in color, and very painful. Various medicines were ineffective. A certain alchemist took four taels of mercury and two sheets of white paper, mixed them until soft, dipped it in mercury and rubbed her with it; after three days it fell off and healed.[521p]
For chronic wounds that do not heal over time: mix one qian of silver and vermillion, five fen of lime from a thousand years underground, five qian of pine resin, and one liang of fragrant oil into a powder, then apply it on paper to stick it on the wound.

For severe sores in Guangdong: take one and a half qian of realgar, thirty peeled apricot kernels, and one qian of light powder, grind to a powder, clean the area, and mix with the bile of a male pig. Apply this for two or three days and it will surely heal.

For long-standing severe sores: grind lime into powder, mix with the clear white of an egg to form a paste, and after calcining, grind again. Apply with ginger juice.

For various swellings and toxins: use three qian of magnetite, four liang of gold and silver vine, eight liang of yellow lead, and one jin of fragrant oil. Boil as usual to make a paste for application.

For all kinds of abscesses, lumps with no name, especially in young and strong individuals: take one he of both black and white morning glory, pack in cloth and crush, then boil it in a bowl of good vinegar until reduced to eight parts, let it rest overnight, and take it warm at dawn. It will be most effective if it brings out pus and blood with a bowel movement; this is called the Universal Rescue Powder.

For painful swollen sores and ulcers: use rose bark for additional heat and application.

For long-term severe sores: take two qian each of heartleaf and dried ginger, and five qian of medicinal mushroom; grind together into a powder for mixing.

For sores and abscesses that do not drain: mix half a liang each of safflower seeds and purple gromwell fibers, two and a half qian of cicada slough, and half of a water clock; decoct until reduced by half, adjusting dosage according to size.[522p]
The swelling and poison have broken: Roast and grind green barley without the husk into a powder, apply it, and once the scab is shed, reapply it several times until healed.

For swollen and hot poisons: Mix powdered mustard seeds with crushed cypress leaves for an application; there is no case that does not heal. Using mountain mustard is even better.

For all types of swellings: Mix pig bile with mustard seed powder and apply it three times a day. Pig fat can also be used.

For festering swellings and vile poisons: Burn Cang Er (Xanthium) weevils, grind them into powder, mix with oil, and apply—immediate effect. Alternatively, soak dead weevils in sesame oil, store them, and each time use one or two ground up for application—the poison disperses immediately with remarkable efficacy.

For all festering sores and unnamed malignant swellings: Use a single weevil from the stem of Cang Er grass, and three to four parts of white plum flesh, pound them into a paste, and apply for immediate effect. Another formula: The weevil from Cang Er grass, roast it yellow, mix equal parts of white silkworms and Jiang tea into a powder, and apply with honey.

Another method: Use forty-nine Cang Er weevils from the nodes, crush them, add a little human saliva, pound into pieces, prick the sore to break it, and shortly afterward pull out the roots, and it will heal.

If the poison from festering sores does not recede, it enters the abdomen: Use shed cicada skin, roast into powder, mix with honey-water and take one qian (a traditional weight), apply with saliva externally. Another method: Use shed cicada skin and silkworms equally powdered, mix with vinegar to apply around the sore, wait for the roots to come out, pull them out and reapply.[523p]
All malignant sores, and the water snake sores from sand fleas: On the fifth of May, take a beetle, steam it, and dry it to a powder; mix with oil and apply it.

For boils and malignant ulcers: Take the large hard-shelled insect from willow trees, or those found in fresh dung or mud piles, soak it in honey water to kill it, and then grind it into a powder from charred new tiles. First, heat a needle and pierce the sore, then apply a mixture of vinegar.

For unidentified sudden ulcers: Use the juice of dead beetles to apply on the sore.

For poisonous boils: Use a bone-penetrating ointment made from four dried star anise shell fragments from willow trees; if not available in winter, substitute with the nest. Add five parts toad venom, one seed of India manseed, a little powdered frost, realgar, and musk. First, grind the star anise into a paste, add a small amount of melted yellow wax, and mix with the other powdered herbs to make an ointment. Seal it tightly. Each time, prick the sore with a needle to draw blood, then use an elm twig to insert an ointment the size of a grain of wheat into the wound and place two pieces of bird droppings at the sore’s opening; once the wound begins to heal, stop using it. Avoid cold water. If the needle pricks without blood, it indicates a bone boil: for males, prick the left; for females, the right. If there’s no blood from the middle fingernail, prick the big toe instead; if still no blood, it is likely difficult to cure.[524p]
Abscess with root: Use a large needle to create a hole, prepare the root of a turnip as if it were the size of the needle, and insert iron cloth into the hole; then mix the turnip root and iron cloth in equal parts, crush and apply it on top. If there is pus, it will soon come out, and the root will emerge, leading to recovery. Avoid oily, cold, pungent, slippery, and stale foods.

When the heat toxin from the heavens attacks the hands and feet, causing swelling and pain: Use a whole pig's hoof, remove the hair, boil it with a bucket of water and a handful of green onion whites, then add a little salt to pickle it.

For carbuncles that do not subside, regardless of where the sore is located: Burn tortoise shell until charred, grind it into powder, and it is very effective.

For intestinal carbuncles with internal pain: Burn tortoise shell, grind it until charred, and take one penny’s worth with water, three times a day.

For an abscess that has not formed, to draw out toxins: Mix oyster powder with water and apply it, allowing it to dry and reapply.

For red swollen carbuncles: Mix rice vinegar with clam shell ash, apply it until it dries and then replace it.

For carbuncles with toxic insects: Burn deer antlers into powder, mix with bitter wine and apply it; or juice can also be used.

For bone abscesses that do not heal, with bone emerging from the hole: Dig a pit with a small opening at the top and a larger area below, three feet deep. Mix two sheng of dry chicken droppings with mugwort and safflower leaves, crush it finely, place it in the pit, and burn to produce smoke. Use the abscess opening to fumigate, covering it with cloth to prevent the escape of air; within half a day, there should be worms emerging, which is highly effective.[525p]
For all types of sores: grind fivefold gall and yellow bile together for a powder, and apply it.

For all swellings and toxic lesions: fry fivefold gall until it turns dark purple, mix with honey and apply.

For earwax: for treating boils that have not yet formed pus, sealing them will disperse them; for canker worms eating into the nose causing sores, and for snake bites, apply it.

For sores that do not heal: grind fivefold gall into a powder, mix it with waxy vinegar, and apply around the affected area.

For all boils and swellings that have not burst: use dried human feces powder and musk, each half a qian, mix them thoroughly, apply to the outside of the head with the patient's saliva, cover it with a vinegar-soaked cloth, and remove the medicine after pus has formed.

For initial eruptions of boils: scrape them open, and apply hot feces; dry and change it frequently, typically after fifteen applications, the root will emerge, leading to immediate healing.

To close a sore: use one qian of bloodstone powder, a small amount of musk, and half a qian of ash from burned jujubes, mix and apply with saliva.

To extract the root of a boil: take the webbing from a spider, mix it with vinegar, first prick the edges to draw out blood until the root is slightly exposed; apply the mixture, dry it, and within one day and night the root will be removed, yielding significant results.

For long-standing sores: apply spider silk and change it several times.

For all types of swellings and toxins, whether formed or unformed: use a piece of water-soaked gelatin, soften it, and make an opening at the top to apply; those that are less than a hundred days will disperse on their own, and those that have already burst will allow pus to be expelled.[526p]

  1. For sores and swellings caused by toxins: Take seven scorpions and seven gardenias, fry them in sesame oil until black, strain out the residue, and mix with yellow wax to form a paste for application.

  2. For carbuncles and swellings: Take soil from a latrine, cicada shells, and scorpions in equal amounts, pound into the size of coins, sauté in fragrant oil until boiling, then apply the residue around the sore; the carbuncle will erupt on its own.

  3. For carbuncles and severe swellings: Use the ashes of male dog feces, burnt on the fifth of May, and apply them, changing frequently. This method is also effective for saddle sores.

  4. For fish navel carbuncles resembling new fire needle sores, with red edges and a black center, they may be pricked; if not very painful, it could be deadly. Use ashes of fish heads from the twelfth lunar month mixed with chicken droppings for application.

  5. For carbuncles and severe swellings: Apply black cow ear wax.

  6. For undrained swellings: Burn white horse teeth to ash, first prick with a needle to drain, then seal with wet flour around the swelling, and wash it off with vinegar; this ensures the root comes out successfully.

  7. For red-root carbuncles: Pound horse teeth into powder, mix with lard from fatty pigs for application, which will draw out the root. Applying burnt ash can also yield a cure.

  8. For carbuncles caused by wind: Fry horse manure and apply it to the sore fifty times for excellent results.

  9. For carbuncles causing swelling and pain from wind: Fry donkey manure and apply to the sore fifty times for excellent results.[527p]

  • When swelling and toxin first appear: Burn and grind one piece of turtle shell, take four qian with wine.

  • For carbuncles and severe swelling: Use field snails and dissolve with borneol in water, apply to the sore.

  • For toxic sores on fingers and toes: Use one live field snail, crush it, and apply it to the area to heal.

  • For carbuncles and severe swelling: Dry pig gall from December, mix with fresh scallions, and pound to apply.

  • To draw out carbuncle pus: Use toad venom formed into pills the size of a walnut, place one under the tongue, and the pus will emerge.

  • To draw out carbuncle toxins: Use toad venom mixed with white flour and yellow orpiment to make pills the size of millet. Insert a pill gently into the sore with fingers; if severe, pierce it and apply a clear ointment made with water.

  • For severe carbuncles and swellings: Take one qian of toad venom, four cow beans, pound into rice-sized pills, take one with ginger soup; after a while, pound the roots of plantain and yellow jujube, take with half a bowl of wine, and take several times, supplemented with congee.

  • For all sores and toxins: Take one qian of toad venom, two qian of white flour, a small amount of cinnabar, mix with well water to form pills the size of wheat grains, take one with well water. If the sore condition is urgent, take five to seven pills, ginger soup is also effective, and sweating will lead to recovery.

  • For abscesses inside the intestines: Burn the feathers from a rooster's crown mixed with feces, take with hollow alcohol.[528p]

  • For abscesses, substitute needles: Burn the first hair on both sides of a white chicken's wing to ash, then take with water to break it.

  • For the initial swelling of abscesses and ulcers: Grind together angelica, yellow barberry bark, and notopterygium into a fine powder; use the juice of the heron’s knee mixed to apply around the wound. Naturally the poison will gather and form a small head to break; do not apply directly on the sore, to avoid spreading the toxins.

  • For abscesses that are hard and stubborn: Use a sharp knife to make a cross incision at the affected area, then mix flour with water to a thick consistency, raising the edges of the wound by about half an inch, akin to a pond. Fill halfway with phoenix tears, then drip good rice vinegar on top. It will boil briefly; do not let it overflow. The next day, rinse with a decoction of honeysuckle, and repeat as before, washing with vinegar only, painlessly, letting rotten flesh fall away.

  • For boils and abscesses: Puncture the boil’s head with a needle or knife, apply toad venom, and afterwards crush wild chrysanthemum, bulrush roots, and beet leaves finely, mixing with ash-free wine to take as needed. As the wine wears off, the boil will drain, alleviating pain. If the heat subsides, it is not necessary to remove the boil; it will heal on its own.

  • For abscesses causing vomiting: Brew and drink a strong decoction made from the head of a Daoist.

  • For the poison from abscesses entering the abdomen, leading to drowsiness and loss of appetite: Use one tael each of purple-flowered ground ivy, cicada slough, and guanzhong, along with two qian of cloves, ground into powder. Take two qian with warm wine on an empty stomach.[529p]
    Surgical Abscesses and Sores Doctrine

Acupuncture

The "Su Wen" states: When the energy of the abscess is stagnant, it should be removed with needles. When the energy is strong and the blood is congested, it should be drained using stones. In the eastern regions, the people eat fish and salty food, leading to abscess-related diseases, which should be treated with stone therapy. When the abscess has no definitive location, palpation does not yield results; it appears and disappears unpredictably. One should puncture the area next to the Taiyin point and the two points of the Jingmai. The "Lingshu" says: In acupuncture, if one does not penetrate properly, essence may leak; if one punctures incorrectly, it may lead to energy stagnation. Essence leakage results in worsening conditions and distress, while energy stagnation leads to the formation of abscesses. When treating the evil of abscesses, do not confront it head-on; it can easily change nature. If pus forms, the path may collapse, unsettling the area, leading to dispersion. For any excesses of yin and yang causing abscesses, one should focus on draining them. A fine needle should be as sharp as a sword's edge to draw out substantial pus.

The onset of illness is often unpredictable, influenced by emotions like joy and anger, irregular eating habits, insufficient yin energy, excessive yang energy, and stagnant nutrients, which lead to abscess formation. When yin and yang are blocked, and two heats clash, they turn into pus. Can a small needle extract it? Qi Bo said: To treat small issues with small methods yields little effect; treating larger issues with large methods often brings more harm. Therefore, once pus and blood have formed, only stone therapy and fine needles can draw them out. The "Jia Yi Jing" states: A swelling in the neck makes it hard to look up or down; cheek swelling can pull the ear, treat it with the governing bone point. For a swollen throat that makes speech difficult, treat it with the Tian Zhu point.[530p]
Swelling of the lips and sores, governed by the Yangbai point.
Swelling and pain in the cheeks, governed by the Tianchuang point.
Swelling of the head and neck that inhibits speech, governed by the Tianrong point.
Swelling of the body, governed by the Guanmen point.
Fullness and pain beneath the chest, with swelling of the breasts, governed by the Rugen point.[531p]
Swelling in the face and eye abscess, needling the valley point to induce bleeding immediately.
If the nose of the ox is swollen, one can needle the top; do not attack it hard, as doing so would lead to death. For sores, the Yin orifice governs it.
When the pulse of wind becomes severe, it indicates a severe sore; the Yin orifice governs it. For the severe sore, Shangqiu governs it.
The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: when the abscess or sore begins to form, there may be great pain or slight pain, or it may emerge like a grain of rice; one should quickly cut the mouth to eliminate its poison, using the bamboo horse moxibustion technique. However, there is no record of this moxibustion method in "Thousand Gold"; the earliest documentation is in the "Emergency Moxibustion Method" authored by the renowned person Wen Renqiannian during the Song Dynasty, which includes a special section on bamboo horse moxibustion. One can also burn moxa directly on the affected area, and for more severe cases, moxibustion should be done all around the center, at least one or two hundred strong burns, and then apply medicine, which is very effective.
The bamboo horse moxibustion method can cure all types of sores and ulcers without exception. Have the patient lean on a table with their elbow, straightening the wrist; use a strip of slender bamboo, measuring from the bend at the wrist to the tip of the middle finger, cutting off the excess and not measuring the fingernail. Then, take a bamboo pole, have the patient undress, and sit firmly on it, with two people lifting them off the ground, ensuring their feet do not touch the ground, and have two others support them, keeping them upright. The bamboo strip measured should be placed from the sitting position on the bamboo pole down to the coccyx, then directly along the spine to the end of the measured strip; use ink to mark this point, which is merely for positioning and is not an acupuncture point.[532p]
Instead, use thin bamboo strips as a measuring tool to gauge the knuckle joint of the patient’s middle finger, with the distance between the two horizontal lines as the standard. For males, measure on the left; for females, on the right. Cut it to one standard length, then measure from the marked point on both sides to find another standard length; the ends will indicate the acupuncture points. Each point should be cauterized five to seven times. If an abscess appears on the left, cauterize the right; if on the right, cauterize the left; if severe, cauterize both sides. This is because these two points correspond with the heart meridian; all abscesses and swellings are due to the stagnation of heart fire and poison. Cauterizing here allows the heart fire to circulate and the poison to dissipate. This method has repeatedly demonstrated its life-saving effectiveness.

For abscesses that have or have not burst, take three sheng of fragrant bean and mash it with a little water to form a paste. Shape this paste into a cake according to the size of the swelling, three-tenths of an inch thick. If the wound has a hole, do not cover it. Place the bean cake on top and burn mugwort sticks above it, ensuring it remains warm but does not burn the flesh. If there’s heat and pain, replace it urgently. The affected area will feel lighter and more comfortable. Cauterize twice a day. If a hole is already present, letting out the juice is most beneficial. This is the bean cake cauterization method, mentioned in the "Thousand Gold Supplement," Volume Twenty-Three, addressing the same topic but with slight differences in wording.

The "Three Causes Formula" states that when an abscess or swelling is first felt, it should be covered with a damp paper. Looking carefully, the first dry area indicates the head. Place sliced garlic on the head and cauterize with a large mugwort torch three times, then replace with another piece of garlic. Cauterize until the pain is relieved, or continue until pain is felt to stop. Generally, a hundred cauterizations is the standard. It is most crucial to recognize early and begin cauterizing promptly.[533p]
If there is a head, there is no need to cover it with paper. If there are ten or so heads that appear in one area, prepare a paste of garlic, make a thin cake, and apply it over the head, then place mugwort on the cake for moxibustion. The "Direct Instruction Method" states: if small dots appear for one or two days, urgently apply garlic slices at the center and perform moxibustion with small mugwort sticks five times and then stop. The "Hejian Six Writings" states: for all sores and ulcers, one must differentiate the pathways and regions, and the amount of qi and blood, as well as the distance to the acupoints.

For those arising from the back, select from the five acupoints of the Sun pathway: Zhi Yin is located on the outer side of the little toe, away from the nail edge like a chive leaf; Tong Gu is found at the indentation before the outer side of the little toe; Shu Gu is located at the indentation behind the outer side of the little toe; Kun Lun is at the indentation above the outer ankle on the heel bone; Wei Zhong is in the middle of the knee crease near the artery.

For those arising from the temples, select from the five acupoints of the Shao Yang pathway: Qiao Yin is at the tip of the little toe and the next toe, away from the nail edge like a chive leaf; Xia Xi is located between the little toe and the next toe at the indentation of the joint; Lin Qi is found at the indentation behind the joint of the little toe and the next toe; Yang Fu is four inches above the outer ankle on the front end of the fibula bone; Yang Ling Quan is one inch below the knee on the outside edge in a depression.[534p]
Those with beard-like growths should select from the five points of the Yangming channel: The "Li Dui" point is located between the big toe and the second toe on the foot, with the nail cut short like chives; the "Nei Ting" point is in the middle groove between the big toe and the second toe; the "Xian Gu" point is located at the back of the joint of the big toe and second toe; the "Chong Yang" point is five inches above the top of the foot, in the space between the bones, three inches away from the protruding bone; the "Jie Xi" point is one inch and five-tenths behind the Chong Yang point, in the middle of the wrist.

For issues arising from the brain, only the "Jue Gu" point should be used, which is located three inches above the outer ankle in the artery. For early-stage carbuncles or abscesses that feel slightly swollen, with hardened skin and a deep pulse without pain, one should perform external moxibustion to expel the pathogenic qi. The classics state that for issues occurring below the surface, moxibustion is indicated. If one feels a slight hardness without pain, urgent moxibustion is required, as the pathogenic qi has deeply settled; if it is shallow, moxibustion should not be performed. If there is pus, moxibustion is also not indicated; needling is warranted.

According to the "De Xiao Fang": When a carbuncle or abscess initially flares up and grows larger, place a piece of damp paper on the wound, and the point that dries first is the primary location. First, wash it with water to remove any salty skin, and place a large pen-tube aligned over the primary location, then insert a large leech inside. Frequently pour cold water over it; the leech should suck out the pus and blood from the precise point, with the skin wrinkling and the tissue turning pale, indicating that the poison has dispersed effectively. If the poison is large and the leech is small, three to four leeches should be used to achieve results. If bleeding does not stop, apply mud from lotus stems to the area.

According to the "Zi Sheng Fang": Those skilled in treating carbuncles and abscesses typically use moxibustion on the wound two to three hundred times, with all cases achieving resolution.[535p]
When using moxa sticks for small ailments, a gentler approach causes less fear of the treatment; if used excessively, the effects will surely manifest. When a hard, unyielding lump is encountered, known as a "stone sore," apply strong moxibustion over it to break apart the stone within.

According to the "Ten Books of Dongyuan," when a sore first appears on the back, signifying potential development, it is red, hot, swollen, and painful. First, cover it with moist paper, then observe where it dries first—that spot indicates the head of the sore. Take garlic, slice it into pieces about the thickness of three coins, place it on the head, and perform strong moxibustion three times, replacing with a new slice of garlic each time. Apply moxibustion until the pain subsides; if there is no pain, continue until it begins to hurt. It is best to treat early. In one to two days, ten treatments yield ten recoveries; in three to four days, six to seven recoveries; by five to six days, three to four recoveries. After ten or more days, moxibustion is no longer advisable.

If multiple heads arise in one spot, crush garlic into a paste and form a thin cake. Place it on the head and burn moxa over it, which can also yield effective results. If a red swelling first appears, and there is a yellow, corn-like head in the middle, take a single clove of garlic, cut off both ends, and slice the middle part to place on the sore head. Apply moxibustion fourteen to a maximum of forty-nine times.

According to the "Heart Method of Danxi," the emergence of sores is either due to internal accumulated heat or external cold combined with internal heat. By applying moxibustion to the site of development to disperse its toxicity, early treatment can change a deep issue into a shallow one, alleviating severity into mildness.[536p]
All methods of moxibustion are good, but the riding bamboo horse moxibustion method is particularly crucial, as it prevents ailments before they manifest. If moxibustion is applied excessively, one should take powdered milk internally to prevent the fire from entering the heart. The "Medical Cliff Original General” states: sores that enter from the outside should not be treated with moxibustion; those that emerge from the inside should be treated. External invasions should be expelled rather than treated internally, while internal discharges should be guided outward. Therefore, the classic says: "If it is trapped, moxibustion should be applied." If moxibustion does not cause pain, one should cease when it becomes painful. If it does not hurt, it must have already reached the ulcer, hence the lack of pain; afterwards, it reaches healthy flesh, hence the pain arises. If moxibustion causes pain, one should stop once the pain alleviates. If it is painful, it must first reach the pre-ulcerative stage; subsequently, it affects areas about to ulcerate, thus not inducing pain.

According to Xue Ji's medical case studies, Wu states: "For moxibustion with garlic cakes, garlic's spicy, warm, and toxic properties primarily disperse sores and abscesses, using the heat to activate the medicinal effects." For those who only use moxa cones, this can be applied to stubborn ulcers, or similar conditions. For all cases of red, swollen, and darkly toxic sores, moxibustion with garlic and moxa together is ideal.

In treating abscesses, furuncles, and carbuncles, if initial moxibustion causes pain, it indicates the toxic gases are superficial; if there is no pain, the toxicity is deeper. Both cases should involve internal medication to eliminate toxins and pus, and external applications to disinfect. Generally, abscesses should not be painless; if they are overwhelmingly painful, or if one is disoriented and feels no pain, treatment becomes difficult.[537p]
Generally, for those who undergo garlic isolation moxibustion, it does not matter whether the condition is severe or mild; the pathogenic energy has no place to reside, and the vital energy remains intact. However, if sores appear on the crown of the head, one should use the bamboo horse method and moxibustion at the acupuncture point Zusanli. Sores and ulcers must manifest externally if there are internal issues; those on the outside should be drawn out, while internal ones should be dispersed and drained. The effects of moxibustion are significant. If toxic energy becomes stagnant and blood coagulates, lighter cases might be relieved with medicinal herbs, but in severe cases, medicine cannot work effectively. Dongyuan stated: If one does not use acupuncture or cautery, the toxic energy cannot be resolved. Therefore, those skilled in treating toxins must use garlic isolation moxibustion. Using harsh, cold remedies to dispel toxins can be effective for those with substantial internal heat, but for those who are weak and have deficient energy, failure is inevitable. Additionally, if toxic energy is hidden, whether due to age or weakness, or from taking harmful medications that further deplete energy, resulting in pus that does not discharge, one must rely on the power of fire to achieve success. Generally, in acupuncture and moxibustion, if there is no discharge, one should draw out the stagnant toxins; if it has discharged, one should restore the Yang energy and eliminate cold pathogenic influence, allowing the sore to close naturally. This method is particularly effective for treating sores in the limbs due to insufficient energy and blood. For such cases, the aforementioned moxibustion method is adequate for healing. In cases of severe abscess, moxibustion is especially advisable, as heat toxins trapped within create a barrier, and without proper release, they cannot be dispersed. If one is in a poor and isolated situation with no medicine available, garlic isolation moxibustion is particularly convenient, changing the garlic slices every three uses, typically capping at around one hundred uses.[538p]
Using garlic for its pungency can disperse, and using mugwort for its fiery properties can promote penetration. If these methods are applied through moxibustion, the sore will inevitably fester and break down, followed by applying a miraculous ointment, leading to self-healing in no time. This method not only prevents the sore from becoming large but also preserves the internal flesh, allowing the sore's opening to close easily, showing remarkable effects. Danxi said: "The head is where all yang energies converge; therefore, mugwort should be used in small and limited amounts."

For sores that do not break, they should be prodded to break. For those not festering, they should be supplemented to promote festering, preventing internal attacks. When the pus forms, timely needling will lead to healing in less than a few weeks. Patients often fear the pain of needles and refuse treatment, or they worry about damaging the flesh. They do not realize that though the sore emerges in thin flesh, if the pus forms, it will swell a couple of inches high, and the skin of the sore will thicken; using a needle, the depth should not exceed two-tenths of an inch. If it arises on the back, the swelling may be two to three inches high, and the needle should only enter about an inch deep. Moreover, when the affected flesh is already damaged, what pain is there? What is there to worry about in terms of injury?

For timid or weak individuals, or those suffering from bone-related abscesses, waiting for the pus to drain naturally often leads to severe ruptures that cannot heal and result in the loss of vital energy and blood, leading to many deaths. Once a sore has formed pus, the skin should not be loosely vented, yet some foolish individuals wait for it to rupture on their own. They fail to understand that younger and more robust individuals might be able to self-resolve. However, for the elderly and weak, with depleted vital energy and blood, or those who excessively induce attacks, not using needling allows the pathogenic toxicity to exploit the situation and attack internally, leading to severe consequences.[539p]
If poison has settled in the limbs, and the acupuncture is not effective, then the decay will be deep and significant, making it difficult to contain. When poison accumulates in critical areas such as the cheeks, neck, chest, and abdomen, regardless of whether the person is strong or weak, urgent puncturing is required; otherwise, it will be hard to treat. Generally, the manifestations of sores and ulcers vary in severity, with deep or shallow presentations. Shallow ones are swollen, raised, and soft, arising from the blood vessels; deep ones, however, are swollen, hardened, and arise from the tendons and bones. There are also those that arise from the marrow, where the skin and flesh remain unchanged. Thus, the ancients devised methods where shallow cases should be treated with scraping and deep cases should be pierced, to eliminate stagnant blood at the onset of the poison accumulation for easier resolution. If pus has formed and the vital energy is strong, it may naturally drain out. For those who are weak and timid, needling is not recommended, as few escape regret. When sores and ulcers penetrate the membrane, there is a ten to one chance of death; even using major tonics cannot save them, thus this serves as a warning to await the pus to drain out. Therefore, Dongyuan states: if the toxic qi cannot be resolved and the pus and stagnation cannot be released, and time passes without treatment, it will turn inward and harm the internal organs. Once the internal decay occurs, how can one hope for survival? I will share one or two examples for my colleagues and alert the patients to be cautious.

If treating symptoms of insufficient vital energy, at the onset of the condition, one should internally use ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and poria to warmly nourish the spleen and stomach; externally, use mulberry branches and green onions for steaming, to help restore the yang energy for natural dissipation.[540p]
If it has been a long time without pus formation, one should employ the previous two methods as supplements to hasten it. If pus has already formed but does not drain, moxa should be applied at the center with a few cones to draw it out, followed by taking a decoction of "Ten Complete Tonics."

It is also noted: if there are ten or more pepper eyes in the abscess, or it resembles a honeycomb or lotus pod, and the pus and blood do not emerge, use a needle to puncture it both horizontally and vertically. If there are no such pepper eyes, simply puncture straight in to extract the pus without splitting. Applying moxa to each pepper eye is also a good method, and it is not necessary to split.

Moreover, it is stated: an abscess has thin skin and a high swelling, often with pepper-like granules; while a carbuncle has tough skin, resembling a cow's neck. When an abscess is ripe, it is appropriate to use a needle, preferably one made of horse bit iron, shaped like a chive leaf, sharp on both sides, capable of slicing five or six tenths of an inch, used to eradicate toxic blood. One must first apply moxa before puncturing. When a carbuncle is ripe, it is suitable for cauterization; a silver spatula about two inches wide and six inches long can be heated until red-hot and quickly applied to the toxic area to cauterize, resulting in the pus being expelled.

For already formed toxic gas, it is advisable to use a tool to hasten the emergence of pus; once the pus is formed, one must check its ripeness, depth, and state before using a needle. If the pus is ripe and a needle is used, the qi and blood will already have flowed out, making it difficult for additional pus to form; however, if the pus is ripe and not punctured, the necrosis will deepen, and the wound will be hard to close. If the wound is deep and the needle is shallow, the internal pus will not exit, and external blood will instead leak out; if the wound is shallow and the needle is deep, while the internal pus may exit, healthy flesh may become damaged.[541p]
If the vital energy is weak, one must first nourish before puncturing. Once the pus is released, the various symptoms will subside. However, if the pus is expelled and there is renewed pain, or if there is restlessness and vomiting, this is due to a deficiency in stomach energy, and urgent nourishment is required. If there is severe heat and toxins from back sores, with the central flesh darkened, internally use medicines to strengthen the spleen and stomach, and externally apply black gold ointment to the darkened area. As the red areas gradually rise and the dark areas gradually lower, within six or seven days, a boundary will be formed between the red and dark areas, with cracks appearing as if marked by a knife, and the dark flesh will begin to deteriorate. One should use fine needles to carefully cut away, ensuring that the patient feels no pain and no blood is seen. Even if there are cracks and pus has not fully flowed, or even if the pus and water have come out but there is still pain, this indicates that the inner pathways are not yet open, and needles should be used to draw it out along the cracks. If there is decay in the flesh between the shoulder blades and pus is released but swelling and pain persist, this indicates the presence of toxic filaments obstructing it, and the pus has not been fully released. It is especially important to draw this out. If the vital energy is weak and there is excessive use or loss of energy, and the affected area is not painful, or if the flesh appears to be dying, urgent warming and nourishing of the spleen and stomach is needed; there may still be a chance for recovery. In the end, pure nourishing medicines should be employed to help consolidate the healing.[542p]
If one recklessly uses knives and needles, causing flesh to be cut and blood to flow, then the vital energy has nowhere to attach, and both the vital energy and blood become increasingly deficient, leading to greater injury of the original energy. How can one expect to grow flesh and promote healing in such a state?

In the practice of acupuncture and moxibustion, there are rules concerning forbidden points and prohibited practices, including the prohibitions of using needles on certain days or during certain times. Violating these rules can lead to difficulties in healing, for this reasoning is indeed sound. However, when wounds and lesions have already harmed the vital energy and blood, and the muscles are damaged, it is better to confront and seize the problem in a straightforward manner. This is not to be compared to the acupuncture of a healthy individual, so what prohibitions need to be observed?

"The Essentials of Surgery" states: In the case of wounds and sores where poisonous energy cannot be resolved and pus and clots cannot be drained, the attack turns inward. When the interior has already decayed, how can one expect healing? The dangers from critical conditions can arise suddenly, with peril lurking at every turn: abdominal abscesses, urinary obstructions, chest and abdominal distension, lip sores, throat paralysis, and swollen and blocked throats lead to swift catastrophe. Patients must be vigilant!

As for the technique of "earthworm needle," it is used to treat initial occurrences of boils and sores. First, a pen tube is inserted into the body of the earthworm, aligning the tube's opening with the sore's head, allowing the earthworm to suck out the pus and blood, dispersing the poison effectively.[543p]
If the sore is large, it must be changed out for three or four strips. If you suck on the right point, the pestilence will surely die; this has been tested repeatedly. If the bleeding does not stop, apply mud from the lotus root's joint. If the sore's head has not yet formed clearly, apply mud from the edge of the well to the part that has dried first.

For initial small points of carbuncles and sores that appear, within one or two days, urgently cut a whole garlic bulb horizontally like a coin and place it at the center, then prompt moxa treatment five times and stop. If the shape is somewhat larger, use yellow straw paper soaked in alcohol and apply it entirely, recognizing the dried part as the sinew. Treat the drier part with moxa, or you can apply it to both drier parts, but limit it to five or seven applications.[544p]
Another method involves bending one's fingers to feel around the affected area. When you encounter a painful spot, that is the root. Press deeply there, and if you feel lighter, then apply moxibustion. Additionally, apply it in other areas. If there is significant swelling, pound garlic into a cake, dry it, and dip it in vinegar for moxibustion. Replace it frequently with hot packs, or use an iron to heat the garlic cake and press it frequently. If you notice the pain radiating, cover the affected area with a soft cloth to prevent the energy from dispersing, and wait a little before applying medicine.

For abscesses that have swollen greatly, resembling the shape of a turtle, observe the position of the head; first, apply moxibustion to the front legs, then to the tail. If there are red veins that are tight and long, treat them from the end, leaving the head and the two back legs untouched. If you apply moxibustion to the entire area, not only will the heat become trapped, but the poison will also not disperse and will invade deeper.

If you are unsure about the diagnosis, use three parts of white angelica, one part each of Sichuan pepper and mulberry bark, and ten pieces of green onion whites. Boil them in freshly drawn water with half a cup of vinegar, and wash the area for a while until the veins appear, so you can identify the head and tail.

Fermented black beans can treat ulcers and solid swellings that do not suppurate, as well as non-healing stubborn sores. Use Jiangxi fermented black beans powdered into fine powder, mix with saliva to form cakes about the size of a coin and three-tenths of an inch thick. Place the cake on the afflicted area and apply moxibustion using mugwort on top of the cake.[545p]
Biscuit: Use saliva to make it the size of a sore, and with mouthwash, adjust it to cover the affected area. Place mugwort on top and burn it. If the sore is not fully formed, it will vanish upon application; if it has already formed, it may not completely disappear, but the toxicity will be greatly reduced. Previous practitioners have all claimed it has miraculous effects, so it should not be overlooked!

Pill of Thunderfire is a wonderful remedy for internal carbuncles, effective for inducing sweat. When a sore is first noticed and no sweating medicine has been taken, after several days, external symptoms will cease, either affecting the chest and abdomen or the sides, with red swelling. This indicates that toxic air has entered within, manifesting as internal carbuncles. This method should be used to induce sweat so that the toxins can be released.

First, prepare a water bucket and an iron pot. Have the patient lie on their side over the bucket, protecting them with clothing and blankets to prevent loss of steam. Then take a heated river stone until it glows red and place it in the pot. Put the pot into the bucket and sprinkle vinegar onto it to create steam for sweating. If the sweat does not penetrate, increase the heat and add more vinegar; ensure that the swollen area sweats through, without requiring the entire body to sweat.

Aconite biscuits treat ulcers when there is deficiency in qi and blood, unable to retract, or when wind evil attacks, preventing qi and blood from circulating in the sore, thus failing to contract. Use processed aconite, peeled and ground, combined with saliva to form a biscuit, and place this on the sore. Burn mugwort on top of the biscuit daily, a few times, ensuring it feels slightly warm without causing pain. Adjust the biscuit's consistency with saliva to keep the sore moist.[546p]
"The 'Principles of Treatment' states: The method of acupuncture for treating carbuncles and sores involves the dispersal of red threads, with possible accumulation of toxic blood. Use a piece of fine ceramic, break it into sharp pieces, take one piece, split it with a chopstick, and secure it with a thread. With your fingers, lightly press the chopstick to align the sharp edge with the affected area, hanging about an inch above it. Then, use another chopstick to repeatedly strike the head of the first chopstick, allowing toxic blood to be released upon puncture. If the toxicity is deep within the belly, it is difficult to treat.

Moxibustion is a method to break up blockages and hard masses. If there is a small white bump, like a grain of millet, surrounded by slight swelling like a coin, moxa should be applied directly to the grain for fourteen or fifteen treatments. If treated within three days, it will only form a sore and disperse; if treated after three days, the swelling will gradually decrease, so it is advisable to apply more moxibustion. If the moxa burns the area, the heat can extend the blockage, and if the treatment area ulcerates first, the toxicity will lessen, hopefully preventing further spread and avoiding damage to muscles, bones, and the blood.

When it is said that moxibustion is painless, it means that if it’s applied to skin and flesh that isn’t damaged, it will hurt; but if it reaches the toxic area, it will not hurt. Therefore, the heat must reach the toxic area to be effective. When it’s said that moxibustion causes pain, it means that the initial application to the toxic area is painless, but it hurts when the heat reaches healthy flesh; thus, the heat must reach healthy flesh to be effective.

Those who are afraid of moxibustion may use a clove of garlic, or a fermented soybean cake, or a paste made from mashed pepper, ginger, and salt, about the thickness of three coins, spread with moxa and treated. If it gets hot, replace it with a fresh cake, which can also aid in dispersing the condition."[547p]
Cauterization is intended for treatment; only the head is where all yang energies converge, and the moxa should be small and few. If it involves the lesser yang regions, it is especially inadvisable to cauterize, as excessive cauterization may lead to no remedy. There are also instances of death resulting from cauterization. This occurs due to severe deficiency; solitary yang approaches extinction, and its pulse is bound to be floating, rapid, and large, while the spirit is bound to be short and murky, lacking the ability to withstand the fire's heat, which naturally leads to danger.

Liu Zonghou said: This refers to the early onset of boils and sores, where cauterization is advisable. However, for longstanding sores that cause pain, which often have continuous pus without an odor and no decayed flesh inside, it is more appropriate to soak with aconite, cut into large pieces, about two to three fen thick, and place them on the sore for moxa cauterization, while also taking internal medicinal remedies. Cauterization should be repeated every two to three days, and after five to seven times, the muscle will naturally fill in. For sores with foul pus and deep-rooted issues, the Guo family uses a combination of flour, sulfur, and garlic, all ground together. Depending on the size of the sore, form them into patties about three fen thick, and apply moxa cauterization twenty-one times, replacing it after each treatment. After four to five days, use the Qingxia pill and Xinxiao pill, alternating their use, and insert them into the sore until all decayed flesh is gone and healthy flesh emerges. Then, apply a consolidating medicine and take internal remedies suited to the condition, and with proper regulation, healing will follow.

Therefore, cauterization is not only appropriate at the initial onset of a sore. Generally, in the early stages, cauterization is indicated, and it is essential to supplement with medicines that contrast the condition while sweating and reducing. Even when cauterizing cold sores, effective internal remedies must be applied. If contrary treatments are used, not only will recovery fail, but it may also lead to the onset of other diseases.[548p]
Needling and Cauterization

When using needling and cauterization, first examine the depth and severity of the abscess and whether the pus is formed or not.
