  4. The eighth type is the snake-eye boil, which has a black head and raised skin resembling a small bean, appearing like a snake's eye in size and is hard in texture. Avoid being seen by someone with an evil eye and jealousy, as well as exposure to poison.

  5. The ninth type is the salt-skin boil, which is large like a spoon's surface, with red all around and black millet-like grains appearing. Avoid salty foods.

  6. The tenth type is the water-wash boil, shaped like a coin or the size of a coin hole, with a white head, black and dark inside, and hard juice flowing from the center.[25p]

忌饮浆水水洗渡河。　　十一曰刀嫌疔，其状疮阔狭如薤叶大，长一寸，左侧肉黑如烧烁。忌刺及刀鎌切割。铁刃所伤，可以药治。　　十二曰浮沤疔，其状疮体曲圆，少许不合，长而狭，如薤叶大，内黄外黑，黑处刺不痛，内黄处刺之则痛。　　十三曰牛拘疔，其状肉疱起，掐不破。　　右十三种疮，初起必先痒后痛，先寒后热，热定则寒，多四肢沉重，头痛，心惊眼花，若大重者则呕逆，呕逆难治。其麻子疔一种，始末惟痒，所最忌者，不得犯触，犯触者即难疗。其浮沤疔、狗疔两种，无所禁忌，纵不疗亦不能杀人，其状寒热与诸疔同，皆以此方疗之，万不失一。欲知犯触之状，但脊强疮痛极甚，不可忍者是也。[26p]

Avoid drinking water and washing when crossing rivers.

On the eleventh, there is the "knife-dislike sore," which has lesions that are wide and narrow like the size of garlic leaves, one inch long, with the flesh on the left side blackened as if burned. It is crucial to avoid stabbing or cutting with knives or sickles. Wounds caused by iron blades can be treated with medicine.

On the twelfth, there is the "floating froth sore," which has a curved and rounded appearance, slightly uneven, long and narrow like garlic leaves, yellow inside and black outside. The black area is painless when pricked, while the yellow area causes pain when pricked.

On the thirteenth, there exists the "cow-captured sore," characterized by raised blisters that cannot be squeezed open.

Among these thirteen types of sores, they initially cause itching followed by pain, cold sensation followed by heat, and when heat settles, cold emerges. There is often a heaviness in the limbs, headaches, and feelings of shock with blurred vision. In severe cases, it can lead to vomiting, which is hard to treat. The "hemp seed sore" type only causes itching from beginning to end; the greatest taboo is that it should not be touched, as touching it makes treatment very difficult. The "floating froth sore" and the "dog sore" types have no taboos; even if left untreated, they do not lead to mortality. They share similar cold and hot characteristics with other sores and can be treated with the same method, with a high likelihood of success. To know the condition of a touched sore, it is extremely painful, particularly around the spine, making it unbearable.[26p]

　　　　疮疡全书 【宋　窦汉卿】

　　　　　围法贴纸诀

　　凡用围药，多加功夫搅千余下，其药自稠，轻手围之，留孔必须如鹅子形状。须用薄纸贴之，务要扯碎贴上，免致绷裂疼痛之苦。待围药略干，再用调药余汁润之，以助药力。况药干不能入肌肉，借湿以通窍耳。
　　　　　开刀手法

　　凡疮疡之起，疼痛固属于心火，久而阳气升上，蒸肉化为脓。若不原其脓之有无，遽尔开刀，则鲜血突出，脓何从来？致患者煎寒发热，日夜疼痛，无法可止。可先将指头按患上，随手而起，四畔悉软，观其头聚，择尻神不犯吉日，将刀头向上开之，方不致伤新肉。取出刀，再捻绵纸条润油度之，使脓水齐会，半日扯出，则脓水易干。外贴呼脓膏，四围再用搜脓散敷之。[27p]

Complete Book of Wounds and Ulcers
By Dou Hanqing of the Song Dynasty

Method for Applying Surrounding Medicine

For applying surrounding medicine, one must make great effort to stir it thoroughly over a thousand times. Since the medicine is thick, apply it lightly, ensuring that the opening is shaped like a goose egg. Thin paper must be used to cover it, making sure to tear it into pieces to avoid tearing and causing pain. Once the surrounding medicine is slightly dry, use the remaining juice of the mixed medicine to moisten it, to enhance the medicinal effect. Moreover, if the medicine is dry, it cannot penetrate the muscles; thus, moisture is needed to open the channels.

Surgical Technique

When a wound or ulcer arises, the pain is fundamentally due to heart fire. Over time, yang energy rises, causing the flesh to fester into pus. If one opens the wound without determining whether there is pus or not, fresh blood will pour out—where would the pus come from? This will cause the patient to suffer from cold and fever, experiencing pain day and night without relief. First, press the affected area with a finger; if it softens, observe where the pus is collecting. Choose a favorable day and orient the knife upwards when making the incision to avoid damaging new flesh. Once the knife is withdrawn, take a piece of cotton paper with oil to help gather the pus; after half a day, it will be easier to extract. Apply pus-drawing ointment on the outside, and use a gathering powder around it for dressing.[27p]

　　　　　疔疮总论

　　大抵疔疮有十三种，而有青黄赤白黑，所以应五脏也。复有暑疔、火疔、气疔，冷疔者，皆以其时候缓急浮实之异。但初发起，或先肿后痛，先寒后热，四肢拘急沉重。强痛者，得证便发寒热，疮边麻，渐至半身大痛应心，呕逆自利，足冷至膝，四畔紫黑色，皆为重证。惟麻子疔始末皆痒，其证候寒热与诸疔疮同，但觉背强其痛甚者，乃触犯所致，即取枸杞根捣汁服之，弥佳。再狗屎白色者，得雨露之功，臭气已去，加枸杞根和匀，绞取清汁服之，尤良。但有卒患喉痛，心寒热，或腹痛恶寒发热者，当预防生此疔证也。凡疔疮多生口边颊内，或舌上，赤黑点点如珠碜痛，应心者是也，不即治之，日夜根长，流入诸脉，如箭入身，不得动摇，经久五六日后，甚者毒气入腹，眼中见火，神昏烦闷，呕吐，恍惚如醉如痴，不可疗矣。[28p]

General Discussion on Carbuncles

Generally, there are thirteen types of carbuncles, which are categorized as blue, yellow, red, white, and black, corresponding to the five organs. There are also heat carbuncles, fire carbuncles, qi carbuncles, and cold carbuncles, each differing in urgency and manifestation based on their timing. At the initial onset, one may experience swelling before pain, or cold before heat, along with rigidity and heaviness in the limbs. Severe pain can lead to chills, fever, numbness at the edges of the sore, and eventually intense pain on one side of the body, with accompanying symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhea, coldness in the feet up to the knees, and purple-black discoloration surrounding the area, all indicating a serious condition.

Only the carbuncle of the itchy type has itching at both the beginning and end; its symptoms of cold and heat are similar to other carbuncles, but if the pain is particularly severe in the back, it may be due to external injury, in which case taking juice from goji root is very effective. For those with sudden throat pain, heart discomfort from cold and heat, or abdominal pain with chills and fever, precautions should be taken against developing carbuncle symptoms.

Typically, carbuncles appear near the mouth, inside the cheeks, or on the tongue, presenting as red and black dots that are painful, particularly affecting the heart. If not treated immediately, they can worsen day by day, spreading to various channels and causing severe harm, similar to an arrow piercing the body. After five or six days, if the condition worsens, toxic energy may enter the abdomen, leading to symptoms such as seeing fire in the eyes, confusion, irritability, vomiting, and a state resembling drunkenness or delirium, indicating that treatment is impossible.[28p]

疔疮有头黑硬而凹者，疮头白而肿实者，疮头如豆垽色者，疮头鲜红色者，疮头内有黑脉者，疮头红赤而浮虚者，疮头如栀而黄者，疮头如金箔者，疮头如茱萸者，疮头如石榴子者；有初如风疹、粉刺，搔破入风则黄水出，其里有赤黑脉而微肿者，肉中突起，如鱼眼赤黑，惨痛彻骨者。结久皆为烂疮，疮下深孔如大针穿物。初生时突起如钉，故名疔疮，令人恶寒发热，四肢强直而牵痛，一二日疮变黑色，焦黑肿大，光起根硬，不可近，犯之则痛甚，甚则发于头面手足骨节间者，此气血聚会之所，宜急治之。有似灸疮四边泡浆者，但其疮熟时脓水出疮孔，如蜂窠病，易瘥也。[29p]

A sore with a head that is black, hard, and concave; a sore with a white, swollen, solid head; a sore with a head that is bean-colored; a sore with a bright red head; a sore with black veins inside the head; a sore with a red, raised, and soft head; a sore with a head that is yellow like a gardenia; a sore with a head like gold foil; a sore with a head like a cornelian; a sore with a head like a pomegranate seed—if it initially resembles wind rash or acne, and when scratched it produces yellow fluid inside, showing red and black veins with slight swelling, and the flesh protrudes like a fish eye, accompanied by excruciating pain that penetrates to the bone. When they persist, they develop into rotten sores, with deep holes underneath like a large needle having pierced through. At first, it protrudes like a nail, hence the name "disease sore," causing chills, fever, and stiffness in the limbs with pulling pain. Within a day or two, the sore turns black, charred, and swollen, and the root is hard and raised, making it painful to approach. If disturbed, it causes severe pain, and in serious cases, it manifests in the head, face, hands, feet, and joints—this is where qi and blood gather, requiring urgent treatment. There are those resembling burn sores with blisters around the edges, but when they mature, pus and fluid ooze from the sore, similar to a honeycomb disease, which heals more easily.[29p]

此疮恶证：眼黄面青舌黑，冷汗发渴，脚冷至膝下，不食自利，疮冷不痛，呕逆，疮不起发，四畔不红，疮边麻木，干黑生刺，疮边紫黑色，碜痛应心，眼中见火，神昏烦闷，神思恍惚，犹如醉如痴者，皆难治也。试以针刺患人手足中指，不痛者难治。凡初生时，红软温和，忽然顶陷黑，谓之走黄，此证危矣，急服飞龙夺命丹、追疔夺命汤。其有发于太阳眼边者，名曰钉脑疔，十死一生。《内经》以白疔发于右鼻，赤疔发于舌根，黄疔发于口唇，黑疔发于耳前，青疔发于目下。盖取五色以应五脏，各有所属部位而已。然或肩或腰或足，发无定处。如在头面手足骨节间者甚急。[30p]

This ulcerous condition is severe: yellow eyes, blue face, black tongue, cold sweat, thirst, feet cold to the knees, lack of appetite yet still passing waste, ulcers that are cold and painless, vomiting, no emergence of the ulcer, the surrounding areas are not red, the edge of the ulcer is numb, dry and black with spines, the edge is purplish-black, unbearable pain responding to the heart, seeing fire in the eyes, confusion of spirit, irritability, and a dazed mind, resembling someone who is drunk or foolish—all are difficult to treat. Try pricking the middle finger and toe of the affected person; if there is no pain, it is hard to cure. Generally, when newly born, soft, red, and warm, if it suddenly sinks and turns black, it is called "running yellow," which indicates a critical condition; urgently take Feilong Duoming Dan or Zhuixing Duoming Tang. If it appears near the outer corner of the eye, it is called "nail brain abscess," with a ten-percent survival rate. The "Neijing" states that white abscesses appear on the right nostril, red ones at the root of the tongue, yellow ones on the lips, black ones in front of the ear, and green ones beneath the eyes. This categorizes the five colors according to the five organs, each corresponding to specific locations. However, it can erupt on the shoulder, waist, or foot; it is particularly urgent if it appears between the head, face, hands, or joints.[30p]

　　　　　拔法

　　凡疔疮之起，多发于嘴唇上边，初如米大，或如粉刺，挤破，入汤火风气，亦要变成疵疮。疵疮者，即疔之别名也。先用葱白同飞龙夺命丹五粒和嚼烂，热酒半碗过下，以衣覆患上，略出汗为妙。上午服药，下午即将绝利磁锋划破疮口十字，即掺飞龙夺命末在内，而外用蟾舌研烂，蟾肚底皮贴之，内服追疔汤剂。若发于须发者，即剃去须发，如前法治之。此法百发百中，活人多矣。凡发于头面上者，切不可用冷药敷之。若敷冷药，赶热毒恶戾之气入于喉间，断不能生矣。[31p]

Method for Removing Abscesses

Abscesses often appear on the upper lip, starting small like a grain of rice or resembling a pimply spot. If squeezed, they can turn into a sore due to exposure to hot steam or cold wind. The sore is another name for the abscess. First, mash five pieces of scallion white with "Feilong Duoming Dan" and take them with half a bowl of hot wine, then cover the affected area with a cloth to induce slight sweating, which is ideal. Take the medicine in the morning, and in the afternoon, use a sharp magnet to make a cross incision on the sore. Then mix and insert "Feilong Duoming" powder inside, while using crushed toad tongue and toad skin on the outside, and take a decoction for chasing the abscess internally. If it occurs on the hair, shave off the hair and treat it as above. This method is highly effective, helping many people. For any occurrence on the head or face, do not apply cold medicine. If you apply cold medicine, it will drive the hot and toxic energy into the throat, preventing recovery.[31p]

　　　　　各种疔

　　芝麻疔，用黑云膏，或用紫花草敷疮上。走注者，遍身疼不能转动，服蠲毒流气饮、蟾酥丸。　　气疔，用胜金锭服蟾酥丸，外用紫花草敷之。　　火疔，用胜金锭服蟾酥丸，紫花草敷疮上。　　冷疔者，高粱之变，风湿余毒，天阴久冷，攻于膝下，传于足太阴经。初生如米，渐成溃烂，其色如煤，败血来侵，骨肉损坏，遂成大患。经年骨节疼痛，累岁不能生肌。先用艾叶、蛇床子、紫苏、豨莶草煎汤洗之，内服黄芪、白朮、苍朮、当归、白芍、连翘、生地之药，外用隔纸膏贴之，节劳内省，亦可瘳矣。　　鱼脐疔，春用黑云膏，夏用蟾舌膏，秋用桐泪膏，冬用胜金锭。[32p]

Various Types of Boils

Sesame boil: Apply black cloud ointment, or purple flower herb on the sore. If it spreads throughout the body causing pain and inability to move, take detoxifying herbal drinks and toad venom pills.

Qi boil: Take toad venom pills with supreme gold ingot, and apply purple flower herb externally.

Fire boil: Take toad venom pills with supreme gold ingot, applying purple flower herb on the sore.

Cold boil: This arises from millets, wind and damp remaining toxins, prolonged exposure to cold weather leading to attack at the knee, transmitting to the foot Taiyin meridian. It initially appears like a grain of rice, gradually turning into an ulcer, dark as coal, with corrupted blood invading, damaging bones and flesh, resulting in serious ailments. Year after year, joint pain persists, and muscle cannot regenerate. First, use a decoction of mugwort, snake bed seed, purple perilla, and pigweed to wash it; internally take astragalus, white peony, wormwood, angelica, and raw prepared earth herbs, while externally using a medicated paper plaster. Should the joints suffer, internal reflection may lead to recovery.

Fish navel boil: In spring, use black cloud ointment; in summer, use toad tongue ointment; in autumn, use tung oil ointment; in winter, use supreme gold ingot.[32p]

　　　　　飞游毒
　　此毒因荣卫受其肌热，故生此疽。赤肿走注不定，用温水洗患处，用三棱针刺毒上二三十针，或磁锋砭之亦妙，随用拔毒散敷之。
　　　　　红丝疮

　　夫红丝者，心肠积毒，气血相凝，灌于经络之间，发于肌肤之上，红丝贯穿，如一红线，或疼或痒，皆由风热相乘而生，如箭之速，若行至心间即死。急当头以磁锋刺破，挤出毒血；其红丝之中再刺之，方绝其根。急用当归、连翘解毒之剂治之。须戒酒数日。[33p]

Flying Toxin

This toxin arises because of the heat from the skin caused by an imbalance in the body's defense systems, resulting in this sore. There is red swelling that spreads unpredictably. Wash the affected area with warm water and prick the toxin with a triangular needle, using two to thirty pricks, or apply magnetic therapy, which is also effective. Then use a toxin-drawing paste to apply.

Red Silk Sore

The "red silk" refers to accumulated toxins in the heart and intestines, causing stagnation of qi and blood, which manifests on the skin. The red lines run through like a red thread, causing either pain or itching, produced by an excess of wind and heat. It acts with the speed of an arrow; if it reaches the heart, it can be fatal. Immediately, use magnetic therapy to pierce it and expel the toxic blood; then prick again within the red lines to eliminate its root. Urgently use decoctions like angelica and forsythia as an antidote. Abstain from alcohol for several days.[33p]

　　　　河间六书 【金　刘完素】

　　　　　总论

　　疮疡者，火之属，须分内外以治其本。《内经》曰：膏粱之变，足生大疔。其原在里，发于表也。受持如虚，言内结而发诸外，未知从何道而出，皆是从虚而出也。假令太阳经虚，从背而出；少阳经虚，从鬓而出；阳明经虚，从髭而出；督脉经虚，从脑而出。经曰：地之湿气，感则害人皮肤筋脉。其在外，盛则内行。若其脉沉实，当先疏其内以绝其原也。其脉浮大，当先托里，恐气伤于内也。有内外之中者，邪气至盛，遏绝经络，故发痈肿。经曰：荣气不从，逆于肉理，乃生痈疽。此因失托里，及失疏通，又失行荣卫也。治疮之大要，须明托里、疏通、行荣卫三法。托里者，治其外之内；疏通者，治其内之外；行荣卫者，治其中也。[34p]

General Discussion on the Six Writings of Hejian

Sores and abscesses belong to the category of fire; they must be treated by distinguishing between internal and external sources. As stated in the Inner Canon: "Changes in rich and fatty foods give rise to large boils. Their origin is internal, manifesting externally." When one is in a state of vacuity, internal blockages express themselves outwardly, yet one may not know the path of their emergence; they all arise from a state of vacuity.

For instance, when the Taiyang channel is vacuous, the symptoms appear on the back; when the Shaoyang channel is vacuous, they manifest at the temples; if the Yangming channel is vacuous, the signs show at the beard; and when the Du Meridian is vacuous, they arise from the head. The classic states: "The dampness of the earth can harm the skin and tendons when they are affected." If it manifests externally, a strong presence can lead to internal circulation issues.

If the pulse is deep and solid, one must first rectify the internal state to eradicate its origin. If the pulse is floating and large, one must first clear the interior, or else internal qi may be damaged. When there is a balance between internal and external, and the pathogenic qi is exceptionally strong, it obstructs the meridians, causing boils and swellings. The classic says: "When the nourishing qi does not follow, it rebels against the flesh, thus causing boils and sores." This occurs due to a failure to clear the interior and to ensure smooth circulation, along with a breakdown in the mechanism of nourishment and defense.

The key to treating sores lies in clearly understanding the three methods: clearing the interior, smoothing out communication, and activating the nourishing and protective functions. Clearing the interior addresses issues from the outside in; smoothing out communication deals with matters from the inside out; and activating nourishment and protection focuses on the internal state itself.[34p]

内之外者，其脉沉实，发热烦躁，外无焮赤痛，其邪气深于内也，故先疏通以绝其原。外之内者，其脉浮数，焮肿在外，形证外显，恐邪气极而内行，故先托里。内外之中者，外无焮恶之气，内亦脏腑宣通，知其在经，当和荣卫也。用此三法之后，虽未差，必无变证，亦可使邪气峻减而易痊愈。故经曰：诸痛痒疮疡皆属心火。又曰：知其要者，一言而终；不知其要，流散无穷。　　《素问》云：痛痒疮疡，痈肿疽疹，瘤气结核，怫郁甚者皆热。五脏不和，九窍不通；六腑不和，留结为痈。近于火气，微热则痒，热甚则痛，附近则灼而为疮，皆火之用也。人之疮肿，因内热外虚所生也。为风湿之所乘，则生疮肿。然肺主气，候于皮毛，脾主肌肉，气虚则肤腠开，为风湿所乘，脾气湿而内热，即生疮也。肿者，由寒热毒气，客于经络，使血濇而不通，壅结成肿。[35p]

In the case of conditions that are internal and external, the pulse is deep and strong, with symptoms of heat and agitation, and there is no external visible inflammation or pain; this indicates that the pathogenic factors are deeply rooted within, thus it is essential to first clear the channels to eliminate the root cause. For conditions that are external but affect the internal, the pulse is superficial and rapid, with inflammation and swelling externally, and the symptoms are clearly manifested on the surface; this raises concerns that the pathogenic factors may be severe and could penetrate inward, thus it is necessary to first relieve the surface. For conditions that are between internal and external, there is neither obvious inflammation nor adverse energy externally, and the internal organs are functioning properly; it is understood that the issue lies within the meridians and that a balance between nourishing and protective energies is needed. After applying these three methods, even if the condition has not changed significantly, it will likely not deteriorate, and the pathogenic factors can be substantially reduced, leading to easier recovery. Therefore, the classic texts state: all pains, itching, sores, and ulcers belong to the heart fire. It also says: to understand the essentials can be summed up in one sentence; to not understand the essentials leads to endless dispersion.

The "Suwen" says: pains, itching, sores, ulcers, boils, swelling, rashes, neoplasms, and severe accumulations are all due to heat. When the five organs are not in harmony and the nine orifices are blocked; if the six bowels are unbalanced, this can lead to accumulations resulting in boils. When close to fire energy, slight heat causes itching, severe heat causes pain, and nearby heat can burn and cause sores; all are manifestations of fire. Boils and swellings in a person arise from internal heat and external deficiency. When wind and dampness invade, they lead to sores and swellings. The lungs govern qi and are reflected in the skin, while the spleen governs muscles; when qi is deficient, the skin pores open, allowing wind and dampness to invade. If the spleen's qi is damp and there is internal heat, sores will develop. Swellings occur due to the accumulation of cold, heat, and toxic energies in the meridians, causing blood to stagnate, resulting in obstructions and swelling.[35p]

风邪不作，即无头无根。寒血相搏作者，即有头有根。壅盛则为脓，赤根肿则风气流溃也。疮以痛痒，痛则为实，痒则为虚。非虚为寒也，正谓热之微甚也。痒则美疾也。故火旺于夏，而万物蕃鲜荣美也。炙之以火，渍之以汤，而其痒转甚者，微热之所使也。痒去者，谓热令皮肤纵缓，腠理开通，阳气得泄，热散而去。或夏热皮肤痒，而以冷水沃之，其痒不去，谓寒能收敛，腠理闭密，阳气郁结，不能散越，怫热内作故也。疮疡皆为火热，而反腐出脓水者，犹谷肉果菜，热极则腐烂而溃为污水也。溃而腐烂者，水之化也。痈浅而大，疽深而恶，热胜血则为痈脓也。疡有头，小疮也。疹浮而小，瘾疹也。瘤气赤瘤丹熛，热胜气，火之色也。　　人近火气，微热则痒，热甚则痛，附近则灼而为疮，皆火之用也。[36p]

When wind pathogenic factors do not arise, there are no roots or heads. When cold and blood clash, there are roots and heads. If there is obstruction and excess, it leads to pus; if there is red swelling, it causes wind and qi to break through. Pain and itchiness from sores indicate pain as real and itchiness as false. The false is not caused by cold, but rather indicates an extreme of heat. Itchiness suggests a mild illness. Therefore, when fire is strong in summer, all things flourish and thrive. If one puts it to the fire or soaks it in broth, and the itchiness worsens, it is due to mild heat. The removal of itchiness implies that heat allows the skin to relax, the pores to open, and yang qi to be released, scattering away the heat. Sometimes, when summer heat causes skin itchiness, pouring cold water on it does not alleviate the itch, suggesting that cold can constrict, keeping the pores tightly closed, leading to stagnation of yang qi, and internal heat arises from this stagnation. All sores and ulcers are due to heat, and when they become infected and produce pus, it is similar to grains and meats that rot when heat reaches its peak, causing decay and discharge of foul moisture. The rotting and decay occur due to the transformation of water. Superficial and large swellings are boils, while deep and severe sores are carbuncles; when heat exceeds blood, it becomes a boil with pus. A sore with a head is a small ulcer. Rashes that are elevated and small are hives. Tumors that are red and inflamed indicate excessive heat. When a person is close to fire, mild heat causes itch, extreme heat causes pain, and being too near leads to burns and sores, all are manifestations of fire’s influence.[36p]

或痒痛如针轻刺者，犹飞迸火星灼之然也。痒者，美疾也。炙之以火，渍之以汤，而痒转甚者，微热之所使也。因而痒去者，热令皮肤纵缓，腠理开通，阳气得泄而热散也。或夏热皮肤痒，以冷水沃之不去者，寒能收敛，腠理闭密，阳气郁结，不能散越，怫热内作故也。痒得爬而解者，爬为火化，微则亦能令痒，甚则痒去者，爬令皮肤辛辣而属金化，辛能散，故金化见则火力分而解矣。或云痛为实痒为虚者，非谓虚为寒也，正谓热之微甚也。或疑疮疡皆属火热，而反腐烂出脓水者，何也？犹谷肉果菜，至于极热，则腐烂而溃为污水也。溃而腐烂者，水之化也。所谓五行之理，过极则胜己者反来制之，故火热过极则反兼于水化，又如盐能固物，令不腐烂者，咸寒水化，制其火热使不过极，故得久固也。万物皆然。[37p]

If one experiences an itch or pain like a light prick of a needle, it is akin to sparks of fire igniting the skin. Itching is a manifestation of a graceful ailment. When treated with fire or soaked in broth, if the itching intensifies, it is due to a slight warmth. Consequently, when the itch subsides, the heat relaxes the skin, opens the pores, allows the yang energy to disperse, and the heat dissipates as well. In summer, if the skin itches and does not alleviate with cold water, it is because the cold can constrict, closing the pores tightly, leading to the accumulation of yang energy which cannot escape, resulting in internal combustion of heat.

If scratching alleviates the itch, scratching represents the action of fire; mildly it can still cause an itch, but when severe, it removes the itch. Scratching makes the skin feel spicy and corresponds to metal transformation, and since spiciness can disperse, when metal transformation appears, the fiery power is divided and resolves.

Some say that pain is real while itch is illusory; this does not imply that illusion is cold but rather indicates varying degrees of heat. If one questions why sores and ulcers are linked to fire and yet can fester and discharge pus, the reason is akin to grains, meat, fruits, and vegetables: when they reach excessive heat, they rot and dissolve into impure water. The process of decay is a result of water transformation.

This aligns with the principle of the five elements: when one aspect exceeds its limits, it paradoxically returns to control itself. Thus, if fire heat becomes excessive, it returns to transformation by water. Similarly, salt can preserve substances and prevent decay because its nature is cold water transformation, controlling fire heat to prevent it from exceeding limits, thus maintaining longevity. This principle applies to all things.[37p]

　　　　东垣十书 【元　李杲】

　　　　　总论

　　膏粱之变，亦是滋味过度，荣气不从，逆于肉理，乃生痈肿。荣气者，胃气也。饮食入于胃中，先输于脾而朝于肺，肺朝百脉，次及皮毛，先行阳道，下归五脏六腑，而气口成寸矣。今富贵之人，不知其节，法酒肥羊，杂以厚味，积久太过，其气味俱厚之物，乃阳中之阳，不能走于空窍而先行阳道，今反行阴道则湿气大盛，子令母实，火乃大旺，实热既盛，必来克肾。若不慎房事，损其真火，则水泛而湿热之化上行，其疮必出背上及脑，此为大疔之最重者。[38p]

General Discussion

The changes brought on by rich foods are also due to an excess of flavors, where the nourishing essence does not flow as it should, working against the body’s natural processes and resulting in boils and swellings. The nourishing essence refers to the stomach's energy. When food enters the stomach, it is first processed by the spleen and then directed towards the lungs. The lungs then disperse this energy through the hundred vessels, which subsequently affects the skin and hair, and sends the essence down to the five organs and six bowels, forming a delicate balance.

Nowadays, those who are wealthy and noble do not understand moderation. They indulge in wine and rich lamb, mixing in heavy flavors, and over time this leads to an excess of thick, rich substances, which are the most yang in nature. These cannot navigate the body's cavities effectively and instead cause a reversal towards the yin pathways, resulting in a significant buildup of dampness. This creates a condition where the son (yang) opposes the mother (yin), leading to excessive fire. When this real heat becomes pronounced, it inevitably impacts the kidneys. If one is not careful in intimate relations and damages their true fire, then moisture will rise, transforming into damp heat, causing sores to appear on the back and head. This is one of the most severe forms of major boils.[38p]

若毒气出肺，或脾胃之部分，毒之次也。若出于他经，又其次也。湿热之毒所止处，无不溃烂。故经言膏粱之变，足生大疔，受如持虚者，如持虚器以受物，则无不受矣。治大疔之法，必当泻其荣气。以标本言之，先受病为本，非苦寒之剂为主为君，不能除其苦楚疼痛也。诸疮疡有痛，往往多以乳香、没药，杂以芳香之药止之，必无少减之理，此其悞也。若使经络流通，脏腑中去其壅滞，必无痛矣。痛则以苦寒之剂除之，无不愈者。疮疡食肉，与自杀无异，法当泻气而反补之故也。[39p]

If toxic gas escapes from the lungs or from parts of the spleen and stomach, it is the next level of toxicity. If it emerges from other channels, it is the next level thereafter. The places where damp heat toxins reside are inevitably subject to decay and corruption. Thus, the classic says that the transformation of rich foods leads to significant sores; those who are in a state of deficiency, like holding an empty vessel to receive substances, cannot help but absorb all.

The method for treating major sores must involve draining the nourishing energy. In terms of root and branch, the initial affliction is the root; without the use of bitter cold medicines as the main remedy, one cannot alleviate the suffering and pain. Many sores and ulcers are painful, often treated with frankincense and myrrh, combined with aromatic medicines to mitigate them; however, there is no rationale for significant reduction in pain, which is a misunderstanding.

If the meridians are unblocked and the viscera are free from stagnation, pain will surely cease. Pain should be alleviated with bitter cold medicines, and none fail to heal. Eating raw flesh is akin to self-destruction, as the principle should be to drain energy and then supplement accordingly.[39p]

　　　　　用药加减法

　　发背疔肿脓溃，前后虚而头痛者，于托里药内加五味子。恍惚不宁，加人参、茯神。虚而发热者，加地黄、(艹舌)萋根。潮热者，加柴胡、地骨皮。渴不止者，加知母、赤小豆。虚烦者，加枸杞、天门冬。自利者，加厚朴。脓多者，加当归、川芎。痛甚者，加芍药、乳香。肌肉迟生者，加白蔹、官桂。有风邪者，加独活、防风。心惊悸者，加丹砂。口目瞤动者，加羌活、细辛。呕逆者，加丁香、藿叶。痰多者，加半夏、陈皮。[40p]

Method of Adjusting Medications

For abscesses with pus and headache accompanied by weakness, add Schisandra to the core remedy. If feeling disoriented and restless, add Ginseng and Poria. If weak with fever, add Rehmannia and the root of a certain herb (艹舌). For tidal fever, add Bupleurum and the bark of Lycium. If thirst is unquenchable, add Anemarrhena and red mung beans. For irritability, add Goji berries and Asparagus. If there's diarrhea, add Magnolia bark. If there is a lot of pus, add Angelica and Chuanxiong. For severe pain, add Peony and Frankincense. If muscles are slow to develop, add White Phosphorus and Cinnamon. If there is wind evil, add Angelica and Siler. For palpitations, add Cinnabar. For involuntary eye movements, add Notopterygium and Asarum. For nausea and vomiting, add Clove and Artemisia. For excessive phlegm, add Pinellia and Dried Tangerine Peel.[40p]

　　　　丹溪心法 【元　朱震亨】

　　　　　总论证治

　　痈疽只是热胜血。
　　六阳经六阴经，有多气少血者，有少气多血者，有多气多血者，不可一概论也。若夫要害处，近虚怯薄处，前哲已曾论及，惟分经之言未闻。诸经，惟在少阳厥阴经生痈疽，理宜预防，以其多气少血，肌肉难长，疮久未合，必成死证。遽用驱毒利药，以伐其阴分之血，祸不旋踵。　　阳滞于阴，脉浮洪弦数；阴滞于阳，脉沉细弱濇。阳滞以寒治之，阴滞以热治之。　　人中年以后，不可生痈。才有痛肿，参之脉证，但见虚弱，便与滋补气血，可保终吉。[41p]

Heart Method of Danxi
By Zhu Zhenheng during the Yuan Dynasty

General Discussion on Treatment

Boils and sores are simply a result of heat overpowering blood.
The six Yang meridians and six Yin meridians each have varying conditions: some have more Qi and less blood, some have less Qi and more blood, and some have both abundant Qi and blood; these cannot be treated uniformly. As for crucial points, those near the areas of deficiency, weakness, and thinness have been previously discussed by sages, but the details have not been widely noted in the texts. Among all the meridians, only the Shaoyang and Jueyin meridians are known to develop boils and sores, and thus they should be proactively prevented, as they have more Qi and less blood, making muscle growth difficult and causing wounds to heal slowly, ultimately leading to serious conditions. Rapidly using detoxifying and purging medicines to attack the Yin aspect of the blood can lead to calamity in no time.

When Yang is stagnant in Yin, the pulse is floating, rapid, and wiry; when Yin is stagnant in Yang, the pulse is deep, thin, weak, and slippery. Treat Yang stagnation with cold and Yin stagnation with heat.
For individuals after middle age, boils should not occur. If there is just pain and swelling, along with signs from the pulse, which only show weakness, then nourishing Qi and blood should be given to ensure a favorable outcome.[41p]

若用寻常驱热拔毒舒气之药，虚虚之祸，如指诸掌。　　内托之法：河间治肿焮于外，根盘不深，形证在表，其脉多浮，病在皮肉，非气盛则必侵于内，急须内托以救其里，宜复煎散除湿散郁，使胃气和平。如或未已，再煎半料饮之。如大便秘及烦热，少服黄连汤。如微利及烦热已退，却与复煎散半两。如此使荣卫俱行，邪气不能内伤也。然世俗多用排脓内补十宣散，若用之于些小疮与冬月时令即可，若溃疡于夏月用之，其桂、朴之温散，佐以防风、白芷，吾恐虽有参、芪，难为倚仗。[42p]

If one uses ordinary medicines to dispel heat, draw out toxins, and soothe qi, the harm may only be as evident as pointing fingers.

As for the method of internal support: in Hejian, treating swelling and burning on the surface, the root of the condition is not deep; the symptoms are superficial, and the pulse is often floating. If the disease resides in the skin and flesh, unless the qi is strong, it must have invaded internally. Urgent internal support is necessary to rescue the inner state, and one should prepare decoctions to eliminate moisture and soothe stagnation, ensuring the stomach qi is harmonious.

If conditions persist, re-decoct half the dosage and drink it. If there is constipation and heat, take a small amount of Huanglian Decoction. If there are slight loose stools and the heat has retreated, again take half a dose of the decoction. This way, both nourishment and protection can function together, preventing evil qi from causing internal injury.

However, the common practice often relies on pus-dispersing and internal supplementing methods like Shixuansan. Such remedies may be fine for minor sores or in winter seasons, but for ulcers in summer, using heating dispersing ingredients like cinnamon and wood can be concerning, even with ginseng and astragalus; it is difficult to rely on them.[42p]

　　疮先发为肿，气血郁积，蒸肉为脓，故其痛多于疮之始作时也。脓溃之后，肿退肌宽，痛必渐减而反痛者，此为虚，宜补。亦有秽气所触，宜和解。风寒逼者，宜温散。　　加味十全汤，治痈疽后补气血，进饮食，实为切要。盖脓血出多，阴阳两虚，非此药何以回生起死？惜其不分经络，不载时令，又在识者触类而长之。今之外科，于疮疡肿平痛宽，遂以为安，漫不加省，往往于结痂后两三月或半年，虚证乃见。[43p]

When sores first develop, they appear as swelling, caused by the accumulation of qi and blood, which transforms into pus within the flesh, resulting in more pain than at the beginning of the sore. After the pus is discharged, the swelling recedes and the flesh relaxes; thus, the pain must gradually lessen. If the pain returns, it indicates deficiency, and one should tonify. There may also be cases where foul qi is involved, requiring harmonization. If it is due to an invasion of wind and cold, warmth and dispersal are recommended.

The modified All-Inclusive Decoction is used to replenish qi and blood after treating abscesses, advancing diet is crucial. This is because excessive discharge of pus and blood leads to deficiency in both yin and yang; without this medicine, how can one revive life? It is regrettable that practitioners do not differentiate between channels and meridians, nor do they adhere to seasonal considerations, and thus their understanding is merely superficial. Nowadays in surgery, when the swelling of wounds subsides and the pain eases, practitioners often mistakenly assume all is well without further investigation, resulting in deficiency symptoms appearing two or three months or even half a year after scabbing.[43p]

医者不察，病者不悟，无补益调养之功，因而转成他病者，惜哉！予治一士夫因脚弱求诊，两手俱浮洪稍鼓，饮食如常，惟言问不答，肌上起白屑如麸片。时在冬月，予作极虚处治。询其弟，乃知半年前曾于臂背腿三处，自夏至秋冬，节次生疽，率用五香连翘汤、十宣散与之，今结痂久矣。予为作参芪白朮当归膏，以二陈汤化饮之。三日后尽药一斤，白屑没者大半。病者自喜，呼吸有力，补药应效以渐，而病家反怨药不速应，自作风病论治。炼青礞石二钱半，以青州白丸子作料，煎饮子顿服之。予谏之不听，因而不救，书以警云。[44p]

The physician fails to observe, and the patient does not understand, which results in a lack of beneficial care and adjustments, leading to the transformation of the illness into another. How regrettable! I treated a man who sought help for weak feet; his hands were both swollen and slightly throbbing, his appetite was normal, yet he could not answer my questions, and his skin had white flakes resembling flour. It was winter, and I treated him as if he were extremely weak. Upon inquiring with his brother, I learned that six months prior, he had developed sores on his arm, back, and legs, which had emerged in cycles from summer to autumn and winter. He had been treated with Five-Spice and Forsythia Decoction, and the Ten Xuan Powder, and the sores had long since scabbed over. I prepared a ginseng, astragalus, white atractylodes, and angelica ointment, using Er Chen Decoction to dissolve it. After three days and consuming a pound of the medicine, most of the white flakes disappeared. The patient was pleased, his breathing became strong, and I expected the tonics to show gradual effect; however, the family instead complained that the medicine didn’t work quickly and insisted on treating according to their own theory of wind illness. They refined two and a half qian of green stone and used Qingzhou white pills as the ingredient, boiling it into a decoction for immediate consumption. I advised against this, but they did not listen, and thus he was not saved. I wrote to caution them.[44p]

　　　　　痛证

　　诸疮痛不可忍者，用苦寒药加黄连、黄芩，详上下根梢用及引经药则可。又云：诸疮以当归、黄连为君，连翘、甘草、黄芩为佐。　　诸痛痒疮疡属火。若禀受壮盛，宜四物加大承气汤下之。　　若性急面黑瘦血热之人，因疮而痛，宜四物加黄连、黄芩、大力子、甘草。在下焦者，加黄蘗。若肥胖之人，生疮而痛，乃是湿热，宜防风、羌活、荆芥、白芷、苍朮、连翘，取其风能胜湿。　　诸疮药：脓窠，治热、燥、湿为主，用无名异；干疥，开郁为主，用茱萸。　　虫疮如藓状，退热杀虫为主，芜荑、黑狗脊、白矾、雄黄、硫黄、水银。杀虫，樟脑、松香。头上多，加黄连、方解石、蛇床，定痒杀虫。松皮岩主脓肿，多者加白芷开郁。痛多，加白芷、方解石。虫多，加藜芦、螌蝥。痒多，加枯矾。阴囊疮，加茱萸。湿多，香油调。干痒出血多，加大黄、黄连、猪脂调。红色加黄丹，青色加青黛。虫多，加锡灰、芜荑、槟榔。[45p]

Pain Disorders

For unbearable pain from sores, use bitter and cold medicines combined with Huang Lian and Huang Qin, detailing the application according to the roots and channels involved. It is also said that for all sores, Dang Gui and Huang Lian serve as the main ingredients, with Lian Qiao, Gan Cao, and Huang Qin as assistants.

Sores that are painful and itchy are related to fire. If the individual has a strong constitution, the formula Si Wu should be supplemented with Da Cheng Qi Decoction. For those who are impatient, dark, thin, and suffering from hot blood, resulting in pain from sores, use Si Wu with Huang Lian, Huang Qin, Da Li Zi, and Gan Cao. For issues in the lower region, add Huang Bo. If the person is overweight, and experiencing painful sores due to damp heat, use Fang Feng, Qiang Huo, Jing Jie, Bai Zhi, Cang Zhu, and Lian Qiao to counteract the damp condition.

For various sores: for pus-filled conditions, focus on treating heat, dryness, and dampness, using unnamed medicines; for dry eczema, emphasize dispersing stagnation with Wu Yao. For insect sores resembling moss, prioritize relieving heat and killing parasites using Wu Yao, Hei Gou Ji, Bai Fan, Xiong Huang, and Sulfur, with Mercurial compounds for pest control, and add camphor and rosin as necessary.

If there is a heavy presence on the head, add Huang Lian, Fang Jie Shi, and She Chuang to relieve itching and kill parasites. For abscesses, use Song Pi Yan, adding Bai Zhi to alleviate stagnation if there is excess. In cases of severe pain, increase Bai Zhi and Fang Jie Shi. If insect presence is high, incorporate Li Lu and Chan Mao. For excessive itching, add Ku Fan. For scrotal sores, apply Wu Yao. In cases of dampness, adjust with fragrant oil.

For dry itch accompanied by significant bleeding, add Da Huang, Huang Lian, and pig fat for adjustment. If red, add Huang Dan; if blue, use Qing Dai. For a heavy presence of insects, include Xi Hui and Wu Yao along with Bing Lang.[45p]

　　　　　疔疮

　　疔，用针刀镞破头上，以蟾酥敷之，后用菉豆、野菊，莎末酒调，饮醉睡觉，即定痛热除，不必去疔，自愈也。　　治一切疗疮，用紫梗菊花，根茎叶皆可，研碎取汁，滴口中饮之。
古今图书集成医部全录卷三百六十

外科痈疽疔毒门

　　　　外科精义 【元　齐德之】

　　　　　诊候入式法

　　夫医者，人之司命也。脉者，医之大业也。盖医家苟不明脉，则如冥行索途，动致颠覆矣。夫大方脉、妇人、小儿风科，必先诊视后，对证处药。独疮科之流，多有不诊其脉候，专攻治外，或有证候疑难，别召方脉诊察，于疮科之辈，甘当浅陋之名。噫！其小哉如是！原夫疮肿之生，皆由阴阳不和，气血凝滞，若不诊候，何以知阴阳勇怯血气聚散耶？由是观之，则须信疗疮肿于诊候之道，不可阙也。[46p]

Boils and Sores

For boils, puncture the head with a needle or knife and apply toad venom. Afterwards, mix mung beans and wild chrysanthemums with wine from a type of grass, drink until intoxicated, and sleep. The pain and heat will definitely subside without needing to remove the boil; it will heal itself. To treat all kinds of sores, use purple stem chrysanthemums, where the roots, stems, and leaves can all be used. Grind them to extract the juice and drop it into the mouth to drink.

Essential Principles of Surgery 【Yuan, Qi Dezhi】

Diagnosis and Treatment Method

The physician is the guardian of life. The pulse is the main pursuit of medicine. If a physician does not understand the pulse, it is like walking in the dark without a path, easily leading to disaster. The diagnosis for major pulses, women, and children’s ailments must be carried out before prescribing medicine. However, in the case of sores, many practitioners tend to overlook pulse diagnosis, focusing solely on external treatment. When faced with difficult conditions, they may call for specific pulse diagnoses but still begrudgingly accept superficial understanding. Alas, how trivial this is! The occurrence of boils and swellings arises from the imbalance of yin and yang, leading to stagnation of qi and blood. Without diagnosis, how can one discern the strengths and weaknesses of yin and yang or the gathering and dispersing of blood and qi? From this perspective, it is essential to trust the treatment of sores and swellings to the method of diagnosis; it cannot be neglected.[46p]

历观古今治疗疮肿方书甚多，其间诊候之法，略而未详，比夫诸科，甚有灭裂。愚虽不才，辄取《黄帝素问》、《难经》、《灵枢》、《甲乙》及叔和、仲景、扁鹊、华佗、《千金》、《外台》、《圣惠》、《总录》古今名医诸家方论之中，诊候疮肿之说，简编类次，贯成篇帙。首裁诊候入式之法，次论血气色脉参应之源，后明脉之名状，所主证候及疮肿逆从之方，庶使为疮肿科者，览此则判然可晓，了无疑滞于胸次，一朝临疾，诊候至此，则察逆从，决成败，若黑白之易分耳。[47p]

Throughout history, there have been many texts on the treatment of sores and swellings, but the methods of diagnosis and symptoms have often been briefly mentioned and lacking in detail, particularly when compared to other medical specialties. Although I am unskilled, I have endeavored to compile insights from works such as the "Huangdi Neijing," "Nanjing," "Lingshu," "Jia Yi," as well as from famous medical practitioners like Shuhe, Zhongjing, Bianque, Huatuo, and writings like "Qianjin," "Wai Tai," "Shenghui," and "Zonglu," focusing on the diagnosis of sores and swellings.

I have organized these concepts, first outlining the methods of diagnosis, then discussing the sources of blood, qi, and the colors and pulses associated with them. Finally, I clarify the names and characteristics of pulses, their related symptoms, and the responses seen in sores and swellings. This should help those in the field of sore and swelling treatment to clearly understand what they read without any uncertainty, so that when faced with a patient, they can diagnose effectively, assessing the situation with clarity, as straightforward as distinguishing black from white.[47p]

　　　　　荣卫色脉参应之法

　　夫天地之道曰阴与阳，阴阳在人曰血与气。盖血者荣也，气者卫也。荣者荣于中，卫者卫于外。所以荣行脉中，卫行脉外。脉者，血气之先也。血非脉则焉能荣于中？气非脉则焉能卫于外？二者相资而行，内则通于五脏六腑十二经络，外则濡于九窍四肢百节万毛，昼夜循行，如环无端，以成其度，会于寸口，变见于脉。故曰：气血者，人之神也。脉者，气血之神也。所以治病之始，五决为纪。盖五决者，五脏之色脉也。脉应于内，色应于外，其色之与脉，当相参应。故曰，能合色脉可以万全也。凡为医先须调明色脉，若于此不精，虽聪慧辩博，亦不足委也。[48p]

The Method of Correlating Color and Pulse for Nourishing and Protecting

The principle of heaven and earth is known as Yin and Yang; within humans, Yin and Yang manifest as blood and Qi. Blood represents nourishment, while Qi represents defense. Nourishment resides within, and defense resides outside, thus nourishment flows within the meridians and defense circulates externally. The pulse is the precursor of blood and Qi. Without the pulse, how can blood nourish within? Without the pulse, how can Qi protect outside? The two support and move together, internally connecting to the five organs, six bowels, and twelve meridians, and externally moistening the nine orifices, four limbs, hundreds of joints, and countless hairs, circulating day and night in an endless loop, forming a continuous rhythm that converges at the wrist and manifests in the pulse. Therefore, it is said: Qi and blood are the spirit of a person. The pulse is the spirit of Qi and blood. Thus, at the beginning of treating illness, the five determinants serve as the criterion. The five determinants are the color pulses of the five organs. The pulse corresponds within while the color corresponds outside; the correspondence of color and pulse should be mutually referenced. Hence, it is said that a harmonious combination of color and pulse can ensure total well-being. When practicing medicine, one must first regulate and clarify color and pulse; if one is not proficient in this, even if they are intelligent and knowledgeable, they are still unworthy of trust.[48p]

　　　　　论持手诀消息法

　　夫诊候脉法，常以平旦为纪。阴气未散，阳气未动，饮食未进，血气未乱，经脉未隆，络脉调匀，故乃可诊有过之脉。若遇仓卒患病，不拘此论。《内经》所谓持脉有道，以虚静为保，但可澄神静虑，调息凝心，视精明，察五色，听音声，问所苦，方始按寸尺，别浮沉，以此参照，可决生死之分矣。复观患人身形长短肥瘦，老少男女，性情缓急，例各不同。故曰：形气相得者生，三五不调者病。谓如室女尼冠脉当濡而弱，婴儿孺子之脉细而疾，三四岁者，呼吸之间脉当七八至为平，比夫常人特不同耳。[49p]

On the Method of Holding the Pulse and Observing Conditions

The practice of diagnosing by observing the pulse typically begins at dawn. At this time, the yin energy has not dispersed, the yang energy has not stirred, food has not yet been ingested, blood flow is not chaotic, the meridians are not prominent, and the collateral vessels are balanced. Therefore, it is possible to diagnose pulses that are in excess. However, in cases of sudden illness, one should not rigidly adhere to this principle. As mentioned in the "Internal Classic," the proper method of pulse-taking is to maintain a state of tranquility and calmness. One should focus the mind, regulate breath, observe the essence clearly, examine the five colors, listen to sounds, and inquire about the patient's suffering; only then should one begin to press on the pulse at the wrist and differentiate between floating and sinking pulses. By using this approach, one can make distinctions that may determine life and death.

Furthermore, one should consider the patient's body shape—tall or short, fat or thin, young or old, male or female—as well as their temperament, which can vary greatly. Thus, it is said: those whose body and energy are well-matched will thrive, while those with imbalances will fall ill. For example, the pulse of a maiden should be soft and weak, while that of an infant should be fine and rapid. For children around three to four years old, the pulse should be around seven to eight beats; this is considered normal and is quite different from that of an average adult.[49p]

大抵男子先诊左手，女子先诊右手。男子左脉大则顺，女子右脉大则顺。大凡诊脉，先以中指揣按掌后高骨，骨下为关，得其关位，然后齐下左右两指。若臂长人疏排其指，若臂短人密排其指。三指停稳，先诊上指曰寸口，浮按消息之，中按消息之，重按消息之，上竟消息之，下竟消息之，推而外之消息之，推而内之消息之，然后先关后尺消息之，一一类此。若诊得三部之中，浮沉滑濇，迟疾不调，何病所主，外观形色，内察脉候，参详处治，以忠告之。不可轻言谈笑，乱说是非，左右瞻望，举止忽略，此庸医也。[50p]

Generally, men should first diagnose the left hand, while women should first diagnose the right hand. If a man's left pulse is strong, it indicates order; if a woman's right pulse is strong, it indicates order. When diagnosing the pulse, begin by using the middle finger to press against the high bone at the back of the palm; below the bone is the "Guan" position. Once the Guan position is identified, place the fingers evenly on both sides. For individuals with long arms, space the fingers widely; for those with short arms, space them closely. Once the three fingers are stable, first diagnose the upper finger, called "Cunkou". Press lightly to feel the response, then press moderately, heavily, and finally, observe responses from above and below. Assess by pushing outward and inward, then proceed to examine the "Guan" and "Chi" positions in the same manner. If you find differences in the three sections between floating and sinking, slippery and rough, slow and fast, and an imbalance in the pulse, identify the related illness by examining the external appearance and internal pulse conditions. Take a detailed approach to diagnosis and treatment, providing faithful advice. One must not speak lightly or laugh, engage in idle gossip, glance about, or behave carelessly; such conduct is characteristic of an incompetent physician.[50p]

　　　　　三部所主腑脏病论

　　夫诊候之道，医者之难精也，若非灯下辛苦，勤于记诵，参师访友，昼夜不遑，造次颠沛，寤寐俯仰，存心于此，安能知神圣之妙哉？古人曰：按其脉，知其疾，命曰神，以悟其探赜索隐之妙也。又曰：切其脉，治其病，谓之巧。以明其指别之功也。盖三指相去毫厘之近，主病若千里之远。观夫指别之功，世人固以为难，命曰神，岂容易可至哉？尝考于经，脉有三部，寸关尺也，从鱼际至高骨，却行一寸曰寸，从寸上一分曰鱼际，从寸至尺曰尺泽，寸后尺前为关，关前为阳，即寸口也。关后为阴，即尺脉也。[51p]

The Theory of Diagnosing Diseases based on the Three Positions of the Pulse

The way of diagnosing signs is difficult for physicians. Unless they toil diligently beneath the lamp, commit their knowledge to memory, consult with teachers and friends, and remain unceasing both day and night—fluctuating between wakefulness and sleep, bowing and looking up, with their minds focused on this—how can they comprehend the profound mysteries? The ancients said: "By feeling the pulse, one can know the disease; this is called 'spirit,' for it helps one understand the intricacies of inquiry." They also said: "By palpating the pulse to treat the disease, this is referred to as 'skill,' which clarifies the importance of distinguishing the nuances of the pulse." Indeed, the three fingers may seem close apart by mere millimeters, yet they point to diseases that could be thousands of miles away. Observing the skill of distinguishing between pulses, people consider it to be challenging and call it 'spirit'; is it not something that can be easily achieved? Upon examining the classics, there are three positions of the pulse: Inch, Bar, and Foot. From the base of the thumb to the highest bone, we travel one inch to signify 'Inch'; one division above 'Inch' indicates the base of the thumb; from 'Inch' to 'Foot' indicates 'Foot Depth.' The area after 'Inch' and before 'Foot' corresponds to the 'Bar,' where the front of the Bar is Yang, represented by the Inch position. The back of the Bar is Yin, represented by the Foot position.[51p]

阳出阴入，以关为界。寸主上焦头手皮毛，关主中焦腹及腰，尺主下焦小腹及足，此三部所主之大略也。左右两手三部，谓之六脉也。又有人迎、气口、神门，所主又各不向。盖左手关前曰人迎，右手关前曰气口，两关之后一分，即曰神门。故脉法赞曰：肝心出左，肺脾出右。肾与命门，俱出尺部。魂魄谷神，皆见寸口。所谓左手关前，心之部也，其经手少阴，与手太阳为表里，小肠合为腑。左手关上，肝之部也，其经足厥阴，与足少阳为表里，胆合为腑。左手关后，肾之部也，其经足少阴，与足太阳为表里，膀胱合为腑。[52p]

The yang emerges and the yin enters, with the guan (barrier) as the boundary. The cun (inch) corresponds to the upper jiao's head, hand, and skin; the guan corresponds to the middle jiao's abdomen and waist; and the chi (foot) corresponds to the lower jiao's lower abdomen and feet. These three areas represent the major parts. The left and right hands correspond to three parts each, referred to as the six vessels. Additionally, there are the renying (human meeting), qikou (qi mouth), and shenmen (spirit door), each having different associations. The left hand in front of the guan is called renying, and the right hand in front of the guan is called qikou; the division after both guans is called shenmen. Thus, the pulse commentary states: the liver and heart are associated with the left, while the lungs and spleen are associated with the right. The kidneys and mingmen (life gate) both correspond to the chi. The soul and spirit and the valley spirit are all seen at the cun. The area in front of the left hand guan corresponds to the heart, whose meridian is associated with the shaoyin (lesser yin) and corresponds with the taiyang (greater yang) of the hand, with the small intestine as its fu (organ). The area above the left hand guan corresponds to the liver, whose meridian is associated with the jueyin (absolute yin) of the foot, corresponding with the shaoyang (lesser yang) of the foot, with the gallbladder as its fu. The area behind the left hand guan corresponds to the kidneys, whose meridian is associated with the shaoyin of the foot, corresponding with the taiyang of the foot, with the bladder as its fu.[52p]

右手关前，肺之部也，其经手太阴，与手阳明为表里，大肠合为腑。右手关上，脾之部也，其经足太阴，与足阳明为表里，胃合为腑。右手关后，命门之部也，其经手厥阴，与手少阳为表里，三焦合为腑。此谓六部所主脏腑十二经之义也。又脉要精微论曰：尺内两旁，则季胁也。尺外以候肾，尺里以候腹。中附上，左外以候肝，内以候膈，右外以候胃，内以候脾。上附上，右外以候肺，内以候胸中，左外以候心，内以候膻中，前以候前，后以候后。上竟上者，胷喉中事也。下竟下者，小腹腰股膝胫足中事也。粗大者，阴不足阳有余，为热中也。[53p]

The right wrist, at the front, corresponds to the lung region, associated with the hand’s Taiyin channel, which is paired with the hand’s Yangming, together forming the large intestine as a hollow organ. The right wrist, at the top, corresponds to the spleen region, associated with the foot’s Taiyin channel, which is paired with the foot’s Yangming, together forming the stomach as a hollow organ. The right wrist, at the back, corresponds to the Mingmen region, associated with the hand’s Jueyin channel, which is paired with the hand’s Shaoyang, together forming the Sanjiao as a hollow organ. This discusses the significance of the six regions governing the organs and the twelve channels.

Furthermore, the "Essentials of Pulse Diagnosis" states: on both sides within the wrist, it pertains to the lower ribs; the outer wrist assesses the kidneys, while the inner wrist assesses the abdomen. Above the wrist, the outer side examines the liver, and the inner side examines the diaphragm; on the right, the outer side checks the stomach, and the inner side checks the spleen. Above that, the outer side checks the lungs, and the inner side assesses the chest; on the left, the outer side checks the heart, and the inner side assesses the Zhongdan (the middle of the chest), the front checks the front, and the back checks the back. The uppermost area relates to matters of the throat and chest, while the lowermost refers to matters of the lower abdomen, waist, thigh, knee, and foot. If the pulse is coarse and large, it indicates a deficiency in Yin and an excess in Yang, which corresponds to internal heat.[53p]

来疾去徐，上实下虚，为厥颠疾；来徐去疾，上虚下实，为恶风也。故中风者，阳气受也。有脉俱沉细数者，少阴厥也。沉细数散者，寒热也。浮而散者为眴仆。诸浮而数者，皆在阳，为热，其有躁者在手。脉诸细而沉者，皆在阴，则为骨痛，其有静者在足。数动一代者，病在阳之脉也，泄及便脓血。诸过者，切之濇者阳气有余也，滑者阴气有余也。阳气有余为身热无汗，阴气有余为多汗身寒。阴阳有余，则无汗身寒。推而外之，内而不外者，有心腹积也。推而内之，外而不内者，身有热也。推而上之，上而不下者，腰足清也。推而下之，下而不上者，头项痛也。按之至骨脉气少者，腰脊痛而身有痹也。[54p]

When coming quickly and going slowly, with fullness above and emptiness below, it indicates a rapid condition; when coming slowly and going quickly, with emptiness above and fullness below, it indicates a harmful wind. Therefore, when one suffers from a wind stroke, the yang qi is affected. If the pulse is both deep and thin, it indicates a condition of lesser yin deficiency. If the pulse is deep, thin, and scattered, it indicates issues of cold and heat. A floating and scattered pulse indicates a collapse. All floating and rapid pulses are in the yang and suggest heat, and those accompanied by agitation are found in the hands. When the pulse is both thin and deep, it relates to the yin, suggesting bone pain, with still conditions in the feet. A rapid pulse that changes is indicative of a disease in the yang pulse, leading to discharge of purulent blood. Those in excess are indicative of abundant yang qi, while slippery pulses show excessive yin qi. An abundance of yang qi results in heat in the body without sweating, while excess yin qi leads to excessive sweating and coldness. When both yin and yang are in excess, there is no sweating and coldness in the body. Pushing outward without revealing internal conditions suggests a build-up in the heart and abdomen. Pushing inward without revealing outward signs suggests heat in the body. If you push upwards and there is no downward movement, it indicates clarity in the waist and feet. Pushing downwards without upward response suggests pain in the head and neck. Pressing down to the bone or the pulse with little qi indicates pain in the lower back and a sensation of numbness throughout the body.[54p]

已上诸疾，若非指明心了，乌可得而尽其妙也？又平人气象论曰：一呼脉再动，一吸脉亦再动，呼吸定息，脉行五动，闰以太息，不大不小，不长不短，不滑不濇，不浮不沉，不迟不数，命曰平人。平人者，不病也。盖平人之常气禀乎胃。胃气者，平人之常气也。所以人常禀气于胃，故脉以胃气为本也。《正理论》曰：谷入于胃，脉道乃行。《灵枢经》云：胃为水谷之海也。又曰：脉应四时曰平。信夫四时之脉，皆以胃气为本，谓春弦、夏洪、秋毛、冬石。春之脉微弦曰平。余皆仿此。逆四时则病矣。[55p]

The aforementioned ailments, if not clearly understood, how can one fully grasp their subtleties? Moreover, according to the discussions on the healthy person’s vital signs: when one inhales, the pulse moves once; when one exhales, the pulse also moves once. When breathing is steady, the pulse moves five times, harmonizing with the essence of vitality. It should be neither large nor small, neither long nor short, neither smooth nor rough, neither floating nor sinking, neither slow nor rapid; this is called the healthy person. A healthy person is one who is not ill. This is because the regular vital energy of a healthy person comes from the stomach. The stomach's energy is the fundamental energy of a healthy person. Therefore, since people consistently draw energy from the stomach, the pulse is fundamentally based on stomach energy. The "Classic of Correct Theories" states: when grain enters the stomach, the pulse pathway circulates. The "Spirit Pivot Classic" says: the stomach is the sea of water and grains. It also states: the pulse responds according to the four seasons, which indicates health. Indeed, the pulses corresponding to the four seasons are all based on stomach energy, namely: spring is the string-like pulse, summer is the rushing pulse, autumn is the hairy pulse, and winter is the stony pulse. The pulse in spring, subtle and string-like, is termed healthy. The others follow this pattern. Failing to adhere to the four seasons results in illness.[55p]

若诊妇人之脉，妊身则慎勿乱投汤散。其妇人之脉，诊得少阴脉动甚，则有子也。又曰：阴搏阳别，有子也。又曰：身汗而无脉者，即有妊也。治重身者，问其月事，观其体貌，然后主治，不可忽也。又经曰：察色按脉，先别阴阳。盖阴阳者，天地之道也。是以治病者，必求其本，本于阴阳寒暑四时五脏之根也。以脉言之，则浮沉也。以部言之，则尺寸也。经故云：脉者阴阳之法，以应五脏。是谓呼出心与肺，吸入肾与肝，呼吸之间，脾受谷味，其脉在中也。以浮沉论之，则曰浮者阳也，沉者阴也。应在脏腑，则浮而大散者心也，浮而短濇者肺也，所以心肺俱浮也。[56p]

When diagnosing a woman's pulse, if she is pregnant, one must be careful not to indiscriminately prescribe decoctions or powders. If the pulse of the woman indicates a very active shaoyin pulse, she is likely to be with child. Furthermore, it is said: when yin overtakes yang, there is a child. It is also stated: a body that sweats but has no pulse is indeed pregnant. In treating a heavily pregnant individual, it is essential to inquire about her monthly cycle and observe her physical appearance before deciding on the treatment; this must not be neglected. The texts further state: observe color and feel the pulse, first differentiate between yin and yang. For yin and yang are the principles of heaven and earth. Therefore, those who treat illness must seek the root cause, which lies in the principles of yin, yang, seasonal changes, and the five internal organs. In terms of pulse, it refers to its floating and sinking nature. In anatomical terms, it refers to its measurements. The texts therefore say: the pulse is a method of yin and yang that corresponds to the five internal organs. This is to say, when exhaling, it involves the heart and lungs, and when inhaling, it involves the kidneys and liver; in the cycle of breathing, the spleen assimilates food flavors, and its pulse resides in between. Considering floating and sinking, the floating represents yang, and the sinking represents yin. In relation to the organs, a pulse that is floating and widely dispersed corresponds to the heart, while a floating and short pulse corresponds to the lungs; hence, both the heart and lungs are considered floating.[56p]

牢而长者肝也，按之而大，举指来实者肾也，所以肝肾俱沉也。迟缓而长者脾也，脾为中州，所以脉在中也。仲景曰：大、浮、数、动、滑，皆阳也；沉、濇、弱、弦、微，皆阴也。阳者热也，阴者寒也。所以寒则脉来沉而迟，热则脉来浮而数。故曰诸数为热，诸迟为寒。无如此验也。《脉经》曰：诸浮为风，诸紧为痛，诸伏为聚，诸弦为饮，芤者失血，长则气治，短则气病，濇则烦心，大则病进，浮为在表，沉为在里，迟为在脏，数为在腑。又形壮脉细，少气不足以息者危。形瘦脉大，胸中气多者毙。形气相得者生，三五不调者病。三部九候皆相失者死。[57p]

The liver is firm and long, its pulse is strong; when pressed down, the kidneys can be felt. Thus, both the liver and kidneys are considered to be sinking. The spleen is slow and long, being situated in the center, hence the pulse is found there. Zhongjing said: A large, floating, rapid, moving, and slippery pulse indicates Yang; a sinking, weak, thin, and subtle pulse indicates Yin. Yang represents heat, while Yin represents cold. Therefore, in cold conditions, the pulse is sinking and slow, and in heat, it is floating and rapid. Thus, it is said that all rapid pulses indicate heat, and all slow pulses indicate cold. This is how one verifies it. The "Pulse Classic" states: all floating pulses indicate wind; all tight pulses indicate pain; all hidden pulses indicate accumulation; all thin pulses indicate thirst. A hollow pulse signifies blood loss; a long pulse indicates the resolution of qi, while a short pulse signifies qi illness. A weak pulse signifies restlessness, a large pulse indicates progression of illness, a floating pulse signifies surface issues, a sinking pulse signifies internal issues, a slow pulse indicates issues in the organs, and a rapid pulse indicates issues in the bowels. Furthermore, a robust body with a thin pulse and insufficient breath is dangerous. A thin body with a large pulse and abundant qi in the chest is fatal. When body and qi complement each other, there is life; when the three or five patterns are not in harmony, there is illness. When the three regions and nine positions are all out of balance, there is death.[57p]

此先圣诊脉之大法也。故曰：凡治病则察其形气色泽治之，无后其时也。所以形气相得者生，色泽以浮者病易已，脉从四时者可治，脉弱以滑者是有胃气，此皆易治也。若形气相失，或色夭不泽，及脉逆四时，或脉实益坚，皆不可治。经所谓必察四难而明告之。又若病热脉静，泄而脉大，脱血脉实，汗后脉躁，此皆难治也。若疮疽之人，脓血大泄，脉滑数者，难治也。凡出脓多，或如清泔，脉滑大散，寒热发渴者，治之无功也。若患肺疮者，咳嗽脓血，脉见洪滑，治之难痊矣。大凡诊脉见浮数，应当发热而反恶寒，虽头项拘急，四肢烦痛，或复战栗渴甚者，但有痛处，欲发疮肿也。[58p]

This is the great method of the sages for diagnosing pulses. Therefore, it is said: In treating illness, one must observe the shape, vitality, color, and texture, and treat accordingly without delay. Those whose shape and vitality are in harmony are alive, while those whose color and texture are superficial are easily afflicted. Pulses that follow the four seasons can be treated, while weak and slippery pulses indicate gastric energy, and these are all easily treated. However, if the shape and vitality are discordant, or if the color is lacking in luster, and the pulse reverses the four seasons, or if the pulse is strong and firm, these cannot be treated. The classic text states that one must observe the four difficulties and clearly inform the patient. Additionally, if the illness is hot with a calm pulse, or if there is diarrhea with a strong pulse, or if there is blood loss with a solid pulse, or if there is restlessness after sweating, these are all difficult to treat. For those with sores or abscesses, if there is a large discharge of pus and blood, and the pulse is slippery and rapid, it is difficult to treat. Generally, if there is a large purulent discharge, or if it resembles clear fluid, and the pulse is slippery and widely dispersed with symptoms of cold, heat, and thirst, treatment will be ineffective. If lung sores are present, with coughing up pus and blood and a pulse that feels surging and slippery, treatment will be difficult for recovery. In general, if the pulse is floating and rapid, there should be fever but a reaction of aversion to cold, accompanied by tension in the head and neck, and discomfort in the limbs, or if there is shivering and severe thirst, there will be a painful area wanting to swell.[58p]

　　　　　脉证名状二十六种所主病证

　　夫脉之大体二十六种，此诊脉之纪纲也。细而论之，毫厘少差，举治必远。总而言之，逆从虚实阴阳而已。两者议之，以要其中。谨于诸家脉法中，撮其机要，剪去繁芜，载其精义。　　浮脉之诊，浮于指下，按之不足，举之有余，再再寻之，状如太过，瞥瞥然见于皮毛间。其主表证，或为风，或为虚。浮而大散者心也，浮而短濇者肺也，浮而数者热也。浮数之脉应发热，其不发热而反恶寒者，疮疽之谓也。[59p]

The Twenty-Six Types of Pulses and Their Corresponding Diagnoses

The pulse can generally be categorized into twenty-six types, which serve as a framework for pulse diagnosis. In detail, even slight discrepancies may lead to significant misdiagnoses. In summary, the analysis revolves around the concepts of Yin and Yang, and the interplay of deficiency and excess. In consideration of various diagnostic traditions, this text condenses their essential points while eliminating superfluities to convey their core meanings.

The floating pulse is felt beneath the fingers; pressing down does not reveal it, but lifting it does; when sought repeatedly, it appears overly pronounced, glancingly observable between the skin and flesh. Its significance relates to superficial conditions, possibly attributable to wind or deficiency. A floating and broadly dispersed pulse indicates issues with the heart, while a floating and short pulse points to the lungs. A floating and rapid pulse suggests heat; if it is rapid without heat but instead accompanied by chills, it indicates sores or ulcers.[59p]

　　洪脉之诊，似浮而大，举按皆泛泛然满三部，其状如水之洪流，波之涌起。其主血实积热疮肿。论曰：脉洪大者，疮疽之病进也。如疮疽结脓未成者，宜下之。脓溃之后，脉见洪大则难治，若自利者，不可救治也。　　滑脉之诊，实大相兼，往来流利如珠，按之则累累然滑也。其主或为热，或为虚，此阳脉也。疮疽之病，脓未溃者，宜内消也。脓溃之后，宜托里也。所谓始为热而终为虚也。　　数脉之诊，按之则呼吸之间，动及六至，其状似滑而数也。若浮而数则表热也，沉而数则里热也。又曰：诸数为热。仲景曰：脉数不时见，则生恶疮也。[60p]

The diagnosis of the flood pulse is characterized by a large and superficial feel, with a broad press that fills all three regions, resembling the rushing flow of water and the surging of waves. It indicates an accumulation of heat and swelling in the blood. It is stated: a large flood pulse suggests the progression of sores and boils. If a sore or boil has yet to form pus, it is advisable to drain it. After the pus has erupted, if the pulse is seen as large and flood-like, treatment is difficult; if there is spontaneous diarrhea, it cannot be treated.

The diagnosis of the slippery pulse is characterized by a combination of fullness and largeness, flowing smoothly like pearls, and when pressed, it feels slippery. It indicates either heat or deficiency; this is a yang pulse. In the case of sores and boils, if the pus has not yet erupted, it is advisable to internally dispel it. Once the pus has erupted, it is advisable to aid in expulsion. This is referred to as beginning with heat and ending in deficiency.

The diagnosis of the rapid pulse, when pressed, moves with breathing, influencing the six positions; it appears slippery and rapid. If it is superficial and rapid, it indicates exterior heat; if it is deep and rapid, it indicates internal heat. Furthermore, it is said: all rapid pulses suggest heat. Zhongjing stated: if the pulse is rapid and not observed at regular times, it indicates the development of severe sores.[60p]

又曰：肺脉洪数则生疮也。诊诸脉洪数者，里欲有脓结也。　　散脉之诊，似浮而散，按之则散而欲去，举之则大而无力。其主气实而血虚，有表无里。疮肿脓溃之后，而烦痛尚未痊退者，诊其脉洪滑粗散，难治也，以其正气虚而邪气实也。又曰：肢体沉重，肺脉大则毙，谓浮散者也。　　芤脉之诊，似浮而软，按之中央空，两边实。其主血虚或为失血疮肿之病。诊得芤脉，脓溃后易治，以其脉病相应也。　　长脉之诊，按之则洪大而长，出于本位。其主阳气有余也。[61p]

It is also said that if the lung pulse is abundant and rapid, it results in sores. When diagnosing a pulse that is abundant and rapid, it indicates that there is likely purulent accumulation inside.

The diagnosis of a scattered pulse appears floating and dispersed; pressing it reveals that it disperses and is prone to leaving; lifting it shows it is large but weak. This indicates that the energy is abundant, but the blood is deficient, with an exterior presence but an interior absence. After sores and swelling have burst with pus, and the pain persists without healing, the pulse will be abundant, slippery, coarse, and scattered, making it difficult to treat due to the deficiency of the righteous Qi and the presence of pathogenic Qi. It is also stated that if the limbs feel heavy and the lung pulse is large, it results in death, which refers to the floating and dispersing pulse.

For the diagnosis of a hollow pulse, it appears floating and soft; when pressed, it is empty in the center but firm on both sides. This indicates blood deficiency or may be indicative of blood loss leading to sores and swelling. If a hollow pulse is detected, it can be treated easily after the pus bursts, as the pulses correspond to the ailment.

In the diagnosis of a long pulse, it feels abundant and long upon pressure, arising from its original position. This indicates excess of Yang Qi.[61p]

伤寒得之，欲汗出自解也。长而缓者，胃脉也，百病皆愈，谓之长则气治也。　　牢脉之诊，按之则实大而弦，且沉且浮，而有牢坚之意。若瘰疬结肿，诊得牢脉者，不可内消也？　　实脉之诊，按举有力而类结曰实。经曰：邪气胜则实，久病则虚。人得此最忌。疮疽之人得此，宜急下之，以其邪气与脏腑俱实故也。　　弦脉之诊，按之则紧而弦、其似紧者为弦，如按弦而不移，紧如内绳而转动，以此为异。春脉浮弦而平，不时见则为饮为痛，主寒主虚。疮疽论曰：弦洪相搏，外紧内热，欲发疮疽也。[62p]

In cases of cold damage, if one desires to sweat it out for relief, the pulse that is long and slow corresponds to the stomach channel; it indicates that all diseases can be cured, which is called 'long' meaning the qi is regulated.

For diagnosing a solid pulse, when pressing it, it feels large and tense, both deep and superficial, conveying a strong solidity. If there are nodules or swellings due to scrofula and a solid pulse is detected, should one not reduce it internally?

In diagnosing a solid pulse, pressing it reveals strength, resembling a knot, thus deemed solid. The classics state: when evil qi prevails, it presents as solid, and in chronic illness, it tends to be vacuous. This condition is most to be avoided. For those suffering from sores and boils who exhibit this pulse, it is advisable to purge urgently, as the evil qi and the organs are both solid.

For diagnosing a wiry pulse, pressing it feels tight and taut; if it appears tense, it is termed wiry. It feels rigid like an unyielding string, and unlike the common sensation of motion, it remains firm. A spring pulse that is floating and wiry but not often observed indicates fluid stagnation leading to pain, signifying coldness and vacuity. In discussions on sores and boils, it is said: a wiry pulse clashes with a surging one, indicating external tension and internal heat, suggesting the impending development of sores and boils.[62p]

　　紧脉之诊，似弦而紧，按之如绳而转动，其主切痛积癖也。疮肿得之，气血沉濇也，亦主痛也。　　濇脉之诊，按之则散而复来，举之则细而不足。脉濇则气濇也，亦主血虚。疮肿溃后，得之无妨也。　　短脉之诊，按举则不及本位。《内经》曰：短则气病，以其无胃气也。诸病脉短，皆难治也。疮肿脉短，真气短也。　　细脉之诊，按之则萦萦如蜘蛛之丝而欲绝，举之如无而似有，细而微，其主亡阳衰也。疮肿之病，脉来细而沉时直者，里虚而欲变证也。[63p]

The examination of the tight pulse feels like a string that is taut; pressing it reveals a rope-like quality that twists. It indicates cutting pain and accumulation. If there is an ulcer or swelling, it reflects stagnation of qi and blood, also implying pain.

The examination of the sluggish pulse shows that pressing it disperses and it returns. When lifted, it feels thin and insufficient. A sluggish pulse indicates stagnation of qi and also suggests blood deficiency. After an ulcer or swelling bursts, this pulse may not be detrimental.

The examination of the short pulse shows that when pressed or lifted, it does not reach its original position. The "Inner Canon" states: a short pulse indicates qi illness, as it lacks stomach qi. Diseases with a short pulse are generally difficult to treat. In cases of ulcers and swellings, a short pulse indicates a deficiency of true qi.

The examination of the thin pulse feels like a web thread that is about to snap when pressed and feels almost absent when lifted, fine and delicate, indicating a decline in yang. In ulcer and swelling diseases, a thin pulse that is deep yet occasionally direct indicates interior deficiency with a tendency to change patterns.[63p]

　　微脉之诊，按之则软小而极微，其主虚也。真气复者生，邪气胜者危。疮肿之病溃后，脉微而匀，乃为瘥也。　　迟脉之诊，按举来迟，呼吸定息，方得三至，其状似缓而稍迟。痼疾得之则善，新疾得之则正气虚惫，疮肿得之溃后自痊。　　缓脉之诊，按举似迟，而稍驶于迟。仲景曰：阳脉浮大而濡，阴脉浮大而濡，阴阳同等谓之缓。脉见长缓，百疾自瘳。凡诸疮肿溃后，其脉濇迟缓者皆易愈，以其脉候相应，是有胃气也。　　沉脉之诊，举之不足，按之方见，如烂绵，其主邪气在脏也。水气得之则逆，此阴脉也。疮肿得之，邪气深也。[64p]

The diagnosis of a fine pulse is that when pressed, it feels soft, small, and extremely subtle, indicating deficiency. If the vital energy is restored, life is possible; if the evil energy prevails, danger arises. After a sore or swelling has ruptured, if the pulse is fine and even, it signifies recovery.

The diagnosis of a slow pulse is that when lifted, it comes up slowly, and only with steady breathing can there be three beats; its appearance is somewhat slow but slightly delayed. In chronic diseases, this pulse is favorable; in new diseases, it indicates exhausted vital energy. After sores or swellings have ruptured, it will heal itself.

The diagnosis of a relaxed pulse shows a resemblance to a slow pulse, but it is slightly quicker. Zhong Jing said: A yang pulse that is floating, large, and moist, and a yin pulse that is also floating, large, and moist, are both referred to as relaxed when yin and yang are equal. A long and relaxed pulse indicates recovery from numerous ailments. Generally, after sores or swellings have ruptured, if the pulse is dry, slow, and relaxed, healing is easy, as the pulse state corresponds to the presence of stomach energy.

The diagnosis of a deep pulse shows inadequacy when lifted; pressing it reveals it feels like rotten cotton, indicating that evil energy resides within the organs. If water energy is involved, it is adverse; this is the yin pulse. In the case of sores or swellings, it signifies deep evil energy.[64p]

　　伏脉之诊，比沉而伏，举之则无，按之至骨方得，与沉相类而邪气益深矣。　　虚脉之诊，按之不足，迟大而软，轻举指下，豁然而空。经曰：脉虚则血虚，血虚生寒，阳气不足也。疮肿脉虚，宜托里和气养血也。　　软脉之诊，按之则如帛在水中，极软而沉细，亦谓之濡。其主胃气弱。疮肿得之，补虚排脓托里。　　弱脉之诊，似软而极微，来迟而似有。仲景曰：微弱之脉，绵绵如泻漆之绝，其主血气俱虚，形精不足。大抵疮家沉迟濡弱，皆宜托里。　　促脉之诊，按之则去来数，时一止而复来。[65p]

The diagnosis of the submerged pulse is characterized by a deep and suppressed feeling; when lifted, it cannot be felt, and pressing it reveals the bone, resembling the submerged type but with the pathogenic qi deeper.

The diagnosis of the empty pulse exhibits an insufficient pressure, slow yet large and soft, lifting the fingers reveals a sudden emptiness beneath. The classics state: "When the pulse is empty, the blood is empty; empty blood generates cold, indicating insufficient yang energy." For ulcers and swellings with an empty pulse, it is advisable to tonify the inside, harmonize qi, and nourish blood.

The diagnosis of the soft pulse feels like silk in water—extremely soft, deep, and fine; it is also termed moist. This indicates weak stomach qi. For ulcers and swellings, one should nourish the deficiency and expel pus.

The diagnosis of the weak pulse resembles the soft pulse but is very faint, coming late and seeming to exist. Zhongjing stated: "The faint and weak pulse feels as fine as the end of a leak; it indicates both blood and qi are deficient, and the body’s essence is insufficient." Generally, for ulcers, the submerged, slow, moist, and weak pulses all warrant inner support.

The diagnosis of the rushing pulse shows a rapid succession, with pauses before returning.[65p]

仲景曰：阳盛则促，主热蓄于里也，下之则和。疮肿脉促，亦急下之。　　结脉之诊，按之则往来迟缓，时一止而复来。仲景曰：阴盛则结。经曰：促结则生，代则死。　　代脉之诊，按之则往来，动则中止不能自还，因而复动者，曰代脉也。代者气衰也，诸病见之不祥。大凡疮肿之病，脉促结者，难治，而况见代脉乎？　　动脉之诊，见于关上，无头尾如豆大，厥厥然而动摇者是也。《脉经》曰：阴阳相搏，故谓之动。动于阳则阳气虚而发厥，动于阴则阴气虚而发热。是阳生于尺而动于寸，阴生于寸而动于尺，不可不辨也。[66p]

Zhongjing said: When yang is strong, it quickens the pulse, indicating heat accumulates internally; if you purge it, it harmonizes. When there are sores and swelling with a rapid pulse, it too must be purged urgently.

In the diagnosis of a knotted pulse, when pressed, it has a slow and intermittent rhythm, sometimes ceasing only to return. Zhongjing said: When yin is strong, it causes knots. The classic states: If the pulse is rapid and knotted, life is present; if it is intermittent, death is imminent.

In the diagnosis of an intermittent pulse, when pressed, it shows a rhythm, but when it moves, it halts and cannot return, and then moves again; this is called an intermittent pulse. An intermittent pulse indicates weakened qi, and its presence in various illnesses is ominous. Generally, diseases of sores and swelling with rapid and knotted pulses are difficult to treat, let alone those with an intermittent pulse.

In the diagnosis of a deep pulse, it is felt at the guan position, without beginning or end, as large as a bean, and it trembles erratically. The “Pulse Classic” states: Yin and yang clash, hence it is called movement. Movement in yang indicates deficient yang qi and leads to fainting; movement in yin indicates deficient yin qi and leads to fever. Yang is generated at the wrist and moves at the inch; yin is generated at the inch and moves at the wrist; this must not be overlooked.[66p]

　　　　　三部脉所主证候

　　夫寸关尺者，脉之位也。浮沉滑濇，脉之体也。奠位分体指文语证者，诊脉之要道也。《脉经》曰：大凡诊候两手三部脉滑而迟，不浮不沉，不长不短，去来齐等者，无病也。　　寸口脉浮者伤风也，紧者伤寒也，弦者伤食也。浮而缓者，中风也。浮而数者，头痛也。浮而紧者，膈上寒，胁下冷饮也。沉而紧者，心下寒而积痛。沉而弱者，虚损也。缓而迟者，虚寒也。微弱者，血气俱虚也。弦者，头痛心下有水也。。双弦者，两胁下痛也。偏绝者，不遂也。俱绝者，不治也。潎潎如羹上肥者，阳气微也。连连如蜘蛛丝者，阳气衰也。　　关主中焦胷腹中事。去来徐而缓者，无病也。浮者，腹满而不欲食，胃虚胀也。滑者，客热在胃也。数者，热结中焦也。[67p]

Symptoms Associated with the Three Regions of Pulse

The "cùn," "guān," and "chǐ" refer to the positions of the pulse. "Fú," "chén," "huá," and "mèn" represent the qualities of the pulse. Establishing the position and understanding the signs indicated by the pulse are the essential methods of diagnosis. The "Pulse Classic" states: Generally, if the pulses in both hands across the three regions are smooth and slow, neither floating nor sinking, neither long nor short, and are even in their rhythm, there is no illness.

A floating pulse at the cùnkǒu indicates a wind injury; a tight pulse indicates a cold injury; a string-like pulse suggests an injury from food. A floating and relaxed pulse indicates a stroke; a floating and rapid pulse indicates a headache. A floating and tight pulse suggests cold above the diaphragm and cold drinks below the ribs. A sinking and tight pulse indicates underlying cold and accumulated pain in the heart area. A sinking and weak pulse indicates deficiency damage; a relaxed and slow pulse suggests cold deficiency; a faint pulse indicates both blood and qi deficiency. A string-like pulse indicates headache with fluid in the heart area. A double string-like pulse suggests pain under both ribs. An incomplete pulse indicates lack of progress; a completely absent pulse suggests no treatment available. A pulse that feels like thick soup indicates weak yang qi; a consistent, thin pulse like spider silk indicates declining yang qi.

The guān region governs matters of the central and abdominal areas. If the pulse is steady and slow, there is no illness. A floating pulse indicates fullness in the abdomen with lack of appetite, suggesting a weak stomach. A slippery pulse indicates heat in the stomach. A rapid pulse indicates heat accumulation in the central region.[67p]

沉伏者，中焦水气或呕逆而吞酸也。弱者，胃气虚也。虽有虚热，不可大攻，须防热去则生寒也。牢而实者，腹满响响，噎塞而不通，或复大痛濇者，气逆也。芤则泻血。濇坚大实，按之不减而有力者，中焦实，有结伏在胃也。微浮者，积食不消，蛔动心悸也。　　尺主下焦腰肾膝胫中事也。尺脉浮者，风热小便难也。沉者，腰背痛而肾气不足。数者，脐下热痛，小便赤色而恶寒也。迟者，下焦寒而阴虚也。紧者，脐下小腹急痛也。缓者，脚弱下肿而痿痹也。弱者，下冷而肾气衰也。软者，脚不收而风痹小便难也。伏者，小腹痛而疝瘕，谷不化也。细者，溏泄而下冷也。芤者，小便濇而血下虚也。牢而小者，足膝寒痹，脚下隐隐疼痛也。细而急者，筋挛不能行也。来而断绝者，男子小腹有滞气也，妇人月水不利也。
　　　　　三部脉所主杂病法诀
[68p]

The沉伏者 indicates that there is water and phlegm in the middle burner, causing nausea and sour regurgitation. The weak refer to deficient stomach qi. Although there may be false heat, one should not attack it vigorously; care must be taken to prevent excess heat from leading to cold. If the pulse is firm and solid, it suggests abdominal fullness with gurgling sounds, blocked flow, and potentially intense pain, indicating qi counterflow. If the pulse is hollow, it may suggest blood loss. A firm, large pulse that does not diminish under pressure and feels strong indicates that the middle burner is solid, with a blockage contained in the stomach. A slightly floating pulse may indicate undigested food, as well as gut disturbances causing anxiety.

The尺脉 relates to the lower burner—waist, kidneys, and shins. A floating pulse indicates difficulties with wind heat affecting urination. A沉 pulse suggests pain in the lower back with insufficient kidney qi. A rapid pulse indicates heat and pain below the navel, with red urine and aversion to cold. A slow pulse signifies cold in the lower burner with yin deficiency. A tight pulse suggests urgent pain in the lower abdomen. A relaxed pulse may indicate weakness in the legs, swelling, or paralysis. A weak pulse points to cold below with declining kidney qi. A soft pulse indicates inability to retract the legs and difficulties with wind-induced paralysis affecting urination. A伏 pulse suggests abdominal pain from hernias, and food fails to digest. A thin pulse signifies loose stools and cold below. A hollow pulse indicates difficult urination with blood loss. A firm and small pulse suggests cold paralysis in the knees with pain in the feet. A thin and rapid pulse indicates muscle spasms making mobility difficult. An intermittent pulse suggests men may have stagnation in the lower abdomen, while women may experience menstrual issues.[68p]

　　夫三部之中，俱见一脉，所主杂病，略而言之。《脉经》曰：阳邪来见浮洪，阴邪来见微细，水谷之邪来见实坚，寒癖之邪来见弦小。又曰：浮而滑者宿食也，短而滑者酒病也，迟而滑者胀满也，洪而大者伤寒也，浮而数者伤风也，浮而急者饮食不消脾不磨也，沉而弦者寒气结而阴痛也，浮而缓者皮肤不仁也，滑而散者瘫痪也，迟而缓者寒症也，浮而濇者霍乱也，弱而濇者反胃也，紧而滑者哇逆也，短而数者心痛也，弦而数者为疟也，紧而急者尸遁也，实小而坚者病在内而冷也，浮滑而紧者病在外而热也，短而急者病在上也，长而缓者病在下也，长而弦者病在肝也，滑而洪者病在心也，微而软者病在脾也，浮而濇者病在肺也，沉而紧者病在肾也。又诀曰：诸浮为风或为虚也，诸紧为痛或为积也，诸濇为痹，诸弦为饮，诸数为热，诸迟为寒，芤则为失血，软则为虚。若脉沉沉泽泽四肢不仁者，亡祟也；或大而搦搦者，社祟也。若脉来乍大乍小乍短乍长者，鬼祟也。[69p]

In the three sections, there is a consistent thread discussing various ailments. The "Pulse Classic" states: Yang pathogens are felt as floating and surging, while Yin pathogens present as subtle and fine. Pathogens from food and water appear as solid and firm, and chills manifest as thin and tight. It further explains: a floating and slippery pulse indicates food stagnation, a short and slippery pulse signals a wine-related illness, a slow and slippery pulse points to bloating, a large and surging pulse suggests cold damage, a floating and rapid pulse indicates a cold from wind, a floating and urgent pulse signifies undigested food and an unrefined spleen, a sinking and tight pulse denotes a buildup of cold and Yin pain, a floating and relaxed pulse indicates skin numbness, a slippery and dispersed pulse signals paralysis, a slow and relaxed pulse points to cold symptoms, a floating and thin pulse indicates cholera, a weak and thin pulse suggests gastroesophageal reflux, a tight and slippery pulse indicates retching, a short and rapid pulse points to heart pain, a tight and rapid pulse indicates malaria, a tight and hurried pulse signifies corpse evocation, a solid yet small and firm pulse indicates a deep internal illness and coldness, a floating, slippery, and tight pulse suggests an external illness with heat, a short and urgent pulse indicates an upper body problem, a long and relaxed pulse suggests a lower body problem, a long and tight pulse indicates liver issues, a slippery and surging pulse signals heart problems, a subtle and soft pulse relates to spleen issues, a floating and thin pulse suggests lung issues, and a sinking and tight pulse indicates kidney problems. Additionally, it notes: all floating pulses can signify wind or deficiency, all tight pulses indicate pain or accumulation, all thin pulses relate to obstruction, all tightness points to fluid retention, all rapid pulses indicate heat, all slow pulses signify cold, a hollow pulse indicates blood loss, and a soft pulse indicates deficiency. If the pulse is deep and dense with numbness in the limbs, it indicates a loss of vitality; if it is large and knotted, it suggests a curse. If the pulse fluctuates between large and small, short and long, it indicates spiritual disturbance.[69p]

　　　　　将护忌慎法

　　大凡有疮疽生，皆只如黍粟粒许大，其状至微，人多不以为急，此蕴大患，宜速辨之，不可自忽。若能防之于未形，理之于未成，或朝觉而夕治，求治于良医，则必无危困矣。若因循慢忽，询于庸医，致令脓血结聚，委之于命，束手待毙，不亦去道远乎？以致筋骨败坏，穿通脏腑，死者十有八九矣，可不慎欤！盖患疮疽之人，托命庸医，任意措置，危殆立至。若用良医，则可保痊愈。[70p]

Caution in Treating Quirks

Generally, when sores or boils appear, they are often only the size of millet or sorghum grains, and their appearance is very slight. Many people do not take this seriously, but this conceals a great danger, and it is advisable to identify it quickly—one should not ignore it.
