　　《元戎》云：疮疡自外而入者不宜灸，自内而出者宜灸。外入者托之而不内，内出者接之而令外。故经云：陷者灸之。灸而不痛，痛而后止其灸。灸而不痛者，先及其溃，所以不痛，而后及良肉，所以痛也。灸而痛，不痛而后止其灸。灸而痛者，先及其未溃，所以痛，而次及将溃，所以不痛也。然此亦约法，因以东垣等法附于左，宜参用之。凡人初觉发背，欲结未结，赤热肿痛，先以湿纸覆其上，立候视之，其纸先干处，即是结痈头也。取大蒜切成片如二三钱厚薄，安于头上，用大艾炷灸之三壮，即换一蒜片，痛者灸至不痛，不痛灸至痛时方住。最要早觉早灸为上。一日二日，十灸十活；三日四日，六七活；五六日，三四活；过七日则不可灸矣。若有十数头作一处生者，即用大蒜研成膏，作薄饼铺头上，聚艾于蒜饼上烧之，亦能活也。[111p]

Moxibustion Method

The "Yuan Rong" states: Sores and ulcers that enter from the outside should not be moxibustioned, while those that arise from the inside should be moxibustioned. External entry should be removed without entering inside, while internal emergence should be connected to allow for outward passage. Therefore, the classics say: "For those that are sunken, moxibustion is needed." If there is no pain during moxibustion, one should stop only after the pain begins. The reason there is no pain during moxibustion is because one first treats the area that is not yet ruptured, causing a lack of sensation, and then addresses the healthy flesh, which causes discomfort.

If there is pain during moxibustion, one should stop only after the pain subsides. The pain indicates the treatment is applied to the area that has not yet ruptured, while the subsequent area that is about to rupture does not cause pain. However, this is merely a general guideline; along with the methods from "East Wall" and others, it is advisable to reference them. When a person first feels the back swelling, which is red, hot, and painful, one should first cover the area with a wet paper and watch. The part of the paper that dries first indicates where the abscess is forming.

Take garlic sliced to thickness of two to three qian, place it on top of the swelling, and moxibustion with a large moxa stick for three rounds. Then replace with another slice of garlic, moxibustion until the pain ceases or, if there is no pain, until pain emerges, at which point one should stop. The key is to recognize the condition early and start moxibustion right away.

If treated within one or two days, it remains highly effective; within three or four days, it is moderately effective; within five or six days, it is less effective; but after seven days, moxibustion should not be performed. If there are ten or more locations forming abscesses at the same spot, mash garlic into a paste, spread it into a thin pancake and place it on the area, burning moxa on top of the garlic pancake can also be effective.[111p]

若背上初发，赤肿一片，中间有一粒如黄粟米头子，便用独蒜切去两头，取中间半寸厚薄，正安于疮上，着艾灸十四壮，多至四十九壮。　　【注　按谓痈疽所发，宜灸之也。然诸疮患久成漏者，常有脓水不绝，其脓不臭，内无歹肉，尤宜用附子浸透，切作大厚三二分于疮上，着艾灸之。仍服内托之药，隔三二日再灸之，不五七次，自然肌肉长满矣。至有脓水恶物渐溃根深者，郭氏治用白面、硫黄、大蒜三物一处捣烂，看疮大小，捻作饼子，厚约三分，于疮上用艾炷灸二十一壮，一灸一易。后隔四五日，方用翠霞锭子并信效锭子互相用之，纴入疮内，歹肉尽去，好肉长平。然后贴收敛之药，内服应病之剂，调理即瘥矣。盖不止宜灸于疮之始发也。大抵始发宜炙，要汗下补养之药对证。至灸冷疮，亦须内托之药切当。设有反逆，不唯不愈，恐致转生他病。】[112p]

If a sore initially appears on the back, with a red and swollen area and a small lump in the middle resembling a grain of millet, take a whole garlic bulb, cut off both ends, and use a piece about half an inch thick, placing it directly on the sore, then apply moxa treatment fourteen times, increasing to a maximum of forty-nine times.

(Note: It is said that for the emergence of furuncles and abscesses, moxibustion is advisable. However, for sores that have long been festering and continuously produce non-foul pus without any rotten flesh, it is particularly beneficial to use aconite, thoroughly soaked, cut into pieces about three to two-tenths of an inch thick, and applied to the sore, followed by moxibustion. Also, take internal medicines, and perform moxibustion again every three to two days, until five to seven times have been done, at which point the muscle will naturally regenerate.

For those with deep-rooted pus and foul substances gradually breaking down, the method by Guo involves using white flour, sulfur, and garlic, all mashed together. Depending on the size of the sore, make into cakes about three-tenths of an inch thick, applying them to the sore with moxa burning twenty-one times, changing the application each time. After four to five days, one may then use the Qingxia and Xinyao products interchangeably, inserting into the sore until all rotten flesh is expelled and healthy tissue begins to grow evenly. Then apply a consolidating medicine and take appropriate internal remedies; once the body is regulated, it will heal.

It is important to note that moxibustion should not only be applied at the initial emergence of the sore. Generally, during the initial stage, it is beneficial to use moxibustion and supportive medicines to promote sweating and nourishment. For treating cold sores, appropriate internal medicines must also be used. If there is any adverse reaction, not only will it not heal, but it may lead to the development of other illnesses.)[112p]

　　　　　攻补法

　　《元戎》云：陷脉为瘘，留连肉腠，营气不从，逆于肉理，乃生痈肿。荣逆血郁，则热聚为脓。《正理论》曰：热之所过，则为痈肿。营气不从，亦有不热者乎？答曰：膏粱之变，芳草之美，金石之过，气血不盛，荣卫之气充满而抑遏不能行，故闭塞血气，腐而为痈也，当泄之以夺盛热之气。若其人饮食疏，精神衰，气血弱，肌肉消薄，营卫之气短促而濇滞，故寒薄腠理，闭郁而为痈肿也，当补之以接虚怯之气，亦当以脉浮沉别之。既得盛衰，泄之则连翘、大黄，补之则内托之类是也。　　 【注　按辨疮疡因热因寒，及气血郁而成，当攻补之法不同，宜与前后诸篇兼看，殆无余蕴矣。但世俗昧此理，而云是疮不是疮，且服五香连翘汤。然或中或否，致悞者多。盖不审形气虚实，疮毒深浅，发表攻里，所因不同故也。今以丹溪先生《外科精要发挥》诸法之义，附于后例之下，庶学者知所鉴焉。】[113p]

Method of Attack and Supplement

The "Yuan Rong" states: When the pulse is trapped, it signifies a fistula, where flesh is entangled, leading to the blockage of vital energy, which then turns backwards against the flesh's structure and results in abscesses and swellings. If the nourishing energy is stagnant and the blood is prolonged, heat gathers into pus. The "Zheng Li Lun" states: Where heat flows, there are abscesses and swellings. Is it possible for nourishing energy to not follow, yet still not be hot? The answer is: The transformation of rich foods, the beauty of fragrant herbs, the excess of metals and stones, causes the energy and blood to not flourish, while the protective and nourishing energies become full but are restrained and unable to move, thereby blocking the blood and energy which then decays and turns into an abscess; it should be dispelled to remove the accumulated heat. If a person has a sparse diet, weak spirit, deficient energy and blood, with thin and emaciated muscles, the protective and nourishing energies short and stagnant, resulting in cold and thin structures that are closed and obstructed leading to abscesses and swellings; thus, they should be supplemented to connect with the weak and cowardly energy. The distinctions in the pulse, whether floating or sinking, should also be recognized. Once the excess and deficiency are understood, dispelling can be achieved using substances like Forsythia and Rhubarb, while supplementation can be approached with internal tonics.

Note: The differentiation of sores caused by heat or cold, and the blockage caused by stagnant energy and blood, necessitates different methods of attack and supplementation, which should be compared with previous and subsequent texts for a comprehensive understanding. However, the common understanding in society often misses this principle, claiming certain conditions are sores while incorrectly administering Five Spice Forsythia Decoction. This leads to mixed outcomes due to a lack of discernment in the deficiency or excess of form and energy, as well as the depth of sores and toxins, and the differing causes of treatments for external vs. internal issues. Therefore, regarding the teachings of Master Danxi in "Essentials of External Medicine," the principles outlined should be appended for the learners' reference.[113p]

　　　　　分三因

　　陈无择云：发背痈疽者，该三因而有之。论曰：痈疽瘰疬，不问虚实寒热，皆由气郁而成。经亦云：气宿于经络，与血俱濇而不行，壅结为痈疽。不言热之所作而后成痈者，此乃内因喜怒忧思有所郁而成也。身有热，被风冷搏之，血脉凝泣不行，热气壅结而成，亦有阴虚阳气凑袭，寒化为热，热盛则肉腐为脓者，此亦外因寒热风湿所伤而成也。又服丹石及炙煿酒面温床厚被所致，又尽力房室，精虚气竭所致者，此乃不因内外所伤而成也，故知三因备也。　　 【注　按所分三因虽备，但未具疮疡之邪，在经在表在里之异，故其治亦不能详备也。】[114p]

On the Three Causes

Chen Wuze states: Those who develop abscesses are affected by three causes. It is stated: Abscesses, boils, and scrofula arise from stagnation of qi, regardless of whether they are caused by deficiency or excess, cold or heat. The classics also say: Qi, stagnating in the meridians and congealing with blood, fails to circulate and leads to abscess formation. It does not specify that heat must be present for an abscess to form; this arises from internal factors such as pent-up emotions of joy, anger, worry, or thought. When the body has heat and is struck by wind and cold, the blood vessels become stagnant and fail to circulate, leading to the blockage of heat gases that results in abscesses. Additionally, when a deficiency of yin allows yang qi to attack, or cold transforms into heat, excessive heat can cause flesh to decay and turn into pus. This too is an external cause caused by cold, heat, wind, and dampness. Furthermore, cases resulting from the intake of dan stone and consuming roasted wine, as well as excessive efforts in intimate activities leading to depletion of essence and qi, arise from internal and external injuries, thus indicating the presence of all three causes.

Note: Although the division of the three causes is comprehensive, if the pathogens of sores and abscesses are not present, and if there are distinctions in the different layers (surface and interior), then the treatment cannot be exhaustively detailed.[114p]

　　　　　阴滞于阳则生痈阳滞于阴则生疽
　　丹溪曰：《精要》云，阳滞于阴，脉浮洪弦数；阴滞于阳，脉沉细弱濇。阳滞以寒治之，阴滞以热治之。切详其意，阳滞阴滞当作热治寒治。求之寒热，固可作阴阳论，于阴于阳，分明是于气于血，他无可言也。热滞于气，固无寒滞耶？寒滞于血，固无热滞耶？何寒不能伤气，热不能伤血耶？以予观之，气为阳，行脉外；血为阴，行脉内。相并分派，周流循环，一身无停止谓之脉。一呼脉行三寸，一吸脉行三寸，呼吸定息，共得六寸，一身通行八十一丈。得热则行速而太过，得寒则行迟而不及。[115p]

When yin stagnates in yang, it creates carbuncles; when yang stagnates in yin, it creates sores.

Danxi said: "The Essentials state that when yang is stagnant in yin, the pulse is floating, surging, and rapid; when yin is stagnant in yang, the pulse is deep, thin, weak, and hesitant. Yang stagnation is treated with cold, while yin stagnation is treated with heat. To understand this more deeply, the stagnation of yang in yin should be treated with heat, and the stagnation of yin in yang should be treated with cold.

When searching through cold and heat, it can indeed be analyzed as a theory of yin and yang; regarding yin and yang, it is distinctly related to qi and blood, with nothing more to be said. If heat stagnates in qi, can there be no cold stagnation? If cold stagnates in blood, can there be no heat stagnation? Why can cold not harm qi, and heat not harm blood?

From my observation, qi is yang, operating in the exterior of the pulse; blood is yin, moving in the interior of the pulse. Together, they circulate and flow without interruption, creating what we call the pulse. With each exhalation, the pulse moves three inches, and with each inhalation, it also moves three inches. The rhythm of breathing continuously amounts to six inches, circulating throughout the entire body, which is 81 zhang (a unit of length). When heat is present, movement is quick and excessive; when cold is present, movement is slow and inadequate."[115p]

五味之厚，七情之偏，运气为滞，津液稠厚，积而久也，为饮为痰，渗入脉内，血为所乱，因而凝浊，运行冱泣，或为沸腾，此阴滞于阳也，正血滞于气也。气病，今人或以药助邪，病上生病，血之病日增，溢出脉外，隧道隘塞，升降有妨，运化失令，此阳滞于阴也，正气滞于血也。病分寒热者，当是禀受之素偏，虚邪之杂合，岂可以阳为热，阴为寒耶？浮洪弦数，气病之脉也。岂可遽以此作热论？沉细弱濇，血病之脉，岂可遽以此作寒论？此万病之根本，岂止疥癣疮疡痈疽而已？幸相评其是否。[116p]

The richness of flavors, the skewness of emotions, the stagnation of qi leads to thick fluids that accumulate over time, becoming either drink or phlegm, seeping into the meridians, causing chaos in the blood, resulting in turbidity, and then either causing boiling or coldness. This is the stagnation of yin in yang, and the proper blood stagnating in qi. Regarding qi-related illnesses, people today may assist the pathogenic influence with medication, leading to the emergence of new diseases, causing blood-related issues to increase daily, overflowing outside the meridians, obstructing pathways, hindering ascension and descent, and disrupting normal transformation—a case of yang stagnating in yin, and proper qi stagnating in blood. When distinguishing between cold and heat diseases, it is essential to consider the inherent predispositions and the mixtures of deficiencies and pathogenic factors. Can we simply equate yin with cold and yang with heat? The floating, rapid, and wiry pulse indicates qi-related illness. Should we hastily label this as a heat condition? The deep, thin, and weak pulse points to blood-related illness. Should we then hastily label this as a cold condition? This is the root of countless diseases; it is not limited to just scabies, sores, carbuncles, or abscesses. It is important to evaluate their correctness.[116p]

　　　　　明本末

　　东垣曰：生气通天论云，营气不从，逆于肉理，乃生痈肿。又云：膏粱之变，足生大疔，受如持虚。阴阳应象论云：地之湿气感则害人皮肉筋脉。是言湿气外伤则营气不行，荣卫者，皆营气之所经营也。营气者，胃气也，运气也。营气为本，本逆不行，为湿气所坏而为疮疡也。膏粱之变，亦是言厚滋味过度，而使营气逆行，凝于经络为疮疡也。此邪不在表，亦不在里，唯在其经中道病也。以上《内经》所说，俱言因营气逆而作也。遍看诸疮疡论中，多言二热相搏，热化为脓者，有只言热化为脓者，又言湿气生疮，寒化为热而为脓者，此皆疮疽之源也。[117p]

The Principles of Vital Energy

Dongyuan states: The theory of vital energy communicating with heaven indicates that when the nourishing energy is obstructed, it goes against the principles of the flesh, leading to the formation of boils and swellings. It also mentions that a diet rich in fatty and fine foods can cause serious sores and ailments like a false void. The theory of yin and yang influence states that the moist conditions of the earth negatively affect a person's skin, flesh, and muscles. This means that external dampness causes the nourishing energy to stagnate, and both the protective and nourishing energies are governed by this vital energy. The nourishing energy is derived from the stomach and is essential for circulation. When this energy is obstructed and adversely affected by dampness, it results in sores and ulcerations. The issue of excessive richness and flavor in food refers to how it causes the nourishing energy to flow in reverse, accumulating in the meridians and leading to sores and ulcers. This pathogenic factor is neither external nor internal, but exists primarily as a disease within the meridians. The aforementioned statements from the "Inner Canon" highlight that conditions arise from the obstruction of vital energy. A comprehensive examination of various discussions on sores and ulcers reveals many references to the interplay of two types of heat, the transformation of heat into pus, as well as instances where heat transforms into pus due to moisture, or cold transforms into heat resulting in pus; these all represent the root causes of sores and carbuncles.[117p]

宜于所见部分，用引经药，并兼见证中分阴阳证，先泻营气，是其本，本逆助火，湿热相合，败坏肌肉而为脓血者，此治之次也，宜远取诸物以比之。一岁之中，大热无过夏，当时诸物皆不坏烂者，而坏于交秋湿令大行之际也。近取诸身，热病在身，止显热而不败坏肌肉，此理明矣。标本不得，邪气不服。言一而知百者，可以为上工矣。　　营气不从，逆于肉理，乃生疮痈。且营气者，胃气也。饮食入于胃，先输于脾而朝于肺，肺朝百脉，次及皮毛，先行阳道，下归五脏六腑，而气口成寸矣。今富贵之人，不知其节，以饮食肥醲之类，杂以厚味，日久太过，其气味俱厚之物，乃阳中之阳，不能走空窍先行阳道，反行阴道，逆于肉理，则湿气大胜，则子能令母实，火乃大旺，湿热既盛，必来克肾，若杂以不顺，又损其真水，肾既受邪，积久水乏，水乏则从湿热之化而上行，其疮多出背出脑，此为大疔之最重者也。[118p]

In the observed parts, it is appropriate to use medicinal references, and also consider the division of yin and yang in the diagnosis. First, drain the nutritive qi, as this is foundational. When the vital energy is reversed, it assists the fire; when dampness and heat combine, they damage the muscles and lead to pus and blood, which is secondary treatment. It is necessary to obtain various items for comparison. During the year, the extreme heat does not exceed summer; at that time, all things do not rot, but spoil when autumn dampness greatly prevails.

Taking close observations of the body, when the hot disease manifests, it shows evident heat without damaging the muscles, which makes this principle clear. Without identifying the root and symptoms, evil qi cannot be eliminated. To understand one thing and know a hundred indicates a skilled practitioner.

When the nutritive qi does not flow and reverses in the muscle structure, ulcers and abscesses arise. The nutritive qi is related to stomach qi. When food enters the stomach, it is first transported to the spleen and then directed to the lungs. The lungs connect to all the meridians, subsequently affecting the skin and hair, first flowing through the yang pathways, then returning to the five organs and six bowls, thus forming the qi in fine increments.

Now, wealthy individuals do not comprehend their moderation, consuming rich and fatty foods mixed with strong flavors. Over time, these overly rich items, being the essence of yang, cannot move through the empty orifices and instead flow through the yin pathways, reversing the muscle structure. This leads to an overwhelming presence of dampness, causing the offspring to thrive at the expense of the mother, with fire becoming excessively vigorous. When damp heat is rampant, it must eventually attack the kidneys. If mixed with improper elements, it further undermines the true water. When the kidneys suffer from evil influences over time, the water becomes scarce; lacking water then leads damp heat to rise, causing ulcers to appear on the back and head, which represents the most severe form of large sores.[118p]

若毒气行于肺或脾胃之部分，毒之次也。若出于他经，又其次也。湿热之毒，所止处无不溃烂。故经言：膏粱之变，足生大疔，受如持虚。如持虚器以受物，无不受焉。治大疔之法，必当泻其营气。以标本言之，先受病为本，非苦寒之剂，为主为君，不能除其苦楚疼痛也。诸疮疡有痛，往往多以乳香、没药，杂以芳香之药止之，必无少减之理。若使经络通流脏腑中，去其壅滞，必无痛矣。苦寒之剂除其疼痛，药下于咽，则痛立已，此神品药也。　　疮疡食肉，乃自弃也。疮疡者，乃营气而作也，今反补之，与自弃何异？虽用药施治而不能愈。地之湿气，自外而入内者，疮疖当先服药而用针。[119p]

If the poisonous gas travels through the lungs or the spleen and stomach, that is the next effect of the poison. If it emerges from other channels, that is secondary. The poison of dampness and heat causes ulceration wherever it settles. Hence, the classics say: the transformation of rich food can lead to severe boils; it is as if holding a vessel in a void. Just as a container receives things, it cannot resist absorbing everything.

To treat severe boils, one must certainly drain the vital energy. From the perspective of root and branch, the initial condition of the illness is the root; if not treated with bitter and cold medications as the primary remedy, it cannot eliminate the suffering and pain. Most sores and ulcers are painful, often treated with frankincense and myrrh mixed with aromatic medicines to relieve this pain; however, this will not necessarily lessen it.

If the meridians are unobstructed and flow through the organs, removing stagnation, there should be no pain. Bitter and cold drugs may alleviate the pain; when the medicine is swallowed, the pain will immediately cease; this is the supreme medicinal remedy.

Consuming meat with sores and ulcers is, in fact, self-neglect. Sores and ulcers arise from the vital energy, so supplementing them is no different from self-neglect. Even if medicines are applied, they may not lead to healing. For dampness from the earth that enters from the outside to the inside, it is essential to take medicine before using needles for treating sores and abscesses.[119p]

如疮疖小，不欲饮药，或婴儿之疮，先当温衣覆盖，令其凝泣壅滞血脉温和，则出血立已者，不如此，血脉凝滞便针，则邪毒不泻，反伤良肉，又益其疮势也。疮疡及诸病面赤，虽伏大热，禁不得攻里，为阳气怫郁，邪气在经，宜发表以去之。故曰，火郁则发之。虽大便数日不见，宜多攻其表，以发散阳气，少加润燥之药以润之。如见风脉风证，只可用发表风药，便可以利通，得大便行也。若只干燥秘濇，尤宜润之，慎不可下也。疮疡郁冒，俗呼昏迷是也，宜汗之则愈。验疮名色治之，当从《素问》、《针经》。《圣济总录》。易老疮论及诸家治疮用药法度，此为紧要，临病之际，宜详审焉！　　【注　按《圣济总录》能悉诸疮之名色，但其用药，则多主寒凉，而无通变之法。唯已上易老、东垣等言，深撷《针经》之大法，陈脉病治例之要，学者能熟此等议论，则临证处方，便自胸中了然明白。】[120p]

If there are small sores or boils, and one does not wish to take medicine, or if it’s an infant’s sore, one should first cover it with warm clothing to help the blood and pulse flow evenly so that any bleeding stops immediately. Otherwise, if one punctures the congested blood vessels, the evil toxins will not be expelled, and it will harm the healthy flesh, aggravating the sore. For sores and other illnesses that cause a red face, even if there is latent heat, one must not force anything internally, as this causes the yang energy to become stagnant and allows the evil energy to remain in the channels. It is appropriate to promote sweating to expel it. Hence, it is said that stagnant fire must be released. Even if there hasn’t been a bowel movement for several days, one should focus on promoting yang energy, adding some moistening herbs to alleviate dryness. If one observes symptoms of wind pulse, only wind-expelling herbs should be used; this will help facilitate bowel movements. If only dryness is present, it is particularly important to moisten it and one must be cautious not to induce a purge. When sores and abscesses occur, commonly referred to as confusion, it is advisable to induce sweating for recovery. Treat the sores by their names and colors, according to "Suwen" and "Zhenjing." The "Shengji Zonglu" contains details on various sores and their colors, but its prescriptions tend to focus on cold and cooling methods, lacking the transformative techniques. However, those like Yi Lao and Dongyuan emphasize important principles from "Zhenjing," outlining key examples of pulse diagnosis and treatment. Scholars who are familiar with such discussions will be clear and confident when prescribing at the point of care.[120p]

　　　　　脓溃论

　　夫痈疽疮疖，皆由气血壅滞而生也，当推其虚实表里而早治之。可以内消，此即托里之意也。若毒气已结者，勿泥此内消之法，当辨脓之有无浅深。若按之即复起者有脓也，不复起者无脓也；大按方痛者脓深也，小按便痛者脓浅也。急酌量刺之。缓则穿通脏腑，烂筋骨，可不慎哉！但病者多喜内消，而医者即用十宣散及败毒散、流气饮之类。殊不知十宣散虽有参、芪，然防风、白芷、厚朴、桔梗，皆足以耗气，况不分经络时令气血多少而概用之乎？败毒散乃表散之药也，虽有表证，不过一二服，况非表证而用之乎？流气饮乃行气散血之剂，若服之过度，则气虚血耗，何以为脓？此三药者，不可轻用明矣。[121p]

Discussion on Abscesses

The conditions of boils, sores, and pustules arise from stagnation of qi and blood; therefore, one must assess their conditions of deficiency and excess, exterior and interior, and treat them promptly. If one can dissolve the issue internally, this aligns with the principle of "expelling toxins." However, if the toxic energies have already consolidated, one should not rely solely on internal resolution; instead, one must distinguish between the presence or absence of pus and its depth. If pressure causes a recurrence, there is pus; if it does not, there is none. If pressing deeply causes pain, the pus is deep; if only light pressure causes pain, the pus is superficial. Immediate and careful judgment on whether to puncture is critical. If handled too slowly, it may penetrate the organs and damage muscles and bones—a caution not to be taken lightly!

Nevertheless, patients often prefer internal resolution, while doctors may resort to remedies like Shixuan Powder, Baiduxing Powder, or Liuqi Decoction. They are unaware that, though Shixuan Powder contains ginseng and astragalus, the other ingredients—fengming, angelica, magnolia, and balloon flower—are all depleting of qi. This is especially true when one indiscriminately uses them without consideration for the specific meridians, seasonal factors, or the quantity of qi and blood. Baiduxing Powder is a remedy for dispersing exterior conditions; even if there are exterior symptoms, it is only effective in one or two doses, and to use it when no exterior symptoms are present is inappropriate. Liuqi Decoction is designed to move qi and disperse blood, but if taken excessively, it can lead to deficiency of qi and depletion of blood. How can one then produce pus? Therefore, these three medicines should not be used lightly.[121p]

若夫疮既成脓，皮肤不得疏泄，昧者待其自穿，殊不知少壮而充实者，或能自解；若老弱之人，气血枯槁，兼或攻发太过，不行针刺，脓毒乘虚内攻，穿肠腐膜，鲜不误事。如沈氏室，乳痈脓成，予为针刺及时，不月而愈。黄上舍腿痈，脓熟恶针，几至危殆，予为刺之，大补三月而愈。练千兵腿痈，脉证俱弱，亦危甚矣，予治以托里得脓，急使针刺，彼固不从，致脓水开泄，淋漓不能收敛而殁。王安人发背，待其自破，毒气内攻；王贵腹痈，溃透腹胁，秽气从疮口而出，予谓其决不起，果然。大抵疮疡之证，感有轻重，发有浅深。浅者肿高而软，发于血脉；深者肿下而坚，发于筋骨。然又有发于骨髓者，则皮肉不变，脓成之时，气血壮实者或自出，怯弱者不行针刺，鲜有不误。东垣云：毒气无从而解，脓瘀无从而泄，过时不烙，反攻于内，内既消败，欲望其生，岂可得乎？兹举一二与同道裁之，使患者知所慎云。[122p]

If a wound has already formed pus, and the skin cannot expel it, the unknowing may wait for it to burst on its own, not realizing that the young and robust may resolve it themselves; however, in the case of the elderly or weak, with depleted Qi and blood, and if there is excessive heat attacking, without puncturing, the toxic pus may invade and damage the intestines and membranes, rarely without causing problems. For instance, in the case of the Shen family, with a milk abscess that had formed pus, I punctured it in time, and it healed within a month. For Huang Shang's leg abscess, where the pus was ripe but he was afraid of the needle, he almost reached a critical state; I punctured it, and he recovered after three months of substantial nourishment. Lian Qianbing had a leg abscess where both pulse and signs were weak; it was perilous, but I treated it by allowing the pus to be brought out and urgently used a needle; he refused, leading the pus-water to open and leak, and he could not recover and ultimately perished. Wang An's skin infection waited for it to burst, but the toxic gas attacked internally; Wang Gui's abdominal abscess burst through the belly and side, with foul gas escaping from the wound; I told him it would not heal on its own, and indeed, it did not. In general, the symptoms of sores and ulcers have their degrees of severity and depth; superficial ones are swollen and soft, arising from the blood vessels; deeper ones are hard and swollen, arising from the tendons and bones. Yet there are cases that arise from the marrow, where the flesh remains unchanged; when pus forms, those with strong Qi and blood may expel it on their own, while the weak may not be able to tolerate puncturing, with rare exceptions. Dong Yuan said: if the toxic gas cannot be resolved externally, and the pus cannot be expelled, if timely intervention is neglected, it will attack internally. Once internal decay occurs, how can one hope for recovery? I mention one or two cases for my colleagues to deliberate, to make patients aware of the need for caution.[122p]

　　　　　生肌止痛

　　夫肌肉，脾之所主也。溃后收敛迟速者，乃气血盛衰使然。世之治者，但知生肌用龙、竭之属，止痛用乳、没之属，恪守不移，予谓不然。盖生肌之法，当先理脾胃，助气血为主，则肌肉自生，岂假龙竭之属？设若脓毒未尽，就用生肌，反增溃烂。壮者轻者，不过复溃或迟敛而已；怯者重者，必致内攻或溃烂而不敛，亦危矣。[123p]

Promoting Flesh Growth and Alleviating Pain

Muscles are governed by the spleen. The speed of healing after a wound closes is determined by the rise and fall of qi and blood. Practitioners today may only know to use substances like dragon’s blood and myrrh for promoting flesh growth and substances like乳 (milk) and myrrh for alleviating pain, adhering strictly to these methods. I argue otherwise. The proper method for promoting flesh growth should first focus on regulating the spleen and stomach to support qi and blood, allowing the muscles to regenerate naturally, thus not requiring substances like dragon’s blood. If purulent toxins remain and one uses methods to promote flesh growth, it could worsen the condition. For robust individuals, the situation may only lead to a recurrence of the wound or slow closure; but for the weak, a serious condition could lead to internal issues or an inability for the wound to close, which is perilous.[123p]

盖止痛之法，热者清之，寒者温之，实者损之，虚者补之，脓郁者开之，恶肉侵蚀者去之，如是则痛自止，岂假乳没之属？如黄汝耘背发毒气未尽，早用生肌，竟致溃烂，予以解毒药治之得愈。许序班患此，毒气始发，骤用生肌，其毒内攻而死。王汝道患腿痈，因寒作痛，与乳香定痛丸；周朝仪母患时毒，因热作痛，与防风通圣散；丁兰患臀痈脓溃，因虚作痛，与益气养荣汤；刘贵患腹痈，因实作痛，与黄连内疏汤；王州守患腿痈，脓成作痛，予为刺之；杨千兵母发背，腐肉侵蚀作痛，予为取之，痛即自止。嗟夫！以寒治热，以热治寒，损实补虚，此用药者之绳墨。若专用龙、竭生肌，乳、没止痛，予恐其功不奏也。[124p]

The methods for alleviating pain are as follows: for heat, use cooling remedies; for cold, use warming remedies; for excess, eliminate it; for deficiency, supplement it; for accumulated pus, open it up; for flesh that erodes, remove it. By doing this, the pain will naturally cease; do we really need the likes of myrrh or frankincense? For instance, when Huang Ruyun's back developed toxic gas that had not yet dissipated, early application of flesh-regenerating medicine led to ulceration; I treated it with detoxifying drugs, and he recovered. Xu Xuban suffered from this when the toxic gas first emerged; with the sudden use of flesh-regenerating remedies, the poison attacked internally and resulted in death. Wang Rudaol had a painful leg abscess caused by cold; I gave him pain-relieving pills with myrrh. Zhou Zhaoyi's mother suffered from temporal toxicity, which caused pain due to heat; I prescribed Fangfeng Tongseng Powder. Ding Lan had a buttock abscess that burst, causing pain due to deficiency; I provided Yiqi Yangrong Decoction. Liu Gui had an abdominal abscess causing pain due to excess; I gave him Huanglian Neishu Decoction. Wang Zhoushou had a painful leg abscess with established pus, for which I recommended incision. Yang Qianbing's mother developed back pain from rotting flesh; I removed it, and the pain immediately ceased. Alas! To treat heat with cold, cold with heat, to reduce excess and supplement deficiency—this is the standard for those who use medicines. If one exclusively relies on dragon's blood and flesh-regenerating remedies, myrrh and frankincense for pain relief, I fear their efficacy will be inadequate.[124p]

　　　　　恶肉论

　　夫恶肉者，腐肉也。大凡痈疽疮溃后，腐肉凝滞必取之，乃推陈致新之意。若壮者筋骨强盛，气血充溢，真能胜邪，或自去，或自平，不能为害。若年高怯弱之人，血液少，肌肉濇，必先迎而夺之，顺而取之，是谓定祸乱以致太平。设或留而不去，则有烂筋腐肉之患。如刘大尹、汪太夫人，取之及时而新肉即生，得以全愈。金工部、陆舍人，取之稍迟，几至不救。郑挥使，取之失期，大溃而毙。予常见腐肉既去，虽少壮者不补其气血，尚不能收敛，若怯弱者不取恶肉，不补气血，未见其生也。[125p]

On Bad Flesh

Bad flesh refers to decayed meat. Generally, when there are tumors, abscesses, or wounds, bad flesh must be removed to make way for new growth. If a person is robust with strong muscles and sufficient vital energy and blood, they can truly overcome evil; in some cases, the issue resolves itself or stabilizes without causing harm. However, for older or weaker individuals, with less blood and weak muscles, bad flesh must be actively removed and taken away to bring order and lead to peace. If it is left untreated, there is a risk of rotting flesh and decayed muscles. For example, Liu Dayin and Madame Wang had their bad flesh removed in time, allowing new flesh to grow, leading to full recovery. Conversely, Jin Gongbu and Lu Sheren had their bad flesh removed too late, approaching the point of no return. Zheng Huishi failed to remove it in time, leading to decay and death. I have frequently observed that once bad flesh is removed, even those who are young and robust do not fully restore their vital energy and blood, while those who are weak and do not remove the bad flesh or replenish their energy and blood rarely survive.[125p]

　　　　　肿疡

　　肿高焮痛脉浮者，邪在表也，宜托之。肿硬痛深脉沉者，邪在内也，宜下之。外无焮痛，内则便利调和者，邪在经络也，当调荣卫。焮痛烦躁，或咽干作渴者，宜降火。焮痛发热，或拘急或头痛者，邪在表也，宜散之。大痛或不痛者，邪气实也，隔蒜灸之，更用解毒。烦躁饮冷，焮痛脉数者，邪在上也，宜清之。恶寒而不溃者，气实兼寒邪也，宜宣而补之。焮痛发热，汗多大渴，便秘讝语者，结阳证也，宜下之。不作脓或熟而不溃者，虚也，宜补之。
　　　　　溃疡

　　脓熟不溃者，阳气虚也，宜补之。瘀肉不腐者，宜大补阳气，更以桑木灸之。脓清或不敛者，气血俱虚，宜大补之。脓后食少无睡，或发热者，虚也，宜补之。倦怠懒言，食少不睡者，虚也，宜补之。寒气袭于疮口不敛，或陷下不敛者，温补之。脉大无力或濇微者，气血俱虚也，峻补之。出血或脓多，烦躁不眠者，乃亡阳也，急补之。[126p]

Swelling and Ulcers

For swelling that is raised, hot, painful with a floating pulse, the evil is on the exterior, and it should be released. For swelling that is hard, painful, deep with a sinking pulse, the evil is internal, and it should be purged. If there is no heat or pain externally, but internally there is ease and harmony, the evil is in the meridians, and nourishment and defense should be regulated. If there is heat pain with restlessness, or dryness and thirst in the throat, it is necessary to reduce fire. For heat pain with fever, and possibly rigidity or headache, the evil is on the exterior and should be dispersed. If there is great pain or no pain, the evil qi is real, treat with garlic moxibustion and additionally use detoxifying methods. If there is restlessness with cold drinks and a rapid pulse with heat pain, the evil is in the upper body, and should be cleared. If there is aversion to cold but it does not fester, it is a combination of full qi and cold evil, and it should be released and supplemented. If there is heat pain with fever, excessive sweating, great thirst, and constipation with incoherent speech, it indicates a collapsed yang condition, and it should be purged. If it does not form pus or if it is ready but does not fester, it is a deficiency, and it should be supplemented.

Ulcers

If the pus is mature but does not fester, it indicates a deficiency of yang qi, and it should be supplemented. If there is stagnant flesh that does not rot, it is advisable to greatly supplement yang qi and additionally use mulberry wood moxibustion. If the pus is clear or does not gather, it indicates deficiency of both qi and blood, and it should be greatly supplemented. If after pus discharge there is little appetite and no sleep, or if there is fever, it indicates deficiency, and it should be supplemented. If there is lethargy, reluctance to speak, little appetite, and no sleep, it indicates deficiency, and it should be supplemented. If cold qi attacks the wound and does not close, or if it sunken and does not close, warmth and supplementation should be applied. If the pulse is large but weak or fine and weak, it indicates deficiency of both qi and blood, and strong supplementation is necessary. If there is bleeding or excessive pus, restlessness, and insomnia, it indicates loss of yang, and urgent supplementation is required.[126p]

　　　　　作痛

　　脓出而反痛者，虚也，宜补之。脉数虚而痛者，属虚火，宜滋阴。脉数实而痛者，邪气实也，宜泄之。脉实便秘而痛者，邪在内也，宜下之。脉濇而痛者，气血虚寒也，温补之。
　　　　　发热

　　脉浮或弱，而热或恶寒者，阳气虚也，宜补气。脉濇而热者，血虚也，宜补血。午前热者，补气为主；后热者，补血为主。脉浮数，发热而痛者，邪在表也，宜散之。脉沉数发热而痛者，邪在内也，宜下之。
　　　　　作渴

　　尺脉大或无力而渴者，宜滋阴降火。上都脉沉实而渴者，宜泻火。上部脉洪数而渴者，宜降火。胃脉数而渴者，宜清胃。火气虚不能生津液而渴者，宜补中气。脉大无力或微弱而渴者，宜补气血。脓血大泄，或疮口出血而渴者，大补气血；如不应，急用独参汤。
　　　　　作呕

　　喜寒恶热而呕者，宜降火。喜热恶寒而呕者，宜养胃气。脉实便秘而呕者，宜泻火。脉细肠鸣腹痛泻而呕者，托里温中。[127p]

Pain

When pus emerges and there is a reverse pain, it indicates deficiency, and one should tonify it. If the pulse is rapid and weak with pain, it relates to a deficiency of Yang fire, and one should nourish Yin. If the pulse is rapid and strong with pain, it indicates an excess of pathogenic Qi, and one should dispel it. If the pulse is strong with constipation and pain, it indicates internal blockage, and one should purge it. If the pulse is thin and painful, it signifies deficiency of Qi and blood due to cold, and one should warm and tonify it.

Fever

If the pulse is floating or weak, accompanied by fever or aversion to cold, it indicates Yang Qi deficiency, and one should tonify Qi. If the pulse is thin and there is fever, it indicates blood deficiency, and one should tonify blood. For fever that occurs before noon, focus on tonifying Qi; for fever that occurs after noon, focus on tonifying blood. If the pulse is floating and rapid with fever and pain, it indicates that pathogenic factors are in the exterior, and one should disperse them. If the pulse is deep and rapid with fever and pain, it indicates that pathogenic factors are internal, and one should purge them.

Thirst

If the pulse at the wrist is large or weak with thirst, one should nourish Yin and reduce fire. If the upper pulse is deep and strong with thirst, one should drain fire. If the upper pulse is surging and rapid with thirst, one should reduce fire. If the stomach pulse is rapid and there is thirst, one should clear the stomach. If fire Qi is deficient and cannot produce fluids, causing thirst, one should tonify the central Qi. If the pulse is large and weak or feeble with thirst, one should tonify Qi and blood. If there is copious discharge of pus and blood, or thirst due to bleeding from a sore, one should greatly tonify Qi and blood; if there is no effect, urgently use Ginseng Decoction.

Nausea

If there is a preference for cold and aversion to heat with nausea, one should reduce fire. If there is a preference for heat and aversion to cold with nausea, one should nourish the stomach Qi. If the pulse is strong with constipation and nausea, one should drain fire. If the pulse is thin, accompanied by rumbling in the intestines, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and nausea, one should warm the middle and support digestion.[127p]

　　　　　便秘

　　脉沉实而秘者，火在内也，宜泄之。脉濇而秘者，属血少，宜养血。脉浮而秘者，属气虚，宜补气。脉浮濇而秘者，气血俱虚也，宜补气血。
　　　　　疔疮

　　脉浮数者散之，脉沉实者下之。表里俱实者，解表攻里。麻痒或大痛及不痛者并灸之，更兼攻毒。古今图书集成医部全录卷三百六十一

外科痈疽疔毒门

　　　　薛氏医案 【明　薛己】

　　　　　灸法用药第一

　　《精要》曰：经云诸痛痒疮疡，皆属心火。前辈又谓痈疽多生于丹石房劳之人。凡人生四十以上，生发背等疮，宜安心早治。此证如虎入室，御而不善，必至伤人。宜先用内托散，次用连翘五香汤，更以骑竹马法，或隔蒜灸，并明灸足三里以发泄其毒。盖邪之所凑，其气必虚，留而不去，其病乃实。故痈疽未溃，脏腑畜毒，一毫热药，断不可用；痈疽已溃，脏腑既亏，一毫冷药，亦不可用。犹宜忌用敷贴之药，闭其毫孔。[128p]

Constipation

If the pulse is deep and solid, it indicates internal heat, and one should release it. If the pulse is thin and secretive, it signifies a deficiency of blood, and one should nourish the blood. If the pulse is floating and secretive, it relates to Qi deficiency, and one should tonify Qi. If the pulse is both floating and thin, it indicates deficiency of both Qi and blood, and one should simultaneously replenish Qi and blood.

Boils and Carbuncles

If the pulse is floating and rapid, disperse it; if it is deep and solid, purge it. If both the exterior and interior are solid, release the exterior while attacking the interior. For itching or severe pain, as well as for those that are painless, apply moxibustion and also attack the poison.

Xue's Medical Cases (Ming Dynasty, Xue Ji)

Moxibustion and Medicinal Methods

The "Essentials" says: The classics state that all pain, itching, sores, and ulcers are related to heart fire. Predecessors also state that boils and carbuncles often arise in laborers exposed to Danstone. Anyone over forty who develops sores on the back should be treated promptly to prevent harm, as this condition is akin to a tiger entering the house—if not handled well, it will cause injury. One should first use the internal dispersing powder, then administer the Lianqiao Wuxiang Decoction, followed by the "Horse Riding on Bamboo" method or moxibustion with garlic separated, as well as moxibustion at Zu San Li to release the poison. Where evil gathers, the Qi must be deficient. If it lingers and does not leave, the illness becomes solid. Therefore, if boils and carbuncles have not yet ruptured, the organs contain toxins; any hot medications must not be used. If they have ruptured, and the organs are already depleted, then even a small amount of cold medicine must also be avoided. Additionally, it is advisable to refrain from using topical medications that would block the pores.[128p]

若热渴便秘，脉沉实洪数，宜用大黄等药以泄其毒，后用国老膏、万金散、蜡矾丸、远志酒之类，选而用之。　　【注　按前证若热毒蕴于内，大便秘结，元气无亏者，宜用大黄等药泄其热毒。若阴亏阳凑，精虚气竭，脾胃虚弱者，宜用甘温之剂培其本源。若疮不焮肿，不作脓者，虽未溃仍须温补。若疮已溃而肿不退，痛不止者，仍宜清凉之剂治之。若病急而元气实者，先治其标；病缓而元气虚者，先治其本。或病急而元气更虚者，必先治本而兼以治标。[129p]

If there is feverish thirst and constipation, with a pulse that is deep, strong, and rapid, it is advisable to use Da Huang and other medicines to drain the poison. Following this, one should choose from substances such as Guo Lao ointment, Wan Jin powder, wax alum pills, or Yuan Zhi wine for further treatment.

(Note: It is stated that if the symptoms indicate internal heat and toxins are consolidated with constipation, and there is no deficiency in vital energy, it is appropriate to use Da Huang and similar drugs to clear the heat and toxins. If there is deficiency in yin while yang is strong, with essence exhaustion and qi depletion, or if the spleen and stomach are weak, then warming medications should be used to strengthen the root. If sores are not inflamed and swollen, and do not produce pus, even if not yet ruptured, they still require warming and nurturing. If sores have ruptured but swelling persists and pain is unrelenting, cooling medicines should be utilized for treatment. In cases where the illness is acute but vital energy is strong, one should first treat the symptoms; if the illness is mild but vital energy is weak, one should first address the underlying issue. In cases of acute illness with greater weakness in vital energy, it is essential to first treat the root while also addressing the symptoms.)[129p]

大抵肿高焮痛，脓水稠粘者，元气未损也，治之则易；漫肿微痛，脓水清稀者，元气虚弱也，治之则难。不肿不痛，或漫肿色黯不溃者，发于阴也，元气虚甚，理所不治。若肿高焮痛者，先用仙方活命饮，后用托里消毒散。漫肿微痛者，宜托里散；如不应，加姜桂。若脓出而反痛，气血虚也，八珍散。不作脓，不腐溃，阳气虚也，四君加归、芪、肉桂。不生肌，不收敛，脾气虚也，十全大补加姜、桂。晡热、内热，阴血虚也，四物加参、朮。欲呕作呕，胃气虚也，六君加炮姜。自汗盗汗，五脏虚也，六味丸加五味子。[130p]

Generally, if there is swelling, heat, and pain, with thick and sticky pus, the vital energy is not damaged, and treatment is relatively easy. If there is diffuse swelling with slight pain, and clear, thin pus, the vital energy is weak, making treatment difficult. If there is no swelling or pain, or if the swelling is diffuse, dark in color, and does not rupture, it arises from yin, indicating severe weakness of the vital energy, and should not be treated.

For high swelling and intense pain, first use the Xianfang Huo Ming drink, followed by the Tuo Li Xiao Du San. For diffuse swelling and slight pain, Tuo Li San is recommended; if it does not respond, add ginger and cassia. If pus emerges but there is pain again, it indicates deficiency of qi and blood, treated with Ba Zhen San. If there is no pus, no necrosis, it indicates deficiency of yang qi, treated with Si Jun Zi San plus Gui, Qi, and Rou Gui. If there is no muscle generation or astringency, it indicates deficiency of spleen qi, treated with Shi Quan Da Bu Tang plus ginger and cassia.

For afternoon heat and internal heat, it indicates deficiency of yin blood, treated with Si Wu Tang plus Ren Shen and Bai Zhu. If there is a desire to vomit or actual vomiting, it indicates deficiency of stomach qi, treated with Liu Jun Zi Tang plus Pao Jiang. For spontaneous sweating or night sweats, it indicates deficiency of the five internal organs, treated with Liu Wei Di Huang Wan plus Wu Wei Zi.[130p]

食少体倦，脾气虚也，补中益气加茯苓、半夏。喘促咳嗽，脾肺虚也，前汤加麦门、五味。欲呕少食，脾胃虚也，人参理中汤。腹痛泄泻，脾胃虚寒也，附子理中汤。小腹痞，足胫肿，脾肾虚弱也，十全大补加山茱、山药、肉桂。泄泻足冷，脾肾虚寒也，前药加桂、附。热渴淋闭，肾虚阴火也，加减八味丸。喘嗽淋闭，肺肾虚火也，补中益气汤、加减八味丸。凡此变证，皆因元气亏损，失于预补所致。故丹溪先生云：但见肿痛，参之脉证虚弱，便与滋补，气血无亏，可保终吉。旨哉斯言！盖古今虚实不同，因时施治，不无少异。是集治论，义悉类此。】[131p]

Eating little and feeling fatigued indicates deficiency of the spleen and qi; supplement with Bu Zhong Yi Qi and add Fu Ling and Ban Xia. If experiencing wheezing and cough, it suggests deficiency of the spleen and lungs; modify the previous decoction by adding Mai Men Dong and Wu Wei Zi. For nausea and decreased appetite, indicating deficiency of the spleen and stomach, use Ren Shen Li Zhong Tang. For abdominal pain and diarrhea, hinting at cold deficiency of the spleen and stomach, apply Fu Zi Li Zhong Tang. If there's distension in the lower abdomen and swelling in the legs, suggesting weakness of the spleen and kidneys, use Shi Quan Da Bu Tang with additions of Shan Zhu Yu, Shan Yao, and Gui Gui. If there's diarrhea and cold feet, indicating cold deficiency of the spleen and kidneys, add Gui Zhi and Fu Zi to the previous remedy. For heat, thirst, and urinary difficulties, indicating yin fire deficiency of the kidneys, use Jia Jian Ba Wei Wan. For wheezing and urinary difficulties, indicating fire deficiency of the lungs and kidneys, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang and Jia Jian Ba Wei Wan. All these different conditions result from loss of original qi and failure to preemptively supplement. Therefore, Master Dan Xi stated: if one observes swelling and pain along with a pulse that indicates weakness, one should provide nourishment; if there is no deficiency of qi and blood, one can ensure a favorable outcome. Such words are profound! It should be noted that the nature of deficiency can differ between past and present, and treatment should be adjusted according to the time, which may have slight variations. This compilation of treatment discussions reflects that principle.[131p]

　　　　　备论第二

　　初虞世云：凡痈疽始作，须以大黄等药急转利之，勿以困苦为念。若与其溃烂而死，不若利之而死，况有生道哉！古人立法，率用五香、连翘、漏芦等药，贫乏者单煎大黄汤以利之。至于脓溃，乃服黄芪等药以排脓，《千金》、《外台》备矣。世以疮发于外，不行转利而死者，多矣。悲夫！　　【注　按前证若肿高焮痛，脏腑闭结，属内外俱实，当用前药泻之。若漫肿微痛，脏腑不实，属内外俱虚，当用内托补之。[132p]

Discussion II

Initially, regarding the emergence of sores and boils, one must urgently use strong laxatives such as rhubarb, without concern for discomfort. If one must choose between allowing them to fester and die or to purge them and die, it is better to purge; moreover, there is the possibility of recovery! In ancient times, treatments typically invoked five spices, forsythia, and reed, and for the impoverished, a simple decoction of rhubarb was prepared to relieve them. Once pus begins to form, one should take astragalus and similar herbs to expel the pus, as outlined in the "Thousand Gold" and "External Treatments." Many have succumbed to sores on the exterior without purging. Alas!

Note: According to previous evidence, if the swelling is high and painful, with internal organs congested, one should use the aforementioned medications to purge. If there is mild swelling with slight pain, and the organs are not congested, one should use internal tonics for support.[132p]

若漫肿无头，肉色不变，当助胃壮气，令其内消。若疼痛不止，焮肿不消，当用人参黄芪散以托里排脓。若饮食少思，肌肉不生，当用参芪托里散以补养脾胃。丹溪云：痈疽因积毒在脏腑，当先助胃壮气，使根本坚固，次以行经活血药佐之，参以经络时令，使毒气外泄，治之早者，可以内消。此内托之旨也。又云：肿疡内外皆壅，宜以托里表散为主。如用大黄，宁无孟浪之非？溃疡内外皆虚，宜以补托为主，如用香散，未免虚虚之失。此盖古今气禀不同，治宜审之。】[133p]

If there is swelling without a head and the color of the flesh does not change, one should aid the stomach to strengthen its energy, allowing for internal resolution. If the pain persists and the swelling does not subside, one should use a ginseng and astragalus powder to release the abscess and expel pus. If appetite is poor and muscles do not develop, one should use a ginseng and astragalus powder to nourish and support the spleen and stomach. Danxi states that abscesses arise from accumulated toxins in the organs; one must first strengthen the stomach’s energy to solidify the foundation, and then use blood-moving medications as an adjunct, allowing the toxins to escape through the meridians in a timely manner, which can lead to internal resolution. This is the principle of internal expulsion. Furthermore, he says: if there is swelling and abscess both internally and externally, one should primarily use exterior dispersing medicines. If rhubarb is employed, could it not lack caution? In cases where both the internal and external are weakened, one should focus on nourishment and reinforcement; using fragrant powders could undoubtedly lead to a loss of vital essence. This indicates that the physiological constitution varies between past and present; hence, treatment should be carefully considered.[133p]

　　　　　灸法论第三

　　陈无择云：痈则皮薄肿高，疽则皮厚肿坚，初发并宜灼艾。唯痈脓成则宜针，疽脓成则宜烙。当审察其证，疏利其毒，补托其里。然痈疽冠于杂病之首，治失次序，多致夭枉。故集得效灸法，以贻学者，庶不致妄投也。　　【注　按前证若发热烦渴，大便秘结者，由邪畜于内，宜内疏黄连汤，以泄内毒。若头痛拘急，发热恶寒者，由邪客于外，宜人参败毒散以散表邪。若肿痛焮赤，发热作渴，此毒气凝于肉里，宜仙方活命饮，解散其毒。若食少体倦，发热恶寒，此中气虚弱，宜六君子汤以补脾胃。】[134p]

Discussion on Moxibustion Method, Volume Three

Chen Wuze said: In cases of abscess, the skin is thin and the swelling is high; in cases of ulcers, the skin is thick and the swelling is firm. Initially, both should be treated with moxibustion. However, when the pus of an abscess has formed, needling is appropriate, while when the pus of an ulcer has formed, cauterization is advisable. One must carefully examine the symptoms, alleviate the toxins, and nourish the internal organs. However, abscesses and ulcers rank at the top of various diseases, and improper treatment order often leads to dire consequences. Therefore, I have compiled effective moxibustion methods to benefit scholars, so that they do not mistakenly apply treatments.

[Note: In cases where there are symptoms like fever, thirst, and constipation, it indicates that pathogens are accumulating within. The internal toxin should be evacuated using Huanglian Decoction. If there is headache, rigidity, fever, and aversion to cold, this suggests an external pathogenic invasion, and Ren Shen Bai Du San should be used to disperse the exterior pathogens. If there is swelling, pain, heat, and thirst, this indicates that toxic energy is trapped in the flesh, and Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin should be used to disperse the toxins. If there is decreased appetite, fatigue, fever, and aversion to cold, this suggests weak spleen qi, and Liu Jun Zi Tang should be used to nourish the spleen and stomach.][134p]

　　　　　骑竹马灸法第四

　　治一切疮疡，即用此法，无有不愈。其法令病人以肘凭几，竖臂腕要直，用篾一条，自臂腕中曲处横纹，男左女右，贴肉量起，直至中指尖尽处截断为则，不量指甲。却用竹杠一条，令病人脱衣，正身骑定，前后用两人杠起，令病者脚不着地；又令二人扶之，勿令伛偻。却将前所量臂篾，从竹杠坐处尾骶骨尽处直贴脊背，量至篾尽处为则，用墨笔点定，此只是取中，非灸穴也。却用薄篾作则子，量病人中指节相去两横纹为则，男左女右，截为一则，就前所点记处，两边各量一则，尽处即是灸穴。两穴各灸五七壮。疽发于左则灸右，疽发于右则灸左，甚则左右皆灸。[135p]

Method of Treating Wounds with Bamboo Horse Riding (Part Four)

To treat all kinds of sores and ulcers, this method can be used, and none will go uncured. The method requires the patient to lean on a table with their elbow, keeping their straight arm. Use a piece of split bamboo, measuring from the bend of the wrist to the mid-finger tip, placing it against the flesh, not measuring the fingernail.

Next, use a bamboo pole to assist the patient who should disrobe and sit upright, supported at the front and back by two individuals to keep their feet off the ground. Two other people should help them maintain an upright posture.

Take the previously measured bamboo strip from the point just above the tailbone along the spine and mark the end of the measured strip with ink. This is merely to find the center point, not an acupuncture point. Then prepare a thin piece of bamboo as a measurement tool, measuring two finger sections from the patient's middle knuckle, placing it likewise (left for males, right for females). Mark this on both sides based on the earlier mark—this defines the acupuncture points.

Each point should be treated with five to seven moxa applications. If a sore is present on the left, apply moxa on the right; if on the right, apply on the left. In severe cases, apply to both sides.[135p]

盖此二穴心脉所过之处，凡痈疽皆心火留滞之毒，灸此则心火流通而毒散矣。起死回生之功，屡试屡验。　　【注　按前证若毒既解，而肌肉不生，当求其属而补之。】　　男以左手，女以右手，先屈中指，用薄篾量取中间一节两横纹尽处为同身一寸，为则子。【此是第一次法。】　　先从男左女右臂腕中曲横纹起，用薄篾一条量至中指齐肉尽处，不量指爪为则，剪断。【此是第二次法。】　　先令病人脱去衣服，以大竹杠一条，跨定，令二人徐徐杠起，足要离地五寸许，两旁更以两人扶定，毋令动摇不稳，却以第一图则子贴定竹杠，从尾闾起贴脊，量至则子尽，以墨点定记之，非灸穴也。此是取中穴止处。却以第二图取同身寸则，取两寸平折自中穴量之，以中分取两旁各一寸，方是灸穴也。【此是第三次法。】[136p]

The area of these two points, through which the heart meridian passes, is where all boils and abscesses are caused by the toxins retained from heart fire. Moxa on these points will facilitate the flow of heart fire and disperse the toxins. The effectiveness of this method to bring the dead back to life has been repeatedly tested and proven.

[Note: If the poison has been resolved but the flesh does not regenerate, one should find its related point and nourish it.]

For males, use the left hand; for females, use the right hand. First, bend the middle finger and use a thin bamboo strip to measure from the end of the two horizontal lines in the middle section, marking this as one body inch. This is the first method.

Next, starting from the left arm for males and the right arm for females, measure from the wrist crease using a thin bamboo strip to the end of the middle finger’s flesh, not including the fingernail, and then cut it. This is the second method.

First, have the patient remove their clothing. Use a long bamboo pole to rest across them, ensuring it is secured by two people lifting it slowly until the feet are about five inches off the ground, with two others steadying it on either side to prevent shaking. Then apply the marking from the first diagram to the bamboo pole, starting from the tailbone and sticking up the spine, measuring to the end of the mark, and using ink to mark it. This is not a moxibustion point; it is a point to determine where to stop.

Using the second diagram, measure an equivalent length for one size, taking two inches and bending it halfway at the midpoint to measure two inches to each side; this is the actual moxibustion point. This is the third method.[136p]

　　　　　隔蒜灸法第五

　　李氏云：治疽之法，灼艾之功胜于用药。盖使毒气外泄，譬诸盗入人家，当开户逐之，不然则入室为害矣。凡疮初发一二日，须用大颗独蒜，切片三分厚，贴疽顶，以艾隔蒜灸之，每三壮易蒜。痛者灸令不痛，不痛者灸之令痛。疮溃贴神异膏。如此则疮不开大，肉不败坏，疮口易敛，一举三得。此法之妙，人所罕知。若头项见疽，则不可用此法。　　【注　按疮疡之证，有诸中必形诸外，在外者引而拔之，在内者疏而下之。苟或毒气郁结，瘀血凝滞，轻者药可解散，重者药无全功，是以灼艾之功为大。凡灸法，未溃则拔引郁毒，已溃则补接阳气。每治四肢患疮，气血无亏者，只以前法灸之皆愈。若中气虚弱，不灸而服败毒之药，复伤中气，未有不败者也。其头项患者，亦宜灸之。但艾炷宜小，而少其壮数为善。】[137p]

The Fifth Method of Garlic Moxibustion

Li says: The method for treating sores relies more on moxibustion than on medicine. It is essential to allow the toxic qi to escape, akin to a thief entering a house; one must open the door to chase them away, or else they will cause harm within. For sores that have just begun, within one or two days, one should use large cloves of garlic, slicing them three-tenths of an inch thick, and apply them directly on the sore. Moxibustion with mugwort should then be performed, alternating the garlic every three applications. If it causes pain, moxibustion should be conducted until the pain subsides; if there is no pain, it should be administered to induce discomfort. When the sore has ruptured, apply the miraculous ointment. By doing so, the sore will not enlarge, the flesh will not decay, and the wound will heal more swiftly, achieving three benefits in one act. This method's effectiveness is rarely known. However, if the head or neck shows signs of sores, this method should not be applied.

Note: Regarding the symptoms of sores, those within will manifest externally; for external issues, draw them out, while for internal ones, disperse and descend them. If toxic qi is stagnant, causing blood to coagulate, milder symptoms can be alleviated with medicine, while more severe cases are not fully resolved through medicine, which is why the efficacy of moxibustion is paramount. Generally, for treating sores on the limbs where qi and blood are not deficient, using this method will lead to recovery. If the middle qi is weak, moxibustion should not be performed, and taking medicines to dispel toxins will further harm the middle qi, resulting in inevitable deterioration. Patients with head and neck conditions should also receive moxibustion; however, the mugwort sticks should be small, and the number of applications should be minimal for the best results.[137p]

　　　　　寻头灸法第六

　　李氏云：凡患背疽，漫肿无头者，用湿纸贴肿处，但一点先干处，乃是疮头。可用大蒜十颗，淡豉半合，乳香钱许，研烂置疮上，铺艾灸之，痛否皆以前法为度。　　【注　按前证或附骨疽，及臀腿诸毒，初起未明者，寻头用灸，多自内消。其毒炽盛，更服活命饮，其功尤捷。若气血虚弱，必以补托为主。若背疽大溃，欲验穿透内膜者，不可用皂角取嚏法，但以纸封患处，令病者用意呼吸，如纸不动者，未穿透也。倘用取嚏鼓动内膜，反致穿透。慎之！慎之！】[138p]

Sixth Method of Seeking the Head of Moxibustion

Li said: For those suffering from back sores that are swollen without a head, use damp paper to cover the swollen area, but first dry a small point, which indicates the sore's head. Take ten cloves of garlic, half a cup of fermented soybeans, and a small amount of frankincense, grind them into a paste and apply it to the sore, then place moxa over it. Whether it hurts or not should be determined by previous methods.

Note: If there are signs of bone sores or various poisons in the buttocks and legs that have just begun, using moxibustion to seek the head often helps resolve them internally. If the poison is severe, taking restorative medicine will yield faster results. However, if the qi and blood are weak, one should primarily use tonics. If a severe back sore has burst and you wish to check if it has penetrated the inner membrane, do not use the soapwort sneezing method. Instead, seal the affected area with paper and have the patient breathe intentionally; if the paper does not move, it has not penetrated. If you use sneezing to agitate the inner membrane, it may lead to penetration. Be cautious! Be cautious![138p]

　　　　　蒜饼分轻重第七

　　伍氏曰：凡用蒜饼灸者，盖蒜味辛温有毒，主散痈疽，假火势以行药力。有只用艾炷灸者，此可施于顽疮痼发之类。凡赤肿紫黑毒甚者，须以蒜艾同灸为妙。　　【注　按前法诚有回生之功。若顽疮痼疾，脾胃虚弱，营气不能滋养患处，以致寒邪内袭而不愈，宜用小艾炷频灸疮口，以祛寒邪，补接营气。其内补之法，说见首论及三十二论。】
　　　　　灸法要论第八

　　伍氏方论曰：夫痈疽发背，皆有所因，前篇言之详矣。凡初觉赤肿，先从背脊骨第二陷中两旁，相去同身寸各一寸五分，名热腑穴，二处各灸七壮，此能疏泄诸阳热气，永无痈疽之苦；或隔蒜灸，不论壮数，则邪无所容，而真气不损。但头项见疮，宜用骑竹马法，及足三里灸之。　　【注　按前论诚为良策。其调理之法，当求首论。】[139p]

Section 7: The Division of Light and Heavy Using Garlic Cakes

Wu's statement: In using garlic cakes for moxibustion, garlic is pungent, warm, and toxic, acting to disperse abscesses and boils, relying on the potency of fire to transmit the effects of the medicine. If one uses only an moxa stick, this can be applied to stubborn sores that have long manifested. For cases of severe red swelling, purple-black toxicity, it is best to moxibust with garlic and moxa together.

[Note: The previous method indeed has the power of revival. If the stubborn sore is due to chronic illness and the spleen and stomach are weak, making it so that the vital energy cannot nourish the affected area, resulting in internal cold evils invading and not healing, it is advisable to use small moxa sticks to frequently moxibust the sore's opening, to dispel the cold evil and replenish the nourishing energy. The method for internal replenishment is discussed in the first discourse and the thirty-second discourse.]

Section 8: The Essential Discussion on Moxibustion Techniques

Wu's discourse states: The onset of abscesses and boils on the back is due to specific causes, as detailed in the previous chapter. Upon first noticing redness and swelling, one should start from the second hollow on either side of the spine, each 1.5 inches from the body, known as the "Heat Organ Points," and moxibust each point seven times. This can help to discharge excess Yang heat and eliminate the suffering of abscesses and boils; if moxibusting with garlic is used, the number of applications does not matter, as the evil has no place to reside, while the true energy is preserved. However, if sores appear on the head and neck, it is advisable to use the sitting-on-a-bamboo-horse method along with moxibustion at the "Zusanli" point (Stomach 36).

[Note: The previous discussion is indeed a good strategy. The method of regulation should be sought in the first discussion.][139p]

　　　　　灼艾痛痒论第九

　　伍氏曰：凡治痈疽发背疔疮，不痛者必灸使痛，痛者必灸使不痛。若初灸即痛者，由毒气轻浅；灸而不痛者，乃毒气深重。悉宜内服追毒排脓，外敷拔毒之药。大抵痈疽不可不痛，又不可大痛。闷乱不知痛者难治。　　【注　按前论唯疔疮一证，其状不一，其色不同，或如小疮，或如水泡，或作痛，或麻木，或有红丝，或寒热头疼，或呕吐恶心，或肢体拘急，其候多端，非前灸法并解毒之剂，卒难济事。若不省人事，或牙关紧急者，即以夺命丹为末灌之。若生两足，多有红丝至脐；生于两手，多有红丝至心；生于唇面，多有红丝入喉，俱难治。若针其红丝出血，多有生者。若患于肢末之处，毒愈凝滞，药难导达，艾灸之功为大。如妄服疏利之剂，耗损真气，不唯无以去毒而害反随之矣。】[140p]

Discussion on Moxibustion for Pain and Itching - Part Nine

Wushi said: When treating boils, carbuncles, shoulder sores, if there is no pain, it is essential to perform moxibustion to induce pain; if there is pain, moxibustion should be done to alleviate it. If pain occurs immediately upon moxibustion, it indicates shallow toxic qi; if there is no pain during moxibustion, the toxic qi is deep and heavy. It is necessary to take internal medicines to expel the toxins and discharge pus, and to apply external medications that draw out the toxins. Generally, boils and carbuncles cannot be entirely painless, but they should not be excessively painful. Cases where there is confusion and lack of awareness of pain are difficult to treat.

[Note: In previous discussions, only the sore condition was mentioned; its symptoms vary widely, with different appearances and colors—some resemble small sores, some like blisters, some are painful, some numb, some have red threads, and others may cause fever, headache, nausea, or muscle stiffness. These symptoms are numerous, and without the previous moxibustion methods and detoxifying agents, it is hard to achieve any effect. If a patient is unresponsive or has tightly clenched teeth, then use the life-reviving powder, ground into fine powder, to administer. When occurring on both legs, often there are red threads reaching to the navel; on both hands, there are usually red threads reaching to the heart; on the lips and face, red threads may reach the throat—all of these are hard to treat. If the red threads are needled to produce bleeding, many will survive. If it attacks the extremities, the toxins become even more stagnated, making it difficult for the medicine to reach; therefore, moxibustion is very important. If one improperly takes purging agents, it depletes genuine qi, not only failing to expel the toxins but potentially causing further harm.][140p]

　　　　　脑疽灸法第十

　　李氏云：脑疽及颈项有疽，不可用隔蒜灸，恐引毒上攻，宜灸足三里穴五壮，气海穴三七壮，仍服凉血化毒之药，或以骑竹马穴法灸之。凡头项咽喉生疽，古法皆为不治，若用此法，多有生者。如五香连翘、漏芦等汤，国老膏、万金散，皆可选用。　　【注　按前证属膀胱经，或湿热上壅，或阴火上炎。若因湿热，则病气有余，元气不足，当用黄连消毒散以除湿毒，用补中益气汤以滋化源。若因阴火，则元气病气俱不足，当用补中益气汤，及六味地黄丸，以滋肾水。若肾水干涸，中传末证，急用加减八味丸及补中益气汤，以固根本，引火归源。若色黯不溃，或溃而不敛，名曰脑烁，不治。大凡肿焮痛甚，宜活命饮，隔蒜灸之，解散瘀血，拔引郁毒，但艾炷宜小而少。若欲其成脓腐溃，生肌收敛，并用托里为主。】[141p]

Method of Moxibustion for Brain Abscess, Chapter Ten

Li states: For brain abscess and abscesses in the neck, do not use garlic to moxibust, as it may cause the poison to rise and attack. It is advisable to moxibust the Zusanli point with five cones, the Qihai point with three to seven cones, and also take medicines that cool the blood and transform toxins, or use the method of moxibustion at the Qimama point. In general, abscesses that arise in the head, neck, and throat are traditionally considered untreatable. However, using this method has resulted in many recoveries. Herbs such as Wuxiang Lianqiao, Leolu decoction, Guolao ointment, and Wanjin powder can be selected for use.

[Note: The previous symptoms belong to the Bladder channel, which may be due to damp-heat stagnation or yin fire flaring upwards. If caused by damp-heat, the pathogenic qi is excessive and the vital qi is insufficient, then Huanglian Xiaoduo San should be used to eliminate damp toxins, along with Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to nourish the source of transformation. If caused by yin fire, both the vital qi and pathogenic qi are insufficient, then Buzhong Yiqi Decoction and Liuwei Dihuang Pill should be used to nourish the kidney water. If kidney water is depleted and the condition has reached a late stage, immediately use the modified Bawei Pill and Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to solidify the foundation and draw the fire back to its source. If the color is dark and does not ulcerate, or ulcerates without healing, it is termed "brain scorching," which is untreatable. Generally, if there is severe swelling and pain, it is advisable to use the Lifesaving Decoction for moxibustion with garlic to dissolve stagnant blood and draw out the accumulated poison, but the moxa cones should be small and few. If pus is desired to form and ulcerate, along with promoting tissue regeneration and healing, Toli should be the main focus.][141p]

　　　　　护脏腑论第十一

　　李氏云：背疽之方虽多，得效者殊少。今择用验者录之，庶不致误人。如护心散，凡有疽疾，早进数服，使毒气外出而无呕吐之患，否则咽喉口舌生疮，或黑烂如菌。若疮发四五日之后，宜间用别药治之。　　【注　按护心散，乃解金石发疽之药。若发热焮肿作渴，饮冷而呕者，宜用。若发热焮肿作渴，饮汤而呕者，不宜用。若脾虚停痰，或寒邪内侵，或痛伤脾胃，宜用六君子汤。若喉舌生疮，口干作渴，或小便频数，宜用六味丸。大凡诸疮作呕，若饮冷便秘，是热毒也，黄连消毒散解之。饮冷便和，是胃火也，竹叶石膏汤清之。懒食饮汤，是胃虚也，补中益气汤以补之。大便不实，喜饮热汤，是脾胃虚寒也，六君加炮姜以温之。常见脾胃虚弱者，用前散反心间阴冷，无不致呕。其喉舌生疮，乃肾水枯涸，虚火炎上，其证甚恶，急用加减八味丸，亦有得生者。】[142p]

On Protecting the Internal Organs, Section Eleven

Li states: Although there are many remedies for back sores, very few prove effective. Now, I select and record those that have been tested, so as not to mislead others. For instance, the Heart Protecting Powder is to be administered early for any sore disease; taking several doses helps expel toxic substances without causing vomiting. Otherwise, there may be sores in the throat, mouth, or tongue, or they might turn black and rotten like fungus. If the sores appear after four or five days, it is advisable to use other medicines.

Note: The Heart Protecting Powder is a remedy for sores caused by metal or stone. If there is fever, swelling, and thirst with vomiting after drinking cold drinks, it is suitable to use. If there is fever, swelling, and thirst with vomiting after drinking broth, it is not advisable to use it. If there is spleen deficiency leading to phlegm stagnation, or internal cold evasion, or pain injuring the spleen and stomach, the Six Gentlemen Decoction should be used. If there are sores on the throat and tongue, dry mouth, thirst, or frequent urination, the Six Flavors Pill is recommended. Generally, if sores induce vomiting and drinking cold leads to constipation, it indicates heat toxicity, which can be relieved with the Huang Lian Xie Du Powder. If drinking cold facilitates bowel movements, it suggests stomach fire, which can be cleared with Bamboo Leaf and Gypsum Decoction. If there is loss of appetite with broth, it indicates stomach deficiency; use the Central Qi Fortifying Decoction to replenish. If the stool is loose, and one prefers hot broth, it indicates cold deficiency of the spleen and stomach; the Six Gentlemen Decoction with roasted ginger should be used to warm it. It is commonly observed that those with weak spleen and stomach often use the preceding powder, which can lead to cold and discomfort in the heart, inevitably resulting in vomiting. The sores on the throat and tongue are due to dehydration of kidney water and upward flaming of deficient fire. This condition is quite serious; promptly using the Adjusted Eight Flavor Pill may lead to recovery.[142p]

　　　　　痈疽论第十二

　　马益卿曰：夫人有四肢五脏，一觉一寐，呼吸吐纳，精气往来，流而为荣卫，畅而为气色，发而为声音，阳用其形，阴用其精，此又常数之所同也。至其失也，蒸则生热，否则生寒，结而为瘤赘，陷而为痈疽，凝而为疮癣，愤则结瘿，怒则结疽。又五脏不和则九窍不通，六气不和则流结为痈。皆经络濇滞，气血不流畅，风毒乘之而致然也。　　【注　按此论可谓善言人身之造化，疮疡之情状者矣。治法当参详前论。】[143p]

Discussion on Abscesses, Chapter Twelve

Ma Yiqing said: The human body has four limbs and five organs, with sensations of wakefulness and sleep, breathing in and out, the flow of essential energy, circulating as nourishment and defense, manifesting as vitality and complexion, expressed through sound. Yang reflects physical form, while Yin represents essence; these are common principles. When there is disturbance, heat arises if the body steams, otherwise, cold develops. If it solidifies, it becomes lumps; if it sinks, it transforms into abscesses; if it congeals, it results in sores and skin issues; frustration leads to goiters, while anger causes abscesses. Furthermore, if the five organs are not harmonious, the nine orifices will be obstructed; if the six Qi are not harmonious, stagnation leads to abscesses. All are due to blocked meridians, with Qi and blood not flowing smoothly, allowing wind and toxins to seize the opportunity and cause these conditions. [Note: This discussion can be considered a profound analysis of the human body's transformation and the conditions of sores and ulcers. Treatment methods should refer to previous discussions.][143p]

　　　　　叙论第十三

　　痈疽之证，若七情亏损，气血经络壅结而成者，属内因；若六淫外侵，气血受伤，寒化而为痈者，属外因；若服丹石补药膏粱酒面房劳所致者，属内外因也。又曰：阴滞于阳则发痈，阳滞于阴则发疽。脉浮洪滑数为阳，沉缓迟濇为阴。阴则热治，阳则冷治。初觉宜清热拔毒，已溃宜排脓止痛。故用远志、大黄、甘草，此三因之法也。治当寒者温之，热者清之，虚者补之，实者泻之，导之以针石，灼之以艾炷，破毒溃坚，各遵成法，以平为期。[144p]

Discussion Thirteen

The condition of abscesses, if caused by the depletion of emotional states (the seven emotions), leading to stagnation of qi and blood in the meridians, falls under internal causes. If it is an external invasion by the six pathogenic factors, resulting in injury to qi and blood, with cold transforming into abscesses, that belongs to external causes. If it arises from the consumption of alchemical substances, tonics, rich foods, or excessive labor, it is a combined internal and external cause. Furthermore, it is said that stagnation of yin leads to abscesses, while stagnation of yang results in carbuncles. A floating, rapid, slippery pulse indicates yang, while a sinking, slow, thick pulse indicates yin. Yin is treated with heat, and yang with cold. In the initial stage, the focus should be on clearing heat and expelling toxins; once there is a rupture, the aim should be to drain pus and alleviate pain. Hence, one uses compounds such as polygala, rhubarb, and licorice, representing these three causal methods. The treatment should warm what is cold, clear what is hot, tonify what is deficient, and drain what is excessive, guided by acupuncture, cauterization with moxa, or breaking up toxins and softening hardness, all adhering to established principles, aiming for equilibrium.[144p]

　　【注　按前证脉沉实，大便秘结者，属内因也，宜疏利之。脉浮，大便调和者，属外因也，宜托里之。脉不浮不沉者，属不内外因也，宜调和荣卫。此亦治三因法也。若焮肿大痛，烦热饮冷，大便秘结，脉洪数实者，为纯阳，宜苦寒之剂，清热拔毒。若不肿不痛，泻利不食，呕吐足冷，是为纯阴，宜辛热之剂，大补阳气。不拘严寒盛暑，当舍时从证。若微肿微痛，似溃不溃，时出清脓者，为半阴半阳，宜辛热之剂温补胃气。此亦治阴阳证法也，治验详见首论。】[145p]

According to the notes, if the pulse is deep and solid, and there is constipation, it indicates an internal cause, and one should use methods to relieve and unblock. If the pulse is superficial and the bowel movements are regular, it indicates an external cause, and one should use methods to promote. If the pulse is neither superficial nor deep, it indicates neither internal nor external causes, and one should harmonize the defensive and nutritive qi. This is also a method of treating the three causes. If there is swelling, severe pain, restlessness, heat, a preference for cold drinks, constipation, and a pulse that is surging, rapid, and solid, this is pure Yang, and bitter-cold herbs should be used to clear heat and expel toxins. Conversely, if there is no swelling or pain, there is diarrhea, a lack of appetite, vomiting, and cold extremities, this is pure Yin, and warming, spicy herbs should be used to greatly supplement Yang qi. Regardless of whether it is extreme cold or intense heat, one should adjust based on the condition. If there is slight swelling and slight pain, resembling a potential abscess but occasionally discharging clear pus, this is half Yin and half Yang, and one should use warming, spicy herbs to tonify the stomach qi. This is also a method for treating Yin and Yang conditions; detailed experiences can be found in the earlier discussions.[145p]

　　　　　素问要论第十四

　　《素问》云：阳气凑袭，寒化为热，热甚则肉腐为脓。凡发背多因服金石而发者，有因上代曾服而发者。其候多发于脾，起如粟，或痛或痒，多致不救，外面如拳。古人云外面如麻，里面如瓜。有数十孔，以手按之，诸孔出脓，寻时失喑。凡有此证，可用净土水调，量大小作饼，厚分许，以艾炷灸之，内服五香连翘汤，及铁浆酢调蚌壳灰涂之，更以骑竹马法，灸之甚良。　　【注　按前证仍参首论主治，恐其表里热毒之不同，元气虚实之不一也。】
　　　　　千金要论第十五

　　《千金》云：痈疽始作，或大痛，或小痛，或发如米粒即便出脓，宜急断口味，利去其毒，用骑竹马灸法，或就患处灼艾。重者四面中央总灸一二百壮，更贴寒药，其效甚速。　　【注　按前证若因元气亏损，或因气血相滞而患者，更当调补其内。】[146p]

Essentials of the Plain Questions, Chapter Fourteen

The "Plain Questions" states: When the yang qi gathers and strikes, cold transforms into heat. When heat is excessive, flesh rots into pus. Generally, back abscesses are often caused by taking metals and stones, or from previous generations who took such substances. The symptoms often arise from the spleen, appearing like grains, sometimes painful or itchy, often leading to severe conditions, appearing externally like a fist. The ancients described the outside as similar to hemp and the inside like a melon. There are several dozen openings; when pressed, pus may emerge from them, and one may lose their voice for a time. For this condition, one may use pure earth water, mixing it into a thick paste for cakes, and moxibustion with mugwort sticks. Internally, consume a Five-Spice and Lianqiao decoction, and apply a mix of iron essence and vinegar with clam shell ash. Furthermore, use the riding bamboo horse technique for moxibustion, which is quite effective.

Essentials of the Thousand Gold, Chapter Fifteen

The "Thousand Gold" states: When boils and carbuncles first occur, there may be either great pain or minor pain, or if something appears like a grain, pus will surely emerge. It is advisable to urgently cut off sour tastes and eliminate the poison, using the riding bamboo horse moxibustion technique, or directly burning mugwort on the affected area. For severe cases, thicken moxibustion at the central and surrounding areas with one or two hundred vigorous applications, and additionally apply cold remedies; the effect is remarkably swift.[146p]

　　　　　别脉辨证论第十六

　　伍氏云：痈疽之疾，有二十余证，熛发、痼发、石发、岩发、蜂窠发、莲拟发、椒眼发、连珠发、竟体发，有肠痈内发、脑背发、眉发、腮颔发、肺痈、瓜瓠发。大率随病浅深，内外施治，不可迟缓。初发如伤寒脉浮而紧，是其候也。　　【注　按前证其名虽殊，处治之法，详具各论。其肺痈胃脘痈别载。】
　　　　　脉证第十七

　　陈无择云：痈疽脉数，身无热，反洒淅恶寒，若有痛处，乃发为痈。以手掩上，若热者为有脓，不热者为无脓。若脉不数，不热而疼者，发于阴也，尤为恶证。凡热甚脉数，用漏芦散，并单煮大黄等汤，不甚热，脉缓弱，投五香连翘汤，仍依四节八事次序三因以药之，无有不济者也。　　【注　按前证洒淅恶寒，有属疮之表邪者，有属脾肺之气虚者。若溃后焮肿，作痛恶寒，发热烦渴脉数，乃真气虚而邪气实也，仍参详首论主之。】[147p]

Discussion on Differentiating Symptoms of Abscesses, Part Sixteen

Wu stated: The diseases of carbuncles manifest in over twenty symptoms, including sudden onset (early-stage), chronic onset, stone-like nodules, rock-like nodules, bee-hive nodules, lotus-like nodules, peppery-nodules, string-of-pearls nodules, and nodules that appear in the entire body. Internally, there are abscesses in the intestines, on the brain's back, in the eyebrows, in the jaw and cheeks, as well as lung abscesses and melon-husk abscesses. Generally, treatment should be adjusted based on the severity of the illness and should be applied both internally and externally without delay. When onset is like a floating and tense pulse due to a cold injury, this indicates the condition.

(Note: Although these symptoms have different names, the treatment methods are detailed elsewhere. Lung and gastric abscesses are separately recorded.)

Pulse Symptoms, Part Seventeen

Chen Wuze stated: In cases of abscesses, the pulse is rapid, there is no fever, but the patient experiences severe chills; if there is a painful area, this indicates an abscess. When feeling over the area, if it feels hot, it indicates the presence of pus; if not hot, there is no pus. If the pulse is not rapid, and there is no fever but pain, it indicates a condition arising from the Yin, which is particularly serious. When heat is severe and the pulse is rapid, a remedy should include Luoluo Powder and decoctions of rhubarb. If there is not much heat and the pulse is weak and slow, use Wuxiang Lianqiao Decoction, following the order of the four seasons and eight conditions for medication; there will be no case that does not respond positively.

(Note: The symptoms of severe chills may relate to external pathogens of the sore, or to internal deficiency of the spleen and lungs. If after an abscess ruptures there is swelling and pain with severe chills, fever, thirst, and a rapid pulse, this indicates true qi deficiency and full evil qi; further consultation of the main text is advised for detailing.)[147p]

　　　　　用药大纲第十八

　　李氏云：余之所著方论，靡不周备，但欲使治者一玩味，次第用之，无有不效。今略书用药要领，节次于后。　　一初患痈疽，便服内托散，以免后来口舌生疮，仍用骑竹马或隔蒜灸。　　一服五香连翘汤，如大便快即止，仍量人虚实。　　一痈疽溃后，宜服排脓内补散；若呕逆，用木香汤下。　　一痈疽初作，便宜灼艾，及麦饭、石膏涂四围，中留口出毒。如疮小，通敷之；既溃，用神异膏贴之。　　一痈疽已溃，日用猪蹄汤淋洗，将愈之际，三日一次。　　一痈疽将敛，宜用神异膏；如毒未尽，不可遽用生肌之剂。[148p]

Outline for Medication, Section 18

Li states: My writings on formulas are comprehensive, intending for the practitioners to savor and apply them sequentially, with no chance of ineffectiveness. Here, I briefly outline the essential points for medication, organized as follows:

  1. For the initial onset of carbuncles or sores, take internal herbs immediately to prevent mouth sores later, and apply moxa or garlic for cauterization.
  2. If taking Wuxiang Lianqiao decoction, stop if bowel movements are swift; still, gauge the person's deficiency and excess.
  3. After a carbuncle or sore has suppurated, it is advisable to take a dispersing and nourishing formula; if there are vomiting or reversal symptoms, administer a wood fragrance decoction.
  4. When a carbuncle or sore first appears, it is best to apply moxa, and use mixtures of rice flour and gypsum around the area while allowing the toxic matter to exit through the mouth. If the sore is small, apply dressings thoroughly; once it has ruptured, use a miraculous ointment for application.
  5. For an already ruptured carbuncle or sore, wash daily with pig trotter soup, which promotes healing; do this every three days.
  6. When the carbuncle or sore is nearing closure, use the miraculous ointment; if there is still remaining toxicity, one must not hastily apply agents that regenerate flesh.[148p]

　　一痈疽将安，宜用加味十全大补汤，补其气血，庶肌肉易生。　　一背疽多先渴而后发，或先疽而后渴，不救多矣。若服加减八味丸，非特杜绝渴疾，抑且大滋气血，生长肌肉。　　【注　按前证及诸治法，各附四十七等论，当审用之。】　　一痈疽呕逆有二：一因初发不服内托散，伏热在心；一因脾气不正。若因伏热在心者，心烦身热，焮肿作痛，宜用内托散三两服。若因脾气不正者，则不烦热，或闻秽气作呕，宜用嘉禾散。如有寒热，用不换金正气散，五更初兼服山药丸以补肾。　　【注　按前证治法，当与第十一论参看。】[149p]

When a carbuncle appears, it is advisable to use the modified "Ten Complete Nourishing Decoction" to replenish Qi and blood, facilitating the growth of muscles. A back carbuncle often manifests with thirst preceding its onset, or thirst following the appearance, leading to much distress. Taking the modified "Eight Flavor Pill" not only prevents thirst-related ailments but also greatly enriches Qi and blood, promoting muscle growth.

There are two types of vomiting associated with a carbuncle: one is caused by the initial outbreak not being treated with "Nei Tuo San," resulting in hidden heat in the heart; the other is due to improper spleen Qi. If the cause is hidden heat in the heart, one would feel restless with body heat, experiencing swelling and pain; in this case, three doses of "Nei Tuo San" should be administered. If due to improper spleen Qi, there would be no restlessness or heat, but nausea triggered by foul smells; here, "Jia He San" should be used. If there are chills and fevers, "Bu Huan Jin Zheng Qi San" should be employed, alongside the use of "Shan Yao Wan" early in the morning to nourish the kidneys.[149p]

　　　　　呕逆第十九

　　李氏云：痈疽呕逆，是毒气冲心，非脾胃之冷，当服内托散。杨氏云：鼻衄初愈，不曾表汗，毒在经络，则背发大疽。自肩下连腰胁，肿硬如石，其色紫黑，以凉药投之，终夜大呕，连进托里散，呕止疮溃，赤水淋漓，四十日而愈。又有患疬者，痛过辄呕，服此即止。今有病疽不服此药者，故引杨氏之言，以解世人之惑。　　【注　按用药之法，有是病必用是药，但今之脾胃虚寒，气逆痰滞而呕吐者十居八九，热毒内攻而呕吐者十才一二，当参首论及第十一论主之。】
　　　　　论源第二十

　　夫痈疽之源，因于气或因于热，以仆之管见，亦有因于膏粱房劳金石等药者。故治法用菉豆、犀角、矾石、国老膏、追毒丸，其属毒明矣。华佗《中藏》所言是毒，服宣热败毒之药，不必疑矣。　　【注　按前证若因金石所致，元气充实者，诚宜此法。若膏粱积热、房劳过度、脾肾虚损者，当滋其化源，不可拘执。】[150p]

Vomiting and Reversal (Section 19)

Li states: “The presence of carbuncles and vomiting is due to toxic energy invading the heart, not the coldness of the spleen and stomach; one should take internal expelling powders.” Yang states: “If nosebleeds just healed and there hasn’t been sweating on the surface, then the toxins are within the meridians, leading to large carbuncles on the back. From the shoulders down to the waist and flanks, there is swelling hard as stone, with a purple-black hue. If cool medicines are administered, there will be vomiting throughout the night. Continuing with the expelling powders will stop the vomiting, leading to ulceration with reddish fluids, healing in forty days. Additionally, there are those who suffer from ulcers, where pain leads to vomiting. Taking this will stop the vomiting.” Now if there are patients with carbuncles who do not take this medicine, I reference Yang’s words to clarify the confusion of the world.
Note: According to medical practice, certain illnesses must use specific remedies. However, in today's cases, the majority experience weakness and coldness in the spleen and stomach, with reversed qi and phlegm causing nausea. Only a small percentage suffer from internal heat toxins leading to vomiting; this should be considered with the first discussion and the main points of the eleventh discussion.

On the Source (Section 20)

The source of carbuncles arises from either qi or heat; as I see it, it can also stem from improper food and excess of rich, fatty meals, or from sexual excess leading to the use of metals and stones. Therefore, the treatment should include mung beans, rhinoceros horn, alum, Gualao ointment, and the Zhuidu pills, all undeniably toxic. What Hua Tuo mentioned in "Zhongcang" refers to toxins; taking medicine that clears heat and eradicates toxins is assuredly necessary.
Note: If prior evidence indicates it is caused by metals and stones, then for those with abundant vital energy, this method is indeed advisable. But if heat from rich foods has piled up, or if there is excessive sexual activity, or weakness in the spleen and kidneys, the source of transformation should be nourished and not rigidly enforced.[150p]

　　　　　华佗论第二十一

　　夫痈疽疮肿之作，皆五脏六腑畜毒不流，非独因荣卫壅塞而发也，其行也有处，其主也有归。假令发于喉舌者心之毒，发于肌肉者脾之毒，发于骨髓者肾之毒；发于下者阴中之毒，发于上者阳中之毒；发于外者六腑之毒，发于内者五脏之毒。故内曰坏，外曰从，下曰逆。发于上者得之速，发于下者得之缓。感于六腑则易治，感于五脏则难瘳。又近骨者多冷，近肤者多热。近骨者久不愈，则化成血虫；近肤者久不愈，则传气成漏。成虫则多痒少痛，或先痒后痛；成漏则多痛少痒，或不疼不痒。内虚外实者，多痛少痒，血不止则多死，溃脓则多生。或呕逆无度，饮食无时，皆痈疽使然，证候多端，要当详治。　　【注　按疮疡生虫乃肝经风热，其成漏乃元气虚弱，其出血乃脾虚有火，其溃脓乃元气充实。至于呕逆等证属脾胃亏损所致，当调补元气，庶保无虞。】[151p]

Hua Tuo's Discussion, Chapter Twenty-One

The occurrence of sores, swellings, and ulcers arises when the organs accumulate toxins that do not flow; it is not solely due to the obstruction of nourishment and defense. Their manifestations have specific locations and principal causes. For example, if they appear on the throat or tongue, it is the heart's toxin; if on the muscles, it is the spleen's toxin; if on the bones and marrow, it is the kidney's toxin; if they erupt from below, it comes from the yin toxins, and if from above, from the yang toxins; externally, it is the toxins of the six bowels, and internally, it is the toxins of the five organs. Therefore, what occurs internally is termed "bad," externally it is termed "follow," and what occurs below is termed "reverse."
