Swelling of the lips and sores, governed by the Yangbai point.
Swelling and pain in the cheeks, governed by the Tianchuang point.
Swelling of the head and neck that inhibits speech, governed by the Tianrong point.
Swelling of the body, governed by the Guanmen point.
Fullness and pain beneath the chest, with swelling of the breasts, governed by the Rugen point.[531p]

　　面肿目痈，刺陷谷出血立已。
　　犊鼻肿，可刺其上，坚勿攻，攻之者死。　　疽，窍阴主之。
　　脉风成为厉，管疽发厉，窍阴主之。　　管疽，商丘主之。
　　《千金方》曰：痈疽始作大，大痛或小痛，或发如米粒，即便出脓，宜急断口味，利去其毒，用骑竹马灸法骑竹马灸法　查《千金》无此灸法。其最初记载见于宋　闻人耆年所撰之《备急灸法》，该书列有骑竹马灸法专篇。，或就患处灼艾，重者四面中央总灸一二百壮，更用敷药，其效甚速。　　骑竹马灸法，治一切疮疡，无有不愈。令病人以肘凭几，竖臂腕要直，用篾一条，自臂腕中曲处横纹，男左女右，贴肉量起，直至中指尖尽处，截断为则，不量指甲；却用竹杠一条，令病人脱衣正身骑定，前后用两人扛起，令病者脚不着地，又令二人扶之，勿令伛偻，却将前所量臂篾，从竹杠坐处，尾骶骨尽处，直贴脊背，量至篾尽处为则，用墨笔点定，此只是取中，非灸穴也。[532p]

Swelling in the face and eye abscess, needling the valley point to induce bleeding immediately.
If the nose of the ox is swollen, one can needle the top; do not attack it hard, as doing so would lead to death. For sores, the Yin orifice governs it.
When the pulse of wind becomes severe, it indicates a severe sore; the Yin orifice governs it. For the severe sore, Shangqiu governs it.
The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: when the abscess or sore begins to form, there may be great pain or slight pain, or it may emerge like a grain of rice; one should quickly cut the mouth to eliminate its poison, using the bamboo horse moxibustion technique. However, there is no record of this moxibustion method in "Thousand Gold"; the earliest documentation is in the "Emergency Moxibustion Method" authored by the renowned person Wen Renqiannian during the Song Dynasty, which includes a special section on bamboo horse moxibustion. One can also burn moxa directly on the affected area, and for more severe cases, moxibustion should be done all around the center, at least one or two hundred strong burns, and then apply medicine, which is very effective.
The bamboo horse moxibustion method can cure all types of sores and ulcers without exception. Have the patient lean on a table with their elbow, straightening the wrist; use a strip of slender bamboo, measuring from the bend at the wrist to the tip of the middle finger, cutting off the excess and not measuring the fingernail. Then, take a bamboo pole, have the patient undress, and sit firmly on it, with two people lifting them off the ground, ensuring their feet do not touch the ground, and have two others support them, keeping them upright. The bamboo strip measured should be placed from the sitting position on the bamboo pole down to the coccyx, then directly along the spine to the end of the measured strip; use ink to mark this point, which is merely for positioning and is not an acupuncture point.[532p]

却用薄篾作则子，量病人中指节，相去两横纹为则，男左女右，截为一则，就前所点记处，两边各量一则，尽处即是灸穴。两穴各灸五七壮。疽发于左则灸右，疽发于右则灸左，甚则左右皆灸。盖此二穴心脉所过之处，凡痈疽皆心火留滞之毒，灸此则心火流通而毒散矣。起死回生之功，屡试屡验。　　痈肿已溃未溃，用香豉三升，入少水捣成泥，照肿处大小作饼，厚三分。疮有孔，勿覆孔。上铺豉饼，以艾列于上灸之，但使温温，勿令破肉。如热痛即急易之。患当减，觉轻快。一日灸二次。如先有孔，以汁出为妙[痈肿……为妙　此即豉饼灸法，见于《千金翼》卷二十三痈疽发背，所述意同而文稍异。]。　　《三因方》曰：痈疽初觉肿痛，先以湿纸覆其上，视之先干处是头也。大蒜切片置头上，以大艾炷灸之三壮，即换一蒜，痛者灸至不痛，不痛者灸至痛乃止。大概以百壮为准。最要早觉早灸为上。[533p]

Instead, use thin bamboo strips as a measuring tool to gauge the knuckle joint of the patient’s middle finger, with the distance between the two horizontal lines as the standard. For males, measure on the left; for females, on the right. Cut it to one standard length, then measure from the marked point on both sides to find another standard length; the ends will indicate the acupuncture points. Each point should be cauterized five to seven times. If an abscess appears on the left, cauterize the right; if on the right, cauterize the left; if severe, cauterize both sides. This is because these two points correspond with the heart meridian; all abscesses and swellings are due to the stagnation of heart fire and poison. Cauterizing here allows the heart fire to circulate and the poison to dissipate. This method has repeatedly demonstrated its life-saving effectiveness.

For abscesses that have or have not burst, take three sheng of fragrant bean and mash it with a little water to form a paste. Shape this paste into a cake according to the size of the swelling, three-tenths of an inch thick. If the wound has a hole, do not cover it. Place the bean cake on top and burn mugwort sticks above it, ensuring it remains warm but does not burn the flesh. If there’s heat and pain, replace it urgently. The affected area will feel lighter and more comfortable. Cauterize twice a day. If a hole is already present, letting out the juice is most beneficial. This is the bean cake cauterization method, mentioned in the "Thousand Gold Supplement," Volume Twenty-Three, addressing the same topic but with slight differences in wording.

The "Three Causes Formula" states that when an abscess or swelling is first felt, it should be covered with a damp paper. Looking carefully, the first dry area indicates the head. Place sliced garlic on the head and cauterize with a large mugwort torch three times, then replace with another piece of garlic. Cauterize until the pain is relieved, or continue until pain is felt to stop. Generally, a hundred cauterizations is the standard. It is most crucial to recognize early and begin cauterizing promptly.[533p]

如有头，则不必纸覆也。　　若十数头作一处生者，即用大蒜研成膏，作薄饼铺头上，聚艾于饼上灸之。　　《直指方》曰：初发小点一二日，急以蒜片贴其中心，以小艾炷灸五壮而止。　　《河间六书》曰：凡疮疡，须分经络部分，气血多少，腧穴远近。　　从背出者，当从太阳五穴选用：至阴在足小指外侧，去爪甲角如韭叶；通谷在足小指外侧本节前陷者中；束骨在足小指外侧本节后陷中；昆仑在足外踝后跟骨上陷中；委中在腘中央约纹中动脉。　　从鬓出者，当从少阳五穴选用：窍阴足小指次指端，去爪甲如韭叶；侠溪在足小指次指，岐骨间本节之陷中；临泣在足小指次指本节后间陷中；阳辅在外踝上四寸辅骨前绝骨端如前三分；阳陵泉在膝下一寸外廉陷中。[534p]

If there is a head, there is no need to cover it with paper. If there are ten or so heads that appear in one area, prepare a paste of garlic, make a thin cake, and apply it over the head, then place mugwort on the cake for moxibustion. The "Direct Instruction Method" states: if small dots appear for one or two days, urgently apply garlic slices at the center and perform moxibustion with small mugwort sticks five times and then stop. The "Hejian Six Writings" states: for all sores and ulcers, one must differentiate the pathways and regions, and the amount of qi and blood, as well as the distance to the acupoints.

For those arising from the back, select from the five acupoints of the Sun pathway: Zhi Yin is located on the outer side of the little toe, away from the nail edge like a chive leaf; Tong Gu is found at the indentation before the outer side of the little toe; Shu Gu is located at the indentation behind the outer side of the little toe; Kun Lun is at the indentation above the outer ankle on the heel bone; Wei Zhong is in the middle of the knee crease near the artery.

For those arising from the temples, select from the five acupoints of the Shao Yang pathway: Qiao Yin is at the tip of the little toe and the next toe, away from the nail edge like a chive leaf; Xia Xi is located between the little toe and the next toe at the indentation of the joint; Lin Qi is found at the indentation behind the joint of the little toe and the next toe; Yang Fu is four inches above the outer ankle on the front end of the fibula bone; Yang Ling Quan is one inch below the knee on the outside edge in a depression.[534p]

　　从髭出者，当从阳明五穴选用：厉兑在足大指次指，去爪甲如韭菜；内庭在足大指次指外间陷中；陷谷在足大指次指间本节后陷中；冲阳在足趺上五寸骨间动脉，去陷骨三寸；解溪在冲阳后一寸五分，腕上陷中。　　从脑出者，则惟绝骨一穴，在外踝上三寸动脉中。　　痈疽已觉微漫肿，硬皮不变，脉沉不痛者，当外灸之，引邪气出而止。经曰：陷下者灸之。如外微觉木硬而不痛者，当急灸之，是邪气深陷也；浅者不可灸。如有脓水，亦不可灸，当针之。　　《得效方》曰：痈疽初发渐大，以湿纸一片搭疮上，其一点先干处，即是正顶。先以水洗去人皮咸，取大笔管一个安于正顶上，却用大水蛭一条安其中，频以冷水灌之，蛭当吮其正穴脓血，皮皱肉白，是毒散无不差。如毒大蛭小，须用三四条方见效。如血不止，以藕节上泥涂之。　　《资生方》曰：有善治痈疽者，皆于疮上灸至二三百壮，无有不愈。[535p]

Those with beard-like growths should select from the five points of the Yangming channel: The "Li Dui" point is located between the big toe and the second toe on the foot, with the nail cut short like chives; the "Nei Ting" point is in the middle groove between the big toe and the second toe; the "Xian Gu" point is located at the back of the joint of the big toe and second toe; the "Chong Yang" point is five inches above the top of the foot, in the space between the bones, three inches away from the protruding bone; the "Jie Xi" point is one inch and five-tenths behind the Chong Yang point, in the middle of the wrist.

For issues arising from the brain, only the "Jue Gu" point should be used, which is located three inches above the outer ankle in the artery. For early-stage carbuncles or abscesses that feel slightly swollen, with hardened skin and a deep pulse without pain, one should perform external moxibustion to expel the pathogenic qi. The classics state that for issues occurring below the surface, moxibustion is indicated. If one feels a slight hardness without pain, urgent moxibustion is required, as the pathogenic qi has deeply settled; if it is shallow, moxibustion should not be performed. If there is pus, moxibustion is also not indicated; needling is warranted.

According to the "De Xiao Fang": When a carbuncle or abscess initially flares up and grows larger, place a piece of damp paper on the wound, and the point that dries first is the primary location. First, wash it with water to remove any salty skin, and place a large pen-tube aligned over the primary location, then insert a large leech inside. Frequently pour cold water over it; the leech should suck out the pus and blood from the precise point, with the skin wrinkling and the tissue turning pale, indicating that the poison has dispersed effectively. If the poison is large and the leech is small, three to four leeches should be used to achieve results. If bleeding does not stop, apply mud from lotus stems to the area.

According to the "Zi Sheng Fang": Those skilled in treating carbuncles and abscesses typically use moxibustion on the wound two to three hundred times, with all cases achieving resolution.[535p]

但艾炷小作之，小则人不畏灸，灸多则作效必矣。坚硬不溃，名曰石痈，当上灸百壮，石子当碎出。　　《东垣十书》曰：初觉痈疽发背，欲结未结，赤热肿痛，先以湿纸覆其上，立视先干处即痈头也。取蒜切片如三钱厚，安头上，用大艾炷灸之三壮，换一蒜片，痛者灸至不痛，不痛者灸至痛，早觉早灸为上，一日二日十灸十活，三日四日六七活，五日六日三四活，过十数日者不可灸。若有十数头作一处者，用蒜研成膏作薄饼。铺头上，聚艾烧之，亦能活也。若初发赤肿，中间有一黄粟米头，用独蒜切去两头，取中间切片安疮头上，着艾灸十四壮，多至四十九壮。　　《丹溪心法》曰：凡痈疽之发，或因内有积热，或因外寒郁内热，若于生发之处艾灸以散其毒，治之于早，可以移深为浅，改重为轻。[536p]

When using moxa sticks for small ailments, a gentler approach causes less fear of the treatment; if used excessively, the effects will surely manifest. When a hard, unyielding lump is encountered, known as a "stone sore," apply strong moxibustion over it to break apart the stone within.

According to the "Ten Books of Dongyuan," when a sore first appears on the back, signifying potential development, it is red, hot, swollen, and painful. First, cover it with moist paper, then observe where it dries first—that spot indicates the head of the sore. Take garlic, slice it into pieces about the thickness of three coins, place it on the head, and perform strong moxibustion three times, replacing with a new slice of garlic each time. Apply moxibustion until the pain subsides; if there is no pain, continue until it begins to hurt. It is best to treat early. In one to two days, ten treatments yield ten recoveries; in three to four days, six to seven recoveries; by five to six days, three to four recoveries. After ten or more days, moxibustion is no longer advisable.

If multiple heads arise in one spot, crush garlic into a paste and form a thin cake. Place it on the head and burn moxa over it, which can also yield effective results. If a red swelling first appears, and there is a yellow, corn-like head in the middle, take a single clove of garlic, cut off both ends, and slice the middle part to place on the sore head. Apply moxibustion fourteen to a maximum of forty-nine times.

According to the "Heart Method of Danxi," the emergence of sores is either due to internal accumulated heat or external cold combined with internal heat. By applying moxibustion to the site of development to disperse its toxicity, early treatment can change a deep issue into a shallow one, alleviating severity into mildness.[536p]

诸项灸法皆好，惟骑竹马灸法，尤为切要，此消患于未形之策。　　多灸则内服乳粉托里散，防火气入心。　　《医垒元戎》曰：疮疡自外而入者不宜灸，自内而出者宜灸。外入者托之而不内，内出者接之而令外。故经曰：陷者灸之。灸而不痛，痛而后止其灸。灸而不痛者，先及其溃，所以不痛；而后及良肉，所以痛也。灸而痛，不痛而后止其灸。灸而痛者，先及其未溃，所以痛；而次及将溃，所以不痛也。　　《薛己医案》曰：伍氏云：凡用蒜饼灸者，盖蒜味辛温有毒，主散痈疽，假火势以行药力也。有只用艾炷灸者，此可施于顽疽痼发之类。凡赤肿紫黑毒甚者，须以蒜艾同灸为妙。　　凡治痈疽、发背、疔疮，若初灸即痛者，由毒气轻浅；灸而不痛者，乃毒气深重。悉宜内服追毒排脓，外敷消毒之药。大抵痈疽不可不痛，又不可大痛，闷乱不知痛者难治。[537p]

All methods of moxibustion are good, but the riding bamboo horse moxibustion method is particularly crucial, as it prevents ailments before they manifest. If moxibustion is applied excessively, one should take powdered milk internally to prevent the fire from entering the heart. The "Medical Cliff Original General” states: sores that enter from the outside should not be treated with moxibustion; those that emerge from the inside should be treated. External invasions should be expelled rather than treated internally, while internal discharges should be guided outward. Therefore, the classic says: "If it is trapped, moxibustion should be applied." If moxibustion does not cause pain, one should cease when it becomes painful. If it does not hurt, it must have already reached the ulcer, hence the lack of pain; afterwards, it reaches healthy flesh, hence the pain arises. If moxibustion causes pain, one should stop once the pain alleviates. If it is painful, it must first reach the pre-ulcerative stage; subsequently, it affects areas about to ulcerate, thus not inducing pain.

According to Xue Ji's medical case studies, Wu states: "For moxibustion with garlic cakes, garlic's spicy, warm, and toxic properties primarily disperse sores and abscesses, using the heat to activate the medicinal effects." For those who only use moxa cones, this can be applied to stubborn ulcers, or similar conditions. For all cases of red, swollen, and darkly toxic sores, moxibustion with garlic and moxa together is ideal.

In treating abscesses, furuncles, and carbuncles, if initial moxibustion causes pain, it indicates the toxic gases are superficial; if there is no pain, the toxicity is deeper. Both cases should involve internal medication to eliminate toxins and pus, and external applications to disinfect. Generally, abscesses should not be painless; if they are overwhelmingly painful, or if one is disoriented and feels no pain, treatment becomes difficult.[537p]

　　凡隔蒜灸者，不论壮数，则邪无所容，而真气不损，但头顶见疮，宜用骑竹马法及足三里灸之。　　夫疮疡之证，有诸中必形诸外，在外者引而拔之，在内者疏而下之。灼艾之功甚大，若毒气郁结，瘀血凝滞，轻者或可药散，重者药无全功矣。东垣曰：若不针烙，则毒气无从而解，是故善治毒者，必用隔蒜灸。舍是而用苦寒败毒等剂，其壮实内热者或可，彼怯弱气虚者，未有不败者也。又有毒气沉伏，或年高气弱，或服克伐之剂，气益以虚，脓因不溃者，必假火力以成功。大凡针灸，若未溃则拔引郁毒，已溃则接补阳气，祛散寒邪，疮口自合，其功甚大。常治四肢疮疡气血不足者，只以前法灸之皆愈。疔毒甚者，尤宜灸。盖热毒中隔，内外不通，不发泄则不解散。若处贫居僻，一时无药，则用隔蒜灸法尤便，每三壮一易蒜片，大概以百壮为度。[538p]

Generally, for those who undergo garlic isolation moxibustion, it does not matter whether the condition is severe or mild; the pathogenic energy has no place to reside, and the vital energy remains intact. However, if sores appear on the crown of the head, one should use the bamboo horse method and moxibustion at the acupuncture point Zusanli. Sores and ulcers must manifest externally if there are internal issues; those on the outside should be drawn out, while internal ones should be dispersed and drained. The effects of moxibustion are significant. If toxic energy becomes stagnant and blood coagulates, lighter cases might be relieved with medicinal herbs, but in severe cases, medicine cannot work effectively. Dongyuan stated: If one does not use acupuncture or cautery, the toxic energy cannot be resolved. Therefore, those skilled in treating toxins must use garlic isolation moxibustion. Using harsh, cold remedies to dispel toxins can be effective for those with substantial internal heat, but for those who are weak and have deficient energy, failure is inevitable. Additionally, if toxic energy is hidden, whether due to age or weakness, or from taking harmful medications that further deplete energy, resulting in pus that does not discharge, one must rely on the power of fire to achieve success. Generally, in acupuncture and moxibustion, if there is no discharge, one should draw out the stagnant toxins; if it has discharged, one should restore the Yang energy and eliminate cold pathogenic influence, allowing the sore to close naturally. This method is particularly effective for treating sores in the limbs due to insufficient energy and blood. For such cases, the aforementioned moxibustion method is adequate for healing. In cases of severe abscess, moxibustion is especially advisable, as heat toxins trapped within create a barrier, and without proper release, they cannot be dispersed. If one is in a poor and isolated situation with no medicine available, garlic isolation moxibustion is particularly convenient, changing the garlic slices every three uses, typically capping at around one hundred uses.[538p]

用大蒜取其辛而能散，用艾炷取其火力能透，如法灸之，必疮发脓溃，继以神异膏贴之，不日自愈。一能使疮不开大，二内肉不坏，三疮口易合，见效甚神。丹溪云：惟头为诸阳所聚，艾壮宜小而少。　　凡疮不起者托而起之，不成脓者补而成之，使不内攻，脓成而及时针之，不数旬即愈矣。常见患者皆畏针痛而不肯用，又有恐伤肉而不肯用。殊不知疮虽发于肉薄之所，若其脓成必肿高寸余，疮皮又厚分许，用针深不过二分，若发于背必肿高二三寸，入针止于寸许，况患处肉既已坏，何痛之有？何伤之虑？凡怯弱之人，或患附骨等疽，待脓自通，以致大溃，不能收敛，气血沥尽而死者多矣。　　凡疮既成脓，皮肤不得疏泄，昧者待其自穿。殊不知少壮而充实者，或能自解。若老弱之人，气血枯槁，或兼攻发太过，不行针刺，脓毒乘虚内攻，穿肠腐膜，鲜不悞事。[539p]

Using garlic for its pungency can disperse, and using mugwort for its fiery properties can promote penetration. If these methods are applied through moxibustion, the sore will inevitably fester and break down, followed by applying a miraculous ointment, leading to self-healing in no time. This method not only prevents the sore from becoming large but also preserves the internal flesh, allowing the sore's opening to close easily, showing remarkable effects. Danxi said: "The head is where all yang energies converge; therefore, mugwort should be used in small and limited amounts."

For sores that do not break, they should be prodded to break. For those not festering, they should be supplemented to promote festering, preventing internal attacks. When the pus forms, timely needling will lead to healing in less than a few weeks. Patients often fear the pain of needles and refuse treatment, or they worry about damaging the flesh. They do not realize that though the sore emerges in thin flesh, if the pus forms, it will swell a couple of inches high, and the skin of the sore will thicken; using a needle, the depth should not exceed two-tenths of an inch. If it arises on the back, the swelling may be two to three inches high, and the needle should only enter about an inch deep. Moreover, when the affected flesh is already damaged, what pain is there? What is there to worry about in terms of injury?

For timid or weak individuals, or those suffering from bone-related abscesses, waiting for the pus to drain naturally often leads to severe ruptures that cannot heal and result in the loss of vital energy and blood, leading to many deaths. Once a sore has formed pus, the skin should not be loosely vented, yet some foolish individuals wait for it to rupture on their own. They fail to understand that younger and more robust individuals might be able to self-resolve. However, for the elderly and weak, with depleted vital energy and blood, or those who excessively induce attacks, not using needling allows the pathogenic toxicity to exploit the situation and attack internally, leading to severe consequences.[539p]

若毒结四肢，砭刺少缓，则腐溃深大，亦难收敛。毒结于颊项胸腹紧要之地，不问壮弱，急宜针刺；否则难治。大抵疮疡之证，感有轻重，发有深浅，浅者肿高而软，发于血脉；深者肿下而坚，发于筋骨。然又有发于骨髓者，则皮肉不变，故古人制法，浅宜砭而深宜刺，使瘀血去于毒聚之始则易消。若脓成之时，气血壮实者或自出。怯弱者，不行针刺，鲜有不悞。凡疮疡透膜，十无一生，虽以大补药治之，亦不能救，此可为待脓自出之戒也。故东垣云：毒气无从而解，脓瘀无从而泄，过时不烙，反攻于内，内既消败，欲望其生，岂可得乎？兹举一二以告同道，并使患者知所慎云。　　若治元气不足之证，即其初患，便当内用参、芪、归、朮，温补脾胃；外用桑枝葱熨，接补阳气，使自消散。[540p]

If poison has settled in the limbs, and the acupuncture is not effective, then the decay will be deep and significant, making it difficult to contain. When poison accumulates in critical areas such as the cheeks, neck, chest, and abdomen, regardless of whether the person is strong or weak, urgent puncturing is required; otherwise, it will be hard to treat. Generally, the manifestations of sores and ulcers vary in severity, with deep or shallow presentations. Shallow ones are swollen, raised, and soft, arising from the blood vessels; deep ones, however, are swollen, hardened, and arise from the tendons and bones. There are also those that arise from the marrow, where the skin and flesh remain unchanged. Thus, the ancients devised methods where shallow cases should be treated with scraping and deep cases should be pierced, to eliminate stagnant blood at the onset of the poison accumulation for easier resolution. If pus has formed and the vital energy is strong, it may naturally drain out. For those who are weak and timid, needling is not recommended, as few escape regret. When sores and ulcers penetrate the membrane, there is a ten to one chance of death; even using major tonics cannot save them, thus this serves as a warning to await the pus to drain out. Therefore, Dongyuan states: if the toxic qi cannot be resolved and the pus and stagnation cannot be released, and time passes without treatment, it will turn inward and harm the internal organs. Once the internal decay occurs, how can one hope for survival? I will share one or two examples for my colleagues and alert the patients to be cautious.

If treating symptoms of insufficient vital energy, at the onset of the condition, one should internally use ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and poria to warmly nourish the spleen and stomach; externally, use mulberry branches and green onions for steaming, to help restore the yang energy for natural dissipation.[540p]

若久而不能成脓者，亦用前二法补助以速之。若脓既成而不溃，用艾于当头灸数炷以出之，却服十全大补汤。　　又云：痈有椒眼十数头，或如蜂窠莲房，脓血不出者，用针横直裂之。如无椒眼之类，只消直入取脓，不必裂之。一法当椒眼上个个灸之亦佳，不必裂也。又云：痈者皮薄肿高，多有椒眼粒；疽者皮肤顽硬，状如牛颈之皮。痈成脓则宜针，针宜用马衔铁为之，形如韭叶样，两面皆利，可以横直裂之五六分许，攻去毒血，须先灸之而后裂。疽成脓则宜烙，可用银篦大二寸，长六寸，火上烧令赤，急于毒上熨烙，得脓利为度。　　毒气已成者，宜用托里以速其脓；脓成者当验其生熟深浅而针之。脓生而用针，气血既泄，脓反难成；若脓熟而不针，腐溃益深，疮口难敛。若疮深而针浅，内脓不出，外血反泄；若疮浅而针深，内脓虽出，良肉受伤。[541p]

If it has been a long time without pus formation, one should employ the previous two methods as supplements to hasten it. If pus has already formed but does not drain, moxa should be applied at the center with a few cones to draw it out, followed by taking a decoction of "Ten Complete Tonics."

It is also noted: if there are ten or more pepper eyes in the abscess, or it resembles a honeycomb or lotus pod, and the pus and blood do not emerge, use a needle to puncture it both horizontally and vertically. If there are no such pepper eyes, simply puncture straight in to extract the pus without splitting. Applying moxa to each pepper eye is also a good method, and it is not necessary to split.

Moreover, it is stated: an abscess has thin skin and a high swelling, often with pepper-like granules; while a carbuncle has tough skin, resembling a cow's neck. When an abscess is ripe, it is appropriate to use a needle, preferably one made of horse bit iron, shaped like a chive leaf, sharp on both sides, capable of slicing five or six tenths of an inch, used to eradicate toxic blood. One must first apply moxa before puncturing. When a carbuncle is ripe, it is suitable for cauterization; a silver spatula about two inches wide and six inches long can be heated until red-hot and quickly applied to the toxic area to cauterize, resulting in the pus being expelled.

For already formed toxic gas, it is advisable to use a tool to hasten the emergence of pus; once the pus is formed, one must check its ripeness, depth, and state before using a needle. If the pus is ripe and a needle is used, the qi and blood will already have flowed out, making it difficult for additional pus to form; however, if the pus is ripe and not punctured, the necrosis will deepen, and the wound will be hard to close. If the wound is deep and the needle is shallow, the internal pus will not exit, and external blood will instead leak out; if the wound is shallow and the needle is deep, while the internal pus may exit, healthy flesh may become damaged.[541p]

若元气虚弱，必先补而后针，其脓一出，诸证自退；若脓出而反痛，或烦躁呕逆，皆由胃气亏损，宜急补之。若背疮热毒炽盛，中央肉黯，内用托里壮其脾胃，外用乌金膏涂于黯处。其赤处渐高，黯处渐低，至六七日间，赤黯分界，自有裂纹，如刀划然，黯肉渐溃矣，当用铍针利剪徐徐去之，须使不知疼痛，不见鲜血为妙。虽有裂纹，脓未流利，及脓水虽出，而仍痛者，皆未通于内，并用针于纹中引之。患于背胛之间，肉腐脓出，肿痛仍作，此内有毒筋间隔，脓未通耳，尤宜引之。若元气虚弱，悞服克伐，患处不痛，或肉将死，急温补脾胃，亦有生者。后须纯补之药，庶可收敛。[542p]

If the vital energy is weak, one must first nourish before puncturing. Once the pus is released, the various symptoms will subside. However, if the pus is expelled and there is renewed pain, or if there is restlessness and vomiting, this is due to a deficiency in stomach energy, and urgent nourishment is required. If there is severe heat and toxins from back sores, with the central flesh darkened, internally use medicines to strengthen the spleen and stomach, and externally apply black gold ointment to the darkened area. As the red areas gradually rise and the dark areas gradually lower, within six or seven days, a boundary will be formed between the red and dark areas, with cracks appearing as if marked by a knife, and the dark flesh will begin to deteriorate. One should use fine needles to carefully cut away, ensuring that the patient feels no pain and no blood is seen. Even if there are cracks and pus has not fully flowed, or even if the pus and water have come out but there is still pain, this indicates that the inner pathways are not yet open, and needles should be used to draw it out along the cracks. If there is decay in the flesh between the shoulder blades and pus is released but swelling and pain persist, this indicates the presence of toxic filaments obstructing it, and the pus has not been fully released. It is especially important to draw this out. If the vital energy is weak and there is excessive use or loss of energy, and the affected area is not painful, or if the flesh appears to be dying, urgent warming and nourishing of the spleen and stomach is needed; there may still be a chance for recovery. In the end, pure nourishing medicines should be employed to help consolidate the healing.[542p]

若妄用刀针，去肉出血，则气无所依附，气血愈虚，元气愈伤矣，何以生肌收敛乎？　　针灸之法，有太乙人神、周身血忌、逐年尻神、逐日人神，而其穴有禁针禁灸之论，犯之者其病难瘳，理固然也。但疮疡气血已伤，肌肉已坏，宜迎而夺之，顺而取之，非平人针灸之比，何忌之有？《外科精义》云：疮疡之证，毒气无从而解，脓瘀无从而泄，反攻于内，内既消败，欲望其生，岂可得乎？危恶之发于致命之所，祸在反掌，腹痈囊痈，二便不通，胸腹胀闷，唇疔喉痹，咽喉肿塞，其祸尤速，患者审之！　　蜞针法，治痈疽初作，先以笔管一个入蚂蜞一条，以管口对疮头，使蜞吮疮脓血，其毒即散。[543p]

If one recklessly uses knives and needles, causing flesh to be cut and blood to flow, then the vital energy has nowhere to attach, and both the vital energy and blood become increasingly deficient, leading to greater injury of the original energy. How can one expect to grow flesh and promote healing in such a state?

In the practice of acupuncture and moxibustion, there are rules concerning forbidden points and prohibited practices, including the prohibitions of using needles on certain days or during certain times. Violating these rules can lead to difficulties in healing, for this reasoning is indeed sound. However, when wounds and lesions have already harmed the vital energy and blood, and the muscles are damaged, it is better to confront and seize the problem in a straightforward manner. This is not to be compared to the acupuncture of a healthy individual, so what prohibitions need to be observed?

"The Essentials of Surgery" states: In the case of wounds and sores where poisonous energy cannot be resolved and pus and clots cannot be drained, the attack turns inward. When the interior has already decayed, how can one expect healing? The dangers from critical conditions can arise suddenly, with peril lurking at every turn: abdominal abscesses, urinary obstructions, chest and abdominal distension, lip sores, throat paralysis, and swollen and blocked throats lead to swift catastrophe. Patients must be vigilant!

As for the technique of "earthworm needle," it is used to treat initial occurrences of boils and sores. First, a pen tube is inserted into the body of the earthworm, aligning the tube's opening with the sore's head, allowing the earthworm to suck out the pus and blood, dispersing the poison effectively.[543p]

如疮大须换三四条。若吮正穴，蜞必死矣，累试累效。若血不止，以藕节上泥涂之。若疮头未明，以井边泥涂上先干处即是。　　痈疽初发小点，一二日间急以大蒜头横切如钱，贴其中心，顿小艾炷灸之五壮而止。若形状稍大，以黄秆纸蘸酒全贴，认先干处为筋脚，于先干处灸之，或两处先干皆灸，但五七壮止。[544p]

If the sore is large, it must be changed out for three or four strips. If you suck on the right point, the pestilence will surely die; this has been tested repeatedly. If the bleeding does not stop, apply mud from the lotus root's joint. If the sore's head has not yet formed clearly, apply mud from the edge of the well to the part that has dried first.

For initial small points of carbuncles and sores that appear, within one or two days, urgently cut a whole garlic bulb horizontally like a coin and place it at the center, then prompt moxa treatment five times and stop. If the shape is somewhat larger, use yellow straw paper soaked in alcohol and apply it entirely, recognizing the dried part as the sinew. Treat the drier part with moxa, or you can apply it to both drier parts, but limit it to five or seven applications.[544p]

又法，屈指从四围寻按，遇痛处即是根，就此重按深入，自觉轻快，即此灸之，更于别处灸。若或大肿，即捣蒜为饼焙干，蘸法酢灸热，更换频罨，或以熨斗火于蒜饼上熨之，更换热饼频熨。如觉患处走散，即以绵帛覆盖，勿令气泄，俟少间敷药。凡痈疽展大如龟之形，且看头向上下，先灸其前两脚，次灸其尾，或红筋走紧而长，从尽处灸之，须留头并后两脚勿灸。若尽灸之，不惟火气壅聚，彼毒无所走散，又攻入里也。或辨认不明，以白芷三分，汉椒、桑白皮各一分，连须葱白十片，取新汲水煎汤入酸酢半盏，淋洗少顷，其筋自现，可以辨验头尾。　　豆豉饼治疮疡肿硬不溃，及溃而不敛，并一切顽疮恶疮，江西豆豉为末，唾津和作饼子，如钱大，厚如三文，置患处，以艾壮于饼上灸之。[545p]

Another method involves bending one's fingers to feel around the affected area. When you encounter a painful spot, that is the root. Press deeply there, and if you feel lighter, then apply moxibustion. Additionally, apply it in other areas. If there is significant swelling, pound garlic into a cake, dry it, and dip it in vinegar for moxibustion. Replace it frequently with hot packs, or use an iron to heat the garlic cake and press it frequently. If you notice the pain radiating, cover the affected area with a soft cloth to prevent the energy from dispersing, and wait a little before applying medicine.

For abscesses that have swollen greatly, resembling the shape of a turtle, observe the position of the head; first, apply moxibustion to the front legs, then to the tail. If there are red veins that are tight and long, treat them from the end, leaving the head and the two back legs untouched. If you apply moxibustion to the entire area, not only will the heat become trapped, but the poison will also not disperse and will invade deeper.

If you are unsure about the diagnosis, use three parts of white angelica, one part each of Sichuan pepper and mulberry bark, and ten pieces of green onion whites. Boil them in freshly drawn water with half a cup of vinegar, and wash the area for a while until the veins appear, so you can identify the head and tail.

Fermented black beans can treat ulcers and solid swellings that do not suppurate, as well as non-healing stubborn sores. Use Jiangxi fermented black beans powdered into fine powder, mix with saliva to form cakes about the size of a coin and three-tenths of an inch thick. Place the cake on the afflicted area and apply moxibustion using mugwort on top of the cake.[545p]

饼干，再用唾津和作如疮大，用漱口水调作饼覆患处，以艾铺于饼上烧之。如未成者用之即消，已成者纵不能全消，其毒顿减，前人俱称有奇功，不可忽之！　　霹雳火治内疔之证，发汗之妙方也。凡疮始觉，不曾服出汗之药，过数日间，外证皆罢，或在胸腹，或在胁肋，赤焮肿起，此乃毒气入里，内疔之所发也。宜用此法出汗，毒气方能出也。先置水桶一个，铁铫一个，令病人侧卧于桶上，四围以衣衾盖护，勿令泄气。却以鹅卵石火烧极红，放铫内，以铫安桶内，以酢投于铫内淬之，熏蒸出汗，未透，再加火力再淬之，须令肿处汗透，不必遍身出汗也。　　附子饼治溃疡，气血虚不能收敛，或风邪袭之，以致气血不能运于疮所，不能收敛。用炮附子去皮脐研末，以唾津和为饼，置疮口处，艾壮于饼上灸之，每日灸数壮，但令微热勿痛。如饼干，再用唾津和做，以疮口湿润为度。[546p]

Biscuit: Use saliva to make it the size of a sore, and with mouthwash, adjust it to cover the affected area. Place mugwort on top and burn it. If the sore is not fully formed, it will vanish upon application; if it has already formed, it may not completely disappear, but the toxicity will be greatly reduced. Previous practitioners have all claimed it has miraculous effects, so it should not be overlooked!

Pill of Thunderfire is a wonderful remedy for internal carbuncles, effective for inducing sweat. When a sore is first noticed and no sweating medicine has been taken, after several days, external symptoms will cease, either affecting the chest and abdomen or the sides, with red swelling. This indicates that toxic air has entered within, manifesting as internal carbuncles. This method should be used to induce sweat so that the toxins can be released.

First, prepare a water bucket and an iron pot. Have the patient lie on their side over the bucket, protecting them with clothing and blankets to prevent loss of steam. Then take a heated river stone until it glows red and place it in the pot. Put the pot into the bucket and sprinkle vinegar onto it to create steam for sweating. If the sweat does not penetrate, increase the heat and add more vinegar; ensure that the swollen area sweats through, without requiring the entire body to sweat.

Aconite biscuits treat ulcers when there is deficiency in qi and blood, unable to retract, or when wind evil attacks, preventing qi and blood from circulating in the sore, thus failing to contract. Use processed aconite, peeled and ground, combined with saliva to form a biscuit, and place this on the sore. Burn mugwort on top of the biscuit daily, a few times, ensuring it feels slightly warm without causing pain. Adjust the biscuit's consistency with saliva to keep the sore moist.[546p]

　　《证治准绳》曰：砭法治丹毒疔疮，红丝走散，或时毒瘀血壅盛。用细磁器击碎，取有锋芒者一块，以箸一根劈开头尖夹之，用线缚定，两手指轻撮箸，稍令磁芒正对患处悬寸许，再用箸一根频击箸头，令毒血遇刺皆出，毒入腹膨胀者难治。　　灸乃开结破硬之法，倘有一点白粒，如粟米起，四围微肿如钱，便当于米粒上着艾，灸十四五壮。三日内灸者，只成灸疮而散；三日外者，其肿渐少，宜多灸之，或灸火着处，则结热可伸，灸处先溃，则毒势分减，庶免展开，不致下陷，及坏筋骨伤气血也。所谓灸至不痛者，谓着皮肉未坏处则痛，火至着毒处则不痛，必令火气至着毒处方止。所谓灸至痛者，谓初着毒处不痛，至好肉则痛，必令火气至好肉方止。畏灸者，或用独蒜瓣、或用豆豉饼、或用椒姜盐烂捣捻作饼子，如三钱厚，铺艾灸之，热则易新饼，亦可散也。[547p]

"The 'Principles of Treatment' states: The method of acupuncture for treating carbuncles and sores involves the dispersal of red threads, with possible accumulation of toxic blood. Use a piece of fine ceramic, break it into sharp pieces, take one piece, split it with a chopstick, and secure it with a thread. With your fingers, lightly press the chopstick to align the sharp edge with the affected area, hanging about an inch above it. Then, use another chopstick to repeatedly strike the head of the first chopstick, allowing toxic blood to be released upon puncture. If the toxicity is deep within the belly, it is difficult to treat.

Moxibustion is a method to break up blockages and hard masses. If there is a small white bump, like a grain of millet, surrounded by slight swelling like a coin, moxa should be applied directly to the grain for fourteen or fifteen treatments. If treated within three days, it will only form a sore and disperse; if treated after three days, the swelling will gradually decrease, so it is advisable to apply more moxibustion. If the moxa burns the area, the heat can extend the blockage, and if the treatment area ulcerates first, the toxicity will lessen, hopefully preventing further spread and avoiding damage to muscles, bones, and the blood.

When it is said that moxibustion is painless, it means that if it’s applied to skin and flesh that isn’t damaged, it will hurt; but if it reaches the toxic area, it will not hurt. Therefore, the heat must reach the toxic area to be effective. When it’s said that moxibustion causes pain, it means that the initial application to the toxic area is painless, but it hurts when the heat reaches healthy flesh; thus, the heat must reach healthy flesh to be effective.

Those who are afraid of moxibustion may use a clove of garlic, or a fermented soybean cake, or a paste made from mashed pepper, ginger, and salt, about the thickness of three coins, spread with moxa and treated. If it gets hot, replace it with a fresh cake, which can also aid in dispersing the condition."[547p]

　　灸乃从治之意，惟头为诸阳所聚，艾炷宜小而少；若少阳分野，尤不可灸，灸之多至不救。亦有因灸而死者。盖虚甚，孤阳将绝，其脉必浮数而大，且鼓精神，必短而昏，无以抵当火气，宜其危也。　　刘宗厚曰：此谓痈疽初发，宜灸之也。然诸疮患久成痛者，常有脓水不绝，其脓不臭，内无歹肉，尤宜用附子浸透，切作大片，厚二三分，于疮上着艾灸之，仍服内托之药，隔二三日再灸之，不五七次，自然肌肉长满矣。至有脓水恶物，渐渍根深者，郭氏治用白面、硫黄、大蒜三物，一处捣烂，看疮大小，捻作饼子，厚约三分，于疮上用艾炷灸二十一壮，一灸一易，后隔四五日方用翠霞锭子，并信效锭子，互换用之，纴入疮内，歹肉尽去，好肉长平，然后贴收敛之药，内服应病之剂，调理即瘥矣。盖不止宜灸于疮之始发也。大抵始发宜灸，要汗下补养之药对证，至灸冷疮，亦须内托之药切当。设反逆，不惟不愈，恐致转生他病之患也。[548p]

Cauterization is intended for treatment; only the head is where all yang energies converge, and the moxa should be small and few. If it involves the lesser yang regions, it is especially inadvisable to cauterize, as excessive cauterization may lead to no remedy. There are also instances of death resulting from cauterization. This occurs due to severe deficiency; solitary yang approaches extinction, and its pulse is bound to be floating, rapid, and large, while the spirit is bound to be short and murky, lacking the ability to withstand the fire's heat, which naturally leads to danger.

Liu Zonghou said: This refers to the early onset of boils and sores, where cauterization is advisable. However, for longstanding sores that cause pain, which often have continuous pus without an odor and no decayed flesh inside, it is more appropriate to soak with aconite, cut into large pieces, about two to three fen thick, and place them on the sore for moxa cauterization, while also taking internal medicinal remedies. Cauterization should be repeated every two to three days, and after five to seven times, the muscle will naturally fill in. For sores with foul pus and deep-rooted issues, the Guo family uses a combination of flour, sulfur, and garlic, all ground together. Depending on the size of the sore, form them into patties about three fen thick, and apply moxa cauterization twenty-one times, replacing it after each treatment. After four to five days, use the Qingxia pill and Xinxiao pill, alternating their use, and insert them into the sore until all decayed flesh is gone and healthy flesh emerges. Then, apply a consolidating medicine and take internal remedies suited to the condition, and with proper regulation, healing will follow.

Therefore, cauterization is not only appropriate at the initial onset of a sore. Generally, in the early stages, cauterization is indicated, and it is essential to supplement with medicines that contrast the condition while sweating and reducing. Even when cauterizing cold sores, effective internal remedies must be applied. If contrary treatments are used, not only will recovery fail, but it may also lead to the onset of other diseases.[548p]

　　　　针烙

　　凡用针烙，先察痈疽之浅深，及脓未成已成。高阜而软者，发于血脉；肿平而坚者，发于筋脉；皮色不相辨者，发于骨髓。高阜而浅者，用铍针开之。疽始生白粒，便可消退，渐长如蜂窠者，寻初起白粒上烙，及四围烙四五处。如牛项之皮者，疽顶平而浅者，皆宜用火针烙之。其针用圆针，如箸如纬，铤大，头圆平，长六七寸，一样二枚，蘸香油于炭火中烧红，于疮头近下烙之，宜斜入向软处，一烙不透，再烙必得脓也。疮口烙者，名曰热疮，脓水常流下，不假按抑，用纴药使疮口不合。旧用纸捻及新取牛膝根，如疮口大小，略刮去皮，一头系线纴之。不如用翠青、搜脓等锭子，临用以糯米饭和成软条子，看浅深纴之，外用拔毒膏贴之。疮毒未成，烙之可散；溃而未破，针之可消，但要用得其宜耳。[549p]

Needling and Cauterization

When using needling and cauterization, first examine the depth and severity of the abscess and whether the pus is formed or not. A raised and soft area corresponds to the blood vessels; a flat and firm area relates to the tendons. If the skin color is indistinct, it originates from the bone marrow. For lightly raised areas, use a copper needle to incise them. If the abscess has just begun with white granules, it can be resolved; if it grows like a beehive, then cauterize the initial white granules and four or five surrounding areas. For those at the level of the skin, if the abscess is flat and shallow, it is appropriate to use a fire needle for cauterization. The needles should be round, similar to chopsticks or weft threads, thicker, with a rounded flat head, each around six to seven inches long, and two alike. Dip in fragrant oil and heat in charcoal until red hot, then cauterize near the base of the wound, angled into the softer area. If one cauterization does not penetrate, a second will yield pus. Cauterization at the wound opening is known as "hot sore"; pus flows without needing pressure to suppress it, using threads to keep the wound open. It was once common to use paper twist or freshly harvested root of the ox knee, sized to the wound, slightly scraping the skin, and tying one end with thread. It is better to use items like emerald green or pus-dispersing pills, mixing them with glutinous rice into soft strips, observing the depth for application, and externally applying detoxifying ointment. If the wound poison has not fully formed, cauterization may disperse it; if it has become ulcerated but not ruptured, needling can resolve it, but care must be taken to use the appropriate method.[549p]

若当用针烙而不用，则毒无从而泄，脓瘀蚀其膏膜，烂筋坏骨，难乎免矣。若毒深针浅，脓不得出，毒浅烙深，损伤良肉，不当其所，他处作头，此皆不能愈疾，反增痛耳。或瘰疬溃久不愈，漏疮经年，或通或闭，痈疽疮口不收，皆因冷滞不能收敛，亦因疮口内外四畔烙之。痈疽正发，及脓见后红肿焮开，用铁针烧赤，四围刺之，则红肿随缩矣。　　《古今医统》曰：烙法，方其已熟未溃之时，用铁一烙，极是快意。方扇火欲着时，诚是惊人！余常用矣，临时犹且颤悸，况未曾经历者乎？烙后脓水流通，百无所忌，名曰熟疮。其疮突者针口宜向下，然须是熟于用烙者，识浅深，知穴道，审生熟。非其时则所出皆生血，当其时则出黄脓瘀肉。用尖针烙者，不得法，尖针头细，其口易合，惟用平圆头者为妙。盖要孔穴透，或恐疮口再合，用牛膝根如疮口之大小，略割去粗皮，插入疮口，外留半寸许，即用嫩橘叶、地锦草各一握，研成膏敷之。[550p]

If one is to use a needle to cauterize but fails to do so, then the poison finds no outlet, pus collects and erodes the mucous membrane, rotting tendons and damaging bones, making it difficult to avoid. If the poison is deep and the needle is shallow, the pus cannot be expelled; if the poison is superficial and the cauterization is deep, it harms the healthy flesh. If not handled correctly, further issues arise, causing more pain. If an abscess has festered and does not heal over time, or if a chronic ulcer alternates between opening and closing, or if the mouth of the abscess does not close, it is all due to cold stagnation that prevents contraction, as well as cauterization from within and without the ulcer.

When an abscess is just beginning and when pus appears, with redness and swelling presenting, one should use a heated iron needle to cauterize the area and prick around it, and then the redness and swelling will shrink. The "Ancient and Modern Medical Compilation" states: "The cauterization technique is best applied when the ulcer is ripe but not yet ruptured; using iron to cauterize at this stage is particularly effective. When the fire of the cauterization is just beginning, it can indeed be alarming! I have used it frequently; even in practice, I still feel a tremor, let alone those who have never experienced it before!"

After cauterization, the pus should flow freely, and there should be no taboos, which is referred to as a ripe sore. When a sore is protruding, the needle's hole should be directed downward; however, it is essential for the practitioner to be experienced with cauterization, to understand the depths, know the acupuncture points, and distinguish between what is mature and immature. If done improperly, only fresh blood will be released; if done at the right time, yellow pus and necrotic tissue will emerge. It is incorrect to use a sharp needle for cauterization; a fine needle tip is prone to closing up, while instead, a flat and rounded tip is ideal. It is crucial that the hole is permeable, or else the ulcer's mouth may close again. One should take a root of the Achyranthes, matching the size of the ulcer mouth, slightly peel the coarse skin off, insert it into the ulcer, leaving about half an inch outside, and then apply a paste made of a handful of tender mandarin leaves and Chinese violet, ground together.[550p]

牛膝能使恶血常流，二药温凉止痛，随干随换，此十全之功也。　　《景岳全书》曰：按立斋云：灼艾之法，必使痛者灸至不痛，不痛者灸至痛，则毒必随火而散，否则非徒无益而反害之。愚意痈疽为患，无非血气雍滞，留结不行之所致。凡大结大滞者，最不易散，必欲散之，非借火力不能速也，所以极宜用灸。然又有孙道人神仙熏照方，其法尤精尤妙。若毒邪稍缓，邪深经远而气有不达，灸之为良；若毒邪炽盛，其势猛急而垂危者，则宜用熏照方，更胜于灸也。　　上古有砭石之制，《内经》有九针之别，制虽不同，而去病之意则一也。其疮疡一科，用针为贵。用之之际，虽云量其溃之浅深，尤当随其肉之厚薄：若皮薄针深，则反伤良肉，益增其溃；肉厚针浅，则脓毒不出，反益其痛，用针者可不慎哉！至于附骨疽，气毒流注，及有经久不消，内溃不痛者，宜燔针开之。[551p]

Niu Xi can cause the evil blood to flow continuously, while the two medicines warm and cool to relieve pain. They should be changed as they dry, which is the full benefit of the ten. The "Complete Book of Jing Yue" states: According to Li Zhai, the method of moxibustion must ensure that the painful area is treated until it no longer hurts; if it is treated until it hurts more, then the poison will disperse with the fire. Otherwise, it would not only be of no benefit but could also be harmful. My humble opinion is that abscesses and sores arise from stagnation of blood and qi, caused by accumulation that fails to move. Generally, large accumulations and stagnations are the hardest to resolve. To disperse them, one cannot quickly achieve results without the power of fire; hence, moxibustion is particularly advisable. There is also the method of the Daoist Sun, known as the Immortal's moxibustion technique, which is especially refined and clever. If the poison is slightly subdued and deeply entrenched, affecting the qi's flow, moxibustion is effective; however, if the poison is fierce and urgent, posing a grave danger, then one should use the moxibustion method, which surpasses that of moxibustion alone.

In ancient times, there was the use of sharp stones, and "The Inner Canon" mentions the distinction of nine needles. Although their methods differ, the intention to eradicate disease is the same. In the case of sores and ulcers, the use of needles is paramount. When using them, although one may determine the depth of the ulcer’s opening, one must still adjust based on the thickness of the flesh: if the skin is thin and the needle is deep, it can injure the healthy flesh and worsen the ulcer; if the flesh is thick and the needle is shallow, the pus and poison will not be expelled, which will increase the pain. It's crucial to be careful when using needles! As for bone abscesses, where qi and poison accumulate, and in cases of long-standing sores that do not drain and are painless internally, it is advisable to use burning needles to open them.[551p]

若治咽喉之患，当用三棱针；若丹瘤及痈毒四畔焮赤，疼痛如灼，宜用砭石去血，以泄其毒，则重者减，轻者消。如洪氏室患腹痈，脓胀闷瞀，以铍针刺脓出，即苏。一人患囊瘫，脓熟肿胀，小便不利，几殆，急针之，脓水大泄，气通而愈。大抵用针之法，迎而夺之，顺而取之，所谓不治已成治未成，正此意也。今之患者，或畏针而不用，医者又徇患者之意而不针，遂至脓已成而不得溃，或得而溃，所伤已深矣，卒之夭枉者十常八九，亦可悲矣！经曰：天温日明，则人血淖溢而卫气浮，故血易泻，气易行；天寒日阴，则人血凝濇而卫气沉，是以因天时而调血脉也。故凡遇天寒水冰，或阴气凝滞之时，欲行针刺，则先当温衣覆盖，或以艾叶炒热，或热盐热衣类，先熨其处，务令血脉温和而后刺之，则血泻气行，其病立已。若血寒脉濇，遽尔用针，则邪毒不泻，徒伤良肉，反以益其病也。[552p]

If treating throat ailments, one should use a three-edged needle; if there are red and swollen tumors or boils causing pain like burning, it is advisable to use a stone to draw blood in order to release the poison, leading to a reduction in severe cases and complete resolution in mild cases. When Hong's family had abdominal boils with swelling and pressure, using a needle to drain the pus resulted in recovery. In another case, a person suffered from a cyst with pus buildup and difficulty with urination, nearly facing death; immediate needling released a large amount of pus, restoring the flow of energy and resulting in recovery.

Generally, the method of using needles involves approaching and drawing back, aligning and obtaining results, so that what should be treated is done before it has fully developed. Nowadays, some patients, fearing needles, refuse treatment, and doctors, conforming to the patients' wishes, avoid needling, leading to the formation of pus without rupture, or if rupture occurs, serious damage has already been done. Ultimately, many meet untimely ends, which is indeed lamentable!

The classics say: In warm and bright weather, human blood becomes abundant, and the defensive qi rises, thus blood is easily drawn, and energy flows freely; in cold and dark conditions, human blood becomes thick and stagnant while the defensive qi sinks, which is why blood vessels should be adjusted according to the season. Thus, whenever encountering cold weather or icy conditions, if one intends to use acupuncture, one should first warm themselves with clothing, or heat mugwort leaves, or use heated salt or clothing to pre-warm the area, ensuring the blood vessels are warm and gentle before needling. This way, blood can flow and energy can move, and the ailment will resolve immediately. However, if blood is cold and vessels are stagnant, hastily using needles will not release the邪毒 and may only harm healthy flesh, worsening the condition instead.[552p]

　　　　导引

　　《保生秘要》曰：诸毒疮肿导引法，以两手交叉抱颈，以左右肩一上一下，用意使气血和畅，内息绵绵，周身得汗，毒自化解。　　运功，疮疖气濇于皮肤，疽毒皆发于脏腑，患在前，归元发引，患在背，起艮行庭。疮疖之疾，随手可运毛窍，发散肿毒之忧，得力通关，逐出大肠，绕患处着意为之。　　毒初起时，先于患处内小圈而至大圈，复用水以洗之。或毒成不散，则自内里用意，以火攻出。待出脓后，则自外大圈旋转至小圈，仍用水而收口。[553p]

Guide to Healing

The "Secrets of Preserving Life" states: For the guidance method of treating various toxic sores and swellings, cross the hands and embrace the neck; use the left shoulder to rise and the right shoulder to descend, focusing intent to harmonize the flow of qi and blood. With calm breathing, let sweat cover the body, thus allowing the toxins to dissolve naturally.

When practicing the exercises, the poisons and sores may affect the skin, and the toxic conditions arise from the internal organs. If the issue is at the front of the body, direct the energy inward; if it is at the back, push outward. For sores and boils, one can easily manipulate the meridians with the hands to disperse swollen toxins, ensuring that energy flows freely, expelling them through the large intestine while focusing on the afflicted area.

At the initial onset of toxins, begin with small circles around the affected area, gradually expanding to larger circles, and cleanse the area with water. If the toxins are firm and refuse to disperse, then apply heat from within to force them out. Once pus is discharged, rotate in large circles outward to small ones, again using water to close the area.[553p]

　　　　医案

　　《李杲十书》曰：元好问饮酒太过，脉候沉数。九月间脑下项上出小疮，不痛不痒，如白头疮。凡四日后脑项麻木，肿势外散，热毒焮发；又二日痛大作，夜不得寐。医处以五香连翘汤，后再邀予诊视。云：膏粱之变，不当投五香连翘汤，已无及矣；且疽已八日，当先以火攻之，然后用药。以大艾炷如两核许者攻之百壮，始觉痛。次为处方，是足太阳膀胱之经，其病逆，当反治；脉中得弦紧，按之洪大而数，又且有力，必当伏其所主而先其所因，其始则同，其终则异，必先岁气，无伐天和，以时令言之，可收不可汗，经与病俱禁下，法当结者散之，咸以软之，然受寒邪而禁咸，遂制黄连消毒饮治之而愈。
　　《丹溪心法》曰：一男子年五十余，形实色黑，背生红肿，近胛骨下痛甚，脉数而洪紧，食亦呕，正冬月，与麻黄桂枝汤加酒黄蘗、生附子、(艹舌)蒌子、甘草节、羌活、青皮、人参、黄芪、半夏、生姜六贴而消，此非内托之意欤？[554p]

Medical Case

The "Ten Books of Li Gao" states: Yuan Haowen drank excessively, his pulse was deep and rapid. In September, small sores appeared on his neck and the back of his head, which were neither painful nor itchy, resembling whitehead sores. Four days later, he experienced numbness in the head and neck, with swelling spreading outward, and heat toxins flared up; after two more days, the pain intensified, and he could not sleep at night. The physician administered Wuxiang Lianqiao Decoction and later invited me for a diagnosis. I noted that due to the transformation from the rich diet, Wuxiang Lianqiao Decoction was inappropriate to use at this point; moreover, the sore had persisted for eight days, and fire therapy should come first, followed by medication. A large moxa stick about the size of two cherries was used to treat the area with strong vigor, and he began to feel pain. Next, I prescribed a remedy specific to the Taiyang Bladder meridian; the condition was reversed and needed to be treated accordingly; the pulse was tight and rapid, but strong. We had to address the underlying cause first, being mindful not to damage the harmony of heaven throughout the seasons. It was crucial to speak in terms of seasonality; hence treatment should focus on dispersing, softening, and not allowing for any cold pathogens while avoiding salty foods. Ultimately, I prescribed Huanglian Xiaodu Decoction, and he recovered.

The "Danxi Heart Method" states: One man over fifty had a dark complexion, with red swelling on his back, near the shoulder blades, extremely painful. His pulse was rapid, strong, and tight; he also experienced vomiting after eating. In the dead of winter, I prescribed a modified Ma Huang Gui Zhi Decoction with added yellow alkaloid wine, Sheng Fuzhu, (wild) Tuozi, licorice segments, Qianghuo, Qingpi, ginseng, Huangqi, Banxia, and fresh ginger in six doses to reduce the condition. Could this be interpreted as an inner constraint?[554p]

　　尝治一妇人，年将七十，形实性急而好酒，脑生疽，十五日，脉弦紧急且濇，予急用大黄酒煨细切，酒拌炒为末，又酒拌炒人参入姜煎调一钱重，又两时再与，得睡而上半身汗，睡觉病已，此亦内托之意也。
　　东阳李兄年愈逾三十，形瘦肤厚，连得忧患，又因作劳且过于色，忽左腿外廉侧上发一红肿，其大如粟。一医闻其大腑坚实，与承气汤二贴下之，不效。又一医教与大黄、朱砂、生粉草、麒麟竭，又二三贴。半月后召余视之，曰：事去矣！又一李兄四十余，面稍白，神甚劳，忽胁下生一红肿如桃。一人教用补剂，众笑且排，于是以流气饮、十宣散杂进之。旬余后召余视之，余日：非惟不与补剂，抑且多得解利，气血俱惫，难矣！已而果然。[555p]

I once treated a woman nearly seventy years old, who was naturally quick-tempered and fond of wine. She developed a sore on her head. On the fifteenth day, her pulse was tight and urgent, yet thin. I urgently used large yellow wine to stew finely chopped herbs, mixing them with wine and frying them into a powder. I also mixed this powder with wine and combined ginseng with ginger for further decoction, weighing a measure of one qian. After two more doses, she was able to sleep, and sweat appeared on her upper body. After sleeping, her illness was resolved; this too reflects the intention of internal support.

Brother Li from Dongyang, over thirty years old, was thin and had thick skin. He had suffered continuous worries and labored excessively, which led to a sudden red swelling on the outer side of his left leg, as big as a millet grain. One doctor, noting that his large intestine was hard, prescribed two doses of Chengqi Decoction, but it was ineffective. Another doctor recommended a formula with large yellow, vermilion, powdered herbs, and Qilin root, which they combined into two or three doses. Half a month later, he called me to see him, saying: "The issue is resolved!"

Another brother Li, over forty years old, had a slightly pale complexion and looked very fatigued. Suddenly, a red swelling appeared under his ribs, resembling a peach. Someone advised him to take tonics, but others laughed and dismissed it. Thus, he was given a mixture of diuretic and Xuanxuan Powder. After ten days or so, he called me to see him, and I replied: "Not only is it inappropriate to give tonics, but it also causes excess discharge and alleviation on its own. Both qi and blood are exhausted, making recovery difficult!" Eventually, this was indeed the case.[555p]

　　一男子年近六十，形素肥，初夏于左髆外廉侧生一核，方圆二寸余，不甚痛。召余治，诊其脉息，缓大而弱。余日：此因忧闷而生，当气升散之时，须急与人参膏五六斤，又看作何应。病家召他外科，以十宣散五六贴而疮甚。余曰：此大虚也，勿以轻小视之！病家不信，一外科仍以十宣散进之，又五六贴，疮平陷出清水而死。此可为因虚而生痈疽者之戒。
　　一老人年七十，患背疽径尺余，已杂与五香、十宣数十贴，脓血腥秽，呕逆不食者旬余，病人自去吃内托散，膈中不安，且素有淋病三十年，今所苦者淋之痛与呕吐不得睡而已，急以参、芪、归、朮煮膏，以牛膝汤入竹沥饮之，三日后尽药一斤半，淋止思食；七日后尽药四斤，脓自涌出而得睡，又兼旬而安。[556p]

A man nearing sixty had a growth on the outer side of his left hip, about two inches in diameter, which was not very painful. He called me for treatment, and upon examining his pulse, I found it weak and slow. I said, "This is due to sadness and worry. When the qi rises and disperses, you must urgently take five or six pounds of ginseng paste." The patient consulted another surgeon who treated him with a mixture of ten fragrant herbs, applying it five or six times, but the sore worsened. I warned, "This is a significant deficiency; do not underestimate it!" The patient did not believe me, and the other surgeon continued with the same mixture, applying it five or six more times, leading to the sore collapsing and oozing clear fluid, resulting in death. This serves as a warning for those whose abscesses arise from deficiency.

An elderly man aged seventy suffered from an abscess on his back more than a foot in diameter. He had already been treated with various mixtures of spices and ten fragrant herbs dozens of times, with foul blood and pus causing him to vomit and be unable to eat for over ten days. The patient self-medicated with internal medicines, causing discomfort in his abdomen. He also had a history of gonorrhea for thirty years, and now his main suffering was from the pain of this condition and inability to sleep due to vomiting. I urgently prepared a decoction of ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and poria, mixing it with cow knee soup and bamboo juice for him to drink. After three days and a total of one and a half pounds of medicine, his pain ceased, and he began to feel hungry. After seven days and a total of four pounds of medicine, pus began to seep out, allowing him to sleep peacefully, and within ten days he was stable.[556p]

　　一男子年六十余，性好酒肉，背疽见脓，呕逆发热，盖其得内托十宣多矣。医以呕逆，于嘉禾散中加丁香以温胃行气。时七月大热，脉洪数有力，余因谓此脉证在溃疡，尤为忌，然形气实，只与人参膏和竹沥饮之，尽药十五斤，竹百余竿而安。余日：此病幸安也，不薄味，必再作。仍厚味自若，夏月醉后，坐水池中，又年余左胁旁生一软块如饼，二年后软块为疽。本人见脓血淋漓而脉洪数有力，又呕逆食少，遂自以人参膏入竹沥饮之，又百余竿而安。今八十岁，强健如旧。此病两次以老年血气弱，专服人参竹沥而愈。若与内托十宣散，恐未能若是之安全也。[557p]

A man over sixty years old, fond of wine and meat, had a back sore that oozed pus, experienced vomiting and fever, likely due to internal excess. The doctor, addressing the vomiting, added cloves to the Jiahe powder to warm the stomach and move qi. It was July, very hot, and his pulse was strong and rapid; I noted that this pulse indicated an ulcer, which is particularly worrisome. However, he was robust, so I just gave him ginseng paste mixed with bamboo juice, using a total of fifteen pounds of medicine and over a hundred stalks of bamboo. I remarked: this condition is fortunately stable; if he doesn't indulge in flavors, he must still take more. He continued to enjoy rich flavors as usual; after drinking in the summer, he sat by the water tub, and a year later a soft lump like a cake appeared near his left side. Two years later, the lump turned into an ulcer. Seeing pus and blood oozing and noting the strong and rapid pulse, along with his vomiting and reduced appetite, I again gave him ginseng paste mixed with bamboo juice, again using over a hundred stalks of bamboo, and he stabilized. Now at eighty, he is as strong as before. This illness was treated successfully twice with ginseng and bamboo juice, specifically because in old age the blood and qi are weak. Had he received the internal formula Jiexuan powder, I fear he might not have achieved such safety.[557p]

　　《卫生宝鉴》曰：丁巳夏末余从军回，住于曹州界，以事至州，有赵同知谓余曰：家舅牛经历病头目赤肿，耳前后尤甚，疼痛不可忍，发热恶寒，牙关紧急，涕唾稠粘，饮食难下，不得安卧。一疡医于肿上砭刺四五百余针，肿赤不减，其痛益甚，不知所由然，愿请君一见！余遂往诊，视其脉浮紧，按之洪缓，此证乃寒覆皮毛，郁遏经络，热不得升，聚而赤肿。经云：天寒则地冻水冰，人气在身中，皮肤致密，腠理闭，汗不出，血气强，肉坚濇。当是之时，善行水者不能往冰，善穿地者不能凿冻，善用针者亦不得取四厥，必待天温冰释冻解，而后水可行，地可穿，人脉亦犹是也。[558p]

The "Hygiene Treasure Mirror" states: In the summer of the Ding-si year, I returned from military service and stayed at the border of Cao Prefecture. While on official business in the prefecture, Zhao Tongzhi informed me that my maternal uncle, Niu Jingli, was suffering from a severe illness. His head was red and swollen, and his ears were particularly affected, with pain that was unbearable. He experienced fever and chills, his jaw was tight, and he had thick, sticky mucus. He found it difficult to eat and could not rest comfortably. A doctor had performed acupuncture on the swollen area with over four or five hundred needles, but the redness and swelling did not subside, and his pain worsened. Unsure of the cause, I was asked to take a look.

I went to examine him and found his pulse to be floating and tense, but when pressed, it was surging and weak. This indicated that cold was enveloping the skin, blocking the meridians, preventing heat from rising, resulting in the swelling and redness. The ancient texts say: "When the heavens are cold, the earth freezes and water turns to ice; when human qi is trapped within the body, the skin tightens and the pores close, sweat cannot escape, and blood and qi become strong, leading to rigid flesh." At such times, those skilled in controlling water cannot breach the ice, those adept at drilling the earth cannot penetrate the frost, and even those skilled in using needles cannot achieve the four extremities. They must wait for the warmth of spring to thaw the ice and dissolve the frost, allowing for the flow of water and the ability to penetrate the earth, just as human pulse conditions are likewise.[558p]

又云：冬月闭藏，用药多而少针石也，宜以苦温之剂，温筋散寒则已，所谓寒致腠理，以苦发之，以辛散之，宜以托里温经汤。麻黄苦温，发之者也，故以为君。防风辛温，散之者也；升麻苦串，葛根甘平，解肌出汗，专治阳明经中之邪，故以为臣。血流而不行者则痛，以白芷辛温，当归身辛甘温，以和血散滞；湿热则肿，苍朮辛甘温，体轻浮，力雄壮，能泄肤腠间湿热；人参、甘草甘温，白芍药酸微寒，调中益气，使托其里，故以为佐。依方饵之，以薄衣覆其首，以厚被覆其身，卧于暖处，使经血温，腠理开，寒乃散，阳气宣通，大汗出后，肿减八九分。再服去麻黄、防风，加连翘、鼠粘子，肿痛悉去。经言汗之则疮已，信哉斯言！或人以仲景言疮家虽身痛，不可发汗，其理何也？余因说此乃营气不从，逆于肉理而生疮肿，身作疼痛，非外感也。若外感寒邪而作疼痛，故戒之以不可发汗，汗之则成痓也。[559p]

It is also said: In the winter month, when there is closure and concealment, it is advisable to use more medicinal substances and fewer needles and stones. One should use bitter and warm medicines; warming the muscles and dispersing the cold is necessary. The so-called cold causes the pores to constrict, which can be released with bitterness and dispersed with spiciness. Therefore, it is appropriate to use the Tongli Wengjing Decoction.

Ephedra is bitter and warm, and it is the principal ingredient because it brings forth. Siler is spicy and warm, serving to disperse. Cimicifuga is bitter and stringy, while Kudzu is sweet and mild, resolving the muscles and inducing sweating, specifically treating the evil in the Yangming channel, thus serving as a minister.

When blood flows but does not circulate, it causes pain; for this, Bai Zhi, which is spicy and warm, is used; and Dang Gui, being spicy and sweet, harmonizes blood and disperses stagnation. If damp-heat causes swelling, Atractylodes is spicy and sweet, light and buoyant, strong and capable of dispelling damp-heat from the skin.

Ginseng and Licorice are sweet and warm, while White Peony is slightly sour and cool, balancing and augmenting Qi to support its interior. Therefore, they serve as assistants. Administer this formula while having the patient wear thin clothing over their head and a thick cover over their body, resting in a warm place to ensure the menstrual blood warms, allowing the pores to open, dispersing the cold, and promoting Yang Qi circulation. After a large sweat, the swelling will reduce by eighty to ninety percent.

If you take away Ephedra and Siler, and add Forsythia and Mouse Glue, all swelling and pain will be alleviated. The classic states that if sweating occurs, the sores will heal—truly wise words! However, some people follow Zhang Zhongjing's teachings, suggesting that those with sores should not sweat even if they experience body pain. What is the reason for this? I suggest that this is due to the Ying Qi not following, countering the flesh and leading to sore swellings and body pains, which are not from external influences.

If there is external invasion of cold evil causing pain, it is advised against inducing sweat; to sweat in such a case can lead to spasms.[559p]

　　戊午冬，余从军住冬于武城县，有贾仓使父年逾六旬，冬至后数日，疽发于背，五七日肿势约七寸许，不任其痛。疡医曰：脓已成，可开发矣，彼惧不从。越三日，医曰：不开恐变证生矣。遂以燔针开之，脓泄痛减。以开迟之故，迨二日变证果生，觉重如负石，热如焫火，痛楚倍常，六脉沉数，按之有力，此膏粱积热之变也。邪气酷热，固宜以寒药治之，时月严凝，复有用寒远寒之戒，乃思《内经》曰：有假者反之，虽违其时，以从其证可也。与疡医议，急作清凉饮子加黄连，秤一两五钱，作一服服之，利下两行，痛减七分。翌日复进前药，其证悉除。后月余平复。[560p]

In the winter of the year of Wuwu, I was stationed in Wucheng County with the army. There was a merchant’s father, over sixty years old, who developed a sore on his back a few days after the winter solstice. After five or seven days, the swelling reached about seven inches and was unbearable. The sore doctor said that pus had formed and could be opened, but he was afraid and did not comply. Three days later, the doctor warned that if it was not opened, it might lead to changes in the condition. Therefore, he used a burning needle to open it, the pus flowed out and the pain lessened. However, due to the delay in opening it, two days later the condition indeed changed; he felt heavy as if carrying a stone, hot as if burning, and the pain was doubled compared to before. His six pulses were deep and rapid, and pressing them felt forceful; this was a transformation due to the accumulation of heat from rich food. The evil qi was extremely hot, thus it was appropriate to treat it with cold medicine. However, the weather was severe and there were warnings against using cold, so I recalled the Inner Canon saying that one can counteract the faux conditions even if it goes against the time if it corresponds with the symptoms. I discussed with the sore doctor and urgently concocted a cooling drink with added bitter herb, weighing one tael and five qian, to be taken in one dose. It induced a bowel movement and the pain decreased by seven parts. The next day, I administered the same medicine again, and all the symptoms were eliminated. After more than a month, he recovered fully.[560p]

　　陈录判母年七十有余，亦冬至后脑出疽，形可瓯而大。命疡医诊视，俟疮熟以针出脓。因怒笞侍女，疮辄内陷凹一韭叶许，面色青黄不泽，四肢逆冷，汗出身清，时复呕吐，脉极沉细而迟。盖因衰老之年，严寒之时，病中苦楚，饮食淡薄，已涤肥脓之气，独存瘦悴之形，加之暴怒，精神愈损，故有此寒变也。病与时同，与疡医议，速制五香汤一剂，加丁香、附子各五钱，剂尽，疡复大发，随证调治而愈。《内经》曰：凡治病必察其下，谓察时下之宜也。诸痛痒疮疡皆属心火，言其常也。如疮盛形羸，邪高痛下，始热终寒，此反常也，固当察时下之宜而权治。故曰经者常也，法者用也，医者意也，随所宜而治之，可收十全之功矣。[561p]

Chen Lu's mother was over seventy years old and developed a sore at the back of her head after the winter solstice, which was as large as a bowl. He ordered a sore doctor to examine it, waiting for the wound to mature before using a needle to drain the pus. Due to anger, he struck a maid, causing the sore to become indented about the size of a leeks leaf. Her complexion turned bluish-yellow and lacked luster, her limbs felt cold, she broke out in a cold sweat, and sometimes vomited. Her pulse was extremely weak, thin, and slow. This was due to her old age, the harsh winter, and the suffering from the illness, with a poor appetite. The dampness and pus had been expelled, leaving only a frail appearance. The added anger further harmed her spirit, leading to this cold transformation.

The illness corresponded with the season, and after discussing with the sore doctor, a swift remedy of five-spice soup was prepared, with five qian each of clove and aconite added. When the dose was completed, the sore flared up again, and she was treated according to the symptoms until she recovered. The “Inner Canon” states: “In treating illness, one must examine its underlying conditions,” meaning one should assess the appropriateness of the current situation. All pains, itching, and sores belong to heart fire, indicating their commonality. If a sore is severe and the appearance skinny, with elevated evil causing pain below, starting with heat and ending in cold, this is abnormal and should certainly be examined according to the current situation and treated accordingly. Hence, it is said that the principles are constant, the methods are applied, and the physician's intentions are vital; treating according to what is appropriate can yield complete success.[561p]

　　至元壬午五月二十八日，王伯禄年逾五旬有七，右臂膊肿盛，上至肩，下至手指，色变皮肤凉，六脉沉细而微。此乃脉证俱寒，予与疡医孙彦和视之，曰：此乃附骨痈，开发已迟，以燔针启之，脓解清稀。次日肘下再开之，加呃逆不绝，彦和与丁香柿蒂散两服，稍缓。次日呃逆尤甚，自利，脐腹冷痛胀满，饮食减少，时发昏愤，于左乳下黑尽处灸二七壮；又处托里温中汤，用干姜、附子、木香、沉香、茴香、羌活等药，(口父)咀一两半，欲与服。[562p]

On the 28th day of the fifth month in the Renwu year of the Zhiyuan era, Wang Bolu, aged over fifty-seven, had a swelling in his right arm, extending from the shoulder to the fingertips, with the skin turning cool in color. His pulse was deep, thin, and weak, indicating a cold condition. I consulted with the ulcer doctor Sun Yanhe, who said: "This is a bone abscess; the treatment has been delayed. We should use a burning needle to stimulate it, allowing the pus to discharge in a clear, thin form."

The next day, he was reopened at the elbow, and he experienced persistent hiccups. Yanhe administered a formula of clove and persimmon calyx, which provided some relief. The following day, hiccups worsened, accompanied by frequent diarrhea, cold pain, and fullness in the abdomen, along with reduced appetite and intermittent bouts of dizziness. I performed moxibustion on the blackened area beneath his left breast seven times. Additionally, I prescribed the Tuo Li Wen Zhong Decoction, containing dried ginger, aconite, wood fragrance, sandalwood, fennel, and qianghuo, to be chewed finely (about one and a half liang) for him to take.[562p]

或者曰：诸痛痒疮疡皆属心火，又当盛暑之时，用干姜、附子可乎？予应之曰：理所当然，不得不然。《内经》曰：脉细皮寒，泻利前后，饮食不入，此谓五虚。况呃逆者胃中虚寒故也，诸痛痒疮疡皆属心火，是言其定理也，此证内外相反，须当舍时从证也，非大方辛热之剂急治之，则不能愈也。遂投之，诸证悉去，饮食倍进，疮势温，脓色正。彦和复用五香汤数服，后月余平复。噫！守常者，众人之见；知变者，知者之事。知常而不知变，细事因而取败者亦多矣，况医乎哉！守常知变，岂可同日而语哉！[563p]

It may be said: All pains, itching, sores, and ulcers are attributed to heart fire. During the height of summer, is it appropriate to use dried ginger and aconite? I respond that it is only natural; it cannot be otherwise. The "Inner Canon" states: Fine pulse and cold skin, diarrhea occurring before and after, inability to take in food, this is called the five vacuities. Moreover, the occurrence of hiccup and reversal stems from vacuity and cold in the stomach. Thus, all pains, itching, sores, and ulcers relate to heart fire, which is the fixed principle. This diagnosis shows a contradiction between internal and external conditions; treatment must be based on the evidence rather than the time, and without urgent treatment with major hot herbs, recovery cannot be achieved. Therefore, I administered the herbs, and all symptoms ceased; food intake doubled, the sores warmed, and the pus had the proper color. Yan He again used Five Spice Decoction several times, and after more than a month, he recovered. Ah! Adhering to the regular is the perspective of the many; understanding change is the concern of the wise. Many have known the constant but failed to understand the change, leading to failures in minor matters, especially in medicine! To adhere to the constant and understand the change, how can they be considered the same?[563p]

　　《薛己医案》曰：一男子胸患痈，肿高焮痛，脉浮而紧，以内托复煎散二剂，表证悉减，以托里消毒散四剂而消。
　　一男子腹患痈肿硬，木闷烦热，便秘脉数而实，以黄连内疏汤一剂少愈；以黄连解毒汤二剂顿退；更以金银花散四剂，疮头出水而消。
　　一男子患腿痛而不焮肿，内亦便利调和，用托里荣卫汤数剂而消。
　　一妇人项患毒，焮痛发寒热，以荆防败毒散二剂少愈；以小柴胡汤加连翘、牛蒡子、桔梗四剂而消。
　　一男子肩患毒，焮痛饮冷，烦躁便秘，脉数而实，以清凉饮二剂少愈；以金银花散四剂悉退；又以十宣散去桂加天花粉、金银花数剂，疮头溃而痊。
　　一妇人臂患肿，恶寒不作脓，以十宣散六剂而溃；以托里散数剂而瘳。
　　一男子患痈，肿硬疼痛，发热烦躁，饮冷脉沉实大便秘，乃邪在脏也，用内疏黄连汤疏通之以绝其源。先投一剂，候行一次，势退一二；再进一剂，诸证悉退，乃用黄连消毒散四剂而消。[564p]

The "Medical Cases of Xue Ji" states:

A man suffered from a carbuncle in his chest, swollen and painful, with a floating and tight pulse. After administering two doses of internal tonic and dispersing decoction, the external symptoms were significantly reduced. Following this, four doses of the internal cleansing and detoxifying powder were given, leading to resolution.

A man had a carbuncle in his abdomen, hard and full, with a feeling of heaviness, heat, constipation, and a rapid, full pulse. One dose of Huanglian Neishu Decoction provided slight improvement; two doses of Huanglian Jiedu Decoction led to a rapid decline of symptoms. Then, four doses of Jin Yin Hua powder were given, causing the sore to weep and heal.

A man experienced leg pain without swelling, with normal bowel movements. He was treated with several doses of the Tuo Li Rong Wei Decoction, leading to resolution.

A woman had a toxic condition in her neck, with pain and fever. Two doses of Jing Fang Bai Du San provided slight relief; four doses of Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with added Lian Qiao, Niu Bang Zi, and Jie Geng resulted in resolution.

A man suffered from toxicity in the shoulder, with pain, cold sensitivity, agitation, and constipation, accompanied by a rapid and full pulse. Two doses of Qing Liang Yin offered slight improvement; four doses of Jin Yin Hua powder led to significant alleviation. Additionally, he was given several doses of Shi Xuan San with a substitution of Tian Hua Fen and Jin Yin Hua, resulting in the sore rupturing and healing.

A woman had a swollen arm, experiencing chills but no pus. After six doses of Shi Xuan San, the swelling burst; several doses of Tuo Li San led to healing.

A man suffered from a carbuncle, swollen, painful, experiencing fever and agitation, with a cold drink, a deep, full pulse, and constipation. As the pathology was inside the organs, Huanglian Neishu Decoction was used to clear it and cut off the source. One dose was given and monitored; symptoms decreased somewhat. After another dose, all symptoms retreated, and then four doses of Huanglian Xiaodu San were administered, leading to resolution.[564p]

　　一男子内股患毒，肿硬痛甚，不作脓，隔蒜灸五十余壮，势退七八；以仙方活命饮四剂而脓成；用十宣散六剂脓溃而愈。凡疮大痛，或不痛麻木，灸最良。
　　一妇人臂肿未成脓，饮食少思，遇劳作痛，发热，以补中益气汤二剂，痛少止；以补气血健脾胃而消。
　　一男子素弱，胸患痈，饮食少而倦，以六君子汤加芎、归、黄芪，脓成针之；更以托里药而愈。
　　一妇人胁患痈，未成脓，恶寒脉紧，以十宣散加柴胡二剂，表证悉退；更以托里散数剂，脓溃而愈。
　　一妇人臂患毒肿硬，咽喉壅塞，四肢逆冷，发寒热，以五香连翘汤二剂顿愈，以疮科流气饮四剂而消。
　　一男子臂患痈，脉弦紧有力，以白芷升麻汤二剂顿退，又二剂而消。
　　一妇人肩下患毒，脉弦紧，以白芷升麻汤二剂，表证已退；更以托里药溃之而愈。[565p]

A man had a painful and hard swelling in his inner thigh, which did not produce pus. After applying garlic for over fifty sessions, the intensity decreased by seventy to eighty percent; after taking four doses of the Immortal Formula for Life, pus formed. He then took six doses of the Ten Xuan Powder, and when the pus burst, he recovered. For sores that are very painful, or that cause numbness without pain, moxibustion is the best method.

A woman had a swollen arm that had not yet formed pus, with little appetite and thoughts of discomfort; when she exerted herself, it hurt and she felt feverish. After taking two doses of the Supplement Middle and Benefit Qi Decoction, the pain diminished; she continued with tonic herbs to strengthen her spleen and stomach, resulting in recovery.

A weak man suffered from a boil in his chest, had little appetite, and felt fatigued. A modified Six Gentlemen Decoction with Chuanxiong, Angelica, and Astragalus was given, leading to pus formation which was then drained by needles; he later took the Elimination of Toxin Medicine and recovered.

A woman had a boil in her side that had not yet produced pus, felt chills, and had a tight pulse. After taking two doses of the Ten Xuan Powder with added Chaihu, her exterior symptoms completely resolved. She then took several doses of the Elimination of Toxin Powder, the pus burst, and she recovered.

A woman had a hard swelling in her arm, with a constricted throat and cold limbs, accompanied by chills and fever. She was rapidly cured after taking two doses of the Five-Spice Lianqiao Decoction, and after four doses of the Sores Department Flowing Qi Decoction, the swelling resolved.

A man had a boil in his arm, with a tight and strong pulse. After taking two doses of the Baizhi Shengma Decoction, it retreated immediately, and it further resolved after two additional doses.

A woman had a toxic swelling under her shoulder, with a tight pulse. After taking two doses of the Baizhi Shengma Decoction, her exterior symptoms receded; she then took the Toxin Elimination Medicine to facilitate drainage and recovered.[565p]

　　一男子臂患痈不作脓，灸以豆豉饼及饮托里药三十余剂而溃，又月余而瘳。
　　一男子脓熟不溃，余欲针之，补以托里。彼不信，乃服攻毒药，反致恶心少食，始悟而用针；更以六君子汤加藿香、当归四剂少可；再以加味十全大补汤数剂而敛。凡疮脓熟不行针刺，脓内侵蚀，轻者难疗，重者不治。老弱之人，或偏僻之处，乃紧要之所，若一有脓，宜急针之，更以托里，庶无变证。
　　一男子患毒作痛，服寒凉药，痛虽止而食愈少，疮亦不溃，以六君子汤而食进；再以托里药溃之而愈。大抵疮疽之证，寒热虚实，皆能为痛。热毒之痛者，以寒凉之剂折之；寒邪之痛者，以温热之剂散之；因风而痛者除其风；因湿而痛者导其湿；燥而痛者润之；塞而痛者通之；虚而痛者补之，实而痛者泻之；脓郁而闭者开之；恶肉侵蚀者去之；阴阳不和者调之；经络秘濇者利之。慎勿概用寒凉之药。况血脉喜温而恶寒，若冷气入里，血即凝滞，反为难瘥之证矣。[566p]

A man had a boil on his arm that did not produce pus. After undergoing treatment with moxibustion using fermented soybean cakes and about thirty doses of Tori medicine, it eventually burst and healed after more than a month.

Another man had a mature abscess that had not ruptured. I wanted to use a needle on it and supplement with Tori, but he did not believe in this method and instead took a toxic purging medication, which led to nausea and reduced appetite. He then realized and used a needle; after that, I added a decoction of Six Gentlemen with fragrant patchouli and angelica for four doses, followed by several doses of a modified Eight Treasure broth to close it up. Generally, for abscesses with mature pus, if one does not perform needle therapy, the pus can erode internally—mild cases are difficult to treat, severe cases are incurable. In elderly or weak individuals, or in remote areas, this becomes critical. If there is any pus, it is advisable to perform needling urgently and supplement with Tori to prevent any complications.

A man suffered from pain due to toxins and took cold medicine. Although the pain subsided, his appetite decreased, and the abscess did not rupture. With Six Gentlemen Decoction, his appetite improved. Then, he took Tori medicine, which led to its rupture and healing. Generally, the symptoms of sores and boils—whether due to cold, heat, deficiency, or excess—can all cause pain. For heat-related pain, cold medications are used to suppress it; for cold-related pain, warm medications are used to disperse it; if pain is caused by wind, the wind is removed; if due to dampness, moisture is expelled; if dryness causes pain, then it is moistened; if blockage causes pain, it is opened; if deficiency causes pain, it is strengthened; if excess causes pain, it is purged; if pus is stagnant and closed, it is opened; if there is necrotic tissue causing erosion, it is removed; if yin and yang are unbalanced, they are adjusted; if meridians are obstructed, they are unblocked. One must be careful not to use cold medications universally. Furthermore, blood vessels prefer warmth and dislike cold; if cold air enters the interior, the blood will coagulate and cause difficult-to-heal conditions.[566p]

　　一男子素弱，肘患肿，欲内消，服凉药反致作泻少食，以二神丸及香砂六君子汤加肉豆蔻而泻止食进，又以托里药而肿亦消。丹溪云：痈疽因积毒在脏腑，当先助胃壮气，使根本坚固；次以行经活血药佐之，参以经络时令，使毒气外发，施治之早，可以内消，此内托之意也。又云：肿疡内外皆壅，宜以托里表散为主。如欲用大黄，宁无孟浪之过？溃疡内外皆虚，宜以接补为主。如欲用香散，未免虚虚之失。大抵痈肿之证，不可专泥为火。经云：营气不从，逆于肉理，乃生痈肿。又云：形伤肿，气伤痛。六淫七情皆能致之，况禀有虚实及老弱不同，岂可概用寒凉之药？设若毒始聚，脓未作，势不盛，庶可消。尤当推其病因，别其虚实。若概用寒凉药，必致悞事。如脓将成，邪盛气实，用消毒之剂，先杀其毒，虽作脓不为大苦，溃亦不甚。若就用托里，必益其势。如脓将成不成，及不溃，方用托里，脓成势盛者针之，脓一出，诸证悉退矣。[567p]

A man of frail constitution had swelling in the elbow and wished for it to be resolved internally. However, taking cooling herbs resulted in diarrhea and reduced appetite. He was treated with Er Shen Wan and Xiang Sha Liu Jun Zi Tang, adding nutmeg to stop the diarrhea and improve his appetite, as well as with medicines for relieving internal pressure, which also resolved the swelling. Dan Xi stated that abscesses arise from a buildup of toxins in the organs, and it's essential to first support the stomach to strengthen its vital energy, establishing a firm foundation. Then, use blood-moving herbs along with seasonal treatment to allow the toxins to emerge and be expelled. This is the essence of internal expulsion. He also mentioned that when there are swellings and sores, it is best to primarily use herbs that relieve internal pressure and disperse exterior conditions. If one desires to use Da Huang (rhubarb), it should be done cautiously to avoid recklessness. When both the internal and external sores are weak, nurturing and supplementing is the priority. Should one choose to use fragrant dispersing herbs, it may lead to excessive weakness. Generally, conditions of abscesses and swellings should not be solely treated with fire-inducing methods. The classics say that when the nourishing energy does not flow properly, it stagnates in the flesh, leading to abscesses. It also states that when the form is injured, swelling results in pain. Six excesses and seven emotions can lead to such conditions, especially considering the variances in constitution, age, and weakness, it would be inappropriate to uniformly apply cold and cool medicines. If the toxins have just begun to accumulate, but there is no pus yet and the condition is not severe, resolution is possible. It is crucial to understand the underlying cause of the illness and differentiate between weakness and strength. Should one apply cold and cooling medicines indiscriminately, it will surely lead to problems. If pus is about to form and the evil is vigorous while the energy is strong, using detoxifying agents first to kill the toxins will ensure that even if pus does form, it will not be excessively painful, and ulceration will not be severe. If one applies remedies for relieving internal pressure, it must be to enhance the condition. When pus is on the verge of forming or not yet ruptured, then one can use methods to relieve internal pressure. When pus is sufficiently formed and the condition is severe, one should use needles, and once the pus is released, all symptoms will retreat.[567p]

　　一男子脓熟不溃，微痛少食，倦怠发热。予为针之，脓涌出，热益甚，乃虚故也，急以人参黄芪汤二剂，热愈甚，此药力尚未及也，又二剂果应，再以当归补血汤数剂而痊。东垣云：发热恶热，大渴不止，烦躁肌热，不欲近衣，脉洪大按之无力，或目痛鼻干者，非白虎汤证也，此血虚发躁，宜当归补血汤主之。
　　一妇人脾气素弱，患毒未作脓，发寒热兼呕，以不换金正气散二剂而止；以托里散六剂而溃；更以健脾药而敛。[568p]

A man had a festering sore that had not ruptured, experienced slight pain and loss of appetite, and felt fatigued with a fever. I treated him with acupuncture, and pus began to flow out, but the heat became more intense, indicating a deficiency.
